title: Hazardous Materials Storage, Transportation, and Disposal: a Critical Analysis of Green Supply Chain Methodologies
authors: Santiago Neira Mendieta, Diana Mercedes Rodriguez, Tony McAleavy, Lisa Wier
abstract: The United States has seen an increase in hazardous materials (HAZMAT) accidents during the supply chain management, prompting the need for green supply chain management techniques (GrSCM). There are few studies that focus holistically on HAZMAT throughout the entire supply chain. Accordingly, this study critically evaluated literature pertaining to HAZMAT storage, transportation, disposal, and green supply chains in the United States. Pragmatism, qualitative content analysis, and induction on twenty-nine academic articles identified twenty-four codes, eleven categories, and four themes, which are presented in a comprehensive network diagram. Only nine of the articles mentioned GrSCM, suggesting a need for further research in GrSCM adoption measures to increase mitigation. The posited model suggests implementations to promote GrSCM initiatives throughout the HAZMAT supply chain holistically to promote resiliency and reduce the risk for HAZMAT incidents.

title: Malaria Detection Using Deep Convolution Neural Network
authors: Sumit Kumar, Sarthak Kapoor, Harsh Vardhan, Sneha Priya, Ayush Kumar
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: According to the WHO World Malaria Report 2024, malaria cases rose to 263 million, with 597,000 deaths—most of them children under five in sub-Saharan Africa. Despite advances, progress in malaria control has slowed due to limited resources and dependence on manual microscopy for diagnosis. Artificial intelligence offers a promising path for rapid, low-cost screening. In this work, we present a lightweight convolutional neural network (CNN) optimized via Bayesian hyperparameter tuning for automated malaria detection from blood smear images. The proposed model achieves high accuracy in classifying parasitized versus uninfected cells. To support deployment in real-world settings, we developed a middleware framework for mobile inference. In addition, we integrate an Out-of-Distribution (OOD) detector based on RRRCF, which flags anomalous inputs responsible for rare CNN misclassifications. Together, the CNN and OOD components yield effective prediction accuracy, demonstrating that compact, mobile-compatible deep learning systems can significantly improve malaria diagnostics in resource-limited environments.

title: Machine Learning Techniques for Maternal Health Risk Prediction: A Comparative Performance Analysis with Real-World Data
authors: Nurdha Arya Pamungkas, Frederica Sharon Sastradi, Arfin Hertanu Wijaya, Adhe Lingga Dewi, Ventje Jeremias Lewi Engel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: This study aims to identify the most effective predictive computational model in assessing maternal health risks. This was achieved through a comprehensive investigation involving the collection, application, and evaluation of various advanced data analysis methodologies. These approaches were integral to the development of the system. The data used in this crucial study was obtained from the UCI Machine Learning Repository, a rich resource of health information. The data included crucial features relevant to maternal health conditions. These features were selected because of their high relevance in indicating health risks. The results of a thorough evaluation showed that the model optimized through cross-validation (Ford) technique consistently performed superior to other approaches. The model achieved an impressive accuracy of 86.7%, precision of 87.0%, recall of 87.6%, and F1 score of 87.2%. Ultimately, this study highlights the significant potential of utilizing artificial intelligence to improve health risk prediction in pregnant individuals. Implementation of these findings may facilitate early detection and support more informed clinical decision-making, contributing to improved maternal health outcomes.

title: Cryptographically Verifiable Fingerprint Authentication Using PEP Hash
authors: Sima Jafarikhah, Yaser Saei, Jafar Tahmoresnezhad, Hossein Siadati
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Current authentication protocols, such as Passkeys, typically rely on device-resident credentials unlocked with locally stored biometric templates. While trusted hardware modules can protect such designs, they pose significant risks for resource-constrained platforms like IoT devices, which often lack secure storage for biometrics. To address this limitation, we propose an authentication framework based on Publicly Evaluatable Perceptual (PEP) hash, which combines lightweight homomorphic encryption (HE) with perceptual hashing (PH) to eliminate the need for local fingerprint storage. In our framework, an IoT device generates a PH of the user's fingerprint via Secure Function Evaluation (SFE) and transmits it securely to the server for verification without exposing the PH algorithm or persisting biometric templates locally. We formally analyze the security guarantees of the design and demonstrate its practicality using benchmark fingerprint datasets and established PH algorithms. By decoupling privacy protection from matching accuracy, our approach enables usercentric biometric authentication that is viable on devices without trusted computing modules (TPMs) and aligns with privacy-bydesign principles.

title: Improving Cooperative NOMA Network Performance Using RIS: An Outage Probability Analysis with Imperfect CSI
authors: Andika Wisnujati, Agung Mulyo Widodo, Karisma Trinanda Putra, Mosiur Rahaman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS) have emerged as a transformative technology for enhancing wireless communication systems by intelligently manipulating the propagation environment. In this paper, we investigate the performance of a Cooperative Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (C-NOMA) network augmented with RIS under the practical constraint of imperfect channel state information (CSI). We consider a downlink scenario where a base station communicates with multiple users via an RIS and a decode- and-forward (DF) relay, forming a cooperative architecture to improve coverage and reliability. Current wireless technology is primarily aimed at boosting radio signal transmission in the context of creating 5G to 6G technology. Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS), Large Intelligent Surface (LIS), or Intelligent Reflective Surface (IRS) is a novel technology that uses electromagnetically controlled surfaces to integrate into current infrastructure. Because RIS passively reflects messages rather than amplification mechanisms like relays, RIS-assisted communication is more energy efficient than traditional delivery approaches. We will examine coverage performance, which is often expressed in terms of outage probability, if RIS is implemented on a radio access system using the Non- Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA) technique used in 5G network scheme, considering the condition of the Imperfect Channel State Information (ip-CSI) via Rayleigh fading channel, in this study. Because of channel estimate errors, perfect channel state information (p-CSI) conditions are difficult to achieve in realistic wireless systems.

title: Study on Combination of CBS and ATS in IEEE 802.1TSN on Centralized Zonal In-Vehicle Networks
authors: Haruto Kawasumi, Yoshihiro Ito
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: To achieve real-time communication on Ethernet-Based in-vehicle networks, the combined use of two Quality of Service(QoS) controls, CBS and ATS, as defined in IEEE 802.1 TSN, will become necessary. However, it is unclear how to combine the two above QoS controls. This study compares four configurations applied to different priorities and evaluates their effect on delay, jitter, and loss rate through experiments. The experimental results show that, while all configurations met the requirements, the obtained QoS differs depending on the application location.

title: Plant Deployment of a 3D Modeling and SLAM-Based Inspection System
authors: Jiho Chang, Jeongho Park
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper reports a plant-scale deployment of an inspection system for refinery, power, and chemical sites. The system performs on-site 3D modeling with RGB and LiDAR and provides robot self-localization via SLAM in a globally consistent frame, enabling reliable route checks and operator displays even in multi-level structures. On top of this frame, daily/weekly/monthly patrols and analog-gauge readings are executed by a schedule; failures, low confidence, or high-risk alerts trigger a policy-driven escalation from re-capture to close-up sensing to robot swap and, if needed, human intervention. Because field operations mix fixed sensors and operator calls with concurrent events, the controller assigns and reassigns heterogeneous robots by combining travel time, payload suitability, battery/health, and floor accessibility, and logs capture outcomes, latencies, and quality indicators for routine reporting. While the implementation uses a fast-livo family LiDAR–IMU–visual stack on ROS 2, this is an implementation choice; the contribution is the coupling of 3D modeling, SLAM-based localization, scheduling, reassignment, and logging into a procedure that remains durable in real plants. Validation comes from deployments in a refinery (2023) and a power facility (2024), with an extended configuration for a chemical plant (2025) that accounts for multi-level layouts and hazardous-area constraints.

title: An Islanding Partitioning of Distribution Networks Based on Refined Modeling of Distributed Generation
authors: Wang Rui, Meng Qingjuan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: The large-scale integration of distributed generation (DG) increases the vulnerability of distribution networks to extreme events, making island partitioning a key strategy for enhancing resilience and reliability. This paper proposes an island partitioning method based on refined DG modeling. A Markov chain-based approach is used to model DG output considering its state transitions and uncertainties. A risk optimization model is formulated to balance expected power surplus and deficiency, ensuring power adequacy and network connectivity within islands. A genetic algorithm optimizes the islanding scheme to maximize DG utilization. An entropy weight-based evaluation framework is introduced, incorporating System Average Interruption Frequency Index (SAIFI), System Average Interruption Duration Index (SAIDI), Average Service Availability Index (ASAI), and Expected Energy Not Supplied (EENS). Simulation results show that the proposed method achieves a SAIFI of 1.8051 (events/year) and ASAI of 0.9999, reducing SAIDI and EENS by 0.0155 hours/year and 1.0753 MWh, respectively. The method enhances distribution network reliability and resilience.

title: Reeds–Shepp Path Planning With a Heuristic Cost Function for Autonomous Parking
authors: Hye Jun Hong, Yeong Gwang Choi, Eun Ho Kim, Hye Hyeon Park, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This study presents a Reeds–Shepp path generation system enhanced with a heuristic cost function for autonomous parking. Unlike approaches that rely solely on path length, the proposed method generates a complete set of Reeds–Shepp paths, filters out infeasible candidates, and applies a cost-based evaluation to select the most practical solution. The cost function considers multiple factors, including path distance, gear transitions, steering switches, path type, and backward driving segments, to evaluate paths that avoid obstacles. The simulation results indicate that this method successfully addresses the challenge of creating smooth, executable parking paths that drivers can follow comfortably to reach their goal position.

title: Multiple-Choice Question Generation Adaptation in Bahasa Indonesia using Large Language Models: A Preliminary Research
authors: Halim Wildan Awalurahman, Indra Budi
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Multiple-choice question (MCQ) generation is one of the research domains that has harnessed the ability of Large Language Model (LLM). However, its application is still limited to certain domains and languages. This study aims to adopt MCQ generation using LLM in unexplored languages. We used prompts from previous studies and adapted them in the new language. Our research found that adaptation worked. Llama 70B consistently produced the longest tokens for MCQs, with 236.69 tokens for the first prompt and 839.57 for the second prompt. We found several flaws in the generated MCQs, including incomplete responses, wrong language, and missing answer keys. The findings could be used as a base for future studies.

title: WiFi Device Re-Identification for Smart Cities
authors: Stepan Mazokha, Fanchen Bao, George Sklivanitis, Jason O. Hallstrom
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: WiFi-based mobility monitoring is confounded by MAC address randomization. We consider radio frequency fingerprinting and re-identification for attributing WiFi traffic to emitting devices without the use of MAC addresses. Specifically, we present MobRFFI, a multi-receiver, AI-based WiFi device fingerprinting and re-identification framework that extracts unique features based on WiFi hardware impairments. When evaluated on the WiFi fingerprinting dataset WiSig, our approach achieves 94 % and 100 % device accuracy in multi-day and singleday re-identification scenarios, respectively. We also collect a novel dataset, MobRFFI, for granular multi-receiver WiFi device fingerprinting evaluation. Using the dataset, we demonstrate that the combination of fingerprints from multiple receivers boosts reidentification performance from 81 % to 100 % on a single-day scenario and from 41 % to 100 % on a multi-day scenario.

title: Network Attack Detection and Protection Model Optimization Based on Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Shengqi Xing
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Aiming at the limitations of traditional network attack detection methods in the face of complex and changeable attack means, this paper proposes a network attack detection and protection model optimization method based on convolutional neural network (CNN). The model automatically extracts the spatio-temporal features of network traffic through 2D convolution kernel, and combines L2 regularization, Dropout and dynamic learning rate adjustment to enhance the anti-over-fitting ability and generalization performance of the model. The experiment uses CIC-IDS2017 data set. After pretreatment, the model shows high accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(96.5 \%)$</tex> and F1-Score (96.2%) in detecting various attack types, and the reasoning time of a single sample is only 1.3 ms, which is significantly better than the traditional machine learning method. In addition, the model shows a high recall rate when dealing with rare attack types, which can effectively reduce missed detection. The optimized CNN model can be widely used in real-time traffic monitoring. By being deployed in network boundary devices, malicious traffic can be identified immediately, and the protection strategy can be updated dynamically by linking with threat intelligence database, which provides strong technical support for network protection.

title: Automated Design Framework Using Regression Learning
authors: Jace Rudolph, Youngsoo Kim, Peng Fang, Jong Park, Ryan Bussett
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Designers face a significant challenge when it comes to relying on time-consuming circuit simulations to help quantify performance metrics. This paper introduces a regression learning framework to automate power converter design by estimating the performance of power converter applications. Our methodology addresses this challenge by applying regression learning networks to predict the power efficiency of a Buck Converter circuit from the component characteristics. To build our model, we developed a Python-based application to automate LTSpice simulations, gathering an initial dataset from 48 transistor models. The dataset was significantly enhanced by incorporating additional inductor models, resulting in over 14,000 data points after preprocessing. We achieved a Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) of approximately 3% with our final model DeeperNet.

title: The Infestation of the Red-Billed Quelea Bird and the Infeasability of a Sutable Deterrent System
authors: Nicholas Ene, Catelle Le Baut, John Gershenson
abstract: Sub-Saharan Africa faces an agricultural crisis as the red-billed quelea, a destructive bird species currently growing exponentially, devastates farms and threatens the livelihoods of smallholder farmers. This problem remains unsolved. By using surveys and a co-design event, we developed a rental service business model instead of selling the product. Additionally, we aimed to learn more about the important people farmers interact with and how it affects their success and a solution's integration. Farmers have expressed that there is a need for a solution, but simultaneously, limited disposable income to spend on a more efficient solution. The team conducted a financial analysis of two solutions, and ultimately if farmers cannot afford the solution, then this problem will continue. This research delves into viable solutions to address this problem while keeping sustainability, effectiveness, and affordability at the forefront. Simultaneously, this research describes the need for a solution and where the solution and integration space are currently. However, our findings reveal that there is no market-based solution in Kenya at the time. The industrial and economical limitations constrain the “fix” for this massive problem. Based on other countries' success in minimizing this problem, the Kenyan government must intervene and implement a large-scale solution.

title: Comparative Analysis of Earthquake Clustering in West Java Using Unsupervised Learning: K-Means, K-Medoids, and Fuzzy C-Means
authors: Dewintha Tresna Reza, Sunarno, Supriadi, Siti Wahyuni, Hanifullah Hafidz Arrizal, Marzuki Sinambela
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: This study explores the use of unsupervised learning algorithms—K-Means, K-Medoids, and Fuzzy C-Means (FCM)—to identify spatial patterns in 6,005 earthquake events in West Java from 2009 to 2023. Clustering was based on location, depth, and magnitude, with performance evaluated using Silhouette Score, Calinski-Harabasz Index, and Davies-Bouldin Index. K-Means produced three well-separated clusters aligned with major tectonic structures, achieving the highest Silhouette Score (0.31). K-Medoids offered finer spatial resolution and the best separation (Davies-Bouldin Index: 1.05), effectively highlighting localized seismic zones. FCM provided the highest Calinski-Harabasz Index (2227.74), capturing transitional regions through overlapping clusters. All models successfully classified the data without noise. The results show that K-Means is optimal for broad seismic zoning, while K-Medoids and FCM offer complementary insights into regional fault complexity and uncertainty. These findings support the integration of clustering methods into regional seismic hazard analysis.

title: Trade-Offs Between Traditional LLM and Chain-of-Thought Reasoning for Mathematical Tasks
authors: Dharani Ravanam, Shivanjali Khare
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have progressed from basic text generators to advanced reasoning tools that can handle complex cognitive tasks. Chain-of-Thought (CoT) models (enable step-by-step reasoning) are now widely adopted for their enhanced problem-solving capabilities. This perspective, however, often overlooks that the performance gains from CoT are not universal. This study investigates the relation between accuracy, latency, and token consumption cost across different mathematical task complexities. An empirical analysis is conducted on two variants of the kimi family: traditional model (kimi-dev-72b) and CoT-enabled model (kimi-vl-a3b-thinking). These models were evaluated on 500 questions sampled from three diverse benchmark datasets: the GSM8K, Nguyen-Brat/asdiv, and SAT-MATH. The results show that traditional LLM achieves higher or equal accuracy, with significantly lower latency and greater token efficiency. Our findings indicate that for simpler problems, computational overhead generated by CoT models often outweighs the minimal increase in accuracy. These results highlight the need for dynamic reasoning frameworks, especially for real-time, cost-sensitive applications, such as adaptive prompting, where the type of LLM model used is based on the inferred complexity of the problem.

title: Intelligent Prediction and Optimization Algorithm of Intelligent Building Energy Management System Based on Deep Learning
authors: Xiaodong Hou, Weidong Ji, Zhengyi Zhu, Weicheng Ji, Xueli Lv
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: An intelligent prediction and optimization algorithm of intelligent building energy management system (EMS) with deep learning is proposed. The system architecture includes three modules: data acquisition, intelligent prediction and optimal decision-making. Multi-source heterogeneous data are collected in real time through sensor networks, and features are extracted and energy consumption is predicted by using deep learning model. In the study, a long short-term memory network (LSTM) combined with spatiotemporal attention mechanism and multi task learning framework was used to effectively improve prediction accuracy, and an online learning module was designed to cope with changes in data distribution. The optimization algorithm is based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL), which achieves the optimization of device operation mode and energy allocation scheme by defining state space, action space, and reward function, significantly reducing energy consumption and operating costs. The experimental results show that the LSTM model improves the prediction accuracy by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15\% \sim 20\%$</tex> compared with the traditional time series model, and the multi-task learning further optimizes the prediction performance. DRL optimization strategy effectively reduces the power grid purchase and improves the utilization rate of energy storage system during peak hours, and achieves a 10% reduction in daily operating costs, which verifies the effectiveness and reliability of the algorithm.

title: Determining The Most Representative Subset of Software Metrics Using Dimensionality Reduction
authors: Iaroslav Kivaev, Navruza Tulkunova, Evgeniy Zuev
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Software metrics play a crucial role in evaluating code quality and predicting defects, but the overwhelming number of available metrics creates challenges for practitioners. This work addresses the problem of selecting optimal subsets of software metrics that preserve essential information while reducing computational overhead and complexity. We propose a novel approach that combines dimensionality reduction techniques with heuristic optimization to identify the most representative metric subsets. Our methodology uses a UMAP-derived objective function to measure information loss and employs Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to search for optimal combinations across different subset sizes. The experimental results demonstrate that small subsets of carefully selected metrics can effectively capture the structural properties of software projects. This research contributes to making software quality measurement more accessible and actionable for development teams.

title: Design of Electronic Information Processing System Based on Deep Learning
authors: Xiao Pan, Bin Lin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Electronic information image processing and analysis is an important research direction in modern information technology. To address the challenges in processing high-dimensional complex image data, this study proposes a deep learning based electronic information image processing method aimed at improving the accuracy and efficiency of image analysis. In the study, traditional methods such as Retinex image enhancement, histogram equalization, and frequency domain filtering were comprehensively applied, and attention mechanism deep learning models were introduced to optimize feature extraction capabilities. The experimental results show that this method exhibits excellent performance in complex scenes such as lighting changes, noise interference, and detail extraction, significantly improving the robustness and accuracy of image processing. With the support of high-performance GPUs and deep learning frameworks, this method demonstrates good stability and scalability, providing an efficient solution for the field of electronic information image processing. This study not only provides a new perspective for theoretical exploration, but also lays a solid foundation for practical applications.

title: Ai-Augmented Multi-Cloud Serverless Framework for Explainable Outbreak Management in Healthcare
authors: Vivek Venkatesan, Deepak Barla
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: We present a multi-cloud, serverless deployment framework and a complementary AI pipeline for outbreak management in large healthcare networks. The framework extends an operational rules-based system deployed during COVID-19 (15,000 employees across 295 facilities) by adding portable Infrastructure-as-Code (IaC), cost-aware scaling, and healthcare-grade security. The AI pipeline integrates facility-level forecasting (LSTM), individual risk scoring (XGBoost), anomaly detection (Isolation Forest), and contact-network analytics, with explainable AI (XAI: SHAP, LIME, counterfactuals) embedded directly into clinician workflows. Evaluation on anonymized operational logs and calibrated synthetic multi-disease streams shows improvements over (i) a rules-only production baseline and (ii) a single-vendor “siloed AI” deployment: higher predictive accuracy, lower end-to-end latency, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 30 \%$</tex> lower cost per million events, and increased clinician agreement. We explicitly delineate (A) benefits from multi-cloud portability (e.g., disaster recovery, data residency, cost control) and (B) benefits from AI augmentation. Together, these yield a portable, explainable, and cost-conscious foundation for outbreak management beyond COVID-19.

title: Beyond Usability: Evaluating User Adoption of AI-Powered Tourism Application using A Combined Approach of SUS and TAM
authors: Khafidlotun Muslikhah, Ting Steven Irvan Pranata, Diva Dwi Puspita Anggraini, Jessica Rehabian Lim, Merlin Reanne Effendi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: This study evaluates user adoption of an AI-powered tourism application by combining the System Usability Scale (SUS) and the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM). With the increasing integration of AI in tourism tools like ChatGPT Trip Planner and Tripadvisor, understanding user acceptance is crucial as AI distrust might affect intention to visit. Thus, studying the user adoption toward AI-powered tourism app is crucial before developing and implementing it in real life. By combining Technology Acceptance Model and System Usability Scale, the user adoption study was conducted using a prototype of an AI-powered tourism mobile app, Travelingo. Data was collected from 77 participants with diverse backgrounds. The findings indicate that usability positively influences intention to use, and perceived usefulness strongly predicts intention to use. However, AI trust and data privacy, while scoring moderately high independently, did not significantly moderate intention to use which is affected by perceived usefulness. The results suggest that for this participant group, perceived usefulness was the primary driver of intention to use, potentially overshadowing concerns about trust and data privacy. This highlights the complex interplay of factors in AI adoption. While usability is foundational, the perceived benefits of AI features are principal for user intention to use. This paper also proposed the idea that the influence of trust and privacy may vary based on user characteristics and the perceived risk level of the application domain.

title: On-Policy vs. Off-Policy HVAC Control: Comparing PPO and SAC–Gumbel in EnergyPlus
authors: Khalil Al Sayed, Abhinandana Boodi, Roozbeh Sadeghian Broujeny, Karim Beddiar
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: We compare two reinforcement learning methods for HVAC control in a university amphitheater simulated in EnergyPlus: Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO, on-policy) and SAC-Gumbel (off-policy). We run two experiments. First, a weekly adaptation test trains each agent for 50 episodes using the first week of January in Luxembourg. Second, a year-long generalization test trains on a full year of data (about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.5 \times$</tex> passes) and then evaluates on two other climates (San Diego and Brest) with realistic occupancy. We assess learning speed, daily average cumulative score, comfort violations during occupied periods (15-minute counts), and energy use (AHU electricity plus district heating). In the weekly test, SAC-Gumbel achieved a better cumulative score (-449.17 vs. -501.33) and used less energy (7.16 GJ vs. 9.05 GJ) than PPO. In the year-long tests, SAC-Gumbel lowered cumulative penalty scores by 31.85 % and reduced occupiedperiod comfort violations by 30.12 % relative to PPO, but consumed 83.04 % more energy. Overall, the off-policy method learned faster and provided stronger comfort control, at the cost of higher energy in cross-climate deployment.

title: Research on Image Recognition and Intelligent Diagnosis Model of Tobacco Leaf Diseases Based on Deep Learning
authors: Yonggang Liu, Hongliang Zhang, Ziyu Liu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Tobacco is an important cash crop, and its leaf diseases seriously affect the yield and quality. Traditional manual detection methods have some problems such as low efficiency and strong subjectivity. Based on deep learning (DL) technology, this study developed an image recognition and intelligent diagnosis model for tobacco leaf diseases. ResNet-50 architecture is adopted as the basic model, and targeted improvements are made, including adding convolution layer for specific diseases and introducing attention mechanism. Through the large-scale tobacco leaf disease image data set, the data set contains 5000 images, covering a variety of common disease types. The experimental results show that the accuracy of the improved ResNet- 50 model is as high as 93.41%, the recall rate is 92.87%, and the F1 score is 93.16%, which is significantly better than other related studies. The model has a better recognition effect on disease types with a large number of samples, indicating that sample distribution is very important to performance. The model proposed in this study shows excellent accuracy and generalization ability, and provides an effective solution for automatic identification and intelligent diagnosis of tobacco leaf diseases.

title: A Compatible RISC-V SoC Platform for Embedded AI Applications
authors: Mijeong Park, Kyuseung Han, Sukho Lee, Jae-Jin Lee, Hyeonguk Jang
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Embedded AI has become essential to technologies such as IoT, autonomous vehicles, and wearable devices. While AI models have been optimized for edge deployment, SoC platforms lag behind due to limited accessibility and compatibility with existing IPs. To address this, we propose an RTL-based RISC-V SoC platform that integrates the Versatile Tensor Accelerator (VTA) using the RVX framework. The platform supports AXI and APB protocols, enabling seamless integration of third-party IPs. We implemented the system on a Digilent Genesys2 FPGA, achieving a 59.66% reduction in Energy-Delay Product (EDP). This demonstrates its suitability for energy-constrained edge AI. The platform offers a practical and extensible solution for embedded AI and serves as a compatible reference for future RISC-V SoC research.

title: Analysis of Transmission Line Channel State Evolution Based on Digital Twin Model
authors: Qishuai Liang, Jiang Ye, Zhao Zhang, Rican Lin, Xuance Wang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: In this paper, an analysis method of transmission line channel state evolution based on digital twin model is proposed. By constructing a virtual model that is highly consistent with physical entities, combining with the mechanical, environmental and image data collected in real time by multi-source heterogeneous sensor networks, the dynamic simulation, real-time monitoring and fault prediction of transmission line channel state are realized by using physical information neural network (PINN) and improved LSTM network. In the research, the hybrid networking technology of LoRa and 5G is used to optimize the data transmission efficiency, and the evolution of line state under complex working conditions such as icing is accurately predicted by the physical-data fusion modeling method. Taking the icing growth process of a 220kV transmission line in southwest China during the winter cold wave as an example, the validity of the model is verified, and the average error of icing thickness prediction is less than 7.5%, which is significantly better than the industry standard. The results show that the digital twin model can effectively reflect the deterioration trend of the line state, and warn the potential risks in advance, providing scientific basis for operation and maintenance decision-making, and significantly improving the efficiency and economy of operation and maintenance.

title: Color Space-Aware Hybrid Cnn Architectures for Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Classification
authors: Minakshi Arya, Shubhavi Arya, Saatvik Arya
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Variations in staining and illumination conditions present a major challenge for consistent and accurate leukemia classification from blood smear images. This study investigates the impact of color space transformations on the performance of deep learning models for classifying Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL). Images were transformed from RGB into HSV, HLS, LAB, YUV, YCrCb, and Grayscale, and evaluated across six architectures: VGG16, DenseNet121, ResNet50, InceptionV3, MobileNetV2, and several hybrid combinations. The results indicate that color space selection significantly influences classification accuracy. VGG16 trained on HSVtransformed images achieved 96.15 % accuracy, while a hybrid model combining DenseNet121 and MobileNetV2 trained on HLS images achieved 94.23 %. These luminance separated color spaces enhanced feature extraction by isolating chrominance components, leading to improved generalization under variable imaging conditions. In contrast, YUV and YCrCb transformations resulted in unstable convergence and reduced accuracy. These findings underscore color space transformation as a simple yet effective preprocessing step to improve biomedical image classification, particularly for deployment on resourceconstrained systems.

title:
Enhanced RBA
                    <sub>θ</sub>
                    method for uncertainty quantification in time varying dataset
authors: Purbak Sengupta, Sambeet Mishra
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: The high velocity and variability of wind power data introduce challenges in reliably detecting ramp events and quantifying uncertainty. To address this, we propose the enhanced Ramping Behavior Analysis (RBA<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">θ</inf>) framework, which extends the original RBA<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">θ</inf> method by introducing two adaptive thresholding strategies: a statistical inference-based threshold and a Random Forest–based Markov Chain Monte Carlo (RF–MCMC) threshold. These replace static thresholds with data-driven, uncertainty-aware mechanisms. Empirical evaluation on wind capacity factor datasets shows that the enhanced RBA<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">θ</inf>-Traditional (statistical thresholding) achieves an overall performance score of 0.82, with perfect robustness (1.00) and strong balance (0.94). Compared to existing approaches, it improves consistency by 20.7% over Sliding Window Ramp Threshold (SWRT) and balance by 88.8% over Cumulative Sum (CUSUM), while enabling reliable detection of both significant and stationary ramp events. Comparative analysis further indicates that while adaptive SWRT attains the highest overall score (0.86), the enhanced RBA<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">θ</inf>-Traditional offers greater robustness and stability, making it a more reliable solution for wind ramp event detection.

title: Machine Learning Algorithms for Spotting 6G Network Penetration of Different Attacks
authors: Anindya Bal, Sumit Chowdhury, Nabonita Halder, Haofan Cai
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: With the exponential evolution of current Internet and mobile connectivity technology, networking schemes, computers and services have become more diverse and heterogeneous in latest years. More sophistication must be deployed in order to effectively coordinate, handle, operate and optimize networking frameworks. Network security devices are extremely critical in securing an information infrastructure. With the enormous development of the internet, assault incidents as well as new possible attacks are growing every day. Intrusion Detection System (IDS) is one of the real concern approach that can be used to deal with the problem. One of several techniques where IDS have used is machine learning(ML). Machine Learning IDS have been delivering high precision and good tracking on novel threats in recent decades. In our research, the efficiency of a ML algorithm called J48-Decision Tree is analyzed and differentiated throughout this research to three other ML algorithms: Neural based Networks (NN), Supportive Vector Machines (SVM), and a flexible narrative web based learning algorithm called fast machine learning (FML). The algorithms were put through their paces in terms of precision rate (PR), selection rate(SR), faulty alarm rate(FAR) and precision of four various attacks on network. According to the results of the tests, the J48-Decision Tree(DT) method outstrip the other three methods.

title: Robust WiFi Channel State Information-Based Localization via Sequence Time Alignment
authors: Dongwoo Kang, Seho Park, Taehyeon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Channel State Information (CSI) enables fine-grained indoor localization without the need for additional hardware. However, its reliability is often degraded by noise, environmental dynamics, and asynchronous packet arrivals. To address these challenges, we propose a preprocessing-driven framework that integrates amplitude extraction, Butterworth filtering, and a novel time-aligned synchronization strategy for multi-ESP CSI streams. A Support Vector Machine (SVM) classifier is then employed to perform localization tasks. We evaluate two scenarios: single-ESP for near/far classification and dual-ESP for left/right localization. Experimental results show that, without synchronization, the dual-ESP model achieved only 78.5% accuracy, whereas the proposed time-aligned preprocessing improved performance to 95.5% with a 2-second window. These findings demonstrate that careful preprocessing substantially enhances the robustness of lightweight models, underscoring its role as a core design principle for resource-efficient CSI-based localization.

title: AI Monitoring of Social Media to Assist in Crisis Preparedness and Response: COVID-19 Case Study
authors: Andy Skumanich, Han Kyul Kim, Nick Sawyer, Reza Davariar, Jahan Dokht Hill, Michael Kan
abstract: Social media has emerged as a critical frontier in public health, serving as both an information platform and a vector for the rapid spread of health-related false information. Infodemiology, the science of identifying and mitigating the consequences of infodemics, is increasingly vital for addressing public health challenges. The proliferation of false information, accelerated by Generative AI, poses significant risks, leading to adverse health outcomes, unnecessary suffering, and systemic burdens on health care providers and practitioners. This study presents an AI Agentic-like approach to crisis preparedness and response by leveraging AIIML analytics to develop a Capture/Track/Respond (CTR) framework for detecting and counteracting medical false information in real-time social media streams. Our analysis demonstrates high accuracy in identifying false information, enabling timely detection of developing issues, rapid interventions and reliable implementation of corrective measures. We focus on health crises as a specific concern, but the findings can be broadly generalized to any crisis. Our research question addresses the urgent need for scalable, data-driven tools to bolster global crisis preparedness and response, with a starting focus on emerging health crises. The CTR (Capture-Track-Respond) methodology is a template for an efficient, AI-powered framework for rapid detection and mitigation of false information-a critical capability in emergent scenarios where misinformation undermines public trust and safety. Given the potential for generalizability, CTR applies across diverse crisis types, from health emergencies to climate disruptions, which are typically reflected immediately in social media discourse. The flexibility of the approach enables targeted, culturally adaptive messaging via locally preferred digital channels, positioning CTR as a practical tool for humanitarian outreach. By providing health professionals with tools to engage underserved and marginalized populations in real time, this approach advances both global resiliency and health equity.

title: Igloo Mobile Primary Health Center: A Systematic Design-Led Approach
authors: Md Haseen Akhtar
abstract: Mobile clinics are critical for delivering healthcare services to underserved populations, yet existing designs face limitations in portability, deployability, and cost-effectiveness. This study presents a novel mobile Primary Health Center (mPHC) developed through systematic design thinking for low-resource settings. We analyzed 15 mobile clinic case studies, followed by concept generation and expert evaluation. Three concepts were assessed by 11 design experts using structured Delphi methodology, selecting a tent-inspired collapsible design. Through iterative prototyping and computational optimization, we developed a lightweight (12.5 pounds), rapidly deployable (8-12 minutes) mPHC system. Mixed-method evaluation with 49 users demonstrated good satisfaction across form (4.12), function (4.31), collapsibility (4.24), portability (4.18), and deployability (4.27) parameters. Qualitative analysis revealed five themes: validation for innovative mobility, durability concerns, deployment enthusiasm, equipment storage questions, and modular expansion suggestions. Statistical analysis revealed moderate correlations between design parameters and deployability (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}=0.53, \mathrm{p}<0.001$</tex>). Competitive benchmarking against 10 existing mobile clinics showed superior performance, achieving 34/40 total score versus 31/40 for the next best alternative. Our findings demonstrate that systematic design approaches can yield innovative healthcare delivery solutions for resource-constrained environments.

title: δ-SCALPEL: Docker Image Slimming Based on Source Code Static Analysis
authors: Jiaxuan Han, Cheng Huang, Jiayong Liu, Tianwei Zhang
abstract: Containerization is the mainstream of current software development, which enables software to be used across platforms without additional configuration of running environment. However, many images created by developers are redundant and contain unnecessary code, packages, and components. This excess not only leads to bloated images that are cumbersome to transmit and store but also increases the attack surface, making them more vulnerable to security threats. Therefore, image slimming has emerged as a significant area of interest. Nevertheless, existing image slimming technologies face challenges, particularly regarding the incomplete extraction of environment dependencies required by project code. In this paper, we present a novel image slimming model named δ–SCALPEL. This model employs static data dependency analysis to extract the environment dependencies of the project code and utilizes a directed graph named command link directed graph for modeling the image’s file system. We select 30 NPM projects and two official Docker Hub images to construct a dataset for evaluating δ-SCALPEL. The evaluation results show that δ–SCALPEL is robust and can reduce image sizes by up to 61.4% while ensuring the normal operation of these projects.

title: Crosstalk Analysis and Advancements in RDL Interposer Design for High-Speed Channels
authors: Yingbo Zhao, Xueqin Kou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: In this paper, we introduce an electromagnetic capacitance matrix for high-speed channels to analyze crosstalk mechanisms in RDL interposers. This is the first study to use the off-diagonal to diagonal capacitance ratio (ODDCR) in the matrix as a quantitative metric to analyze coupling effects in high-frequency scenarios. We then propose two routing layout schemes for RDL interposers: an optimized Ground-Signal-Ground (GSG) configuration in full-coverage wrap mode and a Ground-Signal-Signal (GSS) configuration with multiple signal units. These schemes support high-density packaging and enhance signal routability, aligning with the recent HBM3 and HBM4 protocols. To validate the signal integrity of these proposed configurations, we analyze them in both frequency and time domains, comparing their performance with conventional multiple striplines and reported staggered GSG configurations. The results demonstrate significant improvements in insertion loss, return loss, near-end crosstalk, far-end crosstalk, and eye diagrams. This work provides practical guidelines for designing RDL interposers, ensuring high data transfer rates while addressing signal integrity issues, and offers insights into optimizing interconnect layouts for high-speed channels in 2.5-D ICs.

title: Low-Latency vs High-Precision: LAM-based Cross-Modal Semantic Communication for Emergency Response
authors: Yanan Chen, Dan Wu, Shouxiang Ni, Liang Zhou
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Cross-modal semantic communication plays a crucial role in emergency response systems. However, there are still two major challenges in practical applications: insufficient semantic compression due to the computing constraints of the source device, and poor signal generation at the sink device caused by harsh communication environment. To this end, this work fully leverages multi-modal interactive large AI model (LAM) distillation to enhance sparse feature representation for dynamic residual compression, while utilizing LAM adversarial feature mapping to repair the feature impairment for accurate signal generation, thereby achieving low latency and high reliable communication. Specifically, we first propose a scalable cross-modal semantic communication framework, which constructs a multi-modal semantic knowledge base (MSKB) by semantic similarity to support cross-modal semantic codec. On this basis, residual-guided cross-modal semantic encoding (RCSE) is designed, which employs video-infrared bidirectional knowledge distillation to lightweight LAM for feature extraction, and initially compresses features by inter-modal correlations. Further, according to the link state, the similar features in MSKB are dynamically stripped and the residual features are compressed for low-latency transmission. Additionally, an adversarial mapping-based cross-modal semantic decoding (AMCSD) is developed, which leverages adversarial mutual information (MI) to map features in LAM to impaired features, and discriminate semantic fidelity to enhance the mapping robustness, ensuring accurate signal generation. Finally, an emergency simulation platform is constructed. Experiments demonstrate that our scheme reduces the transmission latency by 27.64% and improves the signal generation precision by 14.06%.

title: Resource-Constrained Decentralized Federated Learning via Personalized Event-Triggering_supp1-3635484.pdf
authors: Shahryar Zehtabi
abstract: Federated learning (FL) is a popular technique for distributing machine learning (ML) across a set of edge devices. In this paper, we study fully decentralized FL, where in addition to devices conducting training locally, they carry out model aggregations via cooperative consensus formation over device-to-device (D2D) networks. We introduce asynchronous, event-triggered communications among the devices to handle settings where access to a central server is not feasible. To account for the inherent resource heterogeneity and statistical diversity challenges in FL, we define personalized communication triggering conditions at each device that weigh the change in local model parameters against the available local network resources. We theoretically recover the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathcal {O}{(\ln {k} / \sqrt {k})}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> convergence rate to the globally optimal model of decentralized gradient descent (DGD) methods in the setup of our methodology. We provide our convergence guarantees for the last iterates of models, under relaxed graph connectivity and data heterogeneity assumptions compared with the existing literature. To do so, we demonstrate a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$B$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-connected information flow guarantee in the presence of sporadic communications over the time-varying D2D graph. Our subsequent numerical evaluations demonstrate that our methodology obtains substantial improvements in convergence speed and/or communication savings compared to existing decentralized FL baselines.

title: Low-Complexity Syndrome-Based Linear Programming Decoding of Quantum LDPC Codes
authors: Sana Javed, Sergio Colet, Francisco Garcia-Herrero, Óscar Ruano, Juan Antonio Maestro, Bane Vasić, Mark F. Flanagan
abstract: This paper proposes a novel low-complexity syndrome-based linear programming (SB-LP) decoding algorithm for decoding quantum low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes. Under the code-capacity model, the SB-LP decoder can be used as a standalone decoder; however, it is particularly powerful when used as a post-processing step following syndrome-based min-sum (SB-MS) decoding. In the latter case, the proposed decoder is shown to be capable of significantly reducing the error floor of the SB-MS decoder for both flooded and layered SB-MS scheduling. Also, an early stopping criterion is introduced to decide when to activate the SB-LP algorithm, avoiding executing a predefined maximum number of iterations for the SB-MS decoder. Simulation results show, for some example hypergraph and generalized bicycle (GB) codes, that the proposed decoder can lower the error floor by one to three orders of magnitude compared to SB-MS for the same total number of decoding iterations. Furthermore, for the class of GB codes, it is shown that as the minimum distance of the code increases, the logical error rate provided by the proposed decoder also improves, indicating that the solution is scalable. Under the circuit-level noise model, it is shown that while the SB-LP decoder does not fully replace the need for ordered statistics decoding (OSD) when flooded SB-MS is used as a preliminary step, it reduces the number of calls to the OSD post-processor, which directly impacts the overall latency. Additionally, the method offers a syndrome-matching decoder and improves the accuracy of the logical error rate for bivariate bicycle codes of distances six to eighteen, particularly at low error rates, when compared to the BP+OSD benchmark.

title: MASDG: Multi-view Augmented Single-source Domain Generalization Method for Robust Remote Sensing Building Extraction
authors: Yunjiao Liu, Yuanyuan Liu, Kejun Liu, Yuxuan Huang, Chang Tang, Wujie Zhou, Zhe Chen, Wei Xiang, Hongyan Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Despite advances in deep learning for remote sensing building extraction (RSBE), Multi-target Domain RSBE (MD-RSBE) remains challenging, as it requires transferring knowledge from a labeled source domain to multiple unlabeled target domains, with domain shifts in texture, style, and semantics. Existing domain adaptation (DA) and generalization (DG) methods face significant limitations: DA requires target-domain training, while DG needs multi-source training, leading to high training costs and low generalization in practical MD-RSBE scenarios. To address this, we propose a Multi-view Augmented Single-source Domain Generalization (MASDG) method, which effectively mitigates domain shifts across RS source and target domains for robust MD-RSBE performance by enriching the diversity of the source domain through multi-view augmentation and enforcing semantic consistency. Specifically, MASDG consists of three key components: Texture-level Domain Augmentation (TDA) module, Style-level Domain Augmentation (SDA) module and Semantic-invariant Representation Learning (SRL). To mitigate texture-level domain shift, TDA first introduces parameter-optimized multi-layer random convolution to modify the texture of source image, generating texture-augmented image pairs for simulating real-world texture diversity across various RS domains. Then, with each image pair from TDA, SDA employs two paralleled encoders, namely the general feature encoder and the batch-guided style encoder, to formulate multi-view building features, further mitigating style-level domain shift. Finally, SRL ensures semantic-invariant representation learning via a dual mechanism, including multi-view segmentation loss and semantic consistency loss. The former generates predictions from diverse feature views (original, texture-augmented, style-augmented, etc.), while the latter performs semantic alignment by minimizing distribution discrepancies among predictions, bridging semantic inconsistency to enable robust segmentation. Extensive experiments across three different MD-RSBE settings with 7 different target domains demonstrate that our MASDG outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods by a significant margin.

title: Long-Tailed Continual Learning for Visual Food Recognition_supp1-3632640.pdf
authors: Fengqing Zhu
abstract: Deep learning-based food recognition has made significant progress in predicting food types from eating occasion images. However, two key challenges hinder real-world deployment: (1) continuously learning new food classes without forgetting previously learned ones, and (2) handling the long-tailed distribution of food images, where a few common classes and many more rare classes. To address these, food recognition methods should focus on long-tailed continual learning. In this work, We introduce a dataset that encompasses 186 American foods along with comprehensive annotations. We also introduce three new benchmark datasets, VFN186-LT, VFN186-INSULIN and VFN186-T2D, which reflect real-world food consumption for healthy populations, insulin takers and individuals with type 2 diabetes without taking insulin. We propose a novel end-to-end framework that improves the generalization ability for instance-rare food classes using a knowledge distillation-based predictor to avoid misalignment of representation during continual learning. Additionally, we introduce an augmentation technique by integrating class-activation-map (CAM) and CutMix to improve generalization on instance-rare food classes. Our method, evaluated on Food101-LT, VFN-LT, VFN186-LT, VFN186-INSULIN, and VFN186-T2DM, shows significant improvements over existing methods. An ablation study highlights further performance enhancements, demonstrating its potential for real-world food recognition applications.

title: Beampattern Synthesis With Element Placement Optimization Under Weight Amplitude Constraint
authors: Zhilun Xiao, Bin Liao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper deals with the problem of minimizing the peak sidelobe level (PSL) in array pattern synthesis with element placement optimization under the constraints on mainlobe flatness and weight amplitude. Unlike existing methods that optimize only the weights with fixed element positions, we jointly optimize the element positions and weights to achieve improved performance in terms of a lower PSL. However, the resulting problem is nonconvex and challenging due to the coupling of optimization variables and fractional objective function. In order to deal with the problem, we present an efficient approach by leveraging the alternate direction method of multipliers (ADMM) framework. The proposed approach decomposes the complex problem into several tractable subproblems, each of which has a closed-form solution or can be efficiently solved. Numerical results show that the proposed approach can obtain desired beampatterns. Compared with the traditional counterparts, the proposed approach achieves improved performance with the guarantee of all the constraints being well satisfied.

title: QSAP: Energy and Area-Efficient Query-Based Sparsity-Aware Accelerator for Voxel-Based Point Cloud Neural Networks
authors: Pan Zhao, Licheng Wu, Ting Yue, Xin Zhao, Jing Zhou, Donghui Xue, Jinxi Huang, Zhe Yang, Liang Chang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: Voxel-based neural networks have been widely applied to the processing of large-scale outdoor point cloud data, which first convert points into voxels and then extract features using several sparse convolution and normal convolution layers. The hardware implementation of these networks suffers from complex rulebook generation, irregular memory access, and low hardware utilization. Meanwhile, these networks still have much data sparsity. In this paper, we propose an energy and area-efficient query-based sparsity-aware accelerator for voxel-based point cloud neural networks, namely QSAP. Specifically, a dedicated unit is used to improve the efficiency of rulebook generation. A query-based input feature-writing method is proposed to enhance parallel reading potential. An efficient weight-mapping method is introduced to store unpruned weights in on-chip buffers. A novel input-feature-reading method with consecutive queries is proposed to enable out-of-order execution of convolution operations, thereby improving hardware utilization. The hardware utilization is further enhanced by a proposed pop strategy that minimizes the total number of empty FIFOs. The MAC related to zero value is also skipped in this process. As a result, QSAP achieves superior performance on 22 nm technology with the throughput, energy efficiency, area efficiency, frame rate, and frame energy of 1074 GOPS, 7.79 TOPS/W, 590 GOPS/mm<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbf {^{2}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, 35.2 FPS, and 3.91 mJ/Frame, respectively, better than state-of-the-art works.

title: Distributed Large Models Training Optimization with Real-Time Wireless Channel Feedback
authors: Jiaming Pei, Valerio Frascolla, Anwer Al-Dulaimi, Wei Liu, Theyazn H.H. Aldhyani, Ali Kashif Bashir, Shahid Mumtaz
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Large-scale deep learning models rely on wireless networks for distributed training approaches, which are essential to meet the immense computational and data demands. However, the stochastic nature of wireless environments introduces significant challenges such as variable delays, noise interference, and packet loss, which lead to degraded gradient synchronization and hinder model convergence. In this work, we propose a novel communication-aware distributed training (CADT) framework that integrates real-time channel state information (CSI) feedback into the gradient aggregation process. Unlike conventional methods that assume static or ideal communication conditions, CADT dynamically reweights gradients from each node based on instantaneous channel quality, enabling robust aggregation under adverse wireless conditions. By dynamically adjusting the contribution of each node based on instantaneous channel conditions, CADT effectively compensates for wireless impairments, thereby ensuring more reliable gradient aggregation and significantly improving both convergence speed and final model accuracy. Extensive experiments on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, ImageNet, and SVHN using Vision Transformer and ResNet-50 demonstrate that CADT outperforms baseline methods in terms of convergence, accuracy, and communication efficiency. In addition, we provide a rigorous theoretical analysis that establishes convergence guarantees under realistic wireless conditions, thereby advancing the theoretical foundation of distributed optimization in non-ideal communication environments.Our framework offers a practical solution for real-world scenarios such as edge computing, where communication constraints and environmental variability are dominant factors.

title: Discriminative Condition-Guided Generative Model for Induction Motor Fault Diagnosis With Limited Data
authors: Xin Chen, Zaigang Chen, Junsheng Xin, Liang Guo, Wanming Zhai
abstract: The scarcity of fault samples degrades the accuracy of data-driven intelligent fault diagnosis (IFD). An auxiliary classifier generative adversarial network (GAN) has therefore emerged as a dominant paradigm for generating multiclass data to mitigate this issue; however, this framework suffers from low intraclass diversity and gradient instability. Specifically, the classifier's strong class-label separability compresses the category's support space, reducing diversity and also causing optimization conflicts. To this end, this article proposes a discriminative condition-guided generative model (DCGM) to synthesize high-fidelity data across categories for induction motor fault diagnosis under small-sample conditions. First, a discriminative classifier is integrated into the conditional GAN to replace the auxiliary classifier, theoretically alleviating diversity constraints and instability. After that, an adaptive feature matching loss based on supervised contrastive learning is proposed to enhance the synthetic quality of the class-label data. Then, three novel evaluation metrics are developed to quantitatively assess the generated data quality. Extensive experiments on induction motor datasets demonstrate that DCGM achieves state-of-the-art evaluation scores compared to diffusion-, transformer-, and GANs-based models. Finally, small-sample fault diagnosis further validates the superiority of the proposed approach, highlighting its potential in engineering applications. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first to introduce the novel discriminative generative framework for conditional data generation in the IFD field.

title: A Continuous-Time Zoom ADC With Coarse Noise-Shaping ADC and Interstage Low-Pass Filter
authors: Junghyun Yoon, Youngcheol Chae
abstract: This article presents a continuous-time (CT) zoom ADC that employs a noise-shaping coarse ADC and an interstage low-pass filter (LPF) to achieve a 6-bit linear zoom-in only with an intrinsically linear 1.5-bit digital-to-analog converter (DAC). The key idea of this design is the interstage LPF, which properly filters the shaped residue signal of the coarse delta-sigma modulator (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\Delta \Sigma M$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) and enables the fine <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\Delta \Sigma M$</tex-math> </inline-formula> to perform with a 6-bit linear zoom-in operation, effectively boosting the overall resolution. This substantially relaxes the design overhead and enhances overall efficiency. The noise-shaping property of the coarse <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\Delta \Sigma M$</tex-math> </inline-formula> eliminates the need for gain mismatch calibration between analog and digital domains, thus ensuring the ADC’s robustness. The ADC prototype, fabricated in a 28-nm CMOS process, occupies an active area of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.12~\text {mm}^{{2}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and consumes only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$392~\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>W from a 1 V supply. It achieves 91.2-dB SNDR, 92.3-dB SNR, 92.7-dB DR, and 101.4-dB SFDR over a 250 kHz bandwidth without using DAC linearization. This performance translates to Schreier SNDR/DR figure-of-merit (FoM) of 179.2/180.7 dB, respectively.

title: Simultaneous Bias-Polarization Control With Dissimilar Time-Division Multiplexing in Electronic-Photonic Monolithic Integration
authors: Jimin Chen, Yuhang Wang, Yaowen Tu, Min Tan
abstract: We introduce a dissimilar time-division multiplexing (DTDM) control scheme that simultaneously achieves polarization and bias control. By time-slicing sensors and actuators and reusing shared readout/driver circuitry, this scheme reduces per-channel control circuitry while enabling simultaneous stabilization of MZI bias point and polarization status. A prototype fabricated in IHP 250 nm BiCMOS electronic-photonic monolithic platform achieves 44.4% area reduction and 23% power savings compared to conventional implementations. Measured results achieved a 0.7<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pi$</tex-math></inline-formula> rad bias control range with 5Hz tracking bandwidth and 0.01<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pi$</tex-math></inline-formula> rad/s polarization-state resolution while maintaining a 34dB extinction ratio. The data path supports stable 100Gbps NRZ transmission when operating the bias or polarization loop individually, and reliable 56Gbps NRZ transmission under simultaneous bias and polarization control at a 6.25Hz multiplexed clock. The proposed scheme provides a scalable, hardware-efficient approach to large-scale integrated control of photonic devices.

title: Adaptive Prescribed-Time Control of Uncertain Self-Restructuring Nonaffine Nonlinear Systems
authors: Jie Su, Yongduan Song
abstract: For uncertain strict-feedback nonlinear systems with self-restructuring structures and nonaffine dynamics, this article addresses the challenge of achieving exact full state zero-error stabilization within a prescribed finite time. An adaptive prescribed-time control scheme is proposed, which guarantees that all system states converge to zero within the user-specified settling time, irrespective of initial conditions. The controller is designed based on a time-varying scaling state transformation and incorporates the Nussbaum function to handle unknown self-restructuring control gains. The self-restructuring structures are treated as a time-state-dependent lump, which is effectively estimated by freezing both time and system states and then applying an adaptive estimation strategy. Numerical simulations on a piezoelectric-actuated stage and a second-order nonlinear system are conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.

title: High airtightness passivation layer for high-temperature all-solid-state thin-film batteries
authors: F. Yue, L. H. Wang, Y. H. Zhuang, H. Z. Sun, X. D. Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: All-solid-state thin-film lithium-ion batteries (ASSTFLBs) offer remarkable advantages, including high safety and excellent compatibility with microelectronic devices, which endow them with extensive application prospects in the industrial Internet of Things (IoT), particularly for powering industrial wireless sensor network nodes at high temperature. Nevertheless, the materials composing ASSTFLBs are highly reactive with moisture, oxygen, and carbon dioxide in air, triggering spontaneous chemical reactions that cause material degradation. This phenomenon leads to a rapid decline in battery performance and severely restricts the practical utilization of ASSTFLBs. To address this challenge, we propose a high airtightness Si<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub>/Al<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>/PDMS composite passivation film for ASSTFLB protection at high temperature. A 600-nm Si<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub> film is fabricated via magnetron sputtering, while a 30-nm dense Al<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> film is deposited using atomic layer deposition (ALD) to overcome the step coverage limitations of sputtered Si<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>N<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sub>. Additionally, a 15-μm PDMS film is spin-coated to enhance the mechanical robustness of the composite structure. The composite passivation film exhibits excellent thermal stability, chemical stability and mechanical robustness, thereby offering enhanced passivation for ASSTFLBs at high temperature. Experimental results indicate that, ASSTFLBs with composite passivation film exhibit remarkable cycling stability in air at room temperature, retaining 80.5% of their initial capacity after 150 cycles, which is significantly superior to that of unpassivated ASSTFLBs, which only maintain 4.7%. More importantly, under an industrial-grade high temperature of 85 °C, ASSTFLBs with composite passivation film show good cycling and thermal stability, retaining 90.2% of their initial capacity after 100 cycles in air, confirming superior thermal and air stability. These findings underscore the strong potential of the proposed passivation strategy for enabling reliable ASSTFLB operation in real-world IoT applications.
