title: Machine Learning Approach to Classify Gas and Position for Single Elder Home
authors: Eman Abdelfattah, Kevin Bowlyn
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: This study enhances the broader understanding of machine learning applications in daily life by focusing on the classification of gas levels and positional data within a single elderly household. The experiment is carried out in two phases, utilizing a total of six supervised machine learning models. In Phase I, which aims to classify gas levels, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-Nearest Neighbors classifier demonstrates superior performance compared to Decision Tree, Stochastic Gradient Descent, and Support Vector Machines classifiers. The result of Phase II, focused on position classification, indicates that Bagging, Decision Tree, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-Nearest Neighbors classifiers exhibit comparable superior performance compared to Adaptive Boosting, Stochastic Gradient Descent, and Support Vector Machines classifiers.

title: Platform for Labeling based on Unsupervised Time series data Anomaly Detection
authors: Jihoon Lee, Jaewon Moon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Time series data are collected in real time across industrial, office and household environments through Internet of Things sensors and exhibit characteristic patterns and periodicities. In field deployments, however, quality anomalies such as sensor drift, intermittent dropouts, flatlines and external interference occur frequently and degrade the reliability of analytics and control. To address this, this paper applies unsupervised anomaly detection and suppresses over-detection by employing conservative thresholding policies based on global statistics and percentiles so that only high-confidence anomalies are declared. Beyond point anomalies at specific instants, the procedure aggregates sustained deviations into intervals, attaches explicit semantic labels, and persists them as metadata within a user-oriented web platform. A demonstration on indoor air-quality time series collected in an office shows that spikes and sustained episodes can be detected and labeled reliably. The resulting labels enable the selection of clean segments and the exclusion of anomalous intervals, and provide supervision for constructing supervised and semi-supervised datasets, thereby improving operational reliability and model performance.

title: Winter Jujube Grading Method Based on Two-Stream Structure and Weakly Supervised Regional Partitioning
authors: Xinrang Tian, Tianrui Wang, Zian Liu, Rufeng Zhang, Shixin Cen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: Winter jujube is a nutritious fruit that often experiences bruises, wrinkles, and maturity issues during harvesting. Therefore, its precise classification is crucial for optimizing economic value and ensuring quality control. In recent years, although CNN and Transformer models have shown great potential in fruit classification in the field of deep learning, they face challenges in handling complex image relationships and dealing with high computational demands. This paper proposes a novel classification method for Winter jujube that synergistically combines the strengths of CNN and Transformer models and incorporates a weakly supervised region partitioning for enhanced feature extraction. This method stacks the CNN backbone and Transformer, where CNN shows strength of capturing features and Transformer exhibits global relationship in each feature. This approach specifically addresses the challenges of distinguishing subtle variations within Winter jujube varieties. Demonstrated through rigorous testing on Winter jujube datasets, this method achieved a notable accuracy of 93.09%, surpassing several established baseline models. Overall, the classification strategy developed in this study significantly enhances the precision and efficiency of Winter jujube classification, marking a substantial advancement for quality control in agricultural practices.

title: Comparative Analysis of Segmentation Models for RTL-Based Lane Recognition in Autonomous Driving
authors: Min Kwon Choi, Gyu Hyeon Hwang, HoBin Oh, HyeonJin Sim, Seung Wook Oh, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: With the recent active research on autonomous driving technology, the importance of deep learning models that accurately recognize the surrounding environment in real time has been highlighted. In particular, it is essential to select a model that considers not only accuracy but also real-time and hardware efficiency in order to mount it on hardware with limited computational resources. In this paper, we aim to select the lightweight segmentation model that is most suitable for RTL (Register - Transistor Level) implementation for the construction of lane recognition system of autonomous driving system. To this end, we compared-analyzed the representative real-time models Fast-SCNN, BiSeNetV2, and DDRNet in the same learning environment. As a result of the experiment, Fast-SCNN showed the best performance among them and showed a advantage in terms of hardware efficiency. Therefore, this study finally selected Fast-SCNN as the semi-segmentation model of the next-generation autonomous driving system.

title: Application of AHP-Entropy Weight Method Assisted by High-Resolution Image in Flood Risk Identification of Transmission Lines
authors: Chao Gao, Wei Du, Maojie Tian, Shirui Sun, Guozhu Yang, Huamin Sun, Wei Hu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: This study discusses the application of Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and Entropy Weight Method (EWM) assisted by high-resolution images in flood risk identification of transmission lines. As an important part of power system, the safe operation of transmission lines is very important to social economy and people's life. The secondary disasters caused by floods often cause the interruption and damage of transmission lines, so it is very important to accurately identify potential risk areas for preventive measures and reducing losses. In this study, a three-dimensional evaluation index system is constructed by using high-resolution image technology and AHP-EWM, including three dimensions of danger, sensitivity and vulnerability, in order to comprehensively evaluate the flood risk of transmission lines. Through geometric correction, radiometric calibration and atmospheric correction, key information such as water boundary, vegetation coverage and surface coverage type are extracted. Then, combined with expert knowledge and data dispersion, the weight of each risk factor is determined, and the flood risk of transmission lines is evaluated and ranked by TOPSIS model. The practical application shows that this method can effectively identify high-risk areas, provide scientific basis for the planning, maintenance and emergency response of transmission lines, and improve the ability of disaster prevention and reduction of power system. The research results emphasize the effectiveness of highresolution image technology and AHP-EWM in flood risk identification of transmission lines, which provides a new perspective and method for risk assessment in related fields.

title: 5G Slicing Low Latency Transmission Technology for Virtual Reality
authors: Bo Jin, Jialin Chen, Chen Chen, Junguo Hu, Ying Li, Xiaorui Wang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: With the commercial popularization of 5G networks, virtual reality (VR) technology is entering a new stage of development. High quality virtual reality video services, with their immersive experience, are gradually being favored by a large number of users. However, VR technology requires extremely high latency for data transmission, as any small delay can cause the virtual world perceived by users to break, greatly affecting the overall user experience. In this context, 5G slicing technology has emerged, which has the ability to provide independent, isolated, and customized network resources for different services or applications on the same physical network. This technology makes the allocation of network resources more flexible and efficient, providing solid technical support for low latency transmission. This article proposes a low latency 5G slicing transmission algorithm for VR, whose core lies in ensuring real-time and stable transmission of VR video data through refined network resource allocation and traffic management. The experimental results show that the algorithm can significantly reduce the latency of data transmission, improve the smoothness and user experience of VR videos.

title: Voice-Based Screening of Lung Cancer and COPD Using Combined Spectral, Cepstral, and Learned-Embedding Features
authors: Haydar Ankışhan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Early, accessible detection of lung cancer and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) remains challenging due to invasive and costly standard methods. Here, we explore a non-invasive, voice-based approach to distinguish healthy controls from lung cancer (Stages I–IV) and COPD (Stages I–III) patients. We collected speech recordings from 128 Turkish-speaking individuals (42 healthy, 50 lung cancer, 36 COPD) reading standardized paragraphs in a quiet setting. Recordings were down-mixed to mono, high-pass filtered, and segmented into 100 ms frames. From each frame, we extracted time-domain statistics (RMS, skewness, zero-crossing rate), frequency-domain descriptors (spectral centroid, bandwidth, flux), MFCCs 1–13, spectrogram and chroma features, and learned embeddings via a 64-dimensional autoencoder and PCA-reduced components. Dimensionality reduction and K-means clustering revealed that learned embeddings and select spectral features achieved clear grouping of healthy, COPD, and lung cancer samples. An XGBoost classifier leveraging all features, coupled with SHAP analysis, identified higher-order MFCCs (MFCC5–MFCC7), spectral bandwidth, skewness, and zero-crossing rate as most discriminative. Physiological interpretation suggests that COPD-induced airflow obstruction leads to breathiness and turbulence—reflected in elevated zero-crossing rates and amplitude irregularities—whereas lung cancer yields formant distortions and heavier spectral tails, captured by higher-order MFCCs and kurtosis. These findings underscore the promise of acoustic biomarkers for scalable, cost-effective respiratory disease screening.

title: Proof of Concept of a Wheelbarrow with Hitch Warning System to Optimize Tasks in Civil Works
authors: Liz Analy Tapahuasco Zúñiga, Victor Cristian Hinostroza Maravi, Romildo Genaro Silva Cuadros, Elian Eleazar Ramos Cordova, Boris Senin Carhuallanqui Parian, Cesar Whesly Segura del Rio
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: The civil construction sector constantly faces challenges in optimizing its processes, particularly in the efficient and safe handling of materials. The wheelbarrow, as a fundamental tool in works of various magnitudes, plays a crucial role in material logistics. However, conventional models present limitations in maneuverability, stability, and safety, particularly regarding hopper hitching. This article introduces a proof of concept for an optimized wheelbarrow designed to address these deficiencies. The proposed design incorporates a hitch warning system based on sensors and visual or auditory alerts to prevent accidents caused by improper hopper engagement. The development process was guided by the VDI 2221 methodology and implemented using Autodesk Inventor and Proteus software. The resulting prototype showcases structural enhancements in the base frame, wheel system, and hopper geometry, thereby improving stability, maneuverability, and excavation efficiency. Comparative analysis with existing designs highlights the novelty and potential of the proposed solution. This work contributes to the advancement of ergonomic and safety-oriented equipment in civil works, laying the groundwork for future experimental validation and potential industrial applications.

title: Terminal Area Severe Convective Weather Forecasting Based on Multi-channel Data Fusion
authors: Yujiang Feng, Weijun Pan, Leilei Deng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: Flight delays are significantly affected by weather, and severe convective weather poses a great threat to aviation safety. Accurate nowcasting of severe convective precipitation is crucial for airport terminal area operations. This study aims to improve the accuracy and reliability of near-term forecasting of severe convective precipitation in the airport terminal area through a dynamic weighted multi-channel data fusion method. Specifically, comparative experiments and attention mechanisms are designed in conjunction with the ConvLSTM model to assess the contribution of dual-polarization radar data (such as $\mathbf{Z}_{\mathbf{H}}, \mathbf{Z}_{\mathbf{D R}}$, and $K_{D P}$) in the near-term forecasting of severe convective precipitation. At the same time, a dynamic weight parameter calculation method is developed to dynamically adjust the precipitation estimation weight parameters, improving estimation accuracy. The experimental results show that dual-polarization radar data contributes significantly, and the dynamic weighted multi-channel data fusion method can greatly enhance the accuracy of near-term forecasting in the airport terminal area, enhancing the model’s spatiotemporal and seasonal adaptability, effectively dealing with severe convective weather.

title: Privacy-Preserving Lightweight IDS for Smart Home Botnet Defense
authors: Mildred Adwubi Bonsu, Philip Akekudaga
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Smart home IoT devices are increasingly exploited by botnets to launch large-scale distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, largely due to weak security configurations and limited processing power. Traditional intrusion detection systems (IDS) rely on deep packet inspection or signature matching, which are computationally heavy and raise privacy concerns when applied to home networks. This paper proposes a privacy-preserving lightweight IDS that detects botnet driven anomalies using only flow-based features, avoiding payload inspection and reducing computational overhead. The system integrates Random Forest (RF) and XGBoost in a hybrid ensemble via weighted soft voting, trained on the TON_IoT dataset containing realistic benign and malicious traffic. During preprocessing, non-predictive attributes were removed, and the feature set was reduced to 38 key attributes using correlation filtering and feature importance ranking. A stratified <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$80: 20$</tex> train-test split with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$z$</tex>-score normalization ensured balanced evaluation. The ensemble achieved 99.61 % accuracy, with precision (99.63 %), recall (99.59 %), and F1-score (99.61 %), outperforming standalone RF and XGBoost models. Compared to deep learning-based IDS, the proposed approach delivers fast inference, lower resource consumption, and preserves user privacy, making it suitable for deployment on constrained smart home gateways and routers. This work demonstrates that lightweight ensemble learning can effectively mitigate botnet threats while ensuring privacy and feasibility for ubiquitous smart home environments.

title: Quantifiable Theory of Change
authors: Franz Busse, Chris Mattson, Truman Spring
abstract: This paper presents a new framework for designing, analyzing, and improving social impact innovations. Theories of change and their associated logic models are standard tools of the trade for social impact programs. However, these tools could be improved to provide more quantitative guidance and unlock a host of computational tools to aid in design and decision-making. This paper introduces Quantitative Theory of Change (QToC). By using tools from control and system engineering such as transfer functions, dynamic modeling, and probabilistic analysis, we can design, implement, and evaluate social innovations with greater accuracy and efficacy. The methodology for building Transfer-function Logic Models (TLM) and using it for probabilistic analysis is demonstrated in a case study of using insecticide treated nets (ITNs) to combat childhood deaths from malaria.

title: Leaking Potential: Uncovering Gaps in Water Technologies and Techniques Adoption in Colorado's Small-Scale Farming Through Asset-Based Analysis
authors: Alexandria Rodgers, Marie Stettler Kleine
abstract: As drought conditions intensify, farmers - partic-ularly small-scale growers - must adapt practices to bridge the widening gap between water supply and demand. This exploratory study examines how small-scale farmers and their mentors in Colorado's Front Range utilize various technologies and techniques to conserve water, revealing obstacles in adopting water-efficient practices. A key finding of this work is the lack of localized, contextual knowledge across experience levels, paired with a strong interest from new farmers in expanding water-related education. Data suggest that agriculture accelerator pro-grams could serve as vital platforms for developing co-produced water conservation technologies (financial and material investment) and techniques (labor and time investment). However, decentralized mentor-based knowledge exchange presents equity barriers to vital information and collaboration. By documenting and analyzing these approaches, this research offers valuable insights for agriculture accelerator programs to better support water resilience in Colorado's farming communities.

title: Enhanced Ensemble Learning with Vision Transformers for Alzheimer’s Disease Classification Using MRI Imaging
authors: Wael Hadi, Mohammad Arafah, Mohammad Alauthman
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) represents one of the most challenging neurodegenerative disorders affecting millions worldwide. Early and accurate detection through medical imaging is crucial for effective intervention and treatment planning. This paper presents an enhanced ensemble learning framework that combines Vision Transformers with traditional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for multi-class Alzheimer’s disease classification using MRI scans. Our approach integrates ResNet50, InceptionV3, and Vision Transformer architectures through a weighted soft voting ensemble methodology. The proposed system addresses the significant class imbalance inherent in AD datasets through comprehensive data preprocessing and augmentation strategies. Experimental validation on a standard Kaggle AD dataset demonstrates superior performance, with our ensemble model achieving an AUC of 1.0, precision of 99.92%, recall of 99.89%, and F1-score of 99.91%. The results significantly outperform individual architectures and existing state-of-the-art methods, establishing a new benchmark for automated AD classification systems.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Boosting-Based Ensemble Learning Models and Stacking Ensemble Approach for Electricity Generation Forecasting in Thermal Power Plants
authors: Mahir Dursun, Betül Ersöz, Saadin Oyucu, Ahmet Aksöz
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: This study was conducted to predict a thermal power plant's energy output accurately. To this end, the performance of several machine learning-based boosting algorithms was systematically evaluated. The algorithms considered include Gradient Boosting Regressor (GBR), eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), Categorical Boosting (CatBoost), and Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM). An overarching objective was to enhance model efficacy by integrating these individual models within a stacking-based ensemble framework. According to the results obtained, LightGBM demonstrated the superior predictive performance among the individual models. However, the Stacking Ensemble method, which learned from the outputs of all constituent models, emerged as the most successful approach, exhibiting the lowest Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE: 3.3424) and the highest coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>: 0.9615). These findings suggest that integrating diverse boosting-based methodologies yields significant performance gains in time series problems, such as energy prediction.

title: Comparative Study of BERT and KNN Algorithms for Indonesian Climate Change Sentiment Analysis
authors: Jason Emmanuel, Wihendro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: This research investigates the comparative performance of BERT and KNN in analyzing sentiment related to climate change discussions on Platform X, focusing specifically on texts written in Bahasa Indonesia. As climate change becomes a dominant theme on social media, accurately interpreting public sentiment in local languages is critical for shaping effective communication and policy. While BERT has shown strong contextual understanding in various NLP tasks, and KNN remains a widely used baseline, there is a lack of studies directly comparing these models within the context of Indonesian climate discourse. This study is one of the first to quantitatively benchmark BERT against KNN for this domain, using multiple statistical significance tests (Mann-Whitney U, Cohen’s d, permutation testing, Bonferroni correction, and Bayesian hypothesis testing). Our results show that BERT consistently outperforms KNN across key metrics, highlighting the model's suitability for capturing nuanced sentiment in complex environmental discussions. These findings offer a novel contribution to Indonesian-language NLP and underscore the importance of advanced deep learning models for supporting climate communication and sentiment monitoring.

title: Motion-Aware Spectral Analysis (MASA): Bridging Robot-Induced Motion Artifacts and CNN Spectral Responses
authors: Youjin Kim, Sungjae Jeon, Seungtae Hong, Jeong-Si Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: In robot vision, motion artifacts from uneven terrain and gait dynamics often introduce blur into captured video, potentially reducing high-frequency information and recognition accuracy. We propose Motion-Aware Spectral Analysis (MASA), which integrates Temporal-to-Spatial Mapping, Synthetic Blur Study, and L1-Regularized Model Spectral Analysis. Experiments on quadruped robot video with MobileNetV2 show that MASA estimates blur in the range of 0.2–1.7 px and provides a spectral diagnostic tool for evaluating model robustness. Our analysis indicates that L1 activation regularization yields modest but consistent increases in high-frequency ratios, while synthetic motion blur leads to only minor spectral variations (within ±1%). MASA provides a principled spectral diagnostic framework for quantifying motion artifacts and guiding the design of motion-resilient robot vision systems.

title: A Critical Review of Feature Extraction and Machine Learning for Plant Disease Detection
authors: Ni Wayan Parwati Septiani, Marimin, Karlisa Priandana, Dwi Guntoro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: The rapid advancement of machine learning technologies has created significant opportunities to address agricultural challenges, particularly in plant disease detection. Accurate, efficient, and scalable diagnostic methods are essential for effective disease management. This study presents a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) using Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analysis (PRISMA) approach, focusing on three key areas: segmentation, feature extraction, and classification techniques in plant disease detection. The review highlights the increasing adoption of Deep Learning (DL) models, such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), hybrid approaches, and feature fusion methods, which enhance classification performance and robustness. However, challenges such as limited labeled datasets, high computational demands, and inefficiencies in segmentation persist. The findings underscore the importance of addressing these limitations through advancements in segmentation methods, domain-specific, pre-trained models, and lightweight architectures optimized for real-time applications. Additionally, leveraging semi-supervised learning techniques can utilize unlabeled data to reduce dependency on extensive feature types, improving segmentation accuracy, and developing scalable models to meet the needs of resource-limited settings. By addressing these challenges, the application of machine learning in plant disease detection can achieve higher accuracy, efficiency, and accessibility, significantly benefiting modern agriculture and sustainable farming practices.

title: Research on Real-Time Motion Control and Error Compensation Model in Mechatronics System
authors: Xiao Bao, Wensheng Liu, Ruifen Hu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Machining errors, assembly errors and interference factors in the operation of mechanical parts will lead to system errors, which will affect control accuracy and production efficiency. Therefore, this paper proposes a model predictive control (MPC) algorithm based on linearization model, and integrates robust design to deal with the nonlinearity, time-varying and uncertainty of the system. The discrete state space model is used to describe the system dynamics, and the rolling time domain optimization strategy is adopted to transform the robust MPC optimization problem into a quadratic programming problem to realize real-time control. At the same time, this paper constructs a comprehensive error decomposition model to decompose the total error into geometric error, thermal error and sensor noise, and uses machine learning algorithm to model and predict the complex error characteristics. The dynamic error compensation is realized by updating the error model parameters online through feedforward compensation and recursive least square method. The simulation results show that the dynamic compensation model is significantly superior to the traditional PID control and static compensation model in terms of the maximum error, root mean square error (RMSE) and control variable volatility, which verifies its adaptability and superiority under complex disturbances. In addition, the dynamic compensation mechanism can effectively suppress the complex interference of time-varying disturbance and random noise, and improve the response speed and stability of the system.

title: Beyond Proportional Control: A Comparative ROS2 Simulation on Path Tracking with PID+Pure Pursuit
authors: Sun Hong Jung, Yeong Gwang Choi, Eunho Kim, Young Hoon Suh, Hyojin Park, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This study presents a quantitative comparison of a proportional controller and a hybrid PID+Pure Pursuit controller for autonomous path tracking in a ROS 2 simulation. Moving beyond single-metric evaluation, we conducted 10 repeated trials for each controller, analyzing more than ten performance indicators to assess the trade-offs between efficiency, stability, and ride comfort. Efficiency improved under the hybrid PID+Pure Pursuit controller—lap time decreased by 13.5% and average speed increased by 15.0% Cost metrics moved in the opposite direction: steering-rate RMS rose by 11.5% and lateral-acceleration RMS by 31.2%. The smoother trajectory did not translate into comfort because higher velocity amplified lateral forces; meanwhile, longitudinal-jerk RMS showed no meaningful difference (p = 0.923). Overall, the evidence argues against single-metric, errorcentric judgments and motivates a reproducible, data-driven, multimetric validation pipeline before field deployment.

title: Precision Assessment of MPP-Calculating Neural Networks Depending on Different Weather Factors
authors: Murad Al-Omary, Rashed Bani-Issa, Rafat Aljarrah, Wasseem Al-Rousan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: The Maximum Power Point Tracker (MPPT) is essential to collect as much solar energy as possible from solar systems of different scales. This tracker would not perform its role effectively without an acceptable calculation for the maximum power point (MPP) as its main task. The neural network technique has been trending recently for this kind of calculation. Different models for the MPP-calculating neural networks were created by changing the type and number of inputs. The level of calculations' precision would differ according to this change from one model to another. This work assesses the precision level for different MPP-calculating neural networks that specifically use weather factors as inputs for Irbid City in Jordan. The results showed that the neural network with the (Air Temperature) only as input is the network with the lowest precision, according to the 0.458 found for the correlation coefficient. In contrast, the neural network that owns the Global Irradiance (GI), Diffuse Irradiance (DI), and Zenith Angle (θ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">z</inf>) as three combined inputs is the most precise one, with 0.9998 registered for a correlation coefficient.

title: Deep Learning Approaches for Livestock Monitoring: Comparing YOLOv11 and Faster R-CNN for Chicken Detection
authors: Ahmad Musthafa Masyhur, Kamarul Hawari Ghazali
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Object detection is essential for the progress of smart farming systems. This research offers a comparative examination of two advanced deep learning models, YOLOv11 and Faster R-CNN, for chicken detection utilizing the publicly accessible "Chickens-Oussaifi" dataset. The dataset contains 5,490 labeled pictures of chickens taken from several places, such as pictures from the internet, screenshots from games, and frames from videos. Standard object detection metrics were used to train and test both models in the same computer environment. With a mAP@50 of 0.867, a precision of 0.788, a recall of 0.819, and a fast inference time of 2.3 milliseconds per image, YOLOv11 was very good at finding things. Faster R- CNN had a higher recall rate (0.9135), but a lower precision rate (0.5312) and a slower inference time (80.6 milliseconds per image). These results show the pros and cons of each model, which helps choose the best detection frameworks for real-time intelligent poultry monitoring and future use in larger smart farming applications.

title: A Comparative Study Between Kotlin and Dart in Making a Simple CRUD Mobile Application
authors: Christian Jonathan Gunawan, Nickson Tan Clarino, Sonya Rapinta Manalu, Muhamad Keenan Ario
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Every year, a new mobile App is created using various programming languages used to meet the growing demand of users. This research compares Dart (Flutter) and Kotlin (Native Android) in the development of simple CRUD App. The comparison focused on beginner friendliness, Line of Code (LOC), data fetch time from Firebase, App and APK size, App build time, handling large upload data to Firebase. The testing required an identical App built using Dart and Kotlin with the latest version of each respective language and tested on the same emulator (Pixel 6 API 35). Beginner friendliness data will be collected through surveys to fellow developers. Each language has its strengths and weaknesses depending on the needs of the projects. Results of the testing reveal that Dart has an advantage in LOC, faster Firebase fetch time, while Kotlin excels in smaller App size, faster build time and a slightly faster performance in uploading data to Firebase. The surveys resulted in more favorable language, Dart for ease of project setup, CRUD deployment and widget usability, while Kotlin is favorable for its code readability and ease of understanding. These findings aim to guide developers in choosing a language based on the project requirements.

title: Bedfellows? Managerial optimism and optimistic alignment in collaborative innovation
authors: Cong Liu, Jie Liu, Jun Yang, Baofeng Huo
abstract: In practice, firms' managers are key decision-makers and are often plagued by optimistic bias. In collaborative innovation, this optimism manifests in both alignment and divergence among parties, which affects the efficiency and stability of collaborative innovation. However, the conditions and mechanisms underlying these effects remain unclear. To explore this issue, we consider a collaborative supply chain in which the supplier and the downstream manufacturer are realistic or optimistic. Our paper demonstrates the positive promotion of managerial optimism in innovation and shows that optimistic managers can innovate even when the profit in the supply chain is negative. Moreover, aligned optimism allows the supplier to shift the burden of innovation and cost to the manufacturer, increasing the manufacturer's innovation level. However, compared to aligned optimism, divergent optimism can lead to win-win outcomes under certain conditions. Furthermore, our findings suggest that when the optimism bias in consumer innovation preference is high, the supplier should choose a collaborator with an aligned attitude. Similarly, when the bias is moderate, the manufacturer should make the same choice. In both cases, aligned attitudes help synchronize decisions, which can benefit both firms due to higher innovation levels and reasonable prices.

title: Tensor-based Graph Learning with Consistency and Specificity for Multi-view Clustering_supp1-3639979.pdf
authors: Long Shi
abstract: In the context of multi-view clustering, graph learning is recognized as a crucial technique, which generally involves constructing an adaptive neighbor graph based on probabilistic neighbors, and then learning a consensus graph for clustering. However, it is worth noting that these graph learning methods encounter two significant limitations. Firstly, they often rely on Euclidean distance to measure similarity when constructing the adaptive neighbor graph, which proves inadequate in capturing the intrinsic structure among data points in practice, particularly for high-dimensional data. Secondly, most of these methods focus solely on consensus graph, ignoring unique information from each view. Although a few graph-based studies have considered using specific information as well, the modelling approach employed does not exclude the noise impact from the common or specific components. To this end, we propose a novel tensor-based multi-view graph learning framework that simultaneously considers consistency and specificity, while effectively eliminating the influence of noise. Specifically, we calculate similarity using pseudo-Stiefel manifold distance to preserve the intrinsic properties of data. By making an assumption that the learned neighbor graph of each view comprises a consistent part, a specific part, and a noise part, we formulate a new tensor-based target graph learning paradigm for noise-free graph fusion. Owing to the benefits of tensor singular value decomposition (t-SVD) in uncovering high-order correlations, this model is capable of achieving a comprehensive understanding of the target graph. Furthermore, we derive an algorithm to address the optimization problem. Experiments on six datasets have demonstrated the superiority of our method. We have released the source code on <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/lshi91/CSTGL-Code</uri>.

title: Multi-sensor Visual Cognition Framework-supported Intelligent Feeding Approach for Industrial Aquaculture
authors: Peng Xu, Haiyu Xu, Peng Xiao, Zhiwei Guo
abstract: In Industrial Recirculating Aquaculture Systems (IRAS), traditional feeding methods often rely on manual experience and judgment, which leads to low management efficiency. To address this problem, this paper introduces a meta-computing framework supported by multi-sensor visual cognition and proposes a new intelligent feeding method for IRAS. First, the architecture design of the meta-computing framework is proposed based on sensor data. Secondly, a computer vision-based target detection algorithm is developed as the first stage, and a trajectory tracking algorithm is developed as the second stage. The combination of these two constitutes a meta-computing visual cognition framework for intelligent feeding methods in the research scenario. In terms of empirical research, we conducted experimental evaluations in a real IRAS supported by multi-sensor meta-computing. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed intelligent feeding method effectively reduces feed residue, enhances feed conversion rates, and shortens water quality control time. It also strengthens the safety and autonomy of decision-making in IRAS.

title: A General-Purpose and Programmable Solver for Coupled Matrix Equations
authors: Sichun Du, Zhengmiao Wei, Shiping Wen, Qinghui Hong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Coupled matrix equations (CMEs) is a powerful mathematical tool in engineering. Most existing algorithms for solving CMEs rely on digital iterative implementations, which require a significant number of computational steps and time. Moreover, different types of CMEs solving algorithms are not universally applicable or require conversion into linear matrix equations for solving. This paper presents a general and programmable analog computational circuit for solving CMEs to address this. It simultaneously solves all unknown matrices in the CMEs with microsecond-level computation speed and requires only a single-step solution without iteration. It also supports solving any type of CMEs without redesigning the circuit structure. Pspice simulation results show that the average accuracy of the proposed circuit exceeds 98%. The final application validation in the stability determination of Markov jump systems (MJSs) demonstrates that the proposed circuit provides a two orders of magnitude speed advantage.

title: A Survey on Speech Large Language Models for Understanding
authors: Jing Peng, Yucheng Wang, Bohan Li, Yiwei Guo, Hankun Wang, YanGui Fang, Yu Xi, Haoyu Li, Xu Li, Ke Zhang, Shuai Wang, Kai Yu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Signal Processing
abstract: Speech understanding is essential for interpreting the diverse forms of information embedded in spoken language, including linguistic, paralinguistic, and non-linguistic cues that are vital for effective human-computer interaction. The rapid advancement of large language models (LLMs) has catalyzed the emergence of Speech Large Language Models (Speech LLMs), which marks a transformative shift toward general-purpose speech understanding systems. To further clarify and systematically delineate task objectives, in this paper, we formally define the concept of speech understanding and introduce a structured taxonomy encompassing its informational, functional, and format dimensions. Within this scope of definition, we present a comprehensive review of current Speech LLMs, analyzing their architectures through a three-stage abstraction: Modality Feature Extraction, Modality Information Fusion, and LLM Inference. In addition, we examine training strategies, discuss representative datasets, and review evaluation methodologies adopted in the field. Based on empirical analyses and experimental evidence, we identify two key challenges currently facing Speech LLMs-instruction sensitivity and degradation in semantic reasoning-and propose concrete directions for addressing these issues. Through this systematic and detailed survey, we aim to offer a foundational reference for researchers and practitioners working toward more robust, generalizable, and human-aligned Speech LLMs.

title: Large-Scale 3D Medical Image Pre-Training With Geometric Context Priors_supp1-3639593.pdf
authors: Hao Chen
abstract: The scarcity of annotations poses a significant challenge in medical image analysis, which demands extensive efforts from radiologists, especially for high-dimension 3D medical images. Large-scale pre-training has emerged as a promising label-efficient solution, owing to the utilization of large-scale data, large models, and advanced pre-training techniques. However, its development in medical images remains underexplored. The primary challenge lies in harnessing large-scale unlabeled data and learning high-level semantics without annotations. We observe that 3D medical images exhibit consistent geometric context, i.e., consistent geometric relations between different organs, which leads to a promising way for learning consistent representations. Motivated by this, we introduce a simple-yet-effective Volume Contrast (VoCo) framework to leverage geometric context priors for self-supervision. Given an input volume, we extract base crops from different regions to construct positive and negative pairs for contrastive learning. Then we predict the contextual position of a random crop by contrasting its similarity to the base crops. In this way, VoCo implicitly encodes the inherent geometric context into model representations, facilitating high-level semantic learning without annotations. To assess effectiveness, we (1) introduce PreCT-160 K, the largest medical image pre-training dataset to date, which comprises 160 K Computed Tomography (CT) volumes covering diverse anatomic structures; (2) investigate scaling laws and propose guidelines for tailoring different model sizes to various medical tasks; (3) build a comprehensive benchmark encompassing 51 medical tasks, including segmentation, classification, registration, and vision-language. Extensive experiments highlight the superiority of VoCo, showcasing promising transferability to unseen modalities and datasets. VoCo notably enhances performance on datasets with limited labeled cases and significantly expedites fine-tuning convergence. Codes, datasets, and models are available at https://github.com/Luffy03/Large-Scale-Medical.

title: Generative Diffusion Model Driven Massive Random Access in Massive MIMO Systems
authors: Keke Ying, Zhen Gao, Sheng Chen, Tony Q.S. Quek, H. Vincent Poor
abstract: Massive random access is an important technology for achieving ultra-massive connectivity in next-generation wireless communication systems. It aims to address key challenges during the initial access phase, including active user detection (AUD), channel estimation (CE), and data detection (DD). This paper examines massive access in massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems, where deep learning is used to tackle the challenging AUD, CE, and DD functions. First, we introduce a Transformer-AUD scheme tailored for variable pilot-length access. This approach integrates pilot length information and a spatial correlation module into a Transformer-based detector, enabling a single model to generalize across various pilot lengths and antenna numbers. Next, we propose a generative diffusion model (GDM)-driven iterative CE and DD framework. The GDM employs a score function to capture the posterior distributions of massive MIMO channels and data symbols. Part of the score function is learned from the channel dataset via neural networks, while the remaining score component is derived in a closed form by applying the symbol prior constellation distribution and known transmission model. Utilizing these posterior scores, we design an asynchronous alternating CE and DD framework that employs a predictor-corrector sampling technique to iteratively generate channel estimation and data detection results during the reverse diffusion process. Simulation results demonstrate that our proposed approaches significantly outperform baseline methods with respect to AUD, CE, and DD.

title:
Characteristics of Nb-based Josephson junctions with TaN
                    <sub>x</sub>
                    and TaN
                    <sub>x</sub>
                    /(Pd-Ni) barriers
authors: Ivan P. Nevirkovets
abstract: Self-shunted, high-j<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</sub> Josephson junctions are required for the development of high-density integrated circuits of superconducting electronics. For this purpose, various electrode and barrier materials have been considered by researchers. Here, fabrication and electrical characterization of Nb/TaN<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</sub>/Nb Josephson junctions is reported. At the thickness of TaNx layer of about 10 nm, the junctions are self-shunted and display the critical current density, j<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</sub>, above 100 kA/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and the effective critical voltage, V′<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</sub>, of about 0.68 mV at 4.2 K. The devices with j<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</sub> = 67 kA/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and V′<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</sub> = 0.96 mV are also fabricated. The effective critical voltage is defined as V′<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</sub> = I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</sub>R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">q</sub>, where I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</sub> is the Josephson critical current and R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">q</sub> is the resistance of the quasiparticle branch of the current-voltage characteristic at the level of maximum I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</sub>. In addition, Nb-based junctions with a composite TaN<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</sub>/(Pd-Ni) barrier were fabricated and characterized. The thickness of TaN<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</sub> was fixed while the thickness of Pd-Ni was varied. As a result, the characteristic voltage V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</sub> = I<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">c</sub>RN (where RN is the normal-state resistance of the junction) initially decreased, but then increased with the thickness of Pd-Ni, indicating the transition to the π state. For some value of the thickness of Pd-Ni, the diode effect was observed. It is suggested that the junctions are promising for applications in superconducting electronics including single-flux quantum digital and quantum computing circuits.

title: Characterizing the strain and temperature dependence of Brillouin gain spectra in a PANDA-type few-mode fiber
authors: Eun Chae Ha, Kwang Yong Song
abstract: A few-mode optical fiber (FMF), which supports higher-order spatial modes, has been extensively researched for optical communications and sensor applications. It serves as a potential platform of mode division multiplexing and fiber sensing with special functionalities. A PANDA-type FMF, featuring strong linear birefringence while also supporting higher-order modes, has proven effective in stabilizing the intensity distribution of these modes by breaking the inherent degeneracy in the LP modes of circular-core FMFs. In this work, we experimentally demonstrate the characterization of various intra- and intermodal Brillouin gain spectra (BGS) in a PANDA-type FMF, with a particular focus on the measurement of strain and temperature dependence. Brillouin optical correlation-domain analysis with differential measurement is employed to analyze the multipeak BGS of higher-order intramodal Brillouin scattering in a distributed manner, and a far-field detection scheme is implemented to distinctly analyze the Brillouin gain in higher-order modes, despite significant mixing with the fundamental mode.

title: Investigation of Effects and Protection from UWB EMP on UAVs
authors: Yansong Li, Yazhou Chen, Min Zhao, Xiaolu Zhang
abstract: The application scenarios of uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs) are becoming increasingly diverse. Enhancing their safety and stability in complex electromagnetic environments remains a challenge. This article investigates the electromagnetic effects and protection of mainstream consumer-grade multirotor UAVs subjected to ultrawideband electromagnetic pulse (UWB EMP) irradiation. The coupling voltages on the UAV's GPS antenna, datalink antenna, and typical cables under UWB EMP exposure are obtained through simulation. The effects of different radiation parameters on UAVs are evaluated via UWB EMP irradiation experiments. Results indicate that UWB EMP primarily enters the UAV through back-door coupling, inducing high voltages on the internal cables—particularly those between the electronic speed controller and the rotor motors. The high voltages and overheating will lead to <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">mosfet</small> breakdown and burnout of the motor's copper windings. Additionally, UWB EMP irradiation can cause abnormalities in the inertial measurement unit, resulting in UAV crashes. In contrast, front-door coupling effects mainly manifest as temporary interference like image distortion and datalink interruption. Finally, electromagnetic protection measures are applied to the back-door pathways of the UAV, and their effectiveness is validated.

title: Spatiotemporal Source Trajectory Tracking using Multiplexed Optomechanical Fiber-Optic FPI Sensors
authors: Yanzhi Lv, Aoxue Zhang, Yuhao Xue, Bin Yin, Yaoming Wei, Xiujie Dou, Shengnan Zhou, Jiawei Wang, Yongkang Dong, Jiajun Tian
abstract: Low-frequency acoustic source tracking is essential for early fault diagnosis and structural health monitoring, yet conventional fiber-optic acoustic sensors that use circular diaphragms face fundamental trade-offs among radius, thickness, and material strength that limit sensitivity and robustness. This work proposes an optomechanical fiber-optic acoustic sensor employing an aluminum spiral-beams–supported diaphragm with a tunable resonant frequency, integrated into a Fabry–Pérot interferometer. Finite-element-guided design and experiments demonstrate a calibrated sensitivity of 6.127 V/Pa, a minimum detectable pressure of 51.23 μPa / √Hz at 112 Hz, and a frequency response spanning 50 Hz to 20 kHz. To enable spatiotemporal tracking, we build a four-sensor array and develop a real-time adaptive strong-tracking unscented Kalman filter (AST-UKF) pipeline that enhances TDOA-based localization under low-SNR, reverberant conditions, reconstructing moving-source trajectories with 0.88 cm RMSE. The combination of low-frequency-optimized sensing and array-level inference yields a compact, passive, and electro-magnetic interference immune platform for weak-signal detection and trajectory tracking, providing practical support for online monitoring and decision-making in industrial environments.

title: RIS Partitioning-aided Multi-User Communications in Asymmetric RF/VLC Indoor Systems
authors: Claudia Leoni, Anna Maria Vegni
abstract: Hybrid radio frequency (RF)/visible light communications (VLC) indoor systems are largely deployed to guarantee high-capacity and seamless connectivity, thanks to the exploitation of benefits coming from both two technologies. Recently, the use of Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS) in VLC systems has provided enhanced network performance thanks to their ability of reflecting the impinging optical intensity to a desired destination, in order to avoid any blockages that may occur in Line of Sight (LoS) links. Taking into account the advantages of RIS deployment in VLC systems, in this paper we present a RIS-aided multi-user communication technique based on a fair RIS partitioning allocation policy (namely, RPMU). The proposed approach is applied in a hybrid RF/VLC indoor system, where asymmetric connectivity links are provided by means of RF uplink and VLC/RIS-aided downlinks. We also present a MAC protocol to support multi-user asymmetric RF/VLC and RIS-aided communications, and investigate packet collision events occurring in the RF uplink. Derivations of the achievable downlink throughput are provided, and the assessment of the proposed RPMU approach is carried out through numerical results showing the achievement of high data rates especially for higher number of RIS elements.

title: Four-Channel Imaging Based on Reconfigurable Metasurfaces: Hyperchaotic Encryption Under Physical Protection_supp1-3639549.docx
authors: Shuyuan Xiao
abstract: Metasurfaces facilitate high-capacity optical information integration by simultaneously supporting near-field nanoprinting and far-field holography on a single platform. However, conventional multi-channel designs face critical security vulnerabilities for sensitive information due to insufficient encryption mechanisms. In this work, we propose a four-channel phase-change metasurface featuring algorithm-physical co-security—a dual-protection framework combining intrinsic metasurface physical security with chaotic encryption. Our polarization-multiplexed metasurface generates four optical imaging channels through meta-atom design, including two far-field holograms and two near-field patterns. To enhance system security, we apply Chen hyperchaotic encryption combined with the Logistic map and DNA encoding to convert near-field information into secure QR codes; far-field holograms are retained to demonstrate the metasurface's information capacity and for attack detection. The phase-change metasurface further provides physical-layer security through its reconfigurable capability, dynamically controlling imaging channels via reversible crystalline-to-amorphous state transitions. This reconfigurability enhances anti-counterfeiting and reliability while demonstrating the physical security mechanism. The proposed metasurface achieves high-fidelity imaging, robust anti-attack performance, and independent channel control. This integrated approach pioneers a secure paradigm for high-density optical information processing.

title: In vivo Positron Emission Particle Tracking (PEPT) of Single Cells Using an Expectation Maximization Algorithm_supp2-3640076.mp4
authors: Guillem Pratx
abstract: Cell tracking is crucial for understanding the complex patterns of cellular migration that underlie many physiological, pathological, and therapeutic processes. Positron emission particle tracking (PEPT) is a method that uses list-mode positron emission tomography (PET) data to localize moving particles non-invasively inside opaque systems. However, while the application of this method to in vivo cell tracking has previously been evoked, its implementation has been limited to tracking one cell at a time. This study investigates the feasibility of tracking multiple cells simultaneously using a recently developed expectation maximization (EM) algorithm called PEPT-EM. The primary challenge to the translation of this algorithm towards biomedical applications is the low radioactivity of the cells being tracked. We experimentally demonstrated the performance of the PEPT-EM algorithm using a preclinical PET scanner for tracking droplets and cells with activities ranging from tens to hundreds of Bq, in phantoms and in a murine model. We found that while background and multiplexing effects impact static source tracking, sensitivity is critical for dynamic tracking of moving sources. We successfully localized multiple single cells in a murine model, moving at speeds up to 25 mm/s, marking the first use of PEPT-EM for such applications. Our findings highlight the exciting potential of PEPT for real-time, high throughput tracking of multiple single cells in vivo, paving the way for studying cell tracking in biological systems.
