title: The Effect of Wind Turbine Distribution Transformers on Grid Stability
authors: Orhun Celil Özen, Onur Akar
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: The widespread adoption of renewable energy sources has introduced new challenges in the management and stability of power grids. Among these sources, wind energy is one of the fastest-growing, standing out with its environmental benefits and limitless potential. However, the natural fluctuations in the energy generation characteristics of wind turbines can lead to stability issues in electrical grids. This paper examines the impact of wind turbine distribution transformers on grid stability. The irregularities in the output power of wind turbines can cause problems such as voltage regulation, reactive power balance, harmonic distortions, and frequency fluctuations during transmission to the grid. Distribution transformers play a critical role in mitigating these effects and ensuring grid stability. The study analyzes the control strategies and protection systems of distribution transformers in the context of wind energy systems’ impact on the grid. Both theoretical and simulation-based analyses are presented, and the behavior of transformers under different scenarios is examined. Additionally, the potential use of energy storage systems and modern power electronics devices to enhance grid stability is discussed. In conclusion, the effective design and management of wind turbine distribution transformers are crucial for the successful integration of renewable energy and the development of sustainable energy systems. This study aims to serve as a guide for future research in the fields of energy engineering and grid stabilization.

title: A Lightweight and Secure One-time Authentication Protocol for MQTT based on SAS-L2
authors: Ryoya Nakamura, Senling Wang, Hiroshi Kai, Hiroshi Takahashi, Akihiro Shimizu
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Message Queuing Telemetry Transport (MQTT) is one of the communication protocols used in Internet of Things (IoT) systems. It is a lightweight protocol characterized by low communication overhead, but as a result, this protocol has security issues such as authentication between the publishers and brokers. To address this issue, we propose a method of applying SAS-L2 (Simple and Secure one-time password authentication protocol, Lightweight version 2), a one-time password authentication protocol designed for IoT systems, to MQTT. SAS-L2 does not require the implementation of hash functions on resource- constrained IoT devices and can perform authentication processing using only exclusive OR (XOR) and addition operations. Evaluation results of security and computational cost demonstrate that this method can achieve robust and lightweight authentication even in resource-constrained environments, compared to existing protocols.

title: Brain Tumor Segmentation Using Ensemble Vanilla U-Net and Residual U-Net Models
authors: Annisa Dwi Puspitarini, Raihan Adam Handoyo Winarso, Yusril Falih Izzaddien, Chastine Fatichah, Hilya Tsaniya Ismet
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: A precise diagnosis depends on the accurate segmentation of brain tumors from Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) scans. Efficient planning of treatments and tracking of therapeutic results. Nonetheless, the variation in tumor size, shape, and intensity presents major obstacles. This study uses the BRaTS 2021 dataset, which consists of multi-modal MRI scans of glioma patients, to assess the effectiveness of Vanilla U-Net, Residual U-Net, and an ensemble-based approach for brain tumor segmentation. In comparison to Residual U-Net, which achieved 98.36% accuracy, a Dice Coefficient of 50.04%, and a Mean IoU of 37.55%, Vanilla U-Net achieved 99.37% accuracy, a global Dice Coefficient of 65.51%, and a Mean IoU of 81.37%. The ensemble approach, which combined predictions from both models using weighted averaging, performed best, obtaining a Mean IoU of 97.85% and a Dice Coefficient of 73.73%. These findings demonstrate how well ensemble-based deep learning techniques can capture complementary features, greatly increasing segmentation accuracy. This study shows how ensemble-based approaches can improve model learning performance, which has great potential to help radiologists diagnose and treat patients more accurately and consistently.

title: Design of Adaptive Fuzzy PID Controller for Electric Vehicle System
authors: Hassan Benariba, Abdelmadjid Boumédiène
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: This work is devoted to the modelling and control of an electric vehicle. A simulation model has been selected that use the PMSM motor coupled to the rear wheels propelling the vehicle via a fixed ratio gearbox. For the independent control of torque and flux, field oriented-control (FOC) is used to drive the PMSM. The Adaptive Fuzzy PID control was applied to optimize the parameters of the speed vehicle conventional PID regulator. A comparative study between conventional PID and Fuzzy PID control strategies for electric vehicles (EVs) reveals that adaptive PID controller generally offer superior performance, especially under varying operating conditions.

title: Towards Federated Health Information Exchange Architecture in Indonesia: Design and Implementation
authors: Diana Wijayanti, Satriawansyah Urbaya, Saldi Yusuf, Chaerus Sulton, Dimas SEW Sumunar, Taufiq Sitompul
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Indonesia continues to face challenges in health data fragmentation and disconnected systems, limiting timely clinical decisions and continuity of care. Although the SATUSEHAT platform adopts HL7 FHIR to promote interoperability, real-time, bidirectional data exchange remains limited due to incomplete electronic health record (EHR) integration. This paper presents a Design Science Research (DSR) case study to develop and evaluate a federated Health Information Exchange (HIE) architecture enabling real-time data sharing across EHRs, regional HIEs, and the national platform. Piloted in Jakarta and East Java, the solution reflects a scalable, standards-based model aligned with national priorities. The study begins with a literature review and case analysis of HIE implementations in diverse settings to extract key architectural and governance strategies. The proposed architecture spans point-of-service, regional, and national levels and includes registry services, business services, and interoperability layers. Design activities involve iterative modeling, prototyping, and scenario-based testing in a controlled environment. The resulting artifact offers a replicable model for HIE advancement in low- and middle-income countries.

title: RzkFL: a Verifiable, Fast and Privacy-Preserving Framework for Federated Learning Inference Using Recursive Zero-Knowledge Proofs and on-Chain Verification
authors: Zeinab Alipanahloo, Michael Duchesne, Kaiwen Zhang
abstract: RzkFL is an end-to-end, privacy-preserving machine-learning framework that fuses Federated Learning (FL) with recursive zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) to protect data, models, and users while unlocking verifiable inference. Models are trained entirely on local devices, so sensitive data never leave the premises. The resulting model can be monetized by offering verifiable predictions on a pay-per-use basis. During inference, each customer independently computes predictions using private data, making it essential to verify that these inference results are computed correctly and honestly. Unlike existing approaches that rely on heavy communication or centralized trust assumptions, RzkFL allows each customer to generate a cryptographic proof of correct local inference, which can be succinctly verified without revealing input data or model parameters either by the customer or a third party. The core innovation lies in the use of recursive ZKPs, enabling each customer to generate small, composable proofs for intermediate layers of neural network inference. These proofs are then recursively aggregated into a single succinct proof using the Nova proof folding scheme. Nova’s design eliminates the traditional sequential dependency of recursive proofs by enabling incrementally verifiable computation through a folding scheme. RzkFL supports on-chain verification via Ethereum smart contracts, allowing AI results to flow directly into financial workflows. A decentralized file storage system maintains the integrity and availability of the global model. We introduce specialized circuits for input, hidden, and output layers to optimize proof generation time and gas costs. The customer can generate proof for the entire inference computation or delegate the proof generation for the intermediate layers and the output layer to another party. The design suits privacy-preserving machine learning scenarios where customer devices are resource-constrained. Our results show that RzkFL can significantly reduce proof size and verification costs while maintaining privacy, integrity, and scalability in federated inference. This makes it a compelling approach for real-world decentralized AI systems requiring strong verifiability guarantees.

title: Optimal Design of Building Energy Saving and Energy Consumption Prediction Based on Genetic Algorithm
authors: Li Ye, Fangda Lin, Zhitian Kou
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: As a critical sector for energy use, the energysaving design of buildings plays a vital role in mitigating energy waste and reducing carbon emissions. This paper begins by highlighting the significance of optimizing building designs for energy efficiency and identifies the limitations and challenges present in traditional design approaches. Subsequently, this paper expounds the application of genetic algorithm (GA) in the optimization design of building energy efficiency, including its effectiveness in multi-objective optimization problems and its advantages in optimizing building design parameters. In this paper, a GA-based optimal design process for building energy efficiency is proposed, which includes three stages: preliminary design, detailed design and optimal design, and describes the eight steps of the design process and method in detail. In addition, this paper also introduces the use of artificial neural network (ANN) model to predict energy consumption, and uses GA to optimize the parameters of ANN model to improve the prediction accuracy. By examining buildings in three distinct thermal zones across different cities, this study validates the effectiveness of the building energy-saving optimization design process and method utilizing GA. It also assesses the precision of the ANN model, refined through this optimization, in forecasting energy consumption. Findings indicate that employing GA for optimizing building energy efficiency can significantly lower annual energy use. Moreover, the improved ANN model demonstrates a high level of accuracy in predicting building energy consumption, thereby offering robust technical support for both the design and retrofitting of buildings aimed at enhancing energy efficiency.

title: Angle-Aware mmWave MISO Wireless Sensing for Vibration Frequency Estimation
authors: Che-Yao Lee, Pei-Tsen Hsieh, Yu-Chieh Chen, Tzu-Hsiang Hsu, Meng-Lin Ku
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Industrial vibration monitoring is essential for equipment health assessment; however, contact-based sensors are unsuitable in hazardous environments, while existing contactless methods suffer from accuracy degradation due to angular misalignment and range limitations. This paper proposes a joint estimation approach for direction-of-arrival (DoA) and vibration frequency in millimeter-wave (mmWave) multi-antenna contactless measurement scenarios. The system integrates an 8×1 multiple-input single-output (MISO) array with a software-defined radio (SDR) platform. A differential method is employed to extract inter-antenna phase differences for DoA estimation using the multiple signal classification (MUSIC) algorithm. Based on the estimated DoA, passive and active angle-aware methods are developed for vibration frequency estimation with passive or active DoA compensation. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed system achieves robust DoA and vibration frequency estimation under directional deviations and extended ranges, highlighting its potential for industrial fault detection and preventive maintenance.

title: Iterative Development of the Mothers of Sierra Leone Cinema Kit: A Culturally-Responsive Humanitarian Engineering Approach to Improving Maternal Health
authors: Eileen Kandie, Chloe Chan, Julia Killar, Maddie Boughner, Eesha Gudoor, Michael Kramp, Fathima Wakeel, Rejoice Obiora
abstract: Sierra Leone endures one of the world's highest maternal mortality rates, engendered by a limited healthcare infrastructure, misinformation, and disparities in rural areas. The effectiveness of health interventions is often constrained by the accessibility of information delivered to communities. This paper presents the deployment of the Mothers of Sierra Leone (MOSL) cinema kit-a portable multimedia device that brings culturally tailored maternal health information films to remote areas. MOSL uses technology to amplify the voices and stories of local women and healthcare professionals, demonstrating how meaningful change must be grounded in cultural contexts and through community collaboration. Pre- and post-surveys indicate improvements in maternal health knowledge among audiences reached by the cinema kit. The paper details the technical evolution of the kit, explores the design process and technical refinements informed by community feedback, and outlines future directions toward sustainable, community-led health storytelling in Sierra Leone.

title: Detection and Tracking of Intruding Unmanned Aerial Vehicles Based on Dual-modality
authors: Ruiheng Zhang, Ruoxi Zhang, Yang Lei, Yu Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: The unmanned aerial vehicles detection and tracking system is of vital significance in the current military and civil aviation fields. The research on this system is inseparable from object detection and object tracking algorithms. This paper first introduces the self- collected dual-modal dataset and briefly explains the data annotation tool. Subsequently, six mainstreams deep learning based object detection algorithms are tested on this dataset, and the basic detection results of these detectors are obtained. To further enhance the detection performance, we improved the YOLOv8 algorithm with the best performance by integrating two types of feature pyramids into it. After the improvement, it can be clearly seen that the detection effect has been enhanced. Finally, this paper elaborates on how to combine the object detector and the object tracker to construct a complete system.

title: Numerical Simulation of a Fractional Timoshenko Beam Model Using High-Order Finite Difference Schemes
authors: Iqbal M. Batiha, Beghou Zineb, Dounia Belakroum, Jamal Oudetallah, Adel Ouannas, Shaher Momani
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: In this paper, we present a fourth-order compact finite difference (CFD) method for numerically solving a fourth-order parabolic partial differential equation describing the transverse vibration of a fractional Timoshenko beam. A fourth-order compact scheme is employed for the spatial discretization, while a second-order Crank–Nicolson method is used for time integration. The proposed approach accurately satisfies the boundary conditions without requiring additional approximations at the boundaries and is easy to implement. The method achieves fourth-order spatial accuracy and second-order temporal accuracy using a single compact stencil. Two numerical examples are considered to assess the performance of the scheme, and the computed results are compared with available reference solutions, confirming the reliability and accuracy of the method.

title: Agentic AI and Police Crime Prediction Using Deep Learning
authors: Swarnamouli Majumdar, Anjali Awasthi
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Urban policing faces growing challenges in anticipating and mitigating crime amidst dynamic, resource-constrained environments. This paper introduces an agentic AI framework that integrates deep spatio-temporal forecasting with adaptive patrol planning to support proactive public safety strategies. Leveraging over 15 years of crime data from the Seattle Police Department, we train and compare multiple deep learning architectures—including LSTM, GRU, and 1D CNN models—to predict short-term spatial distributions of crime risk. The agentic layer transforms these predictions into autonomous decisions using reinforcement-inspired routing algorithms and a feedback module that refines the predictive model based on observed outcomes. Experimental results demonstrate that GRU-based predictors strike the best balance between accuracy and computational efficiency, while the agent's adaptive planning improves coverage in high-risk zones. We also implement fairness-aware mechanisms to reduce bias in over-policed communities. This study offers one of the first fully integrated frameworks for real-time crime forecasting and patrol decision-making, setting the stage for aligned, adaptive, and ethically responsible AI in law enforcement.

title: Research on Intelligent Scheduling Optimization Algorithm of Mechatronics Assembly Line Based on Machine Learning
authors: Ruifen Hu, Xiao Bao, Wensheng Liu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: With the rapid development of intelligent manufacturing technology, scheduling optimization of mechatronics assembly line has become a key issue to improve production efficiency and resource utilization. Traditional scheduling methods often have problems such as large computational volume and poor adaptability when facing complex production environments. Machine learning technology shows great potential in the field of intelligent scheduling to achieve efficient and intelligent scheduling optimization through data-driven methods. In this paper, we study the intelligent scheduling optimization algorithm of mechatronics assembly line based on machine learning method. The key factors of the assembly line scheduling problem are analyzed, and the limitations of traditional scheduling methods are discussed. The intelligent scheduling optimization model based on machine learning is constructed, including data feature extraction, model selection and optimization, and the design of intelligent scheduling algorithm. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm is verified through experiments, and a comparative analysis is conducted with the traditional method to evaluate its optimization effect in terms of scheduling efficiency, resource utilization and production stability. The results show that the scheduling optimization method based on machine learning can significantly improve the scheduling efficiency of the assembly line, which provides new ideas and technical support for production scheduling in the intelligent manufacturing environment.

title: Protecting Magnetic Field Disturbance by Adding Steel Shield based on Magnetic Field Change Phenomenon
authors: Jaekyung Pee, Daejin Park
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Among the various types of sensors that detect the rotation angle in automobile parts, the Hall Sensor (HALL Sensor) is a widely used technology in sensor applications. The rotation angle of a Hall sensor is currently accurate because it detects a precise angle within an error range of less than 1%. However, since the Hall sensor may be affected by the disturbance of the external magnet, the accuracy of the sensor is degraded due to the interaction between the magnetic field of the internal magnet and the magnetic field of the external magnet. To improve this, we try to find a shielding method that shields the external magnetic field using magnetic materials and a method that improves the measurement stability of the Hall sensor by analyzing the magnetic field phenomenon that passes through the magnetic material. In this paper, we present our experimental results to digitize the degree of external magnetic field shielding to secure stability and to maintain the accuracy of the sensor (the disturbance characteristics of the external magnet) below 5%.

title: Spatio-Temporal Data Modeling and Reinforcement Learning Optimization for Tree Hidden Danger Prediction of Transmission Lines
authors: Xiwen Lai, Hongda Li, Weiqiang Qi, Chunsheng Li, Kai Zhou, Ruizhe Zhang, Pei Zhang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: In this paper, a tree hidden danger prediction method for transmission lines is proposed, which combines spatio-temporal data modeling and reinforcement learning (RL) optimization. First of all, by fusing multi-source data such as the spatial distribution of transmission lines, the growth characteristics of trees and meteorological conditions, a prediction model that can reflect the temporal and spatial dynamic characteristics is constructed. The model uses the Spatiotemporal graph convolution network (ST-GCN) to deal with the spatial characteristics, simulates the growth rate of trees by combining the dynamic equation of tree growth, and introduces the spatio-temporal attention mechanism to evaluate the potential risks caused by trees. Secondly, an RL optimization framework based on markov decision processes (MDP) is designed, and the model parameters are dynamically adjusted by using DDPG algorithm with double delays to improve the prediction accuracy and real-time. The experimental results show that the proposed method is superior to the baseline model in terms of accuracy, recall, F1 value, mean absolute error (MAE) and time-consuming of single prediction, especially in extreme weather conditions such as strong wind, which verifies the superiority and application prospect of this method in tree hidden danger prediction of transmission lines.

title: Assessing Partnership: Utilizing Community-Based Participatory Research to Evaluate Participatory Design
authors: Lauren Wojciechowski, Julia Kramer
abstract: Co-design is a participatory approach where stakeholders are engaged as designers, adding insight through their lived and technical experiences. Understanding co-designers' experience designing can help improve co-design processes and their outcomes. However, there is currently a lack of established tools for evaluating participatory design processes, especially from the perspective of co-designers. Community-Based Participatory Research (CBPR), which engages partners as researchers throughout a project, offers validated tools for evaluating partnerships. While CBPR and co-design both aim to actively engage partners throughout a project, limited work has explored how CBPR evaluation tools might apply to co-design. In this methodological paper, we present a CBPR-informed survey developed to evaluate co-designers' experiences. We piloted the survey with community members in Ethiopia and Kenya engaged in designing family planning interventions. Here, we present the survey we developed and share our learnings on how utilizing a CBPR-informed approach to understand co-designers' experiences can provide deeper insight into how co-design processes impact those who participate.

title: Environment-Adaptive Feature Space Reconstruction for Low-Altitude Radar Perception
authors: Shengjie Wang, Tianyi Kong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: The rapid growth of low-altitude unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) applications poses significant challenges for radar signal processing, demanding both high-precision feature extraction and real-time processing capabilities. Traditional methods, constrained by linear processing frameworks, struggle to balance noise suppression and micro-Doppler feature preservation. While time-frequency analysis offers richer signal details, its computational burden hinders real-time performance. Recent deep learning approaches, although enhancing feature representation, rely heavily on large-scale labeled datasets and complex network architectures. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a novel physics-driven high-dimensional space mapping method. Non-linear Dimension Expansion (NDE) enhances target-clutter separability, a One-Hot encoding mechanism forms a sparse feature matrix to reduce computational complexity, and an adaptive sparse modulation factor dynamically adjusts feature space resolution, optimizing features in the preprocessing stage. Compared to traditional methods, this approach eliminates the need for subsequent detection algorithm compensation, balancing accuracy and efficiency. The method offers a promising solution for low-altitude UAV radar signal processing by providing enhanced feature separability and reduced computational cost.

title: Accelerated Network Design for Analyzing Spatial Heterogeneity in Electrification Planning
authors: Yuezi Wu, Vijay Modi
abstract: Electricity access in rural sub-Saharan Africa re-mains a significant challenge. Settlement patterns in this region exhibit considerable heterogeneity, significantly impacting distri-bution network layouts and investment costs. This paper analyzes settlement patterns within communities using a network design model that minimizes transformer count and aggregate costs of LV and intra-community MV infrastructure. The optimization results provide key network metrics for each community, including transformer counts, low-voltage wire, and internal medium-voltage wire requirements per connection. This model builds upon an established two-level network design algorithm while incorporating significant computational improvements. Tests show a two orders of magnitude reduction in computational time by relaxing the voltage drop constraint while maintaining exceptional fidelity in distribution infrastructure cost per connection. Meanwhile, the maximum input size of connection nodes that can be computed is nearly three to four times larger, reducing boundary effects. Additionally, a geospatial outlier exclusion methodology prevents community cost metrics from being distorted by spatially distant connection nodes. These improvements enable the algorithm to be applied to large-scale networks with less time, reduced segmentation requirements, and smaller effects of geospatial outliers. These enhancements allow planners to identify prioritized electrification communities and allocate resources strategically across diverse settlement patterns.

title: Multimodal Fatigue Detection in Remote Tower Air Traffic Controllers: Integrating ECG, EEG, and Subjective Evaluation
authors: Dajiang Song, Weijun Pan, Ruihan Liang, Chen Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: This study focuses on the fatigue monitoring of remote tower controllers and aims to explore the application of multimodal data in real-time fatigue assessment. The article adopts advanced ECG and EEG acquisition techniques, supplemented by subjective evaluation means, to comprehensively analyze the physiological and psychological states of controllers during the execution of monitoring tasks. The study constructs a fatigue detection model that integrates multiple physiological data through the detection of key indicators in ECG signals as well as $\boldsymbol{\alpha}$-waves, $\boldsymbol{\beta}$-waves and other parameters in EEG signals, thus realizing the accurate identification and timely warning of controller fatigue status. The experimental results show that the joint application of multimodal data can effectively reflect the fatigue changes of controllers in a continuous high load working environment, which provides a powerful data support for improving the safety and reliability of the monitoring system. In addition, this study also provides a scientific theoretical basis for the health management and work efficiency improvement of remote tower controllers, which has high practical application value and promotion prospects.

title: Algorithm for Generating and Optimizing Character Behavior in 3D Animation Games Based on Deep Learning
authors: Alex Zihuan Cui Liu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: In modern society, with the diversification of people's entertainment life and the rapid development of technology, the application scope of three-dimensional (3D) animated game characters in the gaming industry is constantly expanding, and their influence is deepening. In this context, it is particularly important to use deep learning (DL) technology to promote the development of the 3D animation game character industry. The generation of game character behavior, as a core part of 3D animation production, relies on real motion data obtained through motion capture and other means, combined with advanced computer technology, to achieve the realistic reproduction of character behavior. This complex process not only requires high technical precision, but also requires comprehensive consideration of multiple dimensions such as the character's action characteristics and scene environment. To address this challenge, this article innovatively proposes a DL based 3D animation game character behavior generation and optimization algorithm. This algorithm can intelligently process and analyze character action data through training and fine optimization of DL models, thereby generating more natural, smooth, and game scene fitting 3D character behaviors. The experimental data fully demonstrates that the algorithm performs excellently in improving the efficiency and quality of character behavior generation.

title: A Scalable Continual Learning Framework for Air Conditioner Fault Diagnosis
authors: Junwon Lee, Chaehyeon Lee, Minsuk Kwak, Nakhoon Kim, Heechul Jung
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: With the advancement of AI, Predictive Maintenance (PdM) for major appliances such as air conditioners has become a critical technology. However, data distribution shifts, driven by new product releases or market expansions, degrade the performance of existing AI models, leading to substantial retraining costs. Continual Learning (CL) is a promising solution to this problem, yet most research has focused on image classification, leaving its application to time-series data from appliance operations largely underexplored. This paper proposes a Transformer encoder-based CL framework for predicting refrigerant deficiency by effectively learning from large-scale air conditioner time-series data streamed sequentially by year and country. We systematically evaluated key CL methodologies—regularization, replay, and hybrid approaches—on real-world operational data. Experimental results demonstrate that replay-based methods successfully mitigate catastrophic forgetting by preserving past knowledge. Notably, a hybrid model combining a replay strategy with Less-Forgetting Learning (LFL) achieved the highest predictive performance. This study suggests that CL presents an efficient and scalable solution for continuously evolving a single PdM model, eliminating the need for periodic retraining in dynamic data environments.

title: AI in Creative Economy as a Key Factor Influencing Gen Z Employee Productivity
authors: Rini Kurnia Sari, Marita T. Salandanan, Aisyah Qanita
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: The creative economy industry is one of the most impacted by the implementation of Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology. The implementation of AI in the industry can increase innovation and efficiency in various business processes. Generation Z as the digital generation, having characteristics that are very adaptable to the work environment, especially those based on AI. Although AI is considered to improve performance productivity, there is still a gap in how AI can improve job satisfaction. This study investigates the influence of AI adoption variables on employee productivity and job satisfaction in Gen Z employees in Indonesia's creative industry. This research uses a quantitative method with research instruments in the form of an online survey of 200 samples. The SEM-PLS technique was used to analyze the data. Researchers found that AI adoption has a significant positive influence on employee productivity and job satisfaction. In addition, researchers also found that job satisfaction has a positive effect on employee productivity by strengthening a balanced AI integration strategy. However, the indirect impact on the relationship between AI adoption on employee productivity through job satisfaction was found to have no significant effect. These findings lead researchers to recommend to organizations that in addition to adopting AI, they also need to consider employee well-being so that the benefits obtained can be optimal. This study provides insights for companies in creating AI-based strategies to manage a sustainable Gen Z work environment in the digital age.

title: Lightweight Dental Image Segmentation with Combined Importance and Redundancy-based Pruning
authors: Minju Hyun, Wan Kim, Jae Hwan Han, Jae hoon Shim, Soon Hyoung Pyo, Byung Cheol Song
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Deep learning-based tooth segmentation models achieve high accuracy as they grow deeper and more complex; however, their practical application in industrial settings is hindered by high computational and memory demands. To address this, pruning techniques have been employed, but existing methods mainly focus on filter importance and fail to consider redundancy among filters. In this paper, we propose DDGWD, a pruning method that simultaneously incorporates filter importance and redundancy evaluation based on Manhattan distance. Experiments on a tooth segmentation dataset demonstrate that the proposed method effectively reduces computational cost and memory usage compared to conventional importance-based approaches while minimizing performance degradation. This study shows that redundancy-aware pruning can play a crucial role in developing lightweight tooth segmentation models suitable for practical industrial deployment.

title: Data-Driven Battery Degradation Modeling for Electric Vehicles under Calendar and Cyclic Aging Conditions
authors: Berk Aşçıoğlu, Chiedozie Augustine Ike-Offiah, Nazif Hakan Yeniay, Canraş Batunlu
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: In recent years, the pollution produced by vehicle fuel consumption has been one of the main environmental contamination factors that could lead to further climate change and global warming. Recent science and technological advancements have shown that reducing fossil fuel consumption significantly mitigates environmental degradation and is beneficial to public health. Using renewable energy to power electric vehicles (EVs) instead of gasoline is one strategy to reduce fuel use. One of the primary problems with electric vehicle batteries is that they deteriorate with time, making them unsafe to use. To reduce the threat caused by EV batteries, the evaluation and prediction of battery health has been a primary research objective. This paper suggests data-driven battery degradation modeling based on a battery performance process followed by a very detailed testing protocol to extract important battery characteristics. For electric vehicle (EV) applications, this process offers a useful tool to maximize battery life and enhance safety.

title: Enhanced Biosensing with Nanodiamond-Decorated In-Fiber Microcavity Interferometer
authors: Monika Janik, Tomasz Gabler, Mateusz Ficek, Mattia Pierpaoli, Mirosław Sawczak, Paweł Niedziałkowski, Marcin Koba, Mateusz Śmietana, Robert Bogdanowicz
abstract: This study presents the first integration of nanodiamonds (NDs) with a microcavity in-line Mach-Zehnder interferometer (μIMZI) fabricated by femtosecond laser micromachining in the side surface of an optical fiber. NDs of different sizes form a structured and functional layer for receptor immobilization. Numerical analyses were performed to investigate how the ND particle size influences the optical field distribution in the cavity. The sensor's spectral response and refractive index sensitivity have been investigated experimentally. The results have shown that the ND layer enhanced light-surface interaction and increased the available area for binding, improving surface sensitivity and enhancing receptor loading. Among the tested configurations, the μIMZI modified with a 250 nm-thick ND layer exhibited the most favorable characteristics, achieving RI sensitivity of approximately 15,300 nm/RIU, and was therefore employed for specific, label-free detection of a model low-molecular-weight protein, green fluorescent protein (eGFP). The modified sensor demonstrated monotonic change and reproducible spectral response down to a protein concentration of 0.35 μg/mL, while the limit of detection was equal to 0.14 μg/mL, with a response time of about 30 minutes, which can be further optimized. In contrast, a non-modified reference μIMZI showed no response to comparable concentrations. Besides label-free detection, the multifunctional nature of NDs was further explored by exciting nitrogen-vacancy centers in the diamond structure, aiming for fluorescence-based sensing. These experiments confirmed that, in this configuration, the centers could be optically excited by a light guided through the fiber core, which is partially exposed within the microcavity and can interact directly with the ND-coated surface. The resulting fluorescence was detected from the microcavity region, demonstrating excitation and readout capabilities. Altogether, this work demonstrates that ND-based surface modification can simultaneously enhance sensitivity and expand the functional capabilities of these highly compact optical fiber biosensors.

title: In vivo Positron Emission Particle Tracking (PEPT) of Single Cells Using an Expectation Maximization Algorithm_supp1-3640076.mp4
authors: Guillem Pratx
abstract: Cell tracking is crucial for understanding the complex patterns of cellular migration that underlie many physiological, pathological, and therapeutic processes. Positron emission particle tracking (PEPT) is a method that uses list-mode positron emission tomography (PET) data to localize moving particles non-invasively inside opaque systems. However, while the application of this method to in vivo cell tracking has previously been evoked, its implementation has been limited to tracking one cell at a time. This study investigates the feasibility of tracking multiple cells simultaneously using a recently developed expectation maximization (EM) algorithm called PEPT-EM. The primary challenge to the translation of this algorithm towards biomedical applications is the low radioactivity of the cells being tracked. We experimentally demonstrated the performance of the PEPT-EM algorithm using a preclinical PET scanner for tracking droplets and cells with activities ranging from tens to hundreds of Bq, in phantoms and in a murine model. We found that while background and multiplexing effects impact static source tracking, sensitivity is critical for dynamic tracking of moving sources. We successfully localized multiple single cells in a murine model, moving at speeds up to 25 mm/s, marking the first use of PEPT-EM for such applications. Our findings highlight the exciting potential of PEPT for real-time, high throughput tracking of multiple single cells in vivo, paving the way for studying cell tracking in biological systems.

title: SW3T-IoT: Smart Water Monitoring Based on a Three-Tier IoT Architecture
authors: Mohammed Kamal Benhaoua, Amine Dahane, Rabaie Benameur, Izzessalam Belhadj Benziane, Houssam Eddine Zahaf, Abderrahmane Benhariga, Abdelkader Elouissi, Cherifa Boudia, Sami Souihi
abstract: The growing impacts of climate change on water resources demand innovative monitoring and management strategies. This paper presents SW3T-IoT, an innovative water monitoring system leveraging Internet of Things (IoT) technologies to enhance water resource management under dynamic conditions. The system adopts a three-tier architecture—edge, fog, and cloud—integrating a custom-designed LoRa-WDS node optimized for low power consumption and long-term autonomous operation. These nodes collect real-time data on water level, flow, pressure, temperature, and quality from distribution networks and reservoirs. Data are locally processed at the edge, then transferred to the cloud for advanced analysis and visualization. A Geographic Information System (GIS) enhances spatial awareness and decision-making. To ensure adaptability, SW3T-IoT integrates a continual learning (CL) framework for Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD) forecasting. The CL mechanism allows models to incrementally update with new environmental data without catastrophic forgetting, maintaining accuracy and robustness as water quality dynamics evolve. A hybrid CNN–BiLSTM–Attention model, reinforced with PER, AER, LwF, and EWC strategies, supports adaptive prediction and knowledge retention. The system delivers intuitive dashboards for engineers and water managers, providing a holistic, scalable, and intelligent solution for sustainable water resource management.

title: AI for Good: Advancing Sustainability in Smart Manufacturing
authors: Adel Ben Youssef, Nessrine Omrani, Adelina Zeqiri
abstract: This paper examines the potential of artificial intelligence (AI) to facilitate sustainable development within smart manufacturing globally, addressing a significant literature gap. While AI clearly plays an important role in operational efficiency, its broader contribution across the manufacturing life cycle remains underexplored. Drawing on 43 expert interviews conducted between June and September 2024, four areas where AI delivers sustainability value are identified: energy optimization, predictive maintenance, sustainable supply chains, and carbon emission management. The robustness of the results is ensured by the Gioia protocol, double coding with adjudication, cross-role and cross-country triangulation, member checking, saturation, and an auditable codebook. First, the findings reveal that many small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) experience greater than expected efficiency gains when moving from manual to AI-based energy monitoring, exposing hidden inefficiencies. Second, a strong link between predictive maintenance and energy savings is revealed, suggesting that equipment longevity and sustainability are more tightly coupled than previously recognized. Third, AI-enabled emission tracking serves both as a compliance mechanism and as a catalyst for internal cultural change and stakeholder trust, positioning AI as a strategic governance tool. Finally, policy and managerial recommendations are provided to foster responsible AI adoption in manufacturing. A multilevel conceptual model that illustrates how AI, supported by digital and organizational enablers, contributes to sustainability outcomes and alignment with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is also presented. This research advances theory and practice by highlighting the transformative, yet still underleveraged, role of AI in sustainable manufacturing transitions.

title: A Gallium Nitride-Based 48V-to-1 V Point-of-Load Converter for Aerospace Telecommunications and Computing Applications
authors: Nathan M. Ellis, Jiarui Zou, Yicheng Zhu, Robert C. N. Pilawa-Podgurski
abstract: This paper presents a regulating hybrid switched-capacitor (HSC) power converter topology suitable for high conversion ratio Point-of-Load (PoL) applications where size and weight are important considerations. Coined the “Dual Inductor Switching Bus Converter” (DISB converter), the proposed topology merges an initial 2:1 switched capacitor conversion stage with a recently developed symmetric dual inductor hybrid (SDIH) conversion stage, reaping benefits of both. The initial 2:1 voltage reduction stage significantly reduces the overall volume/weight of flying capacitors, while the SDIH stage offers reduced component count and an excellent switch stress figure of merit. A preliminary 50 W hardware prototype validates this topology while employing de-rated gallium nitride (GaN) switches to enable operation in harsh environments such as aerospace. Further leveraging topology-specific properties, we also describe the implementation of two highly complimentary circuit blocks; a high density gate drive solution, and a technique termed “resonant charge recovery” (RCR) which serves to reduce overall converter losses by up to 37% while occupying <1% of total converter volume. The resulting prototype achieves a very high measured power density of 2,020 W/inch<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula> (123.3 kW/liter) with 87.3% full-load conversion efficiency (90.1% peak efficiency), while switching at 1 MHz and performing direct 48 V to 1 V conversion.

title: Exploiting Spatial and Temporal Correlations in Massive MIMO Systems Operating Over Non-Stationary Aging Channels
authors: Sajad Daei, Gábor Fodor, Mikael Skoglund
abstract: This work investigates a multi-user, multi-antenna uplink wireless system, in which multiple users transmit signals to a base station. Prior research has explored the potential for linear growth in spectral efficiency by employing multiple transmit and receive antennas. This gain depends heavily on the quality of channel state information and the number of uncorrelated antennas. However, spatial correlations, arising from closely-spaced antennas and channel aging effects, stemming from the difference between the channel state at pilot and data time instances, can substantially counteract these benefits, and degrade the transmission rate, especially in non-stationary environments. To address these challenges, this work introduces a real-time beamforming framework to compensate for the spatial correlation and channel aging effects. First, a channel estimation scheme leveraging temporal channel correlations and considering mobile device velocity and antenna spacing is developed. Subsequently, an expression approximating the average spectral efficiency, which depends on pilot spacing, pilot and data powers, and beamforming vectors, is obtained. By maximizing this expression, optimal parameters are identified. Numerical results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach compared to prior works. Interestingly, the optimal pilot spacing remains unaffected by large-scale channel parameters and the velocities of interfering users. The impact of interference components also diminishes with an increasing number of transmit antennas.

title: Orthogonal Chirp Delay-Doppler Division Multiplexing (CDDM) Modulation for High Mobility Communications
authors: Chaoyuan Bai, Pingzhi Fan, Zhengchun Zhou, Zilong Liu
abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-carrier modulation framework for high-mobility communication scenarios. Our key idea lies in spreading data symbols across the delay-Doppler (DD) domain through orthogonal chirp-Zak transform (CZT). To enable efficient signal multiplexing, the proposed modulation scheme employs a transmitter signal that maintains orthogonality with the inherent resolution characteristics of the DD plane. Termed as Orthogonal Chirp Delay-Doppler Division Multiplexing (CDDM), we demonstrate a synergistic integration of chirp waveform properties with the channel structure of the DD domain, thereby achieving advantages with both lower computational efficiency and improved detection performance. We introduce a novel CZT-based superimposed sparse pilot structure to enable simultaneous estimation of delay-Doppler shifts and channel coefficients. For enhanced performance, we further develop an embedded pilot scheme that demonstrates channel estimation performance comparable to that of Orthogonal Delay-Doppler Division Multiplexing (ODDM) systems. Simulation results demonstrate that CDDM achieves significant bit error rate (BER) improvements over existing modulation schemes , under perfect channel state information (CSI), as well as superior out-of-band emissions (OOBE). Further, for the imperfect CSI case, the proposed CZT-based superimposed pilot scheme leads to significantly reduced normalized mean square error (NMSE), whilst attaining equivalent estimation accuracy to that of ODDM with lower computational complexity.
