title: MTLoc: A Confidence-Based Source-Free Domain Adaptation Approach For Indoor Localization_supp1-3637161.pdf
authors: Negar Mehregan Mehregan
abstract: Indoor localization using radio-frequency identification (RFID) has benefited from deep learning, yet models trained in a labeled source environment often degrade when deployed in a different, unlabeled target environment. Unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) aims to mitigate this distribution shift by aligning a source-trained model with target-domain data. In practice, the source dataset is frequently unavailable at adaptation time due to privacy and resource constraints. This motivates source-free domain adaptation (SFDA); however, most SFDA methods have been developed for classification, and extending them to indoor localization (regression) is challenging, especially when target datasets are small and noisy. Motivated by above limitations, we introduce MTLoc, a source-free mean-teacher approach for indoor localization. MTLoc includes a student and a teacher network: the student network is updated using noisy target data with teacher-generated pseudo-labels. The teacher network maintains stability through exponential moving averages. To further ensure robustness, we propose a correction mechanism in which the teacher’s pseudo-labels are refined using k-nearest neighbor correction. MTLoc allows for self-supervised learning on target data, facilitating effective adaptation to dynamic and noisy indoor environments. Validated using real-world data from our experimental setup with INLAN Inc., our results<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup> show that MTLoc achieves high localization accuracy under challenging conditions, significantly reducing distance error compared to baselines. On average, it reduces MAE (d) by 20.0% on Cross and 22.5% on Square datasets. With confidence correction, these improvements reach 23.9% and 28.2% respectively.

title: TransDiff: Unsupervised Non-line-of-sight Imaging with Aperture-limited Relay Surfaces
authors: Xingyu Cui, Huanjing Yue, Shida Sun, Yue Li, Yusen Hou, Zhiwei Xiong, Jingyu Yang
abstract: Non-line-of-sight (NLOS) imaging aims to reconstruct scenes hidden from direct view and has broad applications in robotic vision, rescue operations, autonomous driving, and remote sensing. However, most existing methods rely on densely sampled transients from large, continuous relay surfaces, which limits their practicality in real-world scenarios with aperture constraints. To address this limitation, we propose an unsupervised zero-shot framework tailored for confocal NLOS imaging with aperture-limited relay surfaces. Our method leverages latent diffusion models to recover fully-sampled transients from undersampled versions by enforcing measurement consistency during the sampling process. To further improve recovered transient quality, we introduce a progressive recovery strategy that incrementally recovers missing transient values, effectively mitigating the impact of severe aperture limitations. In addition, to suppress error propagation during recovery, we develop a backpropagation-based error correction reconstruction algorithm that refines intermediate recovered transients by enforcing sparsity regularization in the voxel domain, enabling high-fidelity final reconstructions. Extensive experiments on both simulated and real-world datasets validate the robustness and generalization capability of our method across diverse aperture-limited relay surfaces. Notably, our method follows a zero-shot paradigm, requiring only a single pretraining stage without paired data or pattern-specific retraining, making it a more practical and generalizable framework for NLOS imaging.

title: Multivariate Time Series Anomaly Detection Using Learnable Spatial-Temporal Graph Ordinary Differential Equations Network
authors: Shiming He, Qingqing Guo, Keyao Feng, Diqing Liang, Kun Xie, Pradip Kumar Sharma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Multivariate time series anomaly detection (MTSAD) plays a critical role in the Internet of Things (IoT) by identifying malfunctions and attacks. Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have been widely employed in MTSAD to capture spatial features but require predefined and explicit graph structures. Graph Structure Learning (GSL) addresses this limitation by jointly learning the graph structure and downstream tasks. However, existing GSL-based MTSAD methods fail to effectively leverage prior knowledge and struggle with insufficient GNN depth, limiting their ability to capture long-range dependencies. To address these challenges, we propose a multivariate time series anomaly detection method based on a learnable spatio-temporal graph ordinary differential equation network (STGODE), named MAD-ODE. Our approach leverages hybird graph learning, which includes two types of graph structures: a static similarity graph and a learnable graph. The static similarity graph is constructed using prior knowledge and provides a stable, interpretable representation of sensor dependencies. In contrast, the learnable graph captures complex relationships between sensors by optimizing its structure through backpropagation. This hybird graph learning effectively incorporates both prior knowledge and learned dependencies, ensuring robust and flexible modeling of sensor relationships. Furthermore, we design a STGODE predictor, which operates on both graph structures and employs continuous graph convolutional networks, enabling it to capturing long-range spatio-temporal dependencies for forecasting the next timestamp. Extensive experiments conducted on five datasets demonstrate that MAD-ODE achieves the best average performance and maintains stable results compared to existing methods.

title: Deep Learning Framework for Multi-Class Segmentation of Photovoltaic Systems
authors: Svea Krikau, Sina Keller
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate mapping of photovoltaic (PV) installations supports renewable energy monitoring, capacity assessment, and policy planning. We introduce a deep learning framework for the simultaneous segmentation of rooftop (RTPV) and ground-mounted (GMPV) PV systems from 0.2m aerial imagery. The approach integrates automatically generated labels from registries and crowdsourced geographic information data with a small set of manually refined annotations, enabling scalable training with high spatial fidelity. A dual-head U-Net++ with a ResNet50 encoder jointly performs pixel-wise segmentation and image-level classification, reducing false positives in heterogeneous landscapes. Exemplarily applied to the state of Hesse, Germany, the model achieves a balanced accuracy of 87.52%, precision of 94.74%, and a recall of 82.89%, with F1-scores of 75.75% (RTPV) and 88.65% (GMPV). Coupled with solar suitability data, the results indicate rooftop PV utilization of only 3.24% statewide and 2.5% in the Dietzenbach case study. This implemented deep learning framework is the first high-resolution, single-step multi-class PV segmentation applied at the federal state scale, offering a transferable tool for large-area PV monitoring.

title: Digital Twin Assisted Dynamic Modeling and Protection Optimization for Coal Mine Power Distribution Systems
authors: Shan Wang, Jingjing Huang, Aimin Zhang, Yudong Du, Xuming Gao
abstract: Conventional relay protection settings face significant challenges in accurately tracking the dynamic operating states of coal mine power distribution systems due to frequent topology changes and substantial load fluctuations. To address these challenges, this article proposes a digital twin (DT)-based approach for real-time dynamic modeling and optimization of relay protection current settings. A modular and automated modeling method driven by a real-time topology matrix is first developed, enabling accurate real-time representation of the system’s structure and operating state. Subsequently, a real-time simulation-driven prediction method for relay current settings is introduced, along with an adaptive optimization model that dynamically adjusts the setting according to evaluation indices. The proposed approach is experimentally validated based on real-time electrical data and historical fault records collected from a coal mine power distribution system. Results demonstrate that the DT model established by the proposed method exhibits excellent capability in both dynamically tracking the actual system states and achieving high simulation accuracy, thereby effectively improving relay protection performance and showing strong potential for practical application.

title: Photovoltaic Power Forecasting for Sustainable Grid Integration: A Hybrid Deep Learning Approach
authors: Abdulrahman Alsafrani, Hammad I. Sherazi, Omar Alrumayh, Shabana Habib, Abdullah A. Alburidy, Muhammad Islam
abstract: Solar power is increasingly recognized as a pivotal alternative to mitigate the utilization of limited fossil fuels and their associated pollution. Photovoltaic (PV) power plants contribute substantially to renewable energy generation; however, they face challenges due to the intermittent and volatile nature of solar energy. Addressing these challenges necessitates an automatic and precise forecasting system to efficiently manage and ensure consistency in the electricity power system. Various deep learning-based techniques have been proposed for PV power forecasting, but there is still a pressing need to further reduce the error rates of these methods to effectively manage the grid. In this paper, we propose a novel hybrid deep learning-based network that combines dilated convolutional neural network (DCNN) and residual long short-term memory (RLSTM) techniques. The DCNN is used to extract spatial patterns from historical PV data under varying weather conditions. These patterns are then input into a bidirectional RLSTM network to capture temporal correlations within the data. The output of the DCNN-RLSTM network is then fed into fully connected layers for making predictions. Our proposed model’s performance is evaluated using various benchmarks and four different evaluation metrics: RMSE, MBE, MSE, and MAE. The results show that our model achieves lower error rates compared to previous models. This research contributes to the ongoing efforts in advancing renewable energy technologies for integration into energy systems and buildings. The proposed model uses innovative deep learning techniques to address key aspects of energy planning, management, and operation, ultimately supporting environmental sustainability, energy diversification, and reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

title: Comparative Evaluation of CNN, LSTM, and Hybrid CNN-LSTM for Spatial-Spectral Classification of Hyperspectral Images
authors: Annisa Divayu Andriyani, Kamarul Hawari Ghazali, Slamet Riyadi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Hyperspectral imaging (HSI) captures spatial and spectral information, making it highly effective for land cover classification. This study assesses the efficacy of three deep learning models—CNN, LSTM, and Hybrid CNN-LSTM— utilizing the Salinas dataset to analyze their capacity for modeling spatial and spectral properties. CNN acquires spatial context from image segments, whereas the LSTM models spectral sequences. The hybrid model combines both methodologies to leverage spatial-spectral relationships. The hybrid model demonstrated superior performance with an accuracy of 99.91%, surpassing LSTM's 95.10% and CNN's 93.02%. The assessment encompasses training curves, confusion matrices, and predicted classification maps, illustrating that the hybrid methodology markedly enhances classification efficacy. This study validates that the integration of convolutional and sequential architectures can improve hyperspectral image processing and establishes a robust basis for future investigations in spatial-spectral learning.

title: Research on Emotional Visualization Design for Pedagogical Virtual Humans
authors: Xin Fang, Minmin Huang, Xiaoyi Song, Jun He
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Online teaching provides personalized, interactive, and practical learning support to teachers and students, compensating for the limitations of traditional teaching methods and meeting the demand for digital technology in education. Within online learning spaces, pedagogical virtual humans can simulate the teaching functions of real teachers, providing instructional assistance in virtual teaching scenarios. The emotional visualization of virtual humans is a crucial factor influencing learner effectiveness. Finding efficient solutions for visualization design can offer a more humanized and effective teaching experience, help educators provide personalized teaching support through emotional feedback, enhance teaching effectiveness and efficiency, boost student learning motivation and engagement, and assist educators in better understanding students' emotional changes to provide personalized support based on different emotional needs.

title: A Block-wise Streaming Extension of FastSpeech2 for Real-Time LLM-TTS Cascade Systems
authors: Uijong Lee, Taewoo Kim, Young Han Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper presents a streaming text-to-speech (TTS) framework for real-time speech synthesis in LLM-driven conversational systems. We extend FastSpeech2, a non-autoregressive model, with block-wise processing that partitions input sequences into fixed-length segments. Block-wise attention masking and buffer-based inference are introduced to preserve prosodic coherence across block boundaries and mitigate training–inference mismatch. Integrated with the HiFi-GAN vocoder, the framework delivers synthesis quality comparable to full-sequence processing while significantly reducing first-block latency (FBL). Experimental results show that block-wise processing maintains audio fidelity under streaming constraints. These findings indicate that feed-forward Transformer architectures can be adapted to streaming synthesis through targeted structural modifications, providing a viable solution for latency-critical LLM–TTS cascade systems.

title: Stable BEV Fusion for Multi-Camera Vehicle Tracking with Wheel-Contact Keypoints and Anchor-Only Tracking
authors: Eun Ho Kim, YeongGwang Choi, Young Hoon Suh, Hye Jun Hong, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Precise estimation of vehicle position and attitude, as well as global ID management, are core challenges for large-scale parking and intelligent transportation infrastructure. This paper defines eight vehicle keypoints that directly describe the vehicle’s pose and BEV (bird’s eye view) coordinates. However, keypoints on glass, roofs, and mirrors, which are not on the road surface, cause a spreading phenomenon during planar homography projection. This occurs because height differences cause the position of the same object to vary across cameras. To address this issue, we propose Anchor-Only BEV Fusion. This technique achieves stable global ID tracking through pre-and post-processing alone, eliminating the need for end-to-end learning. It directly utilizes the YOLOv8 detector, pose estimator, and BoT-SORT tracker. The core approach involves updating the BEV state using only wheel contact points to suppress projection bias, designating the central camera as the ID reference, and using side cameras for auxiliary observations. It also applies gating using slot, field of view (FoV), and velocity constraints, along with Cartesian extended Kalman filter (EKF)-based state estimation. During post-processing, low-quality observations are only used as ID evidence and are not reflected in the state to prevent numerical diffusion. Experiments conducted in Gazebo with 13 cameras demonstrate that this method significantly reduces positional and pose errors, as well as ID switching, compared to existing methods, while achieving near-real-time performance.

title: Analysis of the operation of a starter generator integrated into an aircraft engine
authors: Okhotnikov Mikhail Valerievich, Vavilov Vyacheslav Evgenievich, Ismagilov Fleur Rashitovich
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: The paper analyzes the operating conditions of the integrated starter generator. Calculations are being made and the possibility of practical installation of an integrated starter generator in an aircraft engine is being considered. The minimum power level required by the integrated starter generator is determined. Using the example of the Rolls Royce integrated generator concept, the designs of an integrated starter generator and an integrated generator for placement in an aircraft engine are presented. The main conditions of its operation and the criteria determining the features of operation inside a gas turbine engine are determined. The mechanical losses and the moment created in the integrated starter generator in the presence of oil in it are considered.

title: A Study on the Influence of Ink and Wash Style Noctilucent Effects on Game Atmosphere
authors: Minmin Huang, Xin Fang, Jun He
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper investigates the influence of ink and wash style noctilucent effects on game atmosphere, clarifying its conceptual framework, expressive forms, and operational mechanisms, while verifying its effectiveness through experiments. Based on defining the expressive forms of ink and wash noctilucent effects, it analyzes their mechanisms in strengthening atmosphere tone, guiding visual information, regulating emotions and immersion, and enhancing scene details and emotional connections. A comparative experiment is conducted to evaluate the impact of ink and wash noctilucent effects on game atmosphere. The results demonstrate that ink and wash noctilucent effects outperform traditional noctilucent effects, with different types exhibiting differentiated advantages. This study provides theoretical and practical references for integrating traditional cultural elements into game design and balancing artistic and functional design.

title: Risk Assessment of Mixed Gas Leakage in Power Grid Based on Computer Algorithms
authors: Yingzhe Cheng, Shenghui Li, Jiehao Chen, Wei Pan, Qiukai Lin, Meisen Chen, Kaiyue Wu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Addressing the complexity of mixed gas leakage risk assessment in power grid equipment, this paper proposes a risk assessment method based on improved BP neural network and fuzzy comprehensive evaluation. The method establishes a mapping relationship between gas concentration and equipment status, and constructs a dynamic risk assessment model by combining gas diffusion models and multi-source data fusion technology. Research shows that the proposed algorithm outperforms traditional methods in terms of assessment accuracy, real-time performance, and anti-interference capability, with a 15.3% improvement in assessment accuracy and a 35.2% reduction in response time. This method provides a new technical approach for intelligent assessment of gas leakage risks in power grid equipment.

title: A Unified Hardware Crypto Accelerator for ARIA, HIGHT, LEA, and SEED Block Ciphers
authors: Young-Jong Jang, Junhyuk Baik, Byung-Soo Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper presents a unified hardware crypto accelerator supporting four standardized block ciphers: ARIA, HIGHT, LEA, and SEED. The architecture adopts independent cipher cores while internally sharing key scheduling and round function modules to reduce redundant hardware resources. The accelerator supports various operation modes, including ECB, CBC, OFB, CFB1 /8/16/32/64/128, and CTR, with HIGHT supporting up to CFB64. Implemented in 40 nm LP CMOS technology, the design occupies 196,120 gate equivalents and operates at 200 MHz. At this frequency, the accelerator achieves a maximum throughput of 1,878 Mbps for ARIA-128, with performance validated across other cipher algorithms. Functional verification was conducted using the official KISA test vector system, ensuring compliance with cipher standards. These results demonstrate that the proposed accelerator delivers competitive performance and hardware efficiency, providing a practical solution for secure and resource-constrained embedded platforms.

title: Deep Learning Forecasting of Dissolved Oxygen for Hypoxia Early Warning in the Indian River Lagoon
authors: Jiyahna Price, Sarah Krejci, Juan M. Calderon
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Dissolved oxygen (DO) is a critical indicator of aquatic ecosystem health, and its rapid decline can trigger hypoxic events leading to fish kills and habitat degradation. This study investigates short-term DO forecasting in the Indian River Lagoon (IRL), a highly vulnerable estuarine system in Florida. Using a year-long dataset collected in 2024 from the Kars Park station, we evaluate four forecasting approaches: a Finite Impulse Response (FIR) model with least squares optimization, an Adaptive Linear Neuron (Adaline), a recursive deep neural network (DNN Feedback), and a multi-output deep neural network (DNN Multi-Output). Results demonstrate that the DNN Multi-Output substantially outperforms classical and recursive models, reducing mean absolute error by over 80 % compared to FIR and more than 90 % relative to Adaline. Unlike recursive methods, which suffer from error accumulation, the multi-output architecture maintains stable accuracy across horizons up to 24 hours. These findings highlight the potential of deep learning for real-time hypoxia forecasting and early warning management in coastal ecosystems.

title: A Study of Spiral Structures Based on Finite Difference Method and Variable Step Search
authors: Yifan Wu, Shan Jiang, Ziwei Jiang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: The aim of this study is to investigate the motion model of the spiral structure based on the finite difference method and variable step search, and to analyse the application of the spiral structure through the Archimedean solenoidal equation as a basis. Firstly, for the motion process of the spiral structure, the finite difference method is used to solve the motion positions and velocities of its head, knuckle body and the tail handle of the spiral structure. Secondly, considering the possible collision during the disc entry process, the state of each moment is judged by constructing a rectangular region to determine the termination moment. Further, the study adopts the bifurcation method to search the pitch to ensure that the spiral structure reaches the turnaround region smoothly, and then calculates the minimum pitch and constructs the turnaround path. Finally, in order to optimise the travel speed, this study uses a variable step size search method under constraints to derive the maximum travel speed of the head of the spiral structure. Through this study, an effective model is proposed, which not only provides a new perspective for the scientific analysis of spiral motion, but also lays the foundation for the application in related fields.

title: Design and Implementation of Intelligent Transportation Monitoring Platform Based on Internet of Things Technology
authors: Honggang Kong, Danhua Li
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) technology is a product of the joint development of Internet technology, communication technology, computer technology and other modern information technologies, which has been developed more maturely and has good applications in many fields. With the acceleration of urbanization, traffic congestion and security problems are becoming more and more prominent, and intelligent traffic monitoring has become an important means to solve such problems. The rapid development of Internet of Things (IoT) technology provides technical support for the design and realization of intelligent traffic monitoring platform. Based on IoT technology, this paper proposes a design framework for intelligent traffic monitoring platform, including key aspects such as data acquisition, transmission, processing and intelligent analysis. Real-time data collection is realized by constructing a sensor network, adopting efficient communication protocols to ensure the reliability of data transmission, and combining intelligent algorithms to analyze and predict traffic data. The effectiveness and performance of the platform are verified through actual cases. The platform can significantly improve the efficiency of traffic monitoring and provide scientific support for urban traffic management, and at the same time, it has important reference value for the future research of intelligent transportation system.

title: From Morphemes to Knowledge Graphs: Enabling Abstractions in Large Language Models With Neurosymbolic AI
authors: Thilini Wijesiriwardene, Krishnaprasad Thirunarayanan, Amit Sheth
abstract: Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) have revolutionized natural language processing, achieving impressive performance across a wide range of linguistic tasks. However, these successes often mask a critical limitation: Current evaluation paradigms provide little insight into how well LLMs handle linguistic abstractions, the very cognitive capability that underlies generalization, analogy-making, and systematic reasoning. Without a principled framework for evaluating abstraction, it remains unclear whether LLMs truly engage in abstractions and their nature, how consistently they do so, and to what extent these behaviors reflect genuine abstraction capabilities versus surface-level pattern matching. We propose a structured taxonomy of linguistic abstractions in natural language processing, spanning levels from morphology to knowledge graphs (KGs), organized along two key dimensions: linguistic granularity and contextual dependence. This taxonomy supports a more nuanced evaluation of LLMs’ abstraction capability and helps identify where current models fall short. In particular, we highlight the limitations of LLMs at higher levels of abstraction—such as semantic, topical, taxonomic, and KG levels—where relational composition, context sensitivity, and symbolic structures are critical. To remedy these weaknesses, we advocate for the integration of neurosymbolic artificial intelligence (AI) systems that combine neural representations with symbolic reasoning.

title: Real-Time Drowsiness and Lane Departure Warning System Using Deep Learning and Embedded Systems
authors: Donggyu Seo, Jiyoung Moon, Young Hoon Suh, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This study proposes the implementation of a driver drowsiness detection and lane departure warning system. The main components of the system include a camera, PC, Arduino, buzzer, and LED. Real-Time data of both the driver and the road are collected through the camera. Lane departure is determined using the YOLOPv2 deep learning model combined with post-processing techniques, while driver drowsiness is assessed by employing Dlib-Based facial landmark detection in conjunction with the Eye Aspect Ratio (EAR) method. The results from both detection modules are integrated through the main processing unit, which comprehensively evaluates the driver’s drowsiness state and lane departure status. When a risk is identified, the Arduino activates the buzzer and LED to deliver immediate alerts to the driver. The system operates in real time (≈60 FPS) and is designed to enhance driving safety by mitigating risks associated with drowsiness and unintended lane departure.

title: Continuance Intention of QRIS Payment Adoption for Indonesian Micro and Small Business: An Expectation Confirmation Model
authors: Revaldo Ongko, Rudy, Enggal Sriwardiningsih
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: QRIS (Quick Response Code Indonesia Standard) adoption as a digital payment method for micro and small enterprises (MSEs) in Indonesia remains low. In this context, our research is significant as it aims to analyze the continuance intention of customers and other business owners. We demonstrate why MSEs should offer the QRIS payment method in their businesses, as it has the potential to significantly enhance business income in the digital era, paving the way for a more prosperous economic landscape. The data were collected through questionnaires with methods and questions using ECM variable confirmation, perceived usefulness, satisfaction, and continuance intention, with 210 QRIS users (customers) and 8 QRIS users (business owners) analyzed through the SmartPLS 4.0 framework. The conclusion is that confirmation, perceived usefulness, and satisfaction have positive and significant effects on continuance intention and continuance intention using QRIS among QRIS users and business owners. The use of QRIS as a payment method in MSEs will not only increase income but also reduce the likelihood of someone failing to purchase because QRIS is not available as a payment option.

title: Strengthening the Sickle Cell Care Pipeline: a Systems-Based Approach in Sierra Leone
authors: Owen Holst, Nancy Carcamo–Paiz, Adelaide Ogden, Nicole Hirsch, Amelie Fry, Jacob Feuerstein, Xuanhong Cheng, Khanjan Mehta
abstract: Sickle cell disease (SCD) poses a significant yet under-addressed public health challenge in Sierra Leone where limited diagnostic infrastructure, insufficient medical training, and a lack of unified national protocols hinder effective care and management [1]. The SicklED team at Lehigh University presents a comprehensive five-point strategy aimed at transforming SCD outcomes in the region through accessible, sustainable, and context-specific interventions. This paper outlines the initiative for the development of a low-cost, point-of-care screening tool to increase early detection; the implementation of targeted medical education initiatives to bolster provider knowledge; the distribution of culturally adapted educational materials to enhance community awareness; the creation of nationally recognized supplemental guidelines and a standard operating procedure (SOP) to unify SCD care protocols; and the launch of a robust data collection framework to support evidence-based policy and health system planning. Through interdisciplinary collaboration, global partnerships, and ongoing feedback from Sierra Leonean healthcare professionals and advocacy groups, the SicklED strategy aims to catalyze systemic change and provide a replicable model for addressing noncommunicable diseases in resource-limited settings.

title: Opportunities and Challenges in Leading a Community-Engaged International Research Experience for Students (IRES) Program
authors: Stephanie A. Claussen, Kirsten A. Davis, Jennifer DeBoer
abstract: In this paper, we describe and reflect upon an international summer research experience for U.S. students focused on community-engaged engineering, which took place in Eldoret, Kenya between 2023 and 2025. We begin by presenting the details of our program's motivation and structure. We describe how our program design achieves six outcomes identified in prior work for short-term educational engineering experiences abroad. Finally, we reflect on our collective experiences leading this program and share observations that we hope will benefit the future leaders of similar programs, funding agencies, and other researchers interested in community-engaged engineering.

title: Comparing Random Forest and Naïve Bayes for Sentiment Analysis of ChatGPT and DeepSeek
authors: Vickenzio Leeputra Dharma, Nathanael Kenneth Nurtanio, Kristien Margi Suryaningrum
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: In this era, artificial intelligence (AI) is a big part of people’s life, AI itself has many uses ranging from answering simple questions to making complicated marketing strategies. This experiment aims to analyze people’s sentiment on ChatGPT and DeepSeek, while also finding out which machine learning method between Random Forest (RF) and Bernoulli Naïve Bayes (BNB) has better accuracy based on different variables. This experiment uses data from Google Play Store comment section of ChatGPT and DeepSeek. The methods are scraping, VADER, text preprocessing, TF-IDF, ROS, data preprocessing, classifier model, and data analyzing. This experiment provides consideration for future works on what machine learning method to use between Random Forest and Bernoulli Naïve Bayes when experimenting with ChatGPT and DeepSeek’s Google Play Store comments, while also showing how variables affect the performance of algorithms. Based on the results, Bernoulli Naïve Bayes algorithm achieved higher accuracy than Random Forest algorithm with the highest of ChatGPT 81.40% and of DeepSeek 73.15%. With the exception of higher size of DeepSeek dataset, where its performance is better when using Random Forest rather than Naïve Bayes with accuracy of 75.90%.

title: Wi-Fi Fingerprint Location Based on Adaptive Weighted K Nearest Neighbor Algorithm
authors: Suqing Yan, Weihong Liao, Jianming Xiao, Yuanfa Ji, Qiang Fu, Kamarul Hawari Bin Ghazali
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: With the development of positioning technology, the research value of high-precision indoor positioning algorithm is increasingly prominent. Wi-Fi fingerprint location has attracted much attention because of its low hardware cost and convenient deployment. However, Wi-Fi signals are easily affected by the environment and fluctuate, which leads to the selection of inappropriate reference points. In order to solve this problem, we adopt an adaptive K nearest neighbor algorithm with weighted Euclidean distance. The algorithm optimizes the traditional weighted K nearest neighbor algorithm (WKNN), gives different weights by distinguishing the signal stability of different AP, and calculates the weighted Euclidean distance, and then sets a threshold for the weighted Euclidean distance to get the appropriate K value. The experimental results show that the algorithm adopted in this paper shows higher accuracy than several traditional positioning algorithms.

title: Optimization of Rapid Exit Taxiway Layout for Efficient Training in Small and Medium-Sized Training Airports
authors: Shangjun Li, Xuan Wang, Weijun Pan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: This study focuses on the collaborative optimization of taxiway layout and runway capacity for small and medium-sized training airports, proposing a capacity evaluation model that integrates dynamic taxiing rules and multi-task scheduling. By analyzing the dynamic impacts of key parameters such as taxiway location and takeoff/landing ratios on runway service time, the feasibility of optimized layouts was validated through Visual C++ and MATLAB simulations. The results demonstrate that: reasonable taxiway layout can significantly reduce aircraft runway exit time; when taxiways are dynamically aligned with aircraft landing roll endpoints, runway occupancy time is markedly decreased and mixed-operation capacity reaches its peak; dynamic scheduling strategies effectively mitigate operational disruptions caused by control delays and taxi speed fluctuations, thereby enhancing model adaptability. The theoretical models show high consistency with simulation results. Furthermore, the synergistic effect between environmental factors and dynamic scheduling strategies significantly improves model robustness. This method not only provides quantitative decision-making support for infrastructure planning in small and medium-sized airports, but can also be extended to real-time scheduling optimization in high-density training scenarios, demonstrating significant engineering application value.

title: SpatialMouse: A Hybrid Pointing Device for Seamless Interaction Across 2D and 3D Spaces
authors: Sebastian Hubenschmid, Johannes Zagermann, Robin Erb, Tiare Feuchtner, Jens Grubert, Markus Tatzgern, Dieter Schmalstieg, Harald Reiterer
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 31st ACM Symposium on Virtual Reality Software and Technology

title: Toward Efficient Deployment of Lightweight Object Detectors for Real-Time Inference on Resource-Constrained Edge Devices
authors: Thaising Taing, Yousufzai Fawad Khan, Hayotjon Aliev, HyungWon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Deploying deep neural network (DNN)-based object detectors on resource-constrained edge devices for real-time applications has become increasingly popular. However, resource-constrained edge devices often suffer from limited memory budget and computational resources. To run the modern object detectors with extremely huge computational complexities and costs on such constrained hardware devices, model optimization techniques have been necessarily applied. In this paper, we propose a set of hardware-oriented DNN models optimization techniques, including model operations optimization, model fusion, and layer-wise hardware-friendly integer quantization for object detectors, especially YOLO-based models, to run on these edge devices. Our methods focus on simplifying the model’s hardware-inefficient operations and quantizing the models into an 8-bit integer. Additionally, we apply our techniques to optimize the YOLOv10n model as a case study and implement it on an FPGA-based system. Our experimental results confirm that the proposed approach considerably reduces model size and memory consumption over the baseline, while still achieving an acceptable object detection accuracy. Optimized YOLOv10n achieves approximately a two times reduction in terms of model size, and a four times reduction in terms of peak activation memory, with only 1.90% mAP drop compared to the hardware-friendly model and 3.10% compared to the baseline model, while maintaining competitive performance with ONNX Runtime, OpenVINO, and TensorRT.

title: Development of a Low-Cost Real-Time Crop Detection System Using SSD-Based Deep Learning on a Compact UAV
authors: Daichi Yodoshi, Shun Nishide
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: The adoption of artificial intelligence and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) is transforming modern agriculture, enabling more efficient and data-driven farm management. However, the high cost and operational complexity of advanced agricultural drones limit their accessibility for small and medium-sized farms. This study presents the development and preliminary evaluation of a prototype crop detection system that integrates a deep learning-based Single Shot MultiBox Detector (SSD) model with a compact, low-cost consumer drone, tested under controlled indoor conditions. The system utilizes a monocular camera-equipped UAV to perform real-time object detection of common fruits such as apples and oranges, with image processing handled by an edge device. Experimental results under controlled indoor conditions demonstrate that the proposed solution achieves classification scores exceeding 0.85 at close range (approximately 30 cm), despite inherent limitations in sensor quality and computational resources. The findings suggest potential for affordable, edge AI-powered drones to support precision agriculture, though further validation in real-world settings is needed.

title: Adaptive RWA Token Pricing using Reinforcement Learning: Enhancing Decision Support in SAP ERP Systems
authors: Yuan Xing, David Ding, Xuedong Ding
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Real-world assets (RWAs) like buildings, equipment, and financial contracts are now being turned into digital tokens so they can be more easily bought, sold, or shared. But most pricing methods for these tokens are fixed or manually set, which makes it hard to keep up with market changes or operational shifts inside a business. This paper presents a reinforcement learning model that learns how to adjust RWA token prices over time based on market activity and internal company data. The system can use input from SAP ERP (Systems, Applications, and Products in Data Processing - Enterprise Resource Planning) systems-such as usage history, condition reports, or accounting data-and return pricing decisions that aim to increase participation, keep prices steady, and avoid large swings. These decisions can help enterprise teams make better calls around leasing, investing, or selling assets. The result is a system that connects traditional business software with new digital asset markets in a practical, intelligent way.

title: Application of Visualization and Image Processing Algorithm of Geological Exploration Data in Mineral Resources Evaluation
authors: Ren Zhibin, Wang Zhian, Qiao Jianfeng, Niu Qirui
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Geological exploration is the key link of mineral resources evaluation, but it faces the challenge of complex geological conditions and massive data. This paper discusses the application of geological exploration data visualization and image processing algorithm in mineral resources evaluation, aiming at improving exploration efficiency and accuracy of resource evaluation. By analyzing the characteristics and processing requirements of geological exploration data and combining the principles and methods of data visualization and image processing algorithms, a set of comprehensive solutions is put forward. It is pointed out that the visualization technology of geological exploration data includes 3D dynamic fine modeling of geological bodies and parallel visualization of attribute field data based on CUDA+GPU cluster, which can visually display the spatial distribution and internal structure of geological bodies. The image processing algorithm extracts mineral composition, texture characteristics and other information from core photos and thin slice microscopic images through denoising, enhancement and segmentation. Taking a copper mine as an example, a 3D geological model is constructed by integrating multi-source exploration data, and the mineral resources are quantitatively evaluated by geostatistics method combined with the image processing results. The results show that this method can effectively improve the accuracy and efficiency of mineral resources evaluation, and provide new technical means and ideas for geological exploration and mineral resources development.

title: Modeling and Simulation Analysis of Typical Operation Mode of County Distribution Network Oriented to Multi-Party Resource Interaction
authors: Fei Zheng, Ning Luo, Jinsen Liu, Jie Wang, Jiahuan Long, Jingrong Meng
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Aiming at the operation challenges faced by county distribution network under the background of distributed energy access and diversified load demand, this paper puts forward a typical operation mode modeling and simulation analysis method for multi-party resource interaction. Firstly, the five-in-one interactive architecture of “source-network-load-storage-market” is constructed, which integrates key elements such as distributed power supply, flexible load, energy storage system and market transaction, and realizes the collaborative optimization of physical layer, information layer, market layer and control layer through layered and block method. Secondly, based on multi-agent modeling, resource aggregation model and interactive mechanism, the physical model of distribution network, distributed generation model, load aggregation model and electric vehicle (EV) aggregation model are established, and the market transaction module and collaborative optimization model with double auction mechanism are adopted. Power flow calculation, dynamic simulation and optimization analysis are carried out for different typical scenarios. The results show that at high permeability, the peak photovoltaic output will lead to voltage increase, and the centralized charging of EV will increase the power loss at late peak, while the distributed trading mechanism can significantly improve the photovoltaic absorption rate and reduce the operating cost, but it will increase the voltage fluctuation. In addition, through extreme scenario analysis and electricity price sensitivity analysis, the effectiveness of the model in dealing with faults and stimulating demand response is further verified.

title: Statistical Implausibility Detection: A Framework for Identifying Evaluation Inconsistencies in Large Language Model Security Assessment
authors: Adiba Mahmud, Yasmeen Rawajfih, Fan Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) demonstrate promising capabilities for automated security vulnerability detection, yet current evaluation methodologies lack statistical validation to distinguish genuine security analysis from systematic evaluation inconsistencies. We present a framework for assessing statistical implausibility in LLM security evaluation results using binomial probability analysis, framework-specific variance assessment, and baseline comparison checks. Our analysis of 796 vulnerability detection samples across four recent LLMs suggests performance patterns that warrant methodological examination. Perfect accuracy claims on specific frameworks fall below conventional significance thresholds under realistic expert baselines, which we interpret as possible evaluation inconsistencies rather than clear evidence of capability differences. Furthermore, baseline comparisons showing large improvement factors may reflect evaluation environment differences more than underlying capability. Our statistical validation framework aims to help practitioners assess evaluation reliability when considering deployment in security-critical applications.

title: The Impact of Using AI in Research and Development in Non-Profit Organizations in Saudi Arabia
authors: Bandar F. Alzahrani
abstract: This study investigates the transformative role of artificial intelligence (AI) in research and development (R&D) within non-profit organizations in Saudi Arabia. It explores how AI optimizes operations, enhances decision-making, and fosters innovation, aligning with Saudi Vision 2030's emphasis on technological advancement. The research employs a mixed-methods approach, integrating case studies, interviews, and surveys to assess AI's impact, benefits, and challenges. Key findings highlight AI's potential in data analysis, predictive modeling, resource allocation, and task automation, leading to improved efficiency and strategic outcomes. However, barriers such as financial constraints, expertise gaps, and ethical considerations remain significant. The study underscores the importance of capacity-building, ethical frameworks, and strategic investments to harness AI's full potential, enabling non-profits to achieve greater societal impact and sustainability.

title: Feature Implementation of Lunar Cycles for Flood Disaster Classification using Bi-LSTM
authors: Ganno Tribuana Kurniaji, Azkario Rizky Pratama, Syukron Abu Ishaq Alfarozi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Flood disasters are natural events that frequently occur and have severe impacts, particularly in coastal regions. This study is motivated by the limited research linking lunar cycle phenomena with coastal flooding and the pressing need to develop sequential prediction models for disaster mitigation. Therefore, the objectives of this research are to identify the influence of lunar phase and lunar distance on the occurrence of floods in the coastal areas of Yogyakarta Province; and also, to construct a flood prediction model based on Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) that incorporates climatic factors, tidal coefficient, and lunar cycles. Data were sourced from BMKG, BNPB, and PasangLaut for the period January 2010 to December 2024. The findings reveal that flood risk escalates notably during full and new moon phases and when the moon approaches Earth, contributing to higher tidal coefficients. A Bi-LSTM model was developed by integrating these lunar parameters and optimized through Bayesian Optimization for hyperparameter tuning, yielding a test accuracy of 95% and a ROC-AUC score of 0.96. Further evaluation using K-Fold cross-validation produced an average accuracy of 94%, with balanced performance demonstrated by a precision of 72%, recall of 75%, and F1-score of 73% on test data. Overall, this study elucidates the complex role of lunar factors in flood events and demonstrates that the proposed model can effectively support early warning systems and disaster management by providing accurate predictions to inform decision-making in coastal areas.

title: Application of Neural Networks in Theoretical Line Loss Calculation and Energy Saving Loss Reduction Strategies in Distribution Networks
authors: Hangtian Li, Lei Guo, Xing Pei, Xiaobin Xu, Peng Xi
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: The line loss of the distribution network, as a key parameter for evaluating the operational effectiveness of power enterprises, has a profound impact on the planning, design, and optimization decisions of the distribution network. Accurately predicting line losses is crucial for rational allocation of power resources, reducing energy consumption, and improving the overall efficiency of the power grid. Given its criticality, using cutting-edge algorithms to accurately predict distribution line losses has become a focus of current research. This article aims to explore the potential application of neural network technology in theoretical line loss calculation of distribution networks, and innovatively propose a prediction model based on deep learning (DL) to meet the practical needs of energy conservation and loss reduction. This model relies on the excellent nonlinear fitting and feature learning capabilities of DL technology to deeply mine and analyze complex distribution network data, striving to achieve accurate estimation of line loss values. Experimental data shows that compared with traditional methods, this model has achieved significant improvement in prediction accuracy, effectively reducing prediction errors and providing more solid data support for the formulation of energy-saving and loss reduction strategies for distribution networks.

title: Research on Gamification Design Strategies for School Bullying Prevention Applications
authors: Lingjing Zheng, Haibiao Huang, Yaping Qiu, Jun He
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: As a global issue, school bullying has garnered sustained attention from various countries due to its high frequency and severe harm, highlighting the increasing necessity of preventive education. Based on current situation analysis, existing educational approaches—such as theoretical instruction, video-based learning, and game-based education—exhibit limitations including weak interactivity and a lack of real-time feedback for students. Therefore, it is imperative to explore more engaging and effective educational methods. With the advancement of the digital era, mobile learning via smartphone applications has emerged as a viable educational tool. However, it also faces challenges such as students’ lack of concentration. To address this issue, many mobile educational applications have incorporated gamification elements to stimulate students’ continuous engagement. This study focuses on gamification design strategies for a school bullying prevention app targeted at elementary school students. Integrating the CUBI User Experience Model and the DMC (Decomposition of Motivational Characteristics) Gamification Model, and based on the cognitive level of young learners, the research develops design strategies for the app from perspectives including user goals, interaction, business goals, and content. It aims to provide a reference for the development of such applications in the future.

title: Resource-Efficient Multi-Tone Capacitive Touch Detection Using Compressive Sensing and FISTA Reconstruction
authors: Seongho Cho, Daejin Park
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper presents a resource-efficient architecture for capacitive touch sensing based on multi-tone excitation, compressive sensing, and sparse signal reconstruction using the Fast Iterative Shrinkage-Thresholding Algorithm (FISTA). Conventional systems that rely on multiple analog front-end (AFE) and ADCs with high-rate uniform sampling, the proposed method employs fewer ADC with randomized sampling to acquire compressed measurements of combined Rx signals. Since the signals are sparse in the frequency domain, compressive sensing can be effectively applied to capture essential information with significantly fewer samples. Each Rx channel is independently reconstructed via FISTA, enabling signal magnitude estimation at known Tx frequencies. Implemented on an STM32F767 micro-controller, the FFT of fully sampled ADC data yielded an SNR of 39dB, while the compressive sensing reconstruction showed 32dB. Despite a 3:1 reduction in ADC usage, some SNR degradation was unavoidable. However, this trade-off may be acceptable in systems where multiple ADCs cannot be accommodated.

title: Spiking Neural Networks for ECG Classification and Anomaly Detection
authors: Shruti Bhandari, Batuhan Asiroglu, Sanjog Dhakal, Robin Ghosh, Tolga Ensari, Burak Berk Ustundag
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) have emerged as biologically inspired models that enable event driven, energy efficient computation, making them particularly suitable for biomedical signal processing in resource-constrained environments. Conventional machine learning and deep learning approaches, while effective, often struggle to capture the temporal dynamics of electrocardiogram (ECG) signals and typically demand high computational resources, which limits their applicability in wearable and real-time healthcare systems. To address these challenges, this study introduces a reproducible end to end framework for ECG classification and anomaly detection using a lightweight SNN architecture based on Leaky Integrate and Fire neurons. The framework integrates pre-processing, spike encoding, supervised training, and evaluation, ensuring methodological clarity and replicability. Validated across three benchmark datasets MIT-BIH Arrhythmia, PTB Diagnostic ECG, and ECG Heartbeat Categorization the proposed model achieved accuracies of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$90.35 \%, 93.25 \%$</tex>, and 97.8 % respectively. Despite its simplicity, the framework consistently outperformed or matched more complex deep learning and traditional machine learning methods, while requiring far fewer computational resources. These findings highlight the capacity of SNNs to effectively capture temporal and morphological features of ECG signals, enabling reliable detection of arrhythmias and myocardial infarctions. By combining clinical relevance with algorithmic transparency, the study addresses reproducibility gaps in neuromorphic research and demonstrates the feasibility of deploying lightweight SNNs in real-time, low-power cardiac monitoring applications.

title: Improving LightGBM Performance in Diabetes Risk Prediction Using Fi-Guide SMOTE
authors: Andrian Sah, Adam M Tanniewa, Desi Puspita, Yessi Jusman, Rohmat Indra Borman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Class imbalance between diabetic and non-diabetic patients remains a major challenge in medical risk classification tasks, often leading machine learning models to become biased toward the majority class and fail to accurately identify positive cases. This study proposes a diabetes risk classification model based on the Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) algorithm, integrated with an information-guided oversampling technique named Feature Importance Guided SMOTE (Fi-Guide SMOTE). The proposed method aims to address data imbalance by generating synthetic minority samples based on each feature's contribution to the classification outcome. The dataset consists of 2,000 patient records with nine clinical features, and has undergone preprocessing steps including missing value imputation, normalization, and outlier filtering. Model performance was evaluated across three scenarios: baseline (without oversampling), standard SMOTE, and Fi-Guide SMOTE, using accuracy, recall, F1-score, and ROC-AUC as the primary evaluation metrics. Experimental results show that the LightGBM + Fi-Guide SMOTE model improves classification performance, with an F1-score of 97.45% for the diabetes class and an overall accuracy of 98.25%. Although the numerical improvement is relatively small, it has meaningful implications in medical contexts where accurate early detection is critical. These findings indicate that information-guided oversampling can enhance model reliability on imbalanced medical datasets.

title: Research on Thermal Efficiency Optimization of Thermal Power Units Based on Genetic Algorithm
authors: Hujun Zhao, Tian Ying, Junjie Zhao
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Addressing the thermal efficiency optimization problem of 600 MW supercritical thermal power units, an improved genetic algorithm scheme was designed. The algorithm adopts adaptive crossover and mutation probabilities, effectively overcoming the limitation of standard genetic algorithm's tendency to fall into local optima. By establishing an optimization mathematical model with thermal efficiency maximization as the objective function, collaborative optimization of key operating parameters such as boiler feedwater temperature, main steam pressure, and reheat steam temperature was achieved. Experimental results show that the improved genetic algorithm increases convergence speed by 40 % compared to the standard genetic algorithm, and the unit thermal efficiency improves by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.5-0.8$</tex> percentage points after optimization, verifying the effectiveness of the algorithm.

title: SRA-VFM: Boosting Remote Sensing Change Detection via Slice-Reassembled Augmentation and Vision Foundation Model-Guided Dual Streams
authors: Wenhui Ye, Weimin Lei, Wenchao Zhang, Wei Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: To address the dual challenges of inadequate deep semantic feature representation and limited data diversity in bi-temporal remote sensing change detection (RSCD), we propose a collaborative optimization framework (SRA-VFM) integrating customized data augmentation and hierarchical feature interpretation. SRA-VFM comprises three core components: slice-reassemble augmentation (SRA), a dual-stream feature encoding-decoding network, and a multi-task segmentation head. The SRA module synthesizes diverse training samples through random slicing and semantic reassembly while preserving local feature consistency. The dual-stream encoder, based on the FastSAM pre-trained model, incorporates a top-down feature adapter to align pre-trained features with remote sensing data distributions via cross-level fusion and low-dimensional semantic mapping. The bottom-up decoder leverages semantically aligned pyramid features for progressive upsampling, restoring high-resolution spatial details and enhancing multi-scale representation. The multi-task head jointly optimizes change region detection and edge refinement, accelerating convergence and improving boundary localization. Extensive experiments on 5 benchmark datasets (LEVIR-CD, WHU-CD, CLCD, S2Looking, SYSU-CD) demonstrate SRA-VFM’s superiority over state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods, achieving mF1/mIoU of 96.01%/92.55%, 97.13%/94.53%, 88.91%/81.21%, 83.13%/48.91%, and 88.36%/79.67% respectively. Code will be publicly available upon publication.

title: Dual-channel Learning Framework for miRNA-drug Interaction Prediction Based on Structural Features and Signed Bipartite Graph Neural Network
authors: Xiaoxuan Zhang, Xiujuan Lei, Ling Guo, Ming Chen, Fang-Xiang Wu, Yi Pan
abstract: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play a vital role in regulating a wide range of biological functions and are key players in the development of many complex human diseases, making them novel therapeutic targets for drug development. Given the high expenses and time demands of traditional experimental methods, it is essential to develop efficient computational approaches for predicting miRNA-drug interactions (MDIs). This article presents a dual-channel learning framework, SSMDI, based on structural features and Signed Bipartite Graph Neural Network (SBGNN) for predicting MDIs. Firstly, Graph Isomorphism Networks (GIN) is employed to extract molecular graph features of drugs. Meanwhile, a combined framework of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) network and Self-attention Mechanism is utilized to capture sequence features of miRNAs. Compared with traditional networks, signed networks can deliver richer semantic information in drugs and miRNAs. Therefore, SBGNN is then used to aggregate and update the signed topological features of miRNAs and drugs. Finally, structural and signed topological features are integrated to predict MDIs. The predictive performance of the model is evaluated using 5-fold cross-validation (CV), achieving AUC of 0.9447 and AUPR of 0.9238. The case study further demonstrates the effectiveness of SSMDI in predicting MDIs. In summary, the SSMDI model proves to be an accurate tool for predicting MDIs, which holds significant implications for drug development and miRNA-based therapeutic research.

title: FOVA: Offline Federated Reinforcement Learning With Mixed-Quality Data_supp1-3637043.pdf
authors: Sheng Yue
abstract: Offline Federated Reinforcement Learning (FRL), a marriage of federated learning and offline reinforcement learning, has attracted increasing interest recently. Albeit with some advancement, we find that the performance of most existing offline FRL methods drops dramatically when provided with mixed-quality data, that is, the logging behaviors (offline data) are collected by policies with varying qualities across clients. To overcome this limitation, this paper introduces a new vote-based offline FRL framework, named FOVA. It exploits a vote mechanism to identify high-return actions during local policy evaluation, alleviating the negative effect of low-quality behaviors from diverse local learning policies. Besides, building on advantage-weighted regression (AWR), we construct consistent local and global training objectives, significantly enhancing the efficiency and stability of FOVA. Further, we conduct an extensive theoretical analysis and rigorously show that the policy learned by FOVA enjoys strict policy improvement over the behavioral policy. Extensive experiments corroborate the significant performance gains of our proposed algorithm over existing baselines on widely used benchmarks.

title: Efficient Feedback Design for Unsourced Random Access With Integrated Sensing and Communication
authors: Mohammad Javad Ahmadi, Mohammad Kazemi, Rafael F. Schaefer
abstract: We consider an unsourced random access (URA) system enhanced with a feedback mechanism that serves both communication and sensing tasks. Specifically, the base station employs a multi-antenna array to receive user transmissions and to broadcast a finite-length downlink feedback signal that informs users about their decoding status. Opportunistically, by processing the reflections of this same feedback signal, the base station is also able to estimate the directions of targets present in the environment. To design this dual-purpose feedback, we introduce a modified projected gradient descent algorithm that minimizes a weighted combination of communication and sensing errors. Simulation results show that the proposed feedback design outperforms the state-of-the-art feedback design in the URA literature. Furthermore, we illustrate the trade-off between communication and sensing capabilities, offering valuable insight into balancing these two tasks.

title: Recent Advances in Complexity Reduction Methods for VVC Inter coding, A Review
authors: Komeil ShahHosseini, Abbas Javadtalab, Mohammad Ghanbari, Ahmad Kalhor, Farhad Pakdaman, Moncef Gabbouj
abstract: Video traffic continues to surge, pushing codecs toward higher efficiency at the cost of sharply increased complexity. The H.266/Versatile Video Coding (VVC) standard roughly halves bitrate relative to HEVC at comparable quality but increases encoder complexity substantially. This paper surveys algorithm-level complexity-reduction methods for VVC inter-frame coding, grouping them by decision module—coding unit (CU) partitioning, inter-mode selection, and motion estimation (ME)—and by approach—heuristic/statistical, machine learning (ML), and deep learning (DL). We provide quantitative comparisons of reported complexity–efficiency trade-offs (encoder time vs. BD-rate), and discuss observed trends and potential areas for improvement. Across the literature, CU partitioning is the most heavily targeted module, followed by ME; reported encoder time savings span approximately 10–55% with typically no more than about 3% BD-rate increase, depending on module and method. It is observed that DL methods generally achieve the largest time savings (often around 50% or higher) by predicting partition structures or mode decisions end-to-end, at the expense of training data and inference cost. Heuristic methods remain lightweight and hardware-friendly with small BD-rate impact, and ML methods provide balanced trade-offs. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first comprehensive survey of VVC inter-frame coding, distilling practical lessons and outlining open directions—especially hybrid pipelines that combine inexpensive filters with learned predictors—to guide more efficient VVC implementations and future standards.

title: A consumer-centric framework for measuring product obsolescence using user-generated content and large language models: Evidence from IoT devices
authors: Mohamadreza Azar Nasrabadi, Yvan Beauregard, Amir Ekhlassi
abstract: Identifying product obsolescence factors is essential for guiding sustainable design and extending product longevity. Unlike prior studies, this research leverages online consumer reviews to explore product obsolescence factors. First, ChatGPT-4o, an advanced pre-trained large language model (LLM), is utilized to identify these factors. User-generated content (UGC) time series-based product obsolescence indexes are then defined to quantify each factor's impact, offering a UGC-based complement to earlier methods that depended on expert judgment, supplier input, or survey data. By leveraging real-time customer insights, this approach aligns with Industry 4.0 principles, offering a UGC-based method that can support engineering managers to proactively address product obsolescence. It integrates factors' relative importance, determined through frequency–analytic hierarchy process (Freq-AHP), with their severity impact on consumers, assessed using the Robustly optimized Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers approach (RoBERTa). This is further supported by a robustness check, where small perturbations were applied to sentiment intensities and all indices recalculated, confirming the aggregated obsolescence index remained stable across all product categories. This study focuses on consumer IoT devices, an area underexplored in existing literature, analyzing 47,695 online consumer reviews across nine product categories and selecting 4,771 online obsolescence-related reviews for detailed analysis. Findings reveal nineteen key factors and demonstrate a fundamental shift in obsolescence, indicating that product obsolescence of consumer IoT devices is increasingly driven by adaptability, interoperability, and digital resilience rather than physical durability. These insights demonstrate the potential of the proposed approach to inform product obsolescence mitigation strategies and guide more resilient, user-centered design in IoT ecosystems.

title: PMM: A Parametric Musculoskeletal Model Aligned with Human Body Shape_supp1-3639683.mp4
authors: Taesoo Kwon
abstract: Simulating musculoskeletal models in a physics-based environment enables natural motion that follows human biomechanics. However, constructing musculoskeletal models tailored to diverse body shapes is both time-consuming and labor-intensive. Moreover, achieving robust control over complex, muscle-driven actuation remains a significant challenge. In this paper, we propose a novel shape-parameterized musculoskeletal model that is both anthropometrically and biomechanically plausible. Our approach supports variation in physical attributes—including height, mass, and body shape—as well as muscle–tendon unit parameters. We use the parametric human body model (SMPL) to represent body shape variations and estimate joint locations. From this parameter space, we retarget a template musculoskeletal model to any target shape, adapting both physical properties and muscle-specific parameters. The resulting individualized musculoskeletal models are simulated in a physics-based environment using learned control policies. A hybrid controller combines a stable proportional–derivative servo (PD-servo) servo for the upper body with a Hill-type muscle–tendon model for the lower body.We train these control policies using deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to control diverse locomotion and solve challenging tasks across a wide range of body configurations and environments.

title: Two-Level FEM-Based Inductance Modeling for Real-Time Simulation of Bar Breakages in Squirrel Cage Induction Machines
authors: Sandra Delfa-Baena, Carla Terron-Santiago, Manuel Pineda-Sanchez, Angel Sapena-Bano
abstract: This paper presents an innovative two-level modeling approach for accurately simulating the inductance matrix of induction machines (IMs) under fault conditions. The first level uses Finite Element Method (FEM) simulations to extract the inductance matrix <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$ L(\theta)$</tex-math></inline-formula> of the healthy machine, achieving high spatial resolution with minimal computational resources. The second level enables the introduction of rotor asymmetry faults using tensor algebra, thus eliminating the need for repeated FEM simulations. This approach enhances the efficiency of fault simulations, making it suitable for real-time diagnostic applications. The model is validated through both steady-state and transient analysis, demonstrating its effectiveness in reproducing fault-related harmonics and offering significant improvements in computational performance compared to traditional time-stepping FEM models.
