title: Exploring UTAUT2 Constructs in Generation Z's Behavioral Intention to Use Canva AI
authors: Erika Prajitno, Sari Ramadanty
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is becoming increasingly dominant, with advancements in communication technologies deeply integrated with AI applications. This study explores Generation Z’s behaviour related to their intention to use AI in Indonesia, focusing on Canva AI. This study developed the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT2) framework with an online survey of 184 respondents and were analysed using Structural Equation Modelling (SEM) with SmartPLS 4. The study's findings showed that of all the constructs tested, hedonic motivation (HM) and habit (H) significantly and positively affected the behavioral intentions of Gen Z users to use Canva AI. These results indicate that Canva AI users' behavioral intentions are influenced by emotional involvement, usability, and continuous usage of technology as important parts of technology adoption in Canva AI. This research results augment to the existing treasury of UTAUT2 framework related to the scope of Generative AI use for AI developers in creative and design platforms.

title: Design of Real-Time Sensing and Dynamic Modeling System for Multi-Source Data of Distribution Network Based on Edge Computing
authors: Guilin He, Lei Han, Peifa Shan, Min Lei, Weisen Lin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: In this paper, a design of real-time sensing and dynamic modeling system for multi-source data of distribution network based on edge computing is proposed. The system adopts “end-edge-cloud” three-level collaborative architecture, collects data by deploying smart sensors and other equipment on the end side, and uses sliding window mean filtering method and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \sigma$</tex> criterion for data preprocessing; In the edge computing layer, the multi-source data fusion engine and dynamic modeling module are built by using the industrial edge gateway NVIDIA Jetson AGX Orin, and the data fusion is realized based on D-S evidence theory, and the improved unscented Kalman filter (UKF) is used to estimate the distribution network state. The cloud collaboration layer is responsible for model training and resource scheduling, builds a load forecasting model based on LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory), and designs a dynamic task unloading algorithm to optimize the computing load of edge nodes. The experimental results show that the real-time performance of the system is significantly improved compared with the traditional scheme, and the delay in the scenarios of single-phase grounding fault, interphase short-circuit fault and sudden load change is reduced by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$80.6 \%, 80.0 \%$</tex> and 81.7 % respectively. In terms of data fusion accuracy, D-S evidence theory reduces the KL divergence of voltage-current data fusion and environmentload data fusion by 0.16 and 0.26 respectively compared with the traditional weighted average method. In terms of resource efficiency, the peak CPU utilization rate of edge computing nodes reaches 68 %, the cloud bandwidth occupation is reduced from 120 Mbps to 35 Mbps, and the model update time is shortened from 15s to 4.2 s; In terms of state estimation error, the improved UKF algorithm is superior to the traditional Kalman filter method under different node data, and the error is significantly reduced.

title: Proposal of an Information Delivery Method for Electronic Paper Signage Using Human Mobility as the Communication Medium
authors: Takafumi Akiba, Tsubasa Yumura
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: In environments where communication infrastructure is unstable, remotely updating Electronic Paper Signage (EPS) is difficult. This study proposes a method that leverages human mobility as a communication medium to disseminate content progressively among EPS units. Mobile devices such as smartphones and wearables connect to EPS via short-range links upon encounter and, based on bidirectional version comparison, update to the newer content. On the EPS side, power consumption is reduced by controlling scanning intervals. We implemented a prototype using M5Paper v1.1 and confirmed basic operations, including content handover and display updates. We also outline a future direction to minimize standby power by introducing wake-up mechanisms triggered by touch/proximity and energy harvesting using piezoelectric elements.

title: Deep Learning-Based Drought Prediction Using Conv1D-BiLSTM-GRU with Bayesian Optimization: A Case Study of Central Java, Indonesia
authors: Hanifullah Hafidz Arrizal, Laila Ma’rifatul Azizah, Nelly Florida Riama, Marzuki Sinambela, Munawar, Dwijoko Purbohadi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Accurate drought prediction is essential for agricultural planning and water resource management, particularly in regions like Central Java where rainfall variability strongly affects crop productivity. This study proposes a novel deep learning model combining Conv1D, BiLSTM, and GRU layers, optimized using Bayesian methods, to predict drought conditions across three monsoon zones (ZOM 214, 227, and 230). The model was trained on 33 years of dekadal rainfall data (1991-2023) from 34 meteorological stations and evaluated against baseline models including BiLSTM, BiLSTM- GRU, GRU, and CLG. Experimental results show that the proposed model achieved superior performance with MAE of 23.83 mm and SMAPE of 65.47%, improving up to 22.1% over the baselines. Most notably, the model demonstrated a 0% failure rate in drought classification, compared to 22.22% for other models. The approach also showed high accuracy in detecting drought onset and peak events across diverse monsoon zones, confirming its suitability for real-time drought early warning systems in tropical monsoon regions.

title: E3-MAS: A Self-Evolution Multi-Agent System Framework
authors: Ming-Yi Huang, Yao-Zhi Xue, Chai-Yu Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Large Language Model (LLM)-based Multi-Agent Systems (MAS) have emerged as a powerful paradigm for solving complex, real-world tasks with tedious workflows and frequent errors. However, current self-evolution MAS approaches require extensive manual tuning and lack dynamic adaptation, precise issue identification, and modular flexibility. This paper presents E3-MAS, a general-purpose self-evolution framework that organizes agents into three interacting teams—Execution, Evaluation, and Evolution. We detail role-level designs (Planner/Executor/Replanner, Critic/Evaluator, Analyzer/Prompt Optimizer) and show how task-aware evaluation drives problem attribution and prompt refinement. Using a school administrative assistance scenario (C-Pilot), we demonstrate intelligent search and pipeline automation. In a leave-application case study, E3-MAS improves the task progress rate from 0.83 to 1.0 after one evolution cycle. More broadly, the framework consistently achieves progress rates exceeding 0.9, reduces manual prompt-tuning time by over 50%, and enables modular deployment of MAS applications across heterogeneous environments. These results highlight the potential of E3-MAS as a scalable and adaptive paradigm for reliable multi-agent collaboration.

title: Beyond Entertainment: How AI, Perceived Value, and Service Quality Drive Customer Engagement and Customer Loyalty in Video Streaming Platform
authors: Calvin Andrew Widjaja, Eggan Ojwala Yatalana, Edward Gabriel Nathanael, Michael Pagardin, Nur Anisa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: This study explores how AI, perceived value, and service quality drive customer loyalty in video streaming platforms within the Indonesian market. As the video streaming industry experiences rapid growth, competition necessitates innovation to sustain customer engagement and loyalty. Using a quantitative approach with a survey of 240 Indonesian video streaming platform subscribers, this research evaluates five variables: perceived value, service quality, customer engagement, customer loyalty, and Artificial Intelligence. However, the direct effects between service quality and perceived value on customer loyalty were found to be insignificant, indicating that loyalty is primarily driven through customer engagement. Additionally, Artificial Intelligence plays an insignificant role in linking and moderating the relationship between engagement and customer loyalty, indicating video streaming platforms need to prioritize service quality and customer engagement to retain customer loyalty. These results highlight that sustained customer loyalty is better achieved by enhancing customer engagement and delivering consistently high service quality, while rethinking the strategic application of AI to move beyond functional personalization and toward building deeper user involvement and emotional connection.

title: Online Shopping Platform Preferences: The Role of Product Assortment and Social Influence
authors: Kusumah Arif Prihatna, Isanawikrama
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Gen-Z is a generation that is highly dependent on digital technology, one of which is online shopping, but there has been little research on the factors that influence their platform preferences. This study explores how the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) as a reason for product assortment and social influence to shape Gen-Z's purchase intention on the preferred platform, with gender differences as a moderating element within the Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) framework. Data collection was conducted through a 5-point Likert scale questionnaire, and assessed with PLS-SEM. It was revealed that product assortment and social influence had a significant impact on purchase intention, mediated by perceived ease of use and usefulness. Perceived usefulness was found to have a stronger mediation effect. Multi-group analysis did not reveal significant gender differences in the relationship. These findings offer valuable insights for online platforms targeting Gen-Z, highlighting the importance of product assortment and social influence as platform appeal.

title: Analysis of the sizing of a variable frequency drive and 400 kW squirrel-cage induction motor to increase the operational availability of an 8'x10' ball mill, used in the mining sector
authors: Ricardo Orlando Consolación Mishti, Gabriel Osiris Cairampoma Rodríguez
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: The objective of the research was to size the variable frequency drive and induction motor of 400 kW squirrel cage type, to increase the availability of 8x10 ball mills in the mining sector. The results obtained show that untimely shutdowns per month were significantly reduced from 2 to 0, at the same time availability was increased to 100% in the mill and maintenance service costs were reduced. In addition, energy consumption was reduced at the time of start-up of the equipment. All these results demonstrate the economic savings and additional income generated by these benefits, which shows that the investment executed was an adequate and profitable solution for this type of sizing of the drive and motor. Concluding that by carrying out the proper sizing and the acquisition of the frequency inverter and 400kw electric motor type squirrel cage, the availability increased from 98.98% to 100%, with this result the efficiency of the 8'x10' mill will be improved, in addition to reducing untimely stops of the mill.

title: Enhancing Line Sharpness in Blind Image Super-Resolution using Diffusion Models Color Swapping
authors: Eric Saputra Lays, Shintami Chusnul Hidayati, Wijayanti Nurul Khotimah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Real-world images especially in satellite images, often have low-resolution (LR) images due to being captured from long distances. This makes it difficult to perform computer tasks such as path detection and object recognition. One of the solutions is to implement Image Super-Resolution (ISR) to upscale the LR images into high-resolution (HR) images. Recent method of ISR is diffusion model that has shown promising in generating high quality of images color; however, it lacks of line sharpness due to residual shifting limitation. This research address the problem by modifying the parameter of the diffusion model to create HR image that has better line sharpness, unfortunately the color is too sensitive, thus this study integrates those two HR images by color swapping based on YCbCr color space. Experimental result on a road scene CH6CN satellite image dataset shows that the proposed model performs better than previous diffusion model with improvement of 1.10% and 1.14% on NIQE and NRQM.

title: Research on Automatic Generation Method of Building Facade Design Based on Image Processing and Algorithms
authors: Hongxing Guo
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: With the continuous improvement of intelligence and efficiency requirements in the field of architectural design, the automatic generation method of building façade design based on image processing and algorithms has gradually become a research hotspot. This paper proposes a systematic automatic generation method by combining advanced image processing technology and optimization algorithms from the actual needs of building facade design. From the three aspects of information integration, generation method and tool realization, the paper proposes a hierarchical description method to sort out the data information, study the composition type of facade, establish the mapping relationship between flat and facade based on the internal function, and encode the transformation. The research analyzes the role of image processing technology in facade design, and designs the method of data preprocessing and feature extraction; constructs the optimization algorithm model for the characteristics of architectural design, and explores the key technologies in the automatic generation process; and verifies the feasibility and superiority of the method through practical tests and application cases. The method can effectively improve the degree of intelligence and efficiency of building façade design, which provides an important reference for the research and application in related fields.

title: An Improved Health Information Management System for Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital in Ghana
authors: Jochebed Afua Basil, Aaron Tsastu Tamakloe, Dennis Asamoah-Owusu
abstract: In 2017, Ghana's Ministry of Health adopted the Lightwave Health Information Management System (LHIMS), an outsourced project aimed at streamlining workflows in government hospitals. Despite the portability of patient data, LHIMS poses significant challenges as it does not address the specific needs of medical staff workflows in Ghanaian government hospitals, particularly at Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital (KBTH). Additionally, the system fails to consider context-related issues such as power outages, poor network connectivity, and the No Bed Syndrome prevalent in the Ghanaian healthcare space. This paper addresses the shortcomings of LHIMS by proposing a new software system that is research-driven and tailored to meet the needs of medical workflows at KBTH. The end-product is a progressive web application that streamlines the hospital's unique operational demands, incorporating comprehensive patient data management, biometric patient facial identification, real-time data integration, and advanced analytics and reporting. This paper contributes to Sustainable Development Goal 3 - Good Health and Well-being by addressing system challenges, emergency issues, and the bed shortage at Korle-Bu; by serving as a model for contextualized hospital management systems, especially for developing regions; and contributing to sustainable healthcare solutions.

title: Carbon Stock Classification Using CNN-CatBoost Hybrid Model with Drone and GEE Data
authors: Ferdi Syahputra, Erwin Budi Setiawan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Accurate classification of soil carbon stock is vital for global climate stability and supports climate change mitigation. Traditional field-based methods are often limited in scalability and efficiency, encouraging the use of remote sensing and machine learning. While destructive sampling is considered the most accurate for estimating tree biomass, it requires special permits that are often hard to obtain. This study aims to develop an accurate method for classifying soil carbon stock using a hybrid approach that combines ResNet50 for feature extraction with CatBoost and Random Forest for classification. Three datasets were used: 2,114 drone images, 2,526 satellite images from Google Earth Engine (GEE), and a combined set of 2,320 mixed images. Field data were collected from carbon plots at Telkom University and classified into low, medium, and high carbon stock levels. All images were resized, preprocessed, and passed through ResNet50 to extract high-level features before classification. Model performance was evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The results show that drone imagery outperformed GEE data. CatBoost achieved the highest test accuracy (84.19%), macro precision (83.63%), recall (84.22%), and F1-score (83.44%). On the other hand, the model trained with only GEE data performed lower recall and F1-scores, hence its low capacity to identify all classes. In general, this research stresses the value of high-resolution imagery in machine learning to enhance the precision of carbon stock classification.

title: Design of Autonomous Inspection System for Offshore Wind Power Operation and Maintenance UAV Based on Multi-Objective Optimization
authors: Xinyao Dai, Huan Dong, Yuhan Wu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: The operation and maintenance of offshore wind farms are facing many challenges, such as harsh environment, high cost and security risks. The traditional manual inspection method is inefficient and difficult to adapt to the complex marine environment. Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) has become an ideal choice for offshore wind power inspection because of its flexibility, low cost and weather resistance. The system adopts hierarchical and distributed architecture, including UAV platform, communication network, ground control station and data processing center, and has key functions such as autonomous navigation, target recognition, data acquisition and transmission. Through multi-objective optimization method, considering the inspection efficiency, energy consumption, safety and data quality, the flight path, energy consumption and inspection time of UAV are optimized by NSGA-II algorithm, and the dynamic weight mechanism and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{A}^{*}$</tex> algorithm are introduced to improve the system performance. The system test results show that the defect recognition rate can reach 98.5 %, the energy consumption is lower than the design threshold, the communication interruption recovery success rate is high, and the obstacle avoidance ability is reliable.

title: Integration of AI and Sustainable Computing in Agricultural Electronics for Early Wildfire Smoke Detection and Mitigation
authors: Misbah Ahmad, Imran Ahmed, Abdellah Chehri, Gwanggil Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Wildfires pose a significant threat to agricultural sustainability, with their frequency and destructive power exacerbated by climate change. Early detection of wildfire smoke is crucial to mitigating this threat and enhancing the resilience of agricultural systems. This study contributes to sustainable computing by presenting an AI-driven approach for early wildfire smoke detection, utilising cutting-edge image processing techniques. We leverage the YOLOv9 model, a recent advancement in object detection algorithms, to analyse image data from a benchmark dataset designed for smoke detection in agricultural settings. Our approach is rooted in sustainable computing practices, with the model running on energy-efficient hardware that processes data locally, thereby reducing the carbon emissions associated with data transmission and storage. The effectiveness of the YOLOv9 model in our application is quantified by its mean Average Precision (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{m A P}$</tex>) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 3. 2 \%}$</tex>, Precision of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 1. 3 \%}$</tex>, and Recall of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 1. 2 \%}$</tex>, demonstrating robust performance in detecting smoke patterns. This research not only showcases the integration of high-performance AI models with sustainable computing elements but also underscores the critical role of technological innovation in safeguarding agricultural landscapes from environmental disasters. By improving early detection capabilities, we contribute to the development of smart agricultural systems that are both sustainable and resilient, aligning with global efforts towards carbon neutrality and environmental protection.

title: Integration of Ai, Ar, and Voice Into Daily-Use Gadgets
authors: R. Trivedi
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Voice assistants are now part of many everyday gadgets, but they often struggle in noisy environments, leaving users frustrated. This paper tackles that problem by combining Artificial Intelligence (AI), Augmented Reality (AR), and Voice interfaces into a single multimodal system. The framework brings together speech, vision, and gestures to provide reliable and flexible interaction. Our experiments show that this approach reduces recognition errors by 27%, cuts latency by 43%, and speeds up task completion by 31% compared with voice-only or cloud-based setups. User studies further confirm that multimodal interaction improves usability, trust, and accessibility across different tasks. The results also show that the system stays stable even in noisy or dynamic conditions while reducing the effort required from users. Overall, this work demonstrates how everyday gadgets can become more dependable and practical when multiple input modes are combined.

title: Design and Implementation of an Intelligent Disinfection Robot Based on Multi-Sensor Fusion
authors: Yuefeng Gu, Donghui Guo
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Traditional manual disinfection faces challenges such as low efficiency, high risks, and resource waste. This study designed and implemented an intelligent disinfection robot based on multi-sensor fusion to enhance the automation and intelligence of disinfection operations through technological innovations. The robot utilizes the SLAMWARE system for high-precision localization and navigation in dynamic environments, combined with an improved A* algorithm for optimized path planning, achieving a 6.5% reduction in path length and a 98% success rate in dynamic obstacle avoidance. A composite disinfection mode integrates ultrasonic atomization and ultraviolet lamp technology, along with a detachable mini-drone, increasing disinfection coverage in corners and elevated areas to over 96%. Innovatively, a photoelectrochemical sensor and a virus detection module are introduced, achieving a disinfectant concentration measurement error of <3% and a virus detection sensitivity of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> CFU/m L, enabling dynamic strategy adjustment. Experimental results show that the robot improves disinfection efficiency by 40%, reduces disinfectant consumption by 31%, and supports remote control and unmanned operations. This research provides an efficient and precise disinfection solution for public health safety, demonstrating significant social application value.

title: Humlog Action Lab: Practice in Higher Education
authors: Diana Mercedes Rodriguez Coca, William Javier Guerrero Rueda, Elyn Lizeth Solano Charris, Holman Ospina Mateus
abstract: From a latent need to strengthen disaster risk management capacities, Universidad Tecnológica de Bolívar, Universidad de La Sabana, and Oklahoma State University joined forces to structure a disruptive exchange and training program focused on co-developing and teaching a set of essential skills to mitigate the impact of disasters from a multidisciplinary and international perspective. The project aimed to create a new model of student exchange and inclusive training between the United States and Colombia, aimed at enhancing resilience and adaptive capacities to disasters from an engineering, humanitarian logistics, and organizational management perspective. Project objectives included developing a Collaborative Online International Learning (COIL) course, creating spaces for dialogue among experts in disaster response operations in Colombia and the United States to promote the exchange of knowledge and practical experiences, and building an international, interdisciplinary, and intercultural network in the context of humanitarian logistics. Project outcomes demonstrate that project success factors include diversity of activities, student-centered learning, experiential learning, international integration, journal publications, and a best practice recognition award.

title: Visual and Somatosensory Integration with Higher Sitting Posture Enhances the Sense of Standing and Self-motion in Seated VR
authors: Daiki Hagimori, Naoya Isoyama, Monica Perusquía-Hernández, Shunsuke Yoshimoto, Hideaki Uchiyama, Nobuchika Sakata, Kiyoshi Kiyokawa
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Users are often seated in the real environment, while their virtual avatars either remain standing stationary or move in virtual reality (VR). This creates posture inconsistencies between the real and virtual embodiment representations. The relationship between posture consistency in locomotion techniques and sense of presence in VR is still unclear. This study investigates how visual and somatosensory integration affects the sense of standing (SoSt) and the sense of self-motion (SoSm) when the sitting posture is varied slightly, including highlighting the importance of sitting posture for locomotion design in VR. The degree and occurrence of SoSt and SoSm were assessed by subjective experiments, and it was found that higher sitting and lower sitting postures present higher SoSt and lower SoSm, respectively. Invocation of SoSt also influences postural perception. Perception of travel distance varied according to the posture condition when identical visual flow was presented. The findings suggest that visual and somatosensory integration related to posture enhances SoSt and SoSm, and a sitting posture with a higher seating position is recommended in seated VR locomotion design.

title: Toward an Advanced Temporal Graph Network in Hyperbolic Space
authors: Viet Quan Le, Viet Cuong Ta
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Learning over dynamic graphs poses major challenges, including capturing the evolving relationship in the graphs. Inspired by the advantages of hyperbolic embedding in static graphs, the hyperbolic space is expected to capture complex interactions in dynamic graphs. However, due to the distortion errors in the standard tangent space mappings, hyperbolic methods become more sensitive to noise and reduce the learning capacity. To address the distortion in tangent space, we proposed HMPTGN, a temporal graph network that operates directly on the hyperbolic manifold. In this journal paper, we introduce the HMPTGN+ architecture, an extension of the original HMPTGN with major updates to learn better representations of dynamic graphs based on the hyperbolic embedding. Our framework incorporates a high-order graph neural network for extracting spatial dependencies, a dilated causal attention mechanism for modeling temporal patterns while preserving causality, and a curvature-awareness mechanism to capture dynamic structures. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed HMPTGN+ framework over state-of-the-art baselines in both temporal link prediction and temporal new link prediction tasks. Our implementation is available at the GitHub repository https://github.com/quanlv9211/HMPTGN_plus

title: Identifier-Critic-Based Adaptive Optimal Control for USVs With Guaranteed Performance
authors: Lin Chen, Yaonan Wangu, Zhiqiang Miao, Yiming Jiang, Xudong Wang, Shi-Lu Dai
abstract: An online adaptive reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm is proposed to solve the infinite-horizon optimal tracking control problem for unmanned surface vehicles (USVs), in the presence of modeling uncertainties and external disturbances. A novel identifier-critic neural network (NN) architecture is developed to obtain the approximate solution of the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equations, in which the identifier and critic network weight adaptive laws are designed by gradient descent algorithm. The improved critic network adaptive law can relax the traditional persistence of excitation condition, which facilitates the implementation of the algorithm in practical applications. The time-varying and asymmetric constraint requirement on tracking errors is provided to ensure the satisfaction of transient and steady-state performance. Furthermore, the presented control scheme also works for the unconstrained systems. Through Lyapunov analysis, tracking errors are proved to converge into a small neighborhood of zero. Finally, both numerical simulations and virtual-reality experiments are performed to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme.

title: Uncertainty Estimation-Based Performance Monitoring for Deep Learning-Based CSI Prediction
authors: Chengyong Jiang, Jiajia Guo, Lizhe Liu, Shi Jin
abstract: Deep learning (DL)-based channel state information (CSI) prediction has become a key focus for the 3GPP standards body, with the goal of mitigating channel aging while reducing overhead. However, DL performance can significantly degrade in unfamiliar scenarios, resulting in low-quality CSI predictions that severely impair precoding performance. To address this challenge, we propose a performance monitoring method based on uncertainty estimation to identify and filter out low-quality predictions. Specifically, we incorporate the Monte Carlo dropout technique into the CSI prediction framework, leveraging multiple variable inferences to estimate predictive uncertainty and enable effective monitoring. To further optimize this approach, we integrate ensemble learning with Monte Carlo dropout, facilitating the generation of multiple prediction outcomes in a single inference, thereby reducing the temporal complexity associated with multiple inferences. Simulation results show that proposed methods eliminates over 80% of unqualified predictions across different configurations, significantly enhancing the reliability.

title: Generation of Hard SAT Instances and Its Application in Negative Databases for Privacy Enhancement
authors: Dongdong Zhao, Pang Chen, Changtian Song, Jianwen Xiang, Junwei Zhou, Zebo Tang, Baogang Song
abstract: In recent years, machine learning and deep learning have made remarkable progress and are now widely applied in various fields, including image classification, autonomous driving, natural language processing, and medical diagnosis. However, training these models requires large datasets, which often contain substantial amounts of sensitive personal information, such as medical records and financial details. Without effective privacy protection measures during model training, the risk of sensitive data leakage increases, potentially resulting in severe privacy violations and a loss of trust. As an innovative data representation technique, the Negative Database has proven to be an effective solution in privacy-sensitive domains. Negative databases can be derived from SAT (Boolean Satisfiability Problem) instances, and the hardness of these instances is directly correlated with the level of data protection provided by the Negative Databases. Developing efficient SAT instance generation algorithms to create harder SAT instances can significantly enhance the privacy protection capabilities of the Negative Database. This paper analyzes the hardness conditions of SAT solvers using the Conflict-Driven Clause Learning strategy and proposes a two-stage SAT instance generation algorithm to generate harder SAT instances. These hard instances not only aid in constructing more secure negative databases for enhanced privacy protection but also provide valuable test cases for evaluating and improving SAT solvers.

title: DOSE3: Diffusion-based Unified Out-of-distribution Detection on $\mathbb {SE}(3)$ Trajectories
authors: Hongzhe Cheng, Tianyou Zheng, Ziyong Ma, Tianyi Zhang, Matthew Johnson-Roberson, Weiming Zhi
abstract: Out-of-Distribution (OOD) detection, the task of identifying when an input falls outside the distribution seen at training time, is critical for deploying safe and reliable systems. Traditional OOD methods require retraining models whenever the in-distribution has changed. Recent work introduces unified models for OOD detection, where metrics can be constructed from an unconditional diffusion model trained on an arbitrary dataset, and the inlier distribution can be changed without retraining the diffusion model. However, these unified approaches have been largely confined to Euclidean or latent space domains. In contrast, real-world robotics systems often perceive and act through sequences of 6 degrees-of-freedom poses in the Special Euclidean Group $\mathbb {SE}(3)$, taking into account both translations and orientation changes over time. In this work, we extend OOD detection to trajectories in Special Euclidean Group in 3D ($\mathbb {SE}(3)$) by presenting a Diffusion-based Out-of-distribution detection on $\mathbb {SE}(3)$ ($\mathbf {DOSE3}$). $\mathbf {DOSE3}$ constructs an OOD metric from the noise estimator model of a diffusion model over $\mathbb {SE}(3)$ to separate outlier samples from inlier distributions. We demonstrate $\mathbf {DOSE3}$'s strong performance on OOD detection frameworks through extensive validation on multiple real-world robotics and autonomous systems datasets, covering vehicle and robot manipulator motion trajectories.

title: Multi-Space Crowd Sensing Task Allocation: A Dynamic Co-Optimization Framework With Fairness-Aware Reinforcement Learning
authors: Yingjie Wang, Dihong Luo, Haojun Teng, Peiyong Duan, Yang Gao, Haijing Zhang, Zhipeng Cai
abstract: Multi-space crowd sensing has emerged as a promising paradigm for 3D urban perception. However, it faces critical challenges including space coupling, task heterogeneity, and dynamic resource availability. To address these issues, the Multi-Space Fairness Task Allocation (MSFTA) problem is formulated, aiming to maximize task completion while ensuring fairness across spatial dimensions. The problem is proven to be NP-hard, and a dynamic collaborative optimization framework is proposed. Within this framework, a Multi-Space Clustering QuadTree Voronoi Partition (MCQVP) is developed for fine-grained multi-dimensional partitioning by leveraging DBSCAN and quadtree structures. In addition, a Group Urgency-Based Multi-Shortest Path (GUBMSP) scheduler is incorporated to prioritize time-sensitive task groups via urgency-aware critical paths. Furthermore, a Fairness-Aware Pareto Multi-Objective Ant-Q Learning (FA-PMOAQL) allocator is introduced to integrate Q-learning and ant-colony optimization under fairness-aware multi-objective guidance. These designs establish a unified framework that not only improves task allocation efficiency through multi-space partitioning and urgency-driven scheduling, but also ensures equitable resource utilization by embedding fairness into the learning process. Comparison experiments on Tokyo and New York datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves up to 12.8% higher task completion rate compared with baseline algorithms, while maintaining relatively low runtime. In cross-layer scenarios, the completion rate improves by 20% when agent resources increase, and under heavy task loads it sustains competitive performance with only moderate decline.

title: D3BSR: Blind Super-Resolution via Diffusion-based Disentangled Degradation Representation
authors: Wei Yu, Qinling Liu, Quanling Meng, Chenyang Wang, Xin Sun
abstract: Existing Blind Super-Resolution (BSR) methods are mostly trained on artificial synthetic degradation data pairs or rely on specific degradation priors, which lead to poor performance due to the trained degradation mismatch between other unknown complex degradations in real-world scenarios. To tackle this problem, we propose a novel Diffusion-based Disentangled Degradation representation method for BSR, dubbed D3BSR, which disentangles arbitrary unknown degradation into structure and texture degradations to enhance perception and fidelity quality individually. Specifically, the structure degradation is optimized by degradation distribution transition with a self-supervised collaborative learning strategy to recursively minimize the perception error. The texture degradation is restored through posterior sampling controlled by a fidelity coefficient to leverage rich texture priors encapsulated in a pre-trained diffusion model for preserving fidelity. The degraded image is super-resolved using an analytical solution with the pseudo inverse of the structural and texture degradation, which achieves a controllable trade-off between perception and fidelity and does not rely on any degradation priors or extra-supervised training. Extensive experiments on the nine heavily degraded synthetic and real-world natural and face datasets demonstrate that our D3BSR outperforms SOTA methods on the diverse metrics in reconstruction faithfulness and perceptual quality.

title: Triple-band and Ultra-thin Electromagnetic Shielding Absorber for Discrete Sources
authors: Tian Peng, Wuyin Huang, Xiangyu Zhou, Fanggong Cai, Yuan Xu, Qiangli Xi, Zhixiang Huang, Lixia Yang
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: The achievement of ultra-thin and nearly perfect absorbing metasurface is of great importance both in electromagnetic (EM) interference and shielding. According to the angle-selective Brewster's effect, any absorbing metasurface is angle-dependent which revealed the reason why the mostly researched absorbers were optimized at a predefined incident angle of the electric field. In this work, the absorbing performance of an ultra-thin and inhomogeneous plate designed for EM shielding of discrete sources was researched which showed that the nearly perfect absorption can be fulfilled as long as its constitutive parameters satisfies a particular spatial profile. For illustration, a 0.544mm-thick inhomogeneous absorber working at triple-band was proposed and designed. The measured electric field distributions indicate that the standing wave effects and phase distortion can hardly be observed and the calculated average voltage standing wave ratios at the frequencies of 3.6GHz, 9.8GHz and 11.9GHz were 1.3, 1.18 and 1.22 respectively which were consistent with the theoretical analysis and full-wave simulation.

title: Piezoelectric Shunt Damping Technology With Passive Mechanical Switches for Vibration Isolation
authors: Quan Yuan, Yipeng Wu, Junfeng He, Hongli Ji, Jinhao Qiu
abstract: This article proposes a novel passive implementation of Synchronized Switch Damping on Inductor technology for resonance attenuation in vibration isolation systems. Replacing active electronics with self-recovered mechanical switches eliminates the need for external power, sensors, and complex control algorithms. The mechanical switches leverage their intrinsic auto-recovery capability to autonomously track vibration displacement extrema, triggering LC oscillations in the piezoelectric shunt circuit near these points to generate velocity-opposing control forces. Parametric studies reveal that optimizing the switch’s free-recovery time constant (via increased damping/reduced stiffness) and preset switch distance enhances extreme-point tracking and isolation performance, particularly effective at higher resonance frequencies. Experimental validation using memory foam-based mechanical switches in an isolation prototype demonstrates a 40% reduction in resonant amplitude compared to the uncontrolled case, successfully replicating simulated behaviors including three distinct operational states (noncontact, transitional, and stable oscillation). The technique maintains robustness against abrupt increases in base vibration. This approach offers a promising maintenance-free solution for scenarios demanding environmental resilience and simplified implementation.
