title: Predicting Synergistic Antioxidant Efficiency in Allicin-Flavonoid Complexes: A Machine Learning QSAR Modeling Approach
authors: Richard Kyung, Youna Hong, Byungsik Cho
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: The research investigates how allicin from garlic interacts with flavonoids to create synergistic antioxidant effects, which shows promise for developing new nutraceuticals. The process of testing different allicin-flavonoid pairs through experimental methods proves too expensive for practical use. The research establishes a predictive machine learning system to find the most effective allicin-flavonoid combinations with synergistic effects at high speed. The research used a computational method that combined Density Functional Theory (DFT) with Quantitative Structure-Activity Relationship (QSAR) modeling. The research team built a diverse flavonoid dataset and performed molecular descriptor calculations. The B3LYP/6-311+G(d,p) DFT method calculated precise Bond Dissociation Enthalpy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\triangle \text{BDE}$</tex>) changes for a selected set of compounds when they formed complexes with allicin. The Random Forest Regressor model received <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\triangle \text{BDE}$</tex> data as its target variable to establish a relationship between molecular structures and their synergistic effects. The trained model achieved outstanding predictive accuracy, as indicated by an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex> score of 0.89 when evaluated on a separate test dataset. The number of hydroxyl groups (nOH) emerged as the primary factor, explaining more than half of the predictive power, according to feature importance analysis, followed by topological polar surface area (TPSA). The model demonstrates that H-bond donation ability plays a vital role in stabilizing radicals. The research created a dependable ML-QSAR system that enables scientists to design antioxidant combinations through rational methods. The model serves as an efficient high-speed screening system for large virtual flavonoid libraries, enabling the selection of optimal candidates for experimental verification, thereby accelerating the development of therapeutic and nutraceutical agents against oxidative stress.

title: Terahertz Transmitter Frontend Using Multi-Port Varactors in 65-nm CMOS
authors: Saad Azmeen-ur-Rahman, Young-Joon Lee, Wooyeol Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: A 3<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rd</sup>-order subharmonic up-conversion transmitter in 65-nm CMOS with RF of 278 GHz, LO at 86 GHz, and IF of 20 GHz is presented. In a distributed architecture, the transceiver uses a pair of accumulation-mode asymmetric varactors as 2-port devices for passive up-conversion mixing, utilizing the n-well ports of the varactor for IF input. The Hartley architecture is implemented to reject the lower sideband, and the bias voltages are optimized to maximize the RF while rejecting the center frequency at 3LO. The mixer achieves a simulated maximum conversion gain of -25.2 dB, OP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1dB</inf> of -13.9 dBm, and maximum RF power of -13.2 dBm.

title: Research on Decision-making in Production Processes Based on Simulated Annealing and Dynamic Optimization Models
authors: Liangyi Ma, Haoran Xu, Jin Wu, Cheng Liao
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: As a commonly used heuristic algorithm, simulated annealing algorithm is especially good at solving multi-step, multi-objective, and multi-parameter scene optimization problems. To expand its application scope, this paper applies the simulated annealing algorithm to the production inspection decision-making process of an enterprise in the production of electronic parts. Firstly, a distributive sampling-based detection scheme is designed to accurately estimate the defective rate of parts with as few samples and tests as possible. Then, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-1$</tex> decision model was established through dynamic programming to calculate the production inspection strategy with the lowest total cost. Finally, with the help of simulated annealing algorithm, the optimal detection decision of an electronic product in the three-step production process is successfully obtained. This study not only provides a scientific and feasible production detection strategy for decision makers, but also provides a useful reference for the application of heuristic algorithms such as simulated annealing in production planning.

title: Enhancing Critical Infrastructure Security: Addressing Cybersecurity Risks and Regulatory Gaps in AI-Enabled IoT Systems
authors: Mildred Adwubi Bonsu, Philip Akekudaga
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: The convergence of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things (IoT) has transformed data collection, processing, and decision-making across sectors such as healthcare, manufacturing, finance, and transportation, many of which are designated as critical infrastructure. AI-enabled IoT systems enable real-time analytics, predictive maintenance, and autonomous operations, yet they also expand the cybersecurity threat landscape. Regulatory frameworks such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA), National Institute of Standards and Technology Cybersecurity Framework (NIST CSF), and ISO/IEC 27001 aim to protect sensitive data but often fall short in addressing the unique risks of AI-IoT integration. This paper presents a structured literature review of peer-reviewed research and authoritative standards to examine AI-enabled IoT security risks and associated compliance challenges, with a specific focus on strengthening the resilience of critical infrastructure. The analysis identifies gaps in regulatory coverage related to AI-specific threats, third-party dependencies, and human factors influencing compliance. To address these deficiencies, a strategic framework is proposed that incorporates adaptive risk-based security models, AI-driven threat monitoring, vendor oversight mechanisms, and comprehensive stakeholder training. Aligning technical safeguards with evolving regulatory obligations can enhance critical infrastructure against sophisticated threats while ensuring legal and ethical compliance. The findings provide practical insights for policymakers, compliance officers, and cybersecurity practitioners seeking to develop adaptive, future-ready governance models for AI-enabled IoT ecosystems.

title: A Redactable Blockchain Architecture for Regulatory Compliance
authors: Christopher G. Harris
abstract: Redactable blockchains enable controlled removal or modification of data to meet regulatory demands, but existing solutions often sacrifice decentralization or auditability. This paper presents a redactable blockchain architecture that combines a Redaction Policy Engine (RPE), multi-party validator voting, and post-quantum chameleon hash functions. We introduce a structured lifecycle—from submission and policy validation to execution and logging—anchored by cryptographic enforcement and on-chain governance. Our design supports GDPR-aligned features such as audit trails, user appeals, and purpose limitation enforcement. Implemented on a permissioned Ethereum network, our system demonstrates lower latency (1.82s), gas cost (128.5k), and storage overhead (1.2%) compared to prior solutions. A detailed security and compliance analysis confirms resilience against validator collusion and quantum threats. This work offers a practical framework for deploying redactable blockchains in regulated environments while preserving verifiability and decentralization.

title: Intelligent Scheduling Algorithm for Multi-Time Scale Distribution Network for Electric Vehicle Charging Load
authors: Tianle Xu, Lixiang Xu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: With the rapid growth of technology, artificial intelligence (AI) and big data technology are profoundly influencing many industries such as communication, power, and manufacturing. In the field of electric vehicle (EV) charging stations, optimizing the complementarity of source load resources and achieving coordinated coordination across multiple time scales can not only significantly reduce the operating costs of charging stations, but also effectively reduce the interference of source load randomness on system scheduling strategies. The accurate power load forecasting model provides important support for the intelligent scheduling of EVs. Based on this, this paper proposes a multi time scale intelligent scheduling model for distribution networks based on deep learning (DL). The model first preprocesses the historical data of EV charging load and uses DL technology to dynamically model the reduced dimensional time series data, thereby achieving accurate prediction of charging load. On this basis, the model further optimized the intelligent scheduling strategy of the distribution network. The results indicate that our model has high accuracy in EV load forecasting and can provide strong guarantees for the safety and economic operation of the electrical power system (EPS).

title: Classification of Concrete Cracks Images using HU Moment Features Based SVM Models
authors: Yessi Jusman, Ahmad Zaki, Ahmad Firdaus, Agil Priambada
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Concrete cracking poses a significant challenge in civil infrastructure, as it often signals underlying structural degradation that threatens safety and long-term durability. Manual inspection methods are time-consuming, subjective, and inefficient for large-scale evaluations. This study proposes an enhanced automatic crack classification model that combines HU Moment Invariant features with Support Vector Machine (SVM) classifiers. Image preprocessing is conducted via grayscale conversion and adaptive histogram equalization to improve contrast and standardize input. Geometric features are then extracted using HU Moments, known for their robustness to rotation, translation, and scale. These features are classified using three variants of SVM—Coarse, Fine, and Medium—to explore trade-offs between accuracy and training time. The system is trained and tested on a dataset of 10,073 concrete surface images categorized into three classes: severe cracks, fine cracks, and non-cracked surfaces. Experimental results show consistent classification accuracy of 77% across all models, with Medium SVM achieving the highest specificity of 81.7%. These findings demonstrate that the HU-SVM approach offers a lightweight, efficient, and accurate solution for concrete crack classification in structural health monitoring systems.

title: Integrating Performance Testing Pipelines with Cloud-Based Analytics for Predictive Modeling Using ML
authors: Sowmya Chintakindi, Shiva Shankar Kusuma
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: As technology is evolving rapidly, it is required to develop, test, and deploy software with optimal performance to meet current user demands. To meet this demand, performance testing plays a key role in delivering fast and reliable software under peak workloads. Traditional performance testing frameworks, such as Apache JMeter, are effective in generating load, but operate independently of analytics or machine learning platforms. This research presents a unified pipeline to integrate RESTful API performance testing using JMeter with telemetry via Google Analytics 4 (GA4), streaming analytics in Google BigQuery, and predictive modeling via BigQuery ML. During load testing, performance metrics are sent as custom events in Google Analytics, exported to BigQuery, and used to train built-in ML models for predicting latency or performance bottlenecks. By using ML models from BigQuery, we want to create a more effective and scalable method for predicting website performance and proactively identifying potential problems. This method enables more accurate and insightful predictions, resulting in proactive optimization and a better user experience.

title: Multi-Modal Emotion Temporal Environment Facial Classification to Help Children with ASD
authors: Kaavya Sri Ramarapu, Maria Resendiz, Marcelo M. De Carvalho, Damian Valles
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) frequently encounter difficulties in recognizing and interpreting emotions, primarily when their surroundings affect emotional perception. Traditional emotion recognition systems predominantly emphasize facial features, neglecting the influence of environmental cues on emotional comprehension [1]–[2]. This paper introduces a multi-modal Environment Emotion Recognition (EER) framework that combines environmental and facial emotion cues to deliver a more environmentally thorough emotion classification. The suggested methodology utilizes ResNet-18 for environmental and emotional classification, and InceptionResNetV1 with MTCNN-based facial detection for facial emotion recognition. A weighted fusion layer integrates the outputs of both models, emphasizing facial emotion cues upon face detection. The system is evaluated through accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and confusion matrix analysis. Experimental results indicate that the fusion approach improves classification performance relative to independent models, especially in scenarios where environmental context is inadequate. The proposed framework presents potential applications in assistive technologies for ASD, facilitating more nuanced and reliable emotion recognition in real-world environments.

title: Effects of Load Estimation Detail on Off-Grid System Design and Reliability
authors: Melvin Dang, Dean Aquino, Henry Louie
abstract: Solar-powered standalone off-grid systems can be a practical, least-cost solution to providing electricity access to some of the 700 million people presently without electricity. These systems provide electricity while avoiding the potentially high cost of connecting to an existing power grid. Appropriately designing off-grid systems requires an estimate of the load they will serve. There is a continuum of detail that can be included in this estimate. On one end, the estimate consists of a single value representing the average daily electrical energy expected to be consumed. No hourly, daily, or seasonal variation is modeled. On the other end, the load estimate is a high-temporal resolution time series of power consumption throughout the year. It is expected that, for the same level of accuracy, a load estimate with greater detail will result in a more appropriately sized photovoltaic array, battery bank, and inverter. However, a more detailed load estimate is more challenging to produce. It requires additional inputs, such as surveys or historical data from similar users, to create. This paper explores the benefits of increasing the detail of a load estimate. Measured data from off-grid residential systems in the Navajo Nation are used to create accurate load estimates with differing levels of detail. Then, HOMER Pro software is used to redesign the systems based on the different load estimates. The capital cost and reliability of the resulting designs are then evaluated.

title: Research on Loan Default Prediction Based on KRF-CNN
authors: Zhewei Zhang, Chunfeng Zhang, Huijin Qiao, Zeyu Duan, Yuqing Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: Against the backdrop of economic development and the upgrading of residents’ consumption, credit consumption has emerged. However, the risk of loan defaults has increased accordingly. Therefore, it is of great significance to construct a precise loan default prediction model.Aiming at the problems of complex financial loan data and low prediction accuracy of traditional models, this paper proposes a KRF - CNN prediction model that integrates random forests and convolutional neural networks at the model structure level. In this paper, data is pre - processed through KNN interpolation, point - biserial correlation analysis, and chi - square test, and a feature engineering is constructed. Then, Bayesian optimization is used to iteratively select hyperparameters. This model takes advantage of the strong deep - feature extraction ability of convolutional neural networks and the strong complex - relationship - handling ability of random forests. The feature maps extracted by the convolutional network are flattened and input into the random forest, taking into account both high - dimensional feature extraction and prediction accuracy, thus improving the prediction accuracy and model robustness.Meanwhile, by combining the XGBoost algorithm, random forests, and convolutional neural networks, an XRF - CNN model with feature - level integration is constructed. The test results show that the loan default prediction accuracy of the KRF - CNN hybrid model reaches 0.8845. Compared with a single random forest, convolutional neural network, and the XRF - CNN model, the accuracy is increased by 2.50%, 1.70%, and 1.46% respectively. This provides new ideas and methods for the prediction and prevention of loan defaults.

title: Research on Grid-Connected Control Algorithm of T-Type Three-Level Inverter with Adaptive Parameter Optimization
authors: Zhenhua Zhang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: T-type three-level inverter (Hereinafter referred to as TTTLI) is widely used in renewable energy power generation system because of its high efficiency, low harmonic distortion and good electromagnetic compatibility. However, under complex working conditions, the traditional control algorithm with fixed parameters is difficult to ensure its stable operation and grid-connected current quality. In this paper, the mathematical model of TTTLI is established first, and then a double closed-loop control framework based on adaptive parameter optimization is designed. By monitoring the system state in real time and dynamically adjusting the parameters of PI controller, it can cope with complex working conditions such as voltage fluctuation and load change. The simulation and experimental results show that the proposed adaptive control algorithm is superior to the traditional PI control algorithm in dynamic response speed, harmonic suppression ability and steady-state accuracy, which can significantly reduce the total harmonic distortion rate (THD) of grid-connected current, improve the system stability and response speed, and verify its effectiveness in improving the gridconnected performance of inverters.

title: Automated Public Announcement System Using Template-based Natural Language Generation
authors: Soni Yora, Muhammad Maulana Ramadhan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: A public announcement system is a communication system that broadcasts messages to a public audience amplified by a loudspeaker device. It has widely helped announcers convey messages to the audience quickly and with a pleasant tone in large areas. The benefit is that voice-based announcements help people with visual impairments. In addition, messages can be received directly without looking at them, compared to text-based messages. An announcer with special skills carries out the task of delivering announcements. In addition to requiring particular employees, an announcer may make mistakes when delivering messages. In today’s modern era, an automated public announcement system is essential. Unfortunately, several proposed methods have used static sentences, while actual conditions require dynamic sentences according to current data. For creating dynamic announcement sentences based on current data, this study has worked on forming dynamic sentences using the template-based Natural Language Generation (NLG) method. Next, by using a text-to-speech service, announcement sentences are converted into sound. The Mean Opinion Score (MOS) method assesses the system quality. The testing results of the 50 respondents have scored an excellent rate on 7 test items as proof of good system quality, even though naturalness and audio flow need a little improvement. Thus, the proposed method can be applied to automate dynamic public announcements based on current data.

title: Development of a wearable and Embedded Multi-Sensor Solution for Real-Time Surface Electromyography and Motion Signal Acquisition
authors: Stefano Marocco, Giulio Saroglia, Shasa Nicoloso, Hajer Gammoudi, Inès Chihi, Igor Stefanini
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: The precise monitoring of human movements has become essential in different fields such as biomechanics, rehabilitation and sports sciences. In this field Surface Electromyography (sEMG) and Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs) offers comprehensive insights into neuromuscular activity and body kinematics, providing objective data for theese applications. This paper propose the design and development of a wearable hardware platform that allows to acquire sEMG and kinetic signals. The system is based on a custom-designed Printed Circuit Board (PCB) allowing real time data acquisition from single channel sEMG and IMU sensors, including accelerometers, gyroscopes and magnetometers on three axis. Experimental validation confirmed system reliability in capturing muscle activity and motion data, with high signal fidelity and low error in comparison with literature studies and commercial references.

title: Artificial Intelligence on Corporate Social Responsibility: Comparing Literature Review and Normative Ethical Stances
authors: Aurelia Bianca Hanjaya, Nisrin Husna
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Corporate social responsibility (CSR) has been viewed as one of the main channels for a company to build sustainable business operations, and along the way, these efforts also merge with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Throughout the years, there has been an implementation gap of CSR-artificial intelligence (AI) on the practicality of its ethical standards. This paper attempts to measure the effectiveness of AI on CSR with the systematic literature review method. Results stated that AI benefits the development of these CSR strategies. In line with effectivity, responsibility was assessed based on normative ethical stances, which described that CSR-AI efforts are morally permissible to be done in perpetuity. The analysis further leads to proposed elements to consider in complementing CSR with AI that goes hand in hand with nsormative ethics standards. For further studies, this study implies that CSR strategy ought to be further customized based on industry, company culture, governance practices, and moral offsetting.

title: Evaluating Modern Deep Learning Architectures for Brain Tumor Detection
authors: Elangel Neilea Shaday, Ventje Jeremias Lewi Engel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Brain tumors are among the most lethal types of cancer, with high mortality rates and aggressive progression. Early detection through imaging, particularly MRI, is crucial for improving survival rates. This study evaluates 11 deep learning models which has not been done in previous studies, including CNN, Xception, VGG19, InceptionV3, ResNet50, Inception-ResNetV2, DenseNet201, EfficientNetB3, MobileNetV2, NASNet-Large, and NASNetMobile, for their effectiveness in brain tumor detection using MRI scans. All models were trained and tested with identical preprocessing and hyperparameter settings to compare their performance. Adam optimizers were used to train each model with a learning rate of 0.0001, decay steps of 100, and a decay rate of 0.95 across 50 epochs. Dropout is used to reduce overfitting and speed up the learning process, with a rate of 0.2. L1 and L2 regularization are applied to the three dense layers to prevent overfitting and help the model learn better as it becomes more complex. Each dense layer uses the ReLU function, with 256 neurons in the first layer, 128 neurons in the second, and a SoftMax function in the final layer for classification. The final results show the DenseNet201 model achieves the highest accuracy of 95.65%, while the EfficientNetB3 model achieves the lowest accuracy of 75.89% on the testing data. These findings suggest that deep learning models like DenseNet201 show real potential for enhancing medical imaging diagnostics. Additional research on hybrid architectures, larger and clinical data validation, and fine-tuning are needed in order to improve the generalizability and accuracy of models.

title: Stance Analysis of YouTube Comments on Videos About Severe Extremist Attacks
authors: Rediet Ababayehu, Andrew J. Park, Dominic Nootebos
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: The rise of online discourse regarding political and ideological beliefs has transformed the YouTube comment section into a space where extremist ideologies are both spread and challenged. The study of online radicalization has often been approached through the lens of sentiment analysis, but several limitations have been identified using this technique. As technology evolves, new tools such as Large Language Models (LLMs) can be used in stance detection. This study explores how users engage with extremist content through stance detection and social network analysis. These techniques help researchers analyze both the content of each comment and the emotion behind it. Using a dataset of videos reporting on extremist events, stance detection was applied to classify comments as supporting, against, or neutral. Moreover, social network analysis of the reply structure was used to identify key users and visualize clusters and conversations.

title: Information Systems in Healthcare: Machine Learning-Driven Diagnostic Support System for Early Detection of Diabetes
authors: Jason Kosasih Saputra, Muhammad Henry Sulistyo, Edi Purnomo Putra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Diabetes mellitus remains a major global health concern, impacting not only mortality rates but also the quality of life and the sustainability of healthcare systems. Early detection and timely intervention are crucial to slow disease progression and prevent complications. However, conventional diagnostic methods often require complex lab work and trained personnel, which can delay diagnosis, especially in resource-limited areas. This study introduces a machine learning-based diagnostic support system designed to detect diabetes quickly and accurately using standard blood test parameters. The system was trained on a publicly available medical dataset containing 1,015 patient records and 18 clinical features, such as HbA1c, glucose, and cholesterol levels. To address data imbalance, the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) was applied, and model performance was validated through k-fold cross-validation as well as external dataset testing. The Random Forest classifier demonstrated the highest performance, achieving an average accuracy of 99%. To benchmark its effectiveness, the model was compared with other algorithms, including K-Nearest Neighbors, Support Vector Machine, and Logistic Regression. The findings suggest that machine learning can offer a practical and scalable tool for early diabetes screening, particularly in under-resourced areas. By providing fast and accurate diagnostic support, this system can assist healthcare professionals in improving triage, refining treatment plans, and ultimately enhancing patient outcomes. Its strong performance indicates potential for real-world clinical integration, offering a valuable second opinion that supports more efficient healthcare delivery.

title: Application of Multi-Scale Feature Fusion Network Combined with YOLOv7 in Transmission Line Corridor Monitoring
authors: Guozhu Yang, Shirui Sun, Maojie Tian, Huamin Sun, Enhui Wei, Junlei Li
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Traditional transmission line corridor monitoring relies on manual inspection, which is inefficient and limited by environmental factors. YOLOV7 algorithm is outstanding in the field of target detection because of its high efficiency and accuracy, but in the face of complex and changeable transmission line corridor environment, the detection accuracy requires further enhancement. In this research, the Feature Pyramid Network (FPN) and PANet are integrated to strengthen YOLOV7's capability for multi-scale feature fusion, so as to improve the accuracy and robustness of detecting targets of different scales. The findings indicate that integrating a Multi-scale Feature Fusion Network (MFFN) with the YOLOV7 model leads to enhanced performance over the standard YOLOV7 in terms of accuracy, recall, and F1 score. This improvement markedly boosts the effectiveness and precision of monitoring transmission line corridors. Furthermore, when contrasted with alternative object detection algorithms like Faster R-CNN, SSD, and YOLOV5, the proposed model exhibits superior capabilities in detecting objects across multiple scales and within complex environments. This research not only ensures safer and more reliable operation of the power grid but also establishes a robust theoretical basis and practical significance for advancing the application of computer vision and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A I$</tex> technologies within the power industry.

title: Performance Analysis of Convolutional Architectures for Image Pattern Recognition
authors: Assel Mukasheva, Dina Koishiyeva, Almas Saduakas, Jeong Won Kang
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Classifying dermatoscopic images is a complex task due to the visual similarity of lesion types. Manual dermatoscopic analysis requires specialized knowledge and experience and is characterized by variable diagnostic accuracy. Automated classification systems require the evaluation of several architectural approaches to determine optimal performance characteristics. This study evaluates seven convolutional neural network architectures for skin lesion classification. The methodology applies intensity normalization and morphological operations to remove artifacts. All models use pre-trained ImageNet weights with transfer learning implementation. DenseNet121 achieves 86.0% validation accuracy and 0.963 AUC. EfficientNet-B1 demonstrates 83.2% accuracy with an AUC of 0.969. Error analysis reveals classification difficulties between actinic keratosis and basal cell carcinoma classes. The custom model demonstrates lower performance with 40.8% accuracy. The results provide a quantitative comparison of architectural performance for dermatoscopic classification applications.

title: IoT based Irrigation Monitoring and Management System for Precision Farming
authors: Subrata Dutta, Anshuman Mahato, Abhishikt Ashirwad Ekka, Abhirup Paria, Arindam Giri, Sarmistha Neogy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Software, Knowledge, Information Management &amp; Applications (SKIMA)
abstract: This paper proposes an irrigation monitoring and management system to remotely manage farm irrigation. The proposed system uses multiple ESP32 nodes with environmental sensors spread across the farm field to gather soil moisture and other environmental data. This data can be accessed from a dedicated mobile application designed and developed by us. The user, possibly the farmer can set a threshold for soil moisture level by regularly checking the field data obtained from the sensors. The application will notify the farmer whenever moisture levels change around the thresholds. The farmer can act accordingly from anywhere without much physical intervention. By utilizing wireless sensor networks and IoT technologies, the research demonstrates a novel approach to agricultural management that bridges technological innovation with traditional farming practices. The research addresses critical challenges in modern agriculture, such as water conservation, efficient resource management, and the need for intelligent agricultural automation.

title: Proof of Increased Security of Polymorphism
authors: Albert Carlson, Benjamin Williams, Sai Ranganath Mikkilineni, Christopher Briscoe, Mandeep Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Polymorphic ciphers are ciphers that continually change the encryption algorithm and keys used for encryption to reduce the susceptibility of encrypted messages to unintended decryption. This property drew the attention of the research community to these ciphers. Despite the growing interest in polymorphic ciphers, there is no literature effectively demonstrating the strength and speed of these ciphers. In this paper, we utilize cipher properties such as idempotence, mathematical phenomena like the birthday paradox, and cipher characteristics such as the unicity distance and isomorphism to demonstrate that polymorphic ciphers are stronger than single-key ciphers. We present our analysis through four comparative cases, examining the strength of a single-key cipher and a polymorphic cipher based on the encryption shard/block size. The conclusion from our analysis is that polymorphic ciphers are always at least as secure as a single-key cipher. We also present the conditions under which polymorphic ciphers are always more secure than non-polymorphic ciphers.

title: HEMA-CIM: A Dual-Macro Hybrid-Domain CIM Architecture for Energy-Efficient FP MAC Operations in Edge AI
authors: Yan Yan, Shaochen Li, Wenlun Zhang, Xin Si, Kentaro Yoshioka
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: As the complexity of artificial intelligence (AI) tasks like large language models (LLMs) grows, the demand for energy-efficient floating-point (FP) computation has become critical. While the existing computing-in-memory (CIM) designs demonstrate excellent performance in inference tasks with low precision requirements, they face challenges in achieving energy-efficient FP multiply-accumulate (MAC) operations. This paper proposes HEMA-CIM, a novel dual-macro hybrid-domain CIM architecture based on: 1) a dual-macro architecture that separates computations into a digital-exponent-CIM (DECIM) macro and an analog-mantissa-CIM (AMCIM) macro; 2) a data-aware DECIM employing high-bit prediction units (HBPUs) and conditional clock gating, which leverages the statistical distribution of exponents to reduce dynamic power without compromising accuracy; 3) a highly efficient AMCIM using novel adaptive range-focusing (ARF) analog-to-digital converters (ADCs), with a two-stage, coarse-fine quantization scheme; and 4) a dynamic range aligner (DRA) and a FP formatting unit (FFU) connected with the dual macro to realize a complete FP computation pipeline. HEMA-CIM achieved a peak energy efficiency of 37.2 TFLOPS/W for BF16 MAC operations, representing a 1.18 × to 2.11 × improvement over prior work.

title: Architectural Concepts for Integrating Fundamental Drives and Emotions Into Artificial Intelligence
authors: Teddy Ferdinan, Wiktoria Mieleszczenko-Kowszewicz, Jan Kocoń, Przemysław Kazienko
abstract: Current large language models display limited emotional intelligence, often mimicking affective patterns without genuine understanding, which raises manipulation and safety risks. We argue that artificial intelligence (AI) should prioritize long-term human well-being over short-term engagement, and that advancing toward artificial general intelligence (AGI) requires embedding fundamental drives and artificial emotions in model architectures. Building on Lazarus’s cognitive-rational theory, we propose a framework with an emotional module and a rational module, where artificial drives guide affective appraisal and decision-making. This enables alignment of artificial emotions with core values—such as human well-being, fairness, and environmental preservation—anchoring AI safety at the architectural level rather than through post hoc fixes. We discuss technical and ethical challenges, including data needs and reward modeling, and call for open science and regulation to ensure human-centered AGI.

title: Evaluation of Productivity and Environmental Impact of Hybrid Sweet Corn Varieties with Digital Twins
authors: Ruturaj Patil, Abhishek Kumar, Sanket Junagade, Rushikesh Kulat, Swagatam Bose Choudhury, Sanat Sarangi, Suryakant Sawant, Nandan Rajpoot, Ajay Mittal, Dineshkumar Singh, Srinivasu Pappula
abstract: Sweet corn is a highly valued crop across the world for its nutritional and economical importance. With growing demand for sustainable produce, selecting the most productive and resilient variety is essential to maximising yield while minimising environmental impact. Optimal variety selection must balance environmental, agronomic, and post-harvest factors for productivity and sustainability. For informed varietal selection in sustainable farming, the study emphasises the importance of combining Artificial Intelligence (AI) with process based modelling. In this context, our research combines Digital Twin technology, machine learning models, and process-based environmental simulations to assess and compare two hybrid sweet corn varieties, Golden Honey and Mithas, under organic farming conditions. Utilising deep learning-based algorithms for detecting pests, diseases, and assessing kernel quality, we evaluated both the varieties for their vulnerability to key stressors. We also employed the Denitrification-Decomposition model to simulate yield and carbon footprint, focusing on greenhouse gas emissions, carbon sequestration, and nutrient cycling. According to our findings, Golden Honey performed better than Mithas in terms of yield potential, insect resistance, and kernel quality, while both varieties showed environmental benefits. This study demonstrates how an integrated approach enables data-driven decisions for varietal selection, balancing sustainability and production in sweet corn varieties.

title: Machine Learning for Emotional Tone Detection: Comparing Naive Bayes and Support Vector Machine in Mental Health Contexts
authors: Ahmad Ihda Falah Annur, Devina Salsabilla Irawan, Talitha Rahmadewati Witanto, Sulthan Rafif
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Mental health disorders are psychological conditions that occur due to a person's inability to deal with pressure or problems. In recent years, mental health issues have received increasing attention in the world of public health, especially among university students. The growing use of social media platforms like X (formerly Twitter) has provided users with a space to share experiences and opinions related to mental health. However, posts on social media are often unstructured, using informal language, slang, or sarcasm, making them difficult to manual analysis. This research focuses on comparing Naïve Bayes and Support Vector Machine algorithms for mental health sentiment classification. The dataset used in this research is obtained from GitHub, which contains X user uploads categorized into two classes: Depression (Positive) and Non-Depression (Negative). The findings indicate that the SVM algorithm outperforms Naïve Bayes, achieving an accuracy of 99% across precision, recall, and F1 Score, whereas Naïve Bayes only reaches an accuracy of 87%. This finding shows that the application of hyperplane lines in SVM is more effective in separating two classes, depression and non-depression for sentiment analysis on mental health through social media data.

title: Percussion and Instrumentation in Music Emotion Recognition: a Feature Engineering Approach
authors: Hugo Redinho, Pedro Lima Louro, André C. Santos, Ricardo Malheiro, Rui Pedro Paiva, Renato Panda
abstract: We propose a new set of features for audio-based Music Emotion Recognition (MER) that are related to percussion and individual instrument information. One limitation of current feature engineering approaches in MER is that they primarily focus on melodic elements. However, the percussive elements and instrumentation are also essential for conveying and recognizing emotions in music. Our approach leverages the Demucs framework for music source separation (which enables drum channel separation) and the MT3 framework for automatic music transcription and instrument recognition. Building on the results of these frameworks, we created a new set of features that primarily capture information about musical texture, rhythm, dynamics, expressivity, tone color, and musical form. To validate our work, we utilized the MERGE dataset, which comprises over 3000 30-second audio clips annotated with Russell's emotion quadrants. To evaluate the impact of the new features, we compared classification results with those obtained using current state-of-the-art features, demonstrating statistically significant improvements in F1 score (from 71.1% to 74.2%). Moreover, the novel features helped to reduce the confusion between quadrants 3 and 4 (a common difficulty in MER models). The most significant finding of the present study is the impact of separately analyzing the drum channel, whose features proved particularly relevant.

title: sqid: A Multipurpose Virtualization Tool, Streamlining Setups for UbiComp Research
authors: Roland Aigner, Andreas Pointner, Michael Haller, Florian Michahelles
abstract: Frequently, pervasive computing research involves numerous distributed and interconnected components that must work in concert. Setting up the required technical backbone is often demanding, time-consuming, tedious, and repetitive. Existing tools for developing, testing, and tuning data-processing pipelines to extract high-level control data from low-level sensor data rely on specialized interfaces that are nontransparent, complicated, and inflexible, requiring specific personnel, such as programmers, which limits accessibility for specialists in other related fields, such as interaction designers. To address these challenges, we present a virtualization platform for data processing, transfer, and relaying. By coupling the visual programming paradigm with coherent data visualization and a network-based architecture, it facilitates adaptability and modularity, and is also compatible with a variety of hardware devices and third-party software.

title: Adaptive isogeometric analysis with THB-splines and multi-level Bézier extraction for coupled magnetostatics
authors: Andreas Grendas, Michael Wiesheu, Sebastian Schöps, Benjamin Marussig
abstract: Adaptive refinement in isogeometric analysis provides a flexible way to improve accuracy while controlling computational effort. This work builds on spline basis functions, used both for geometry representation and numerical discretization, and extends them with truncated hierarchical B-splines (THB-splines) to enable local mesh refinement with structured flexibility. To support standard finite element assembly, multi-level Bézier extraction is applied, allowing THB-spline bases to be expressed in terms of local Bernstein polynomials. Refinement is driven by a least-squares a posteriori error estimator integrated into the spline discretization. A unified formulation is presented that couples this estimator with the harmonic mortaring of the rotor-stator, ensuring consistency of the interface while guiding refinement in the coupled problem. The method is demonstrated with 2D magnetostatic simulations involving a permanent magnet synchronous machine.

title: Assembly in Motion with a Mobile Manipulator Based on Servoing Control and Disturbance Compensation
authors: Jialong Hu, Jianhua Su, Xiaochun Ji
abstract: Assembly in motion is a key solution to enhancing system efficiency in dynamic manufacturing environments. However, kinematic uncertainties and external disturbances often hinder mobile manipulators from performing high-precision tasks. This paper addresses this challenge by proposing a robust servoing control method. Specifically, we integrate sliding mode control with neural networks to enable accurate motion tracking and assembly operations without requiring precise knowledge of the disturbance model or uncertainty parameters. To ensure the stability of the tracking system, we implement a Barrier Function-based Adaptive Sliding Mode Controller (BFASMC) as a self-tuning position controller for the mobile manipulator. This controller compensates for external bounded disturbances while avoiding overestimation of control gains. Additionally, we employ an Input-to-State Stability Long Short-Term Memory Neural Network Controller (ISS-LSTM-NNC) as an auxiliary module to handle uncertainties in target motion. As a result, the proposed framework allows the robot to safely and effectively complete dynamic tracking and assembly tasks. We validate our method through experiments on the AMB150-UR5 mobile manipulator, involving both object tracking and assembly operations. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method.

title: Electrical and Thermal Design of Millimeter-Wave High-Gain Heatsink Antenna Array
authors: Binshan Zhao, Min Tang, Yue-Ping Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Heatsink antennas perform dual functions of both radiation and heat dissipation. Thus, their electrical and thermal performance should be considered carefully in a codesign procedure, especially in the high-frequency range. In this paper, the electrical and thermal design of a millimeter-wave high-gain heatsink antenna array is presented. The radiation is generated by the laminated resonator antenna (LRA) in the low temperature co-fired ceramic (LTCC) substrate, and then enhanced by the specially designed heatsink structure. To facilitate the independent control of electromagnetic and thermal performance, the vertical structure of the heatsink element is divided into two parts: the upper fins are utilized to enlarge the effective radiation area and thus improve the gain, while the lower fins are designed to satisfy the heat dissipation demand, which has a negligible impact on the radiation performance. The element gain achieves 11.5 dBi at 60 GHz by loading the proposed heatsink structure, and the element spacing reaches 1.25 λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> (λ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</sub> is the wavelength in free space at 60 GHz) for a 4×4 heatsink antenna array. In measurement, the peak gain and aperture efficiency are 21 dBi and 48.6% at 61.1 GHz, respectively. The impedance bandwidth is 19.1%, from 56.3 GHz to 68.2 GHz. A heatsink antenna array prototype with multiple chips is fabricated to demonstrate its thermal performance. The overall thermal resistance is reduced by about 38% with the proposed design. Under the forced-air cooling condition, the hotspot temperature is lower than 85 ℃, with an input power of 2.5 W.

title: A Complete Set of Quadratic Constraints for Repeated ReLU and Generalizations
authors: Sahel Vahedi Noori, Bin Hu, Geir Dullerud, Peter Seiler
abstract: This paper derives a complete set of quadratic constraints (QCs) for the repeated ReLU. The complete set of QCs is described by a collection of matrix copositivity conditions. We also show that only two functions satisfy all QCs in our complete set: the repeated ReLU and flipped ReLU. Thus our complete set of QCs bounds the repeated ReLU as tight as possible up to the sign invariance inherent in quadratic forms. We derive a similar complete set of incremental QCs for repeated ReLU, which can potentially lead to less conservative Lipschitz bounds for ReLU networks than the standard LipSDP approach. The basic constructions are also used to derive the complete sets of QCs for other piecewise linear activation functions such as leaky ReLU, MaxMin, and HouseHolder. Finally, we illustrate the use of the complete set of QCs to assess stability and performance for recurrent neural networks with ReLU activation functions. We rely on a standard copositivity relaxation to formulate the stability/performance condition as a semidefinite program. Simple examples are provided to illustrate that the complete sets of QCs and incremental QCs can yield less conservative bounds than existing sets.

title: Learning-Based Uncertainty-Guided Adaptive Image Denoising: A Multi-Scale Patch Selection Framework
authors: A Shalini, Christy Jackson Joshua
abstract: Traditional image denoising methods apply processing strategies uniformly across entire images, which leads to failure in adapting to the diverse local characteristics and noise patterns. We propose a system that adaptively selects strategies based on the uncertainty by selecting optimal patch sizes and denoising methods. Our system introduces an uncertainty model that has six components, which are used to capture spatial variance, structural proximity, spectral characteristics, algorithmic disagreement, chromatic coherence, and textural discrimination. To predict method selection, a machine learning ensemble is trained on 75,000 diverse samples and achieves a 93.4±1.6% accuracy. The framework employs bilateral filtering, non-local means, and consensus-based denoising as primary methods, with adaptive method selection guided by the uncertainty-based ensemble model. Using these two strategies, when an image is given as input, adaptive patch sizes are applied based on the characteristics, the uncertainty map is found for the patch, relevant function selection is done by the ensemble, and the patches are fused using confidence weights. Consistent improvements of 0.33-0.56 dB PSNR are noted over traditional filters when extensive evaluation is performed over five benchmark datasets (BSD68, Set12, CBSD68, SIDD, DND). An increase of 18% in processing speed is noted, in addition to a 66% decrease in memory usage. A robust generalization is achieved, validated by low cross-dataset performance degradation. The proposed framework emphasizes its potential for broad applicability across imaging domains.

title: Embodied Natural Language Interaction (NLI): Speech Input Patterns in Immersive Analytics
authors: Hyemi Song, Matthew Johnson, Kirsten Whitley, Eric Krokos, Amitabh Varshney
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Embodiment shapes how users verbally express intent when interacting with data through speech interfaces in immersive analytics. Despite growing interest in Natural Language Interactions (NLIs) for visual analytics in immersive environments, users' speech patterns and their use of embodiment cues in speech remain underexplored. Understanding their interplay is crucial to bridging the gap between users' intent and an immersive analytic system. To address this, we report the results from 15 participants in a user study conducted using the Wizard of Oz method. We performed axial coding on 1,280 speech acts derived from 734 utterances, examining how analysis tasks are carried out with embodiment and linguistic features. Next, we measured Speech Input Uncertainty for each analysis task using the semantic entropy of utterances, estimating how uncertain users' speech inputs appear to an analytic system. Through these analyses, we identified five speech input patterns, showing that users dynamically blend embodied and non-embodied speech acts depending on data analysis tasks, phases, and Embodiment Reliance driven by the counts and types of embodiment cues in each utterance. We then examined how these patterns align with user reflections on factors that challenge speech interaction during the study. Finally, we propose design implications aligned with the five patterns.

title: p-Harrow: Optical Logic Synthesis for Efficiency Optimization via Partial Harmonic Mean and Integer Partition
authors: Jun-Wei Liang, Iris Hui-Ru Jiang, Kai-Hsiang Chiu, Tung-Yu Su
publish: IEEE Journal on Emerging and Selected Topics in Circuits and Systems
abstract: With the advancement of high-speed and energy-efficient optical interconnect and computation, photonic integrated circuits (PICs) have become a promising alternative to traditional CMOS circuits. A PIC can be synthesized by mapping the binary decision diagram (BDD) of target functions to optical switches and combiners. However, excessive signal attenuation along the light propagation may require extra optical-electrical signal conversion, thus introducing unwanted delays. In this paper, we aim to overcome this deficiency during logic synthesis: First, we optimize the signal efficiency factor by applying the concept of harmonic mean to optimize DC combiners. Second, we properly arrange these proposed techniques in an optimal sequence of operations to form our main framework. Furthermore, we propose partial harmonic mean to minimize the hardware cost under an efficiency factor constraint. Experimental results show that our framework outperforms the state of the art in terms of efficiency factor.

title: An Agent-Based Approach for Implementing Asset Administration Shell Type 3
authors: Lucas Sakurada, Fernando De La Prieta, Paulo Leitao
abstract: Industry 4.0 (I4.0) is driving the digitization of traditional manufacturing systems toward intelligent and adaptable factories, where industrial assets are interconnected and capable of collaborating inside and cross-company to enhance production processes. A key enabler of this transition is the Asset Administration Shell (AAS), a standardized digital representation of an asset that encapsulates all asset-relevant information throughout its lifecycle. The AAS ensures that all assets, regardless of their type or function, can be seamlessly integrated into the I4.0, facilitating interoperability and efficient data exchange across the entire production network. However, traditional AAS solutions, namely AAS Types 1 and 2, cannot address all the requirements of modern industry environments. To overcome these limitations, the AAS Type 3 (proactive) extends beyond the conventional functionalities of traditional AAS by incorporating more sophisticated features, enabling I4.0 components to operate with greater autonomy, intelligence, and collaborative capabilities. While traditional AAS implementations (Types 1 and 2) have been widely studied and adopted, research on AAS Type 3 is still in its early stages, lacking formal specifications and standardized guidelines for its design and implementation. In this context, this article presents an agent-based AAS approach for implementing AAS Type 3, offering readers a clearer, more accessible description of its features and practical applicability while encouraging further research and development in this emerging topic. For this purpose, several experiments were performed to gain a better understanding of its application in industrial scenarios. Additionally, the article discusses the experiences, insights, limitations and future perspectives derived from the design and experimental implementation of the agent-based AAS approach.
