title: Towards Safe Commute: An AI Driven Fusion Model for Real Time Forecasting and Emergency Alerting
authors: Sai Teja Bainapalepu, Krishna Bathula
abstract: Extreme weather events increasingly pose risks to public safety and critical infrastructure, especially in underserved and resource-constrained communities. This paper presents a realtime weather alert framework that integrates multivariate time series forecasting with social media analysis to improve situational awareness and risk mitigation. The proposed system employs Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to predict key environmental variables, including temperature, wind gusts, precipitation probability, humidity, snow depth, and UV index, over shortterm horizons. To complement these forecasts, a lightweight Natural Language Processing (NLP) pipeline applies sentiment analysis to social media data using the VADER model, capturing community-level perceptions and concerns. A novel attentionguided fusion mechanism integrates forecast deviations from seasonal thresholds with sentiment-derived weights to compute dynamic risk scores, enabling adaptive prioritization of alerts based on both meteorological severity and real-time social signals. We implement this framework as a functional prototype featuring an inference-driven fusion model, configurable risk parameters, and GPT-powered natural language alert generation. The system automatically delivers targeted alerts to stakeholders when highrisk conditions are detected. By combining environmental and social signals, this framework provides a novel, community-driven approach to climate resilience and early warning systems.

title: Application-Specific AI/ML Core Synthesis on FPGA
authors: Youngsoo Kim, Isaac Glenzinski, Jace Rudolph
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) have contributed to improving both performance and energy efficiency in many AI/ML applications. However, hardware-oriented programming is still not easy for software developers, especially, those who have limited knowledge of hardware. We present two case studies to help the developers implement AI subblocks on FPGA systems easily. The use of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) in recent years has led to some important advancements in computer vision, object detection, and object recognition. Visual processing is not the only field that has seen benefits of implementation of CNNs. A plethora of other deep learning and artificial intelligence application have also made major advancements through utilizing these blocks. With the popularity and applications for use of CNNs and DWTs continually showing growth, ensuring the ability to run efficiently and quickly while maintaining high accuracy is a critical building block in advancing the performance of CNNs and DWTs. The System on Chip (SOC) FPGA platform provides great opportunity for improvement of AI cores through the enormous flexibility and software tools available. This paper explores the efforts to accelerate the AI core operation on the SOC FPGA. This includes the methods for improving performance using SIMD thumb instructions. This paper will also investigate the potential methods for achieving performance improvements utilizing high level synthesis (HLS). These different methods of improving the AI cores have been tested and implemented on a Zybo Z7 SOC FPGA using Xilinx Vitus and Xilinx Vitis HLS.

title: RedCap for Rural Areas: Olive Tree Agriculture Use Case
authors: Mehmet İzzet Sağlam, Muzaffer Kerem Savran, İlker Bilik
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: The 5th generation (5G) wireless technology has primarily been developed to support three key pillars of use cases: enhanced mobile broadband, ultra-reliable low-latency communication, and massive machine-type communication. These three 5G pillars have significantly different requirements regarding data rate, latency, connection density, and energy consumption. Implementing a use case within one of these pillars can be challenging, especially in rural areas. Fulfilling the need for continuous service and adaptive response capabilities for sustainable agriculture falls between these three pillars. The 3rd generation partnership project has developed a mid-range use case with a new device type, enabling reduced capability (RedCap) new radio (NR) devices that target lower costs and complexity, smaller physical size, and longer battery life compared to regular 5G NR devices. This paper represents one of the first contributions to the simultaneous deployment of 5G RedCap NR and enhanced machine-type communication networks in rural areas.

title: Revenue Optimization in Multi-Blockchain Mining: Adaptive Allocation and Scheduling Approaches
authors: Daewoong Cho, Gowri Ramachandran, Raja Jurdak, Salil S. Kanhere
abstract: As blockchain adoption expands and mining competition intensifies, miners face increasing challenges in maximizing revenue across multiple networks. We investigate adaptive hash power scheduling strategies for multi-blockchain mining, focusing on revenue optimization across Bitcoin (BTC), Bitcoin Cash (BCH), and Bitcoin SV (BSV). We propose and evaluate three approaches—Profit-Weighted, Priority-Based, and Nonlinear Programming (NLP)-Optimized—using real block data during 1-30 April 2025 (13,008 blocks) under simulated total hash power capacities of 100, 200, and 500 PH/s. Our results show that the Priority-Based strategy consistently delivers the highest BTC-equivalent revenue, followed by the Profit-Weighted strategy, which offers competitive performance with a simple allocation mechanism. The NLP-Optimized method provides stable allocation patterns but yields lower revenue overall. Across all configurations, BCH and BTC dominate in both allocation and contribution, while BSV shows persistently lower efficiency. Importantly, revenue growth demonstrates diminishing returns beyond 200 PH/s, and BTC’s contribution share increases with scale—rising from 40.50% at 100 PH/s to 52.15% at 500 PH/s. These findings demonstrate how miner profitability is sensitive not only to strategy design but also to changing market conditions and mining capacity.

title: Research and Application of Smart Retail Decision Support System based on Big Data Technology
authors: Naxi Chen, Yibo Zhang, Bolin Huang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: With the rapid development of big data and information technology, the retail industry is entering a critical period of digital transformation. This paper proposes a smart retail decision support system based on big data technology. By integrating the sales, inventory and membership data within the enterprise and multi-source data such as external markets and social media, a multi-level data collection, cleaning, storage and processing platform is constructed. The system uses distributed computing architecture, machine learning and deep learning algorithms to realize core functions such as consumer behavior analysis, hybrid recommendation, inventory optimization and sales forecasting, effectively improving data processing efficiency and decision accuracy. In an empirical study of 15TB data of a large retail enterprise, the system showed significant advantages in high-concurrency transaction scenarios: sales, gross profit margin and inventory turnover rate were all improved, while out-of-stock rate and inventory cost were significantly reduced. This study provides an innovative technical path for retail enterprises’ precision marketing and resource allocation and also provides a practical reference for the application of big data technology in traditional industries.

title: A Review on Design, Analysis, and Application of Conformal Antennas for Capsule Endoscope
authors: Lida Kouhalvandi, Ladislau Matekovits, Sercan Aygun, Ildiko Peter, Serdar Ozoguz, Saeid Karamzadeh
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: For human healthcare applications, radio frequency sensors that can be used inside the body are developing day by day. In this kind of sensor, an implantable antenna in a capsule endoscopy system is executed leading to communication with external equipment. For this case, these implantable circuits are growing famous in the biotelemetry field for which large bandwidth, and high gain, with compact configurations, are required in the lossy human tissue. This work presents the various state-of-the-art conformal antennas for capsule endoscopes, with a focus on introducing structures and outcomes achieved from the simulation/measurement process. As this paper is reporting the recent developments in the domain of capsule endoscopy, anyone reading this work will get general and up-to-date views regarding this concept.

title: Civil Aviation Accident Named Entity Recognition Based On Improved Entity Recognition Model
authors: Lei Zhang, Dong Du, Ke Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: Abstract-In response to the problems of inaccurate feature extraction and low efficiency in traditional entity recognition models for civil aviation accidents,this study proposes an improved BERT-TextCNN-BiLSTM-CRF model that utilizes the convolutional properties of TextCNN to enhance the model’s ability to recognize entities.Comparative experiments were conducted between the improved model and traditional models BERT,BiLSTM-CRF,and BERT-BiLSTM-CRF.The experimental results showed that the $P ? R ? F_{1}$ values are better than traditional models,reaching $0.90,0.89$,and 0.89 respectively.

title: Blockchain Architecture Design and Multi-Party Security Analysis of Power Metering Data Sharing Platform
authors: Yitao Zhao, Xinglong Liu, Yiming Zhang, Jiahao Li
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of data security and privacy protection in the traditional power metering data sharing mode, this paper puts forward an architecture design of power metering data sharing platform based on blockchain, and deeply analyzes its multi-party security. The platform adopts hierarchical architecture, including data layer, network layer, consensus layer, contract layer and application layer. The data can not be tampered with and can be traced through distributed ledger technology, and the improved DPoS consensus algorithm and intelligent contract technology are used to ensure data consistency and automatic processing. In terms of security, differential privacy, zero-knowledge proof and improved PBFT fault-tolerant model are adopted to effectively resist data tampering, unauthorized access and potential attacks. Through case analysis, the results show that the platform has obvious advantages in data integrity protection, access control, privacy protection and inter-agency collaboration efficiency improvement, and shows good adaptability in resource consumption. The research shows that blockchain technology provides a safe, efficient and reliable solution for power metering data sharing.

title: Design of an Automotive OTA System with Zonal Gateways and PQC-Hybrid TLS
authors: Jiseong Chung, Sungkwon Park, Songnam Hong
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper proposes an over-the-air (OTA) software update architecture for vehicles adopting zonal electrical/electronic (E/E) architectures. Overall proposed OTA between the server and the ECUs comprises four stages: ready, distribution, user consent, activation and supports functional safety with dual bank (A/B)switching and anti-roll back policy. Clear roles are assigned to an OEM server with a Key Management Interoperability Protocol (KMIP), a Vehicle Mobile Gateway (VMG) / Vehicle Central Computer (VCC) ingress, zonal gateways, and ECUs. To ensure long-term cybersecurity, we adopt post-quantum cryptography (PQC): a hybrid-PQC TLS 1.3 air interface using a PQC key-encapsulation mechanism (KEM), PQC-aware key lifecycle for long-lived artifacts such as firmware metadata and device credentials. Cryptographic workloads are concentrated at the VMG/VCC and zonal gate-ways and ECUs retain final signature verification to preserve end-to-end authenticity. The proposed architecture serves as a reference framework, showing how the VMG/VCC, zonal gateways, and ECUs coordinate OTA updates under PQC-aware security processes to prepare for the post-quantum era.

title: TrackTB: An Accessible Solution for Improved Tuberculosis Treatment Adherence in the Philippines
authors: Maia Wainwright, Sanvi Bhatnagar, Kyle Smith, Francisco Villa, Barbara Monteiro-Carvalho, Sean Vassilaros, Khanjan Mehta
abstract: Tuberculosis (TB) remains a leading cause of death in the Philippines, which reports one of the highest TB-related mortality rates in Southeast Asia. Despite being treatable and curable, poor patient adherence to medication undermines outcomes and contributes to drug-resistant strains—driving healthcare costs up by as much as tenfold. Physicians frequently cite limited communication between patients and providers as a barrier to effective treatment. To address this challenge, a multidisciplinary team developed TrackTB, a low-data mobile application that leverages widely accessible platforms such as Facebook and SMS to improve adherence. The app includes a 2–13 question survey, co-developed with USAID's TB Platforms initiative, to monitor common adverse drug reactions (ADRs). Patient responses are securely transmitted to a clinician portal that visualizes adherence and ADR data in an actionable format. This article describes the development, validation, and planned deployment of TrackTB. In July 2024, fieldwork in Manila included stakeholder engagement and usability testing with patients, healthcare workers, and public health officials. Feedback confirmed the app's accessibility, ease of use, and fit within the existing health care system. TrackTB is now positioned for beta testing in summer 2025. By empowering patients and equipping clinicians with real-time data, TrackTB offers a scalable, cost-effective solution to improve treatment outcomes and reduce TB mortality in the Philippines.

title: GPU-based Pricing Scheduler for Joint User Association and Resource Allocation in MU-MIMO
authors: Minjae Lee, Seongjin Hwang, Hyun Jong Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: The joint optimization of user association and resource allocation in multi-cell MU-MIMO networks is known to be NP-hard, and conventional centralized approaches suffer from excessive computational delays, making them impractical for large-scale systems with real-time constraints. In this paper, we make the following contribution: (i) we propose a pricing-based distributed optimization framework derived from the Lagrangian dual, which decouples the problem into tractable UA and RA subproblems; (ii) we implement the algorithm using CuPy in a GPU-parallel execution pipeline that exploits independence across users, resource blocks, and base stations, enabling high scalability and near real-time operation. Experimental results show that the proposed GPU-based solver achieves a 35× to 55× reduction in total computation delay compared to the CPU implementation. In particular, user association and channel/spectral efficiency computations benefit substantially from GPU parallelism. These findings validate the effectiveness of GPU acceleration for large-scale MU-MIMO scheduling and highlight its potential for practical deployment in next-generation wireless systems.

title: A Compact Radial Line Slot Array Antenna Based on Partially Reflecting Surface
authors: Homeira S. Jouybari, Keyvan Forooraghi, Zahra Atlasbaf
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: A compact monopulse radial line slot array (RLSA) antenna, enhanced with a partially reflective surface (PRS), is proposed for X-band applications in this paper. The source RLSA antenna consists of a radial waveguide with six split-ring slots on the upper plate embedded in the ground plane. A dielectric-based PRS, formed by circular metallic patches printed on the underside of a Rogers RO4003C substrate, is positioned at an optimized height above the RLSA to form a Fabry–Perot cavity, resulting in a boresight pencil gain of 19.9 dBi at 9.7 GHz. The gain of the conical beams in both elevation and azimuth directions reaches approximately 15 dB. A 4×4 microstrip Butler matrix, designed on RT5880, is used to feed the antenna with appropriate phase combinations. The design achieves good performance in terms of axial ratio (< 0.9 dB), sidelobe level (SLL) of the sum beam (–32 dB), and difference beams (–21 dB), with a compact total radius of 89.7 mm. All simulations were performed using CST and validated with HFSS to ensure accuracy and reliability of the results.

title: Lessons Learned from Designing a Wireless Universal Electrochemical Sensing System
authors: Sigmond Kukla, Batuhan Uzunoglu, Md Jahangir Alam Khondkar, Timothy Sweeney-Fanelli, Silvana Andreescu, Masudul Imtiaz
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: We present the design of an open-source wireless electrochemical sensing system intended for wearable use. The system is a low-cost potentiostat capable of performing common electrochemical measurements (chronoamperometry, cyclic voltammetry, square-wave voltammetry, etc.) on a miniaturized hardware platform with Bluetooth 5.3 connectivity to a smartphone. The goal is to enable electrochemical sensing outside of laboratory settings for applications ranging from environmental monitoring (e.g., heavy metal detection) to health diagnostics (e.g., biomarker detection in sweat). We describe the hardware and software architecture of the system and demonstrate its functionality through initial experiments, and we also discuss challenges encountered during development and the key lessons learned that informed iterative improvements to the design. Future enhancements, including integration into smart bandages and on-device machine learning for real-time analysis, are also outlined. The open-source mobile app and design files are available in https://github.com/AVHBAC/BLEElectroChemicalSensor.

title: Design and Implementation of an IoT-Enabled Deep Learning-Based Fault Detection System for Solar Panels
authors: Sofian Saidi, Mayed Aljneibi
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: This research presents a scalable and cost-effective IoT-enabled deep learning system designed for fault detection in photovoltaic (PV) panels, addressing the urgent need to optimize solar power efficiency in the UAE. The system employs Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architectures, including VGG-16, to analyze both thermal and regular imagery, accurately identifying six major fault types: hotspots, shading, dust accumulation, physical damage, inverter malfunction, and degradation through AI-based classification techniques. To enable real-time monitoring and timely fault detection, IoT sensors measure critical electrical and environmental parameters such as voltage, current, heat, and solar irradiance, with this data processed by a Raspberry Pi and transmitted to a cloud-based dashboard that offers visualization and automated alerts. Additionally, the deployment of an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) equipped with thermal and normal cameras facilitates efficient inspection of large-scale solar farms, further enhancing fault detection coverage. By integrating advanced AI, IoT sensing, and UAV technology, the system significantly improves the reliability and maintenance of PV installations, making it applicable for both industrial and residential settings. Furthermore, this innovative solution aligns with the UAE’s 2050 carbon emissions reduction goals, supporting the nation’s sustainable energy transition and reinforcing the resilience of its solar power infrastructure.

title: Enhancing End-To-End Autonomous Driving through Loss Function Optimization
authors: Hyojin Park, HyeongKeun Hong, YeongGwang Choi, Eunho Kim, Young Hoon Suh, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: End-To-End (E2E) autonomous driving provides simple structure that directly maps sensor inputs, such as camera images, to steering angles and speeds. However, existing studies have limitations in that the model merely mimics the driving dataset, learning the limitations of the algorithm that generated the data or human drivers. To address this issue, this study proposes a new loss function by extending the existing Mean Squared Error (MSE) with two additional regularization terms: a smoothness loss for steering stability and a curvature-based speed penalty for adaptive speed control. The proposed loss function enables the model to go beyond dataset reproduction, learning to decelerate stably in curves and accelerate more aggressively on straight roads. Images were collected using a lane detection-based driving algorithm in the Gazebo simulation environment for training, and intentional lane departure-recovery scenarios were included to improve generalization. Experimental results show that the proposed loss function not only achieves lower steering variance and higher average speed compared to MSE-only models but also outperforms the original driving algorithm used to generate the dataset. This study demonstrates that beyond simple dataset mimicry, a designed loss function can enable an end-to-end model to outperform the very algorithm that generated its training data.

title: Remote Signal Analysis and Diagnosis of ILS Based on QAR Data
authors: Wang Xuhui, Yang Le, Zhao Jiangge, Sun Fanrong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: The Instrument Landing System (ILS) is a critical navigation equipment installed at airports in China, and it is imperative to avoid approach and landing safety issues caused by signal interference and jitter. Based on airborne QAR (Quick Access Recorder) data, this paper explores the airborne data parameters that can be utilized for quality analysis of the ILS, identifies key indicators that represent the operational quality of the ILS, and innovatively establishes an analysis method and evaluation model for these key indicators using QAR data. Taking Changsha Airport as an example, and combining QAR data parameters, this paper evaluates the changes in related parameters of the localizer and glide slope beacons before and after calibration flights, demonstrating the feasibility of the proposed research method and solving the challenge of accurately assessing the signal quality of the ILS.

title: Neural Network-based Channel Estimation and Interference Suppression for Massive MIMO Systems
authors: Ruiyang Wang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: As the demand for higher data rates and improved spectral efficiency increases in 5 G and upcoming 6 G wireless communication systems, massive MIMO technology has become a key solution and a central area of research While massive MIMO is widely deployed in modern wireless networks, its high-dimensional channels introduce significant challenges, particularly in terms of channel estimation overhead. In order to tackle this challenge, the present paper investigates a channel estimation approach for millimeter-wave massive MIMO uplink systems, which is based on a self-encoder, leveraging the low-overhead advantage of neural networks. Traditional channel estimation and interference suppression methods struggle with excessive computational complexity and performance bottlenecks in high-dimensional environments. In order to address these limitations, this paper introduces a neural network-driven method for channel estimation and interference suppression, with the goal of improving the performance of massive MIMO systems. The critical challenges of channel estimation in massive MIMO are analyzed, and a deep learning-based neural network model is designed to achieve efficient and accurate channel estimation. Additionally, to mitigate interference in massive MIMO systems, an optimization algorithm based on neural networks is introduced, effectively reducing interference and improving system capacity and signal quality through network training. Simulation experiments are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, demonstrating that the neural network-based approach significantly outperforms traditional methods in both accuracy and computational efficiency. Finally, this paper discusses the practical application prospects and potential optimization directions of the proposed method, offering theoretical support and technical insights for the real-world deployment of massive MIMO systems.

title: Advancing Quality Management in Smart Wind Power Construction Projects Through Digital Twin and IoT Integration
authors: Fang Wang, Hengyang Li, Qiushuang Xie
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative framework for quality management in wind power construction projects, leveraging digital twin technology integrated with Building Information Modeling (BIM) and Internet of Things (IoT) sensors. The system addresses the challenges of traditional methods by enabling real-time data collection, dynamic model updates, and predictive analytics. Key quality factors-personnel, materials, machinery, methods, testing, and environmental conditions-are monitored through IoT-enabled devices, feeding data into a digital twin for comprehensive analysis and control. A case study of a wind farm construction project demonstrates the system's application, showcasing significant improvements in efficiency, compliance, and safety. The proposed approach provides a scalable and adaptive solution for managing quality in complex, large-scale energy infrastructure projects.

title: Technology Trends and Requirements Analysis of Development Support Platforms for Future Intelligent Vehicles
authors: Tai-Gil Kwon, Yongseong Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: The automotive industry is rapidly evolving from a conventional means of transportation into an intelligent mobility platform. Advances in autonomous driving, connected services, electrification, and artificial intelligence(AI)-based driving assistance are accelerating the transition from mechanically oriented vehicles to SDV(Software-Defined Vehicle). These technological shifts are closely aligned with social and economic demands such as improving traffic efficiency, enhancing driver safety, and reducing carbon emissions, thereby underscoring the growing necessity of future intelligent vehicles. Consequently, the importance of systematically designing SDV development support platforms and analyzing requirements to improve development efficiency is increasingly recognized. This paper investigates the latest technological trends in SDV development support platforms and, based on this analysis, identifies and synthesizes the essential requirements demanded by both developers and the automotive industry.

title: How Well Do Llms Imitate Human Writing Style?
authors: Rebira Jemama, Rajesh Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) can generate fluent text, but their ability to replicate the distinctive style of a specific human author remains unclear. We present a fast, training-free framework for authorship verification and style imitation analysis. The method integrates TF-IDF character <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{n}$</tex>-grams with transformer embeddings and classifies text pairs through empirical distance distributions, eliminating the need for supervised training or threshold tuning. It achieves 97.5 % accuracy on academic essays and 94.5% in cross-domain evaluation, while reducing training time by 91.8 % and memory usage by 59 % relative to parameter-based baselines. Using this framework, we evaluate five LLMs from three separate families (Llama, Qwen, and Mixtral) across four prompting strategies: zero-shot, one-shot, few-shot, and text completion. Results show that the prompting strategy has a more substantial influence on style fidelity than model size: few-shot prompting yields up to 23.5 x higher style-matching accuracy than zero-shot, and completion prompting repeatedly reaches 99.9 % agreement with the original author's style. Crucially, high-fidelity imitation does not imply human-like unpredictability: human essays average a perplexity of 29.5, whereas matched LLM outputs average only 15.2. These findings demonstrate that stylistic fidelity and statistical detectability are separable, establishing a reproducible basis for future work in authorship modeling, detection, and identity-conditioned generation.

title: Users’ Loyalty on Online Grocery: The Influence of Customer Experience and Engagement
authors: Ringgi Cahyo Dwiputra, Putu Wuri Handayani, Nabila Clydea Harahap
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: The online grocery industry in Indonesia has experienced significant growth in recent years. However, retaining existing consumers has become a very tough task for online grocery providers. This study adopts attitude-behavior-context theory with the aim of analyzing factors that influence consumer loyalty in online grocery in Indonesia from a consumer experience perspective, using the Segari application as a case study. This study employed a mixed-methods approach, involving 480 survey respondents and 15 interviews with online grocery users. Quantitative data analysis was analyzed using covariance-based structural equation modeling, while qualitative data were analyzed using content analysis. The results indicate that customer service, product experience, and delivery experience play roles in building customer loyalty to continue using an online grocery app, primarily through online customer experience and engagement, while personalization contributes to customer engagement. However, the online customer experience is not significantly impacted by economic value, personalization, or application experience. Online grocery service providers can use the insights from this study to improve the caliber of their apps and cultivate client loyalty. (Abstract)

title: CLIP-based Chest X-ray Anomaly Detection
authors: Seungin Baek, Kyuhoon Moon, Jitae Shin
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Chest radiographs are inherently multi-label, as a single study may exhibit multiple co-occurring findings. While CLIP supports prompt-based recognition, naïve uniform aggregation of per-class scores (e.g., max/mean) ignores finding multiplicity and can limit accuracy. We introduce Count-Aware Noisy-OR (CANOR), a plug-and-play aggregation head that is parameter-efficient: it trains only 6,169 of 151,277,313 parameters (0.004%) while keeping the CLIP encoders frozen. CANOR leverages image-level multi-label supervision with count-aware training—weighting each sample by its pathology count—and learns a small set of calibration scalars (one global temperature and class-wise biases), together with a noisy-OR aggregation rule that accounts for disease co-occurrence. On CheXpert, CANOR modestly improves accuracy while maintaining comparable AUC and F1 to published baselines, and adds negligible inference overhead. These results indicate that exploiting the structure of multi-label supervision with a count-aware noisy-OR head yields consistent improvements with minimal additional parameters.

title: A Study on Gradient Sparsity-based Federated Learning Training Method Utilizing DPU
authors: Yuting Li, Peng Gao, Zheng Dong, Xu Dong, Zhanpeng Zhang, Runjing Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: Federated learning is a privacy-preserving distributed machine learning method that can train models without centralizing the original data sets. However, the large-scale federated learning training requires a lot of network communication bandwidth for gradient exchange, which limits the scalability of multi-node training. Mobile devices are more seriously affected by high latency and low bandwidth in federated learning on the move. To reduce the communication overhead and accelerate the federated training process, this paper proposes an adaptive threshold selection gradient sparsification algorithm. However, gradient sparsification algorithms often result in model accuracy loss in federated learning. In order to ensure that federated learning does not suffer from model accuracy loss due to gradient sparsification, this paper further proposes a momentum compensation algorithm, which determines the effective ratio of old gradients and new gradients based on the loss value during the model training process, thereby generating new gradient information. Finally, the algorithm is deployed on the data processing unit, utilizing the data parallelism and communication capabilities of the DPU to assist training. In this experiment, the classical CNN model was adopted, LeNet-5 and ResNet-101 were used for image classification, and mnist and cifar10 data sets were used for testing. Compared with the traditional Top-1% sparse algorithm, the communication compression ratio of the proposed method can be improved by about 40%.

title: The Role of Gamification Elements in Digital Banking Adoption
authors: Oktavian Heryanda, Rachel Afifah Wafa, Shofi Zayyan Azhari, Dyah Wahyu Sukmaningsih
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Digital banking applications are increasingly implementing gamification, However, there is limited understanding of how gamification elements influence intrinsic motivation and continuance. This micro-scale study combines the Expectation-Confirmation Model of IS Continuance with the analysis of the effects of gamification elements, like levels, rewards, and points, on autonomy, competence, and relatedness in Self-Determination Theory to analyze the influence of intrinsic motivation on satisfaction and continuance intention. Data collected through an online survey involving 415 digital banking app users in Indonesia and analyzed using PLS-SEM with the help of SmartPLS4 software. The results show that gamification increases autonomy and relatedness, which contribute positively to intrinsic motivation, while competence has no significant effect. Intrinsic motivation also increases satisfaction, which in turn drives satisfaction and intention to keep utilizing. Therefore, this research provides valuable insights for developers in creating more effective gamification strategies that aim to increase user satisfaction and ultimately drive continued usage of digital banking apps.

title: Sentiments Analysis Using Bayesian-Optimized Binary Coordinate Ascent and Chi-Square Feature Selection
authors: Guilbert Nicanor Abiera Atillo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Feature selection reduces dimensionality, mitigates overfitting in sentiment classification, and addresses challenges associated with processing text data. To overcome these challenges, hybrid feature selection models have recently been explored. This study integrated Bayesian Optimization into Binary Coordinate Ascent (BCA) to enhance feature selection and improve sentiment classification performance, specifically for prolife vs. pro-choice sentiment analysis using the Naïve Bayes classifier. The performance of the combined Chi<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> feature selection with the hybrid BCA-Bayesian Optimization is evaluated across various n-gram configurations. Results indicate notable improvements in both accuracy and recall compared to conventional methods. The enhanced model achieved an accuracy of 93.80% with unigrams and a recall of 100% with four-grams, surpassing the conventional Chi2-BCA hybrid approach. Although the Chi<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>-BCA method exhibits lower computational complexity, the Bayesian Optimization-enhanced model demonstrated superior classification performance. This study highlights the trade-off between efficiency and accuracy and recommends Bayesian Optimization as a valuable enhancement to feature selection. Further research is encouraged to evaluate this approach with other classification models to improve sentiment analysis on complex societal issues such as abortion.

title: Parallel Optimization of NTT for Kyber Key Encapsulation Mechanism Using GPU-Accelerated Plantard Arithmetic
authors: Muhammad Asfand Hafeez, Wai-Kong Lee, Arslan Munir, Seong Oun Hwang
abstract: CRYSTALS-Kyber is a key encapsulation mechanism that has been standardized by the National Institute of Standards and Technology. Number theoretic transform (NTT) is used to compute the polynomial multiplication in Kyber, which is also the main performance bottleneck. In this letter, a GPU-optimized implementation of Plantard arithmetic intended for improving the performance of NTT is introduced. Various techniques are proposed to avoid warp divergence and expensive division in Plantard arithmetic, thus achieving a faster implementation. Experimental outcomes reveal performance improvements of 6.57%, 6.88%, and 6.76% for NTT, as well as 2.18%, 2.67%, and 3.24% for inverse NTT (INTT), when compared to Lee et al., for Kyber-512, Kyber-768, and Kyber-1024, respectively. These results underscore the efficient and scalable implementation of Kyber, rendering it particularly suitable for the Internet of things platforms where high throughput and moderate latency is imperative.

title: Interpretable Individual Manatee Identification using Sketch Images and Deep Neural Networks
authors: Zhiqiang Wang, Sheri L. Barton, Jennifer H. Johnson, Yi He, Xingquan Zhu
abstract: Individual manatee identification is crucial for understanding their behaviors, traits, threats, population health, etc. Traditional methods rely on photo-identification, which entail extensive expert efforts during and after the field studies. These efforts include drawing sketches that highlight the scars and mutilations of documented individuals, as manatees often sustain injuries from encounters with boats, fishing gear, and other hazards, leaving unique scars or mutilations on their bodies. Despite using strategies to narrow down possible results, identifying an individual manatee from a database containing tens of thousands of sketches remains a challenge. Traditional image-by-image search methods struggle with the uniformity of these sketches, which are derived from a standard template and contain arbitrarily shaped regions in a low-resolution and monochromatic format. In this paper, we propose a deep neural network (DNN)-based framework leveraging Region-based Convolutional Neural Network (R-CNN) to explicitly learn and extract markers from sketch images and further employ makers to fulfill image search and matching. Unlike other DNN methods, our approach is fully transparent and interpretable, through representing markers as polygons and carrying out matching based on the overlaps between polygons. Benchmark experiments on real-world sketch images substantiate that our approach significantly outperforms existing baseline methods, achieving a Top-1 accuracy of 0.3205, and improving Top-5 and Top-10 accuracies to 0.4872 and 0.6026, respectively. This advancement showcases the potential of using DNNs for effective identification of individual manatees for conservation studies.

title: Measurements of thermal resistance between metallic surfaces for high current HTS Cable-in-Conduit Conductor
authors: S. Severo, L. Savoldi, K.-P. Weiss, N. Bagrets
abstract: High Temperature Superconductors (HTS) are promising candidates for high current Cable-In-Conduit Conductors (CICCs) for large high-field magnets. In many cases, these CICCs are made from stacks of several HTS tapes. This work focuses on the thermal contact resistance in various metal to-metal interfaces among tapes and between tapes and surrounding materials. Three main configurations were examined: soldered tapes, unsoldered tapes, and braided copper structures wrapped around the HTS tapes (BRAST). Samples were tested in a controlled cryogenic environment, from 6 K to 300 K, under applied forces ranging from 50 N to 200 N. The analysis reveals that thermal contact resistance plays a prominent role at low temperatures and can be reduced by increasing the applied force. For soldered tapes, an additional reduction in thermal contact resistance was observed after the removal of surface oxides. Unsoldered tapes, by contrast, showed higher sensitivity to contact pressure, pointing to the importance of precise mechanical alignment. These observations highlight the importance of interface quality, contact characteristics, and surface preparation in minimizing thermal contact resistance in HTS cables. By varying the temperature and applied force during measurements, it was possible to characterize the distinct contributions from each interface type, offering valuable insights for improving thermal performance in superconducting systems operating at cryogenic temperatures.

title: Uncertainty-Guided Adaptive Correction for Semi-Supervised Medical Image Segmentation_supp1-3636145.pdf
authors: Lyuyang Tong
abstract: Consistent perturbation strategies have emerged as a dominant paradigm in semi-supervised medical image segmentation. Nevertheless, prevailing approaches inadequately address two critical challenges: (1) prediction errors induced by data uncertainty from distribution shifts, and (2) loss instability caused by model uncertainty in parameter generalization. To overcome these limitations, we propose an Uncertainty-Guided Adaptive Correction (UGAC) framework with three key innovations. First, we develop a dual-path uncertainty rectification mechanism that employs normalized entropy measures to detect error-prone regions in unlabeled predictions, followed by bilateral correction through confidence-weighted fusion. Second, we introduce adversarial consistency constraints that leverage labeled data to discriminate authentic segmentation patterns, effectively regularizing uncertainty propagation in unlabeled predictions through spectral normalization. Third, we architect a frequency-aware segmentation backbone through our novel Freqfusion module, which performs adaptive spectral decomposition during feature decoding to explicitly disentangle high-frequency (boundary-aware) and low-frequency (structural) components, thereby enhancing anatomical boundary sensitivity. Comprehensive evaluations on MM-WHS, BUSI, M&Ms and PROMISE12 datasets demonstrate UGAC’s superior performance. The proposed framework exhibits robust generalizability across CT, MRI, and ultrasound modalities, while achieving significantly lower computational complexity than baseline UNet implementations. The code will be available at https://github.com/SIGMACX/UGAC.

title: Multi-Functional Antenna–Filter/Polarization Converting–Antenna Metamaterial Featuring Wideband Tx/PC/Rx Behavior
authors: Zhefei Wang, Chao Li, Jianqiang Hou, Qingsheng Zeng, Jiahui Fu, Mingxin Song, Lixin Ran, Tayeb A. Denidni
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper presents a multifunctional metamaterial based on an antenna-filter/polarization converting-antenna (A-F/ PC-A) module array, that could provide ultra-wideband transmission (Tx), polarization conversion (PC), and reflection (Rx) responses for two polarizations through six active modes. Reconfigurable receiving and radiating antenna arrays are elaborately designed to enable this system could operate under arbitrarily linear polarized waves. Moreover, to further facilitate the polarization manipulation between the receiving and radiating antennas arrays, while providing a good impedance matching for each operating mode, an improved active filter array with strong coupling mode and PC mode is proposed. Attributing to the proposed second-order structure, high-transmittance windows (the minimum insertion loss is 0.1 dB) with a −3 dB fractional bandwidth of 66.7% are realized in the Tx mode. Within this passband, the polarization characteristics and transmission state of the incidence electromagnetic wave can be flexibly modulated. In the PC mode, the relative bandwidth with a polarization conversion rate (PCR) of more than 90% reaches 55.6%. When switching to Rx mode, the structure acts as an effective electromagnetic shield with the transmission coefficient below -10 dB throughout the operating band. Finally, a prototype is fabricated for measurements, and the calculated, simulated, and measured results validate the proposed design.

title: Design and Quasi-Static Analysis of a Multidirectional Bending Fiber-Reinforced Soft Pneumatic Actuator_supp1-3630039.docx
authors: Jianzheng Wei
abstract: Soft pneumatic actuators (SPAs) have demonstrated significant advantages in unstructured environments due to their geometrically nonlinear deformations characterized by large deflections, high strain, and curvature. However, existing SPA designs predominantly exhibit unidirectional actuation or require mechanical transmissions for multidirectional bending actuation, which restricts their operational flexibility. To solve this limitation, this article proposes a multidirectional bending fiber-reinforced soft pneumatic actuator (MDB-FRSPA), and studies its deformation response characteristics under multiple pneumatic boundary conditions. We establish a response surface model for free-end contact force characterization in the MDB-FRSPA. A moment equilibrium-based quasi-static modeling approach is proposed for investigating the correlation between bending angles and internal pressures across varying pressurization states. Building upon this foundation, an experimental testbed is established for validation analysis. The experimental results demonstrate that the contact force output and deformation response characteristics under varying pressure conditions closely align with both finite element method results and theoretical predictions. Experimental validation confirms enhanced adaptability and operational stability of the three-mode flexible gripper with self-reconfigurability composed of MDB-FRSPA s during complex grasping tasks.

title: Static and Dynamic Event-Triggered Control for Disturbed Interconnected Systems Through Adaptive Critic Designs
authors: Ding Wang, Zeqiang Yuan, Ao Liu, Qinna Hu, Junfei Qiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This article develops decentralized static and dynamic event-triggered control (ETC) strategies for continuous-time (CT) nonlinear systems featuring unmatched external disturbances and matched interconnections. Both static and dynamic ETC schemes can be used separately to alleviate the computational load and communication resources. The proposed static and dynamic event-triggering conditions differ from existing approaches in terms of condition design and stability proof. The static event-triggered mechanism (ETM) relies solely on the system state, whereas the dynamic ETM integrates the system state with an internal variable derived from a differential equation. The decentralized event-triggered (ET) controller is established for the large-scale system, which is comprised of many ETC policies for each individual subsystem. Based on the critic-only architecture, the optimal policies are obtained within the adaptive critic framework by solving the relevant ET Hamilton–Jacobi–Isaacs (HJI) equation. Specifically, the weight vectors of critic neural networks (NNs) are updated using a novel gradient descent strategy with momentum. Finally, the effectiveness of the developed method is validated through two simulation examples.

title: HMAT: A Meta-Path Based Heterogeneous Graph Neural Network for Large-Scale Cellular Localization
authors: XiChao Yang, Kun Zhao, KeXin Yang, XueTing Mao
abstract: With the large-scale commercial deployment of fourth-generation (4G) and fifth-generation (5G) networks, cellular-based localization has emerged as a cost-effective solution for Internet of Things (IoT) applications. However, existing methods face two critical challenges: input sparsity and dimensionality explosion due to the exponential growth of Base Stations (BSs) in wide-area scenarios, and underutilization of diverse cellular signal parameters. To address these issues, we propose a Heterogeneous Graph Neural Network (HGNN)-based framework for seamless large-scale cellular localization. First, we model cellular associations as a heterogeneous graph of User Equipments (UEs) and BSs, bypassing fixed-dimensional input constraints inherent to conventional input form. This graph also explicitly utilizes cell-type relationships and topology features to enhance structural expressiveness. Then a dynamic pruning strategy is introduced to remove spatial irrevelent nodes, reducing structural noise. Further, meta-paths with explicit semantics are designed to constrain information propagation with interpretable spatial-semantic rules. Building on this graph, we propose a Heterogeneous Multi-feature enhanced graph ATtention network (HMAT) to fully utilize diverse features in the graph across metapaths for accurate and robust coordinate regression. Additionally, we introduce a lightweight variant, L-HMAT, with fewer parameters and zero-shot localization capability in new regions. Extensive experiments on three real-world cellular network datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms current state-of-the-art methods on large-scale cellular data.

title: A Physics-Informed Dual-Branch Neural Network for Scattering from 3D Dielectric Objects
authors: Ze-Lin Li, Bi-Yi Wu, Kun-Yi Guo, Xin-Qing Sheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: The scattering center (SC) model provides a compact, physically interpretable, and efficient representation of electromagnetic (EM) scattering by approximating the total field as a superposition of dominant contributors characterized by location, amplitude, and phase. However, extending the SC model to three-dimensional (3D) dielectric objects remains challenging due to complex scattering mechanisms inherent to 3D dielectric objects. This paper presents a physics-informed dual-branch convolutional learning (PhiDCL) neural network for efficient, accurate, and interpretable EM scattering from arbitrarily shaped 3D dielectric objects. The proposed approach employs a dual-branch convolutional neural network (CNN) to learn the real and imaginary components of the complex scattering weights associated with equivalent scattering centers. By incorporating wavelength-scale geometric embedding and directional feature encoding, the network captures physically meaningful scattering behaviors while requiring only a limited set of full-wave simulations for training. Extensive validation on canonical and realistic objects, including cones, cubes, SLICY-like structures, and UAVs, demonstrates that PhiDCL achieves accurate radar cross-section (RCS) predictions with consistently low mean absolute errors (typically below 1 dB) across different geometries, material parameters, and incident angles. Compared with traditional numerical full-wave methods, it improves the computational efficiency by more than two orders of magnitude. The resulting parametric model serves as a scalable surrogate for rapid RCS estimation, target recognition, and inverse scattering analysis, enabling real-time EM signature prediction in resource-constrained applications.
