title: A Multi-Mode Step-Up/Down Hybrid Converter With Always Reduced Inductor Current for USB PD 3.1 Standard in EV Applications
authors: Yinglyu Xiong, Yong Zhou, Ruichen Wang, Zehao Tao, Xun Liu, Ka Nang Leung
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: This paper presents a step-up/down hybrid converter for USB power delivery (PD). The proposed converter features a wide range of voltage conversions similar to the conventional four-switch buck-boost converter (FSBBC). Compared with the FSBBC, the average inductor current of the proposed converter is decreased to a certain extent for all operation modes, reducing the power loss caused by dc resistance (DCR) of inductors. Additionally, the transfer function of the proposed converter demonstrates that the right-half-plane (RHP) zero is pushed to a higher frequency in boost mode compared to FSBBC, simplifying compensator design for voltage-mode control. Moreover, the proposed converter is adaptable to the new USB PD 3.1 standard and the maximum output power is configurable up to 240 W (i.e., 48 V/5 A). Detailed dc analysis, small-signal modeling, loss analysis, and overall circuit implementation of the proposed converter are also included in the paper. Measurement results verify the effectiveness and performance of the proposed converter. A peak efficiency of 96.8% is achieved when the converter operates in light boost mode at 1.5-A load current.

title: StableV2V: Stabilizing Shape Consistency in Video-to-Video Editing_supp1-3639307.pdf
authors: Dong Liu
abstract: Recent advancements in generative artificial intelligence have significantly promoted content creation and editing, where prevailing studies further extend this exciting progress to video editing. These studies mainly transfer the inherent motion patterns from the source videos to the edited ones, where they often produce inferior results with inconsistency to user intentions, especially when shape changes between the edited and original objects might occur, due to the lack of particular alignments between the delivered motions and edited content. To address this limitation, we present a shape-consistent video editing method, namely StableV2V. Our method decomposes the entire editing pipeline into several sequential procedures, where we first edit the initial video frame, then simulate the shape-aware alignment between the delivered motions and edited sequence, and propagate the edited content to all other frames based on such alignment. Furthermore, we curate a testing benchmark, namely DAVIS-Edit, to offer a comprehensive evaluation of video editing, considering various types of prompts and difficulties. Experimental results and analyses illustrate the superior performance, visual consistency, and inference efficiency of our proposed method compared to existing state-of-the-art video editing studies.

title: Improved DBT Image Quality for Breast Cancer Detection Using Fuzzy Weighted Median Filtering
authors: Slamet Riyadi, Qodri Aziz, Sunardi, Anggita Putri Kantilaras, Yessi Jusman, Muhammad Abdul Haq, Siti Noraini Binti Sulaiman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Still a major cause of cancer-related death among women worldwide is breast cancer. Early detection is essential to improving survival rates, and it relies heavily on digital breast imaging for effective screening and diagnosis. Low resolution, distortions, and noise often damage the quality of these photographs, therefore affecting the correct interpretation. We propose an approach to enhance digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) images using advanced filtering and enhancement techniques. We used three techniques—BD, TVM, and FWMF—to enhance image clarity while preserving essential characteristics. We measured MSE, PSNR, and CNR to see how well these methods worked. The results indicate that FWMF achieves the lowest MSE (0.000030), the highest CNR (29.36), and the best PSNR (45.76 dB) among alternative approaches. These results indicate that FWMF is the best way to raise the quality of DBT pictures, therefore increasing the accuracy of detection and diagnosis of breast cancer.

title: Traffic Flow Prediction Model Based on Algorithm Optimization in Intelligent Traffic Monitoring
authors: Jian Li
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: The efficiency of intelligent traffic monitoring system depends on the accurate prediction of traffic flow, which is of great significance to traffic management and planning. Traditional statistical models have limitations in dealing with nonlinear characteristics and complex traffic patterns, while modern machine learning and deep learning models can effectively improve the prediction accuracy. However, the existing models still have shortcomings in prediction accuracy and convergence speed. This article proposes a traffic flow prediction model optimized based on Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) algorithm. By introducing attention mechanism, bidirectional LSTM structure, and Dropout mechanism, combined with grid search method to optimize parameter combination, the model's generalization ability and prediction accuracy are further improved. The experimental data comes from real-time traffic flow records, weather data and special event data of a city traffic management department. The experimental results show that the mean square error (MSE) of the optimized LSTM model is reduced by 26% compared with the traditional LSTM model, and the convergence speed is increased by about 29%, showing higher prediction accuracy and stability. The model shows high accuracy in regular time periods such as morning and evening peak hours on weekdays.

title: Understanding Effects and Advantages of Artificial Intelligence ChatGPT's for Higher Education Students
authors: Fikri Faiq, Muhamad Kevin Iqzad, Dedy Syamsuar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: The deployment of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in the field of education has attracted substantial interest, with AI-powered technology such as ChatGPT transforming learning experiences. This study examines the determinants that affect students' Behavioral Intention (BIU) AI tools, focusing on Perceived Usefulness (PU), Perceived Intelligence (PIE), Perceived Ease of Use (PEU), Perceived Trust (PTT), and Technology Anxiety (TA). Using SEM-PLS, data from 303 university students were analyzed to evaluate measurement and structural models. The findings suggest that PIE and PU significantly impact BIU, suggesting that students adopt AI tools when they perceive them as intelligent and beneficial. Technology Anxiety (TA) (β = 0.160, p < 0.001) also plays a role. However, PEU and PTT were insignificant, indicating that the variables are not primary determinants of AI adoption among students. These results enhance the existing literature on the adoption of AI technologies, challenging traditional technology acceptance factors and emphasizing the importance of AI's perceived intelligence and usefulness.

title: Digital Technology Adoption and Digital Literacy: The Support Factors for Entrepreneurial Intention
authors: Bernaldo Valentino, Alvien Leosan Ramli, Doni Purnama Alamsyah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: IT developments support efforts to increase interest in entrepreneurship through digital technology adoption and good digital literacy. In line with the problem phenomenon, this study aims to examine the influence of digital technology adoption and digital literacy in supporting the increasing students' entrepreneurial intention with the mediation of self-efficacy. The research was carried out with a survey of students in the city of Bandung (Indonesia) to measure entrepreneurial intention. There were 268 students who were asked via an online questionnaire and analyzed using SmartPLS. There is a research model that is tested in two stages (PLS Algorithm and Bootstrapping Process), and analysis is carried out according to research hypothesis testing. The research results found that digital technology adoption and digital literacy were able to support positive student self-efficacy. Digital technology adoption plays an important role in increasing student abilities (self-efficacy). It was directly found that self-efficacy and digital literacy were able to support increasing students' entrepreneurial intentions. The model study found that there was good mediation from self-efficacy in supporting the relationship between digital literacy and student entrepreneurial intention. It is known that the importance of digital technology adoption during study is for student self-efficacy and good digital literacy to support student initiatives to become independent entrepreneurs after graduating.

title: A Model for Utilizing a Global Capstone Course to Strengthen International Humanitarian Engineering Programs
authors: Adithya Jayakumar, Patrick Sours
abstract: Humanitarian engineering (HE) courses which involve travel have been offered at US universities for many years. When implemented thoughtfully these courses have the potential to have a significant impact on both community and student learning outcomes. At The Ohio State University, a multi-year human centered design approach was implemented across these courses with the intention of centering the community's wants, expectations, and voices. However, ensuring positive community impact can be challenging. One significant challenge is project continuity and maintaining relationships with the community throughout the year. To help address this, a partnership between HE courses which involve field experiences and a two-semester engineering capstone course, the Global Capstone Design Sequence, was established. Results from this collaboration have shown positive impacts on the relationship with the community, improved quality of student project work, an increase in student motivation, and gains in student intercultural competency. This paper documents the structure of this partnership and the lessons learned. Additionally, to assess the impact of this partnership on student intercultural competence, an analysis of Intercultural Development Inventory (IDI) scores is performed. The overarching aim of this paper is to continue to shift HE centric programs and projects towards parity in community and student outcomes.

title: Developing and Leveraging Project Management Frameworks to Maximize Impact in Undergraduate Humanitarian Engineering Practice
authors: Paul Kupfer
abstract: Clemson Engineers for Developing Communities (CEDC) is a Humanitarian Engineering signature service program at Clemson University that addresses domestic and international humanitarian issues. To ensure success over a variety of projects, CEDC has developed project management initiatives to streamline project development, including creating two project lifecycles managed inside a hierarchical organizational structure.

title: Impact of Electrolyte Thickness and Ionic Conductivity on the Electrochemical Performance of Solid-State Lithium Batteries: A 1D Modeling Study
authors: Ahmad Rahhal, Abdallah Berrouk, Ahmed Al Hajaj, Dirar Al Homouz
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Solid-state lithium batteries (SSLBs) are a promising next-generation energy storage solution due to their enhanced safety and potential for high energy density. However, the electrolyte thickness critically affects the electrochemical performance of these batteries, especially under high-rate operation. In this study, a one-dimensional, isothermal model was developed to investigate the impact of electrolyte thickness variations (5 μm, 25 μm, 45 μm, 65 μm, and 85 μm) on discharge behavior across different C-rates (1C and 2C) and ionic conductivities (0.02 S/m and 1 S/m). Simulation results demonstrate that increased electrolyte thickness leads to higher ohmic polarization, faster voltage decay, and reduced delivered capacity, particularly under fast discharge conditions. Furthermore, higher ionic conductivity effectively mitigates these losses, enabling thicker designs without severe performance penalties. These results provide important insights into the design optimization of solid-state battery architectures, highlighting the trade-off between mechanical robustness and electrochemical efficiency.

title: Live Streaming and Its Effect on Impulse Buying in Indonesian Fashion Electronic Commerce
authors: Angelica Hana Verontyna, Devyano Luhukay, Danang Prihandoko
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: This study investigates the impact of live streaming on Indonesian e-commerce buyers' impulse buying behavior in the fashion product category, with a focus on critical aspects in information systems and management. The research explores the impact of live streaming on impulse buying behaviour in terms of e-commerce, employing the SOR framework to examine the relationship between interface design, responsiveness, visibility, and metavoicing (Stimulus), perceived usefulness and immersion (Organism), and impulse buying behaviour (Response). 424 survey data from active Indonesian e-commerce consumers who had watched live streaming while buying for fashion items within the previous three months were used in this quantitative study. Using SmartPLS 4.0 to analyse the data, the findings suggested that immersion which is impacted by visibility and metavoicing had a greater direct impact on impulse purchase behavior than perceived usefulness. Researchers and industry professionals can learn a lot from this study about how technology-enabled retail spaces and customer behavior patterns are related.

title: Research on Line Loss Anomaly Detection and Loss Reduction Algorithm in Low Voltage Substation Area Based on Local Outliers
authors: Quan Yao, Xiaojun Li, Nan Song, Pengfei Sun, Tongfei Cui
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: In order to solve the problem that it is difficult for traditional methods to accurately identify abnormal line losses, this study proposes a line loss anomaly detection algorithm based on local outliers. By calculating the local density or distance of data points, the algorithm can effectively identify abnormal points which are significantly different from most data points, and provides a new means for line loss management. In the experimental verification stage, this paper selects the real line loss data set of low voltage station area, and makes a comprehensive test and evaluation of the algorithm. The results show that the algorithm performs well in key indexes such as accuracy and recall, and can accurately identify abnormal points in line loss data. The loss reduction strategy based on the experimental results has achieved remarkable results in practical application, effectively reducing the line loss rate and improving the operation efficiency of the power grid. This research method enriches the theoretical research of line loss anomaly detection, and also provides practical guidance for line loss management in power enterprises. The research conclusion shows that the line loss anomaly detection algorithm based on local outliers has high practical value and application prospect.

title: Overhead-Aware Resource Management Framework for Multi-RIS-Assisted Wireless Networks
authors: Jihyung Kim, Junyoung Son
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) is emerging as a key technology for future wireless networks by intelligently controlling the propagation environment. However, most existing research overlooks the considerable control overhead associated with reconfiguring RISs, which can limit their practical performance. In this paper, we propose a resource management framework for multi-RIS environments that explicitly accounts for the practical control overhead. The proposed framework features a two-timescale approach and a new objective function, the weighted sum-rate efficiency, which explicitly incorporates the costs of RIS selection and tile-phase updates. Furthermore, a hysteresis mechanism is introduced to mitigate excessively frequent reconfigurations. Simulation results indicate that the proposed framework consistently shows improved cost-aware efficiency compared to conventional schemes, offering a favorable trade-off between spectral efficiency and update rates.

title: Study of a 100 kW Photovoltaic System Using the Sandia Array Performance Model (SAPM): Experimental Validation and Results Analysis
authors: Hemza Medoukal, Farid Hadjrioua, Antar Beddar, Djelloul Djafer, Khelifi Reski
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive modeling and simulation study of a 100 kW photovoltaic (PV) system using the Sandia Array Performance Model (SAPM). The simulation incorporates real-world data, including solar irradiance, ambient temperature, and measured DC/AC electrical quantities. SAPM, an empirical model developed for predicting PV array output, is employed to estimate DC power as a function of environmental variables. The simulation results are evaluated against experimental field measurements to assess the model’s predictive accuracy. The study demonstrates a strong correlation between measured and simulated outputs, with a mean power error of just 42.12 W. Further statistical validation using RMSE and MAPE confirms the reliability of the SAPM under real-world operating conditions, particularly for high-power PV systems deployed in harsh climates. These results provide critical insights into performance modeling and highlight environmental and system-level factors influencing energy yield. Ultimately, the findings contribute to the broader effort of optimizing large-scale PV systems through robust empirical modeling.

title: QuantumCry: The Engineering and Implementation of a Post-Quantum Ransomware
authors: Aniello Castiglione, Jacopo Gennaro Esposito, Vincenzo Loia, Alessia Maffei, Michele Nappi, Fabio Narducci
abstract: In recent years, the continuous evolution of malicious software (malware) has posed an increasingly significant threat to governments, research institutions, businesses, and military organizations. Numerous malware variants have been developed with the aim of exfiltrating sensitive information, compromising industrial infrastructure operations, or extorting money causing serious financial, reputational, and operational repercussions for the affected entities. Among the most widespread types of malware are rootkits, botnets, spyware, trojans, and ransomware. Many of these, despite posing a serious threat, rely on traditional asymmetric cryptographic primitives such as Key Encapsulation Mechanisms (KEMs) and Digital Signature Algorithms (DSAs), which are vulnerable to the advent of Quantum Computing. An attacker equipped with a sufficiently powerful quantum computer could employ algorithms such as Shor’s and Grover’s to derive private keys from public ones, thereby compromising the entire security model upon which these systems are based. Consequently, the transition towards post-quantum cryptographic algorithms becomes imperative in order to guarantee robustness and long-term resilience in such adversarial scenarios. In this context, this study proposes the design and implementation of a post-quantum ransomware/mal-ware, capable of successfully fulfilling its objectives even in the presence of an adversary with quantum capabilities. The malware leverages post-quantum cryptographic primitives, integrated with a decentralized, blockchain-based PKI infrastructure compatible with quantum-resistant algorithms, thereby ensuring the system’s resilience in a post-quantum cryptographic landscape.

title: NLP-Driven Emotion Recognition for Individuals with Impaired Speech
authors: Riya Jain, Fiona Keaney, Kanika Sood
abstract: Recent advancements in Natural Language Processing (NLP) and speech recognition have significantly enhanced human-computer interaction. However, these technologies often fails to serve people with speech impairments, creating persistent barriers to communication, education, and inclusion. The re-search introduces a humanitarian-focused NLP system designed to bridge this gap by integrating emotional recognition into the visual text processing pipeline. This system extracts text from images using Optical Character Recognition (OCR), classifies the emotional tone of the extracted content using sentiment analysis, and converts it into audible speech using Text-to-Speech (TTS) technology. This dual-layer processing particularly supports speech-impaired individuals by enabling them to access not only content but also the emotional tone, bridging criti-cal communication gaps. This project brings forward a more meaningful interactions with written content, particularly for those with impairments affecting literacy, vision, or cognitive processing.

title: Stepwise Question Rephrasing: Enhancing Long-Context Reasoning in Small-Scale Language Models
authors: Minyoung Kyoung, Hyungbae Jeon, Sungeun Park
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Small-scale language models (SLMs) offer practical advantages in efficiency and deployment cost, but they often struggle with long-context question answering (QA) tasks that require multi-hop reasoning over dispersed or implicit evidence. We present a lightweight and model-agnostic method that improves QA performance by dynamically rephrasing complex questions into stepwise subquestions, effectively guiding the reasoning process without additional training or architectural modifications. Experiments on the LongBench and LongBench v2 benchmarks demonstrate consistent improvements, achieving average gains of 2–5% and reaching up 10% in specific domains. We further validate the generalizability of our approach by applying it to two representative SLM families, LLaMA and GLM, observing consistent gains across both.

title: IV Curve Fitting Using Machine Learning Techniques and Low-Cost Technologies for Data Acquisition
authors: Jimmy Córdova-Villagomez, Manuel S. Alvarez-Alvarado, Ivan Endara Velez, Fernando Vaca-Urbano, Augusto Carpio Astudillo, Kevin García Gonzales
abstract: Developed countries have a clear advantage over developing nations due to greater access to modern technologies and stronger cognitive support from educators. Effective teaching strategies enhance information processing and reduce cognitive load, significantly influencing student achievement [1]. As the world confronts climate change, the development and adoption of renewable energy technologies becomes vital [2]. Among them, solar-photovoltaic (PV) technology stands out for its recent advancements [3]. However, its implementation in developing countries is limited by a persistent technological gap [4]. In Ecuador, approximately 3800 new electric engineers graduate every year, most of them without practical experience in testing renewable energy components, due to the lack of test benches in local Universities. Optimizing PV-system performance requires accurate measurement of electrical characteristics, particularly the current-voltage (IV) curve. This curve provides critical information on panel efficiency, aging, and environmental impacts, essential for effective design, maintenance, and system optimization. This study proposes a low-cost solution using an Arduino microcontroller connected to a custom electronic load circuit to vary panel voltage and measure current. A machine learning algorithm models the IV curve, while MATLAB handles control, data processing, and visualization through a Graphical User Interface. Results indicate that, even with basic hardware and software tools, efficient data acquisition and analysis are achievable. Machine learning significantly enhances IV curve modeling by enabling reliable, fast curve fitting based on historical data, offering a valuable tool for PV system monitoring in resource-limited countries. This system enables hands-on PV diagnostics in engineering labs and remote solar sites in developing countries

title: Multi-Task Face Attribute Detection with ResNet50 and MobileNetV3 Backbones in Faster R-CNN
authors: Vito Xavier, Raymond Dehenrich Susilo, Kenny Nathaniel, Abram Setyo Prabowo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Amid a rising interest in edge-based computer vision applications for customer analysis and marketing, this paper explores the application of a modified Faster R-CNN model for the multi-task object detection of age range, gender, and facial-expression classification from facial bounding boxes. Pre-trained ResNet50 and MobileNetV3 backbones were also implemented and compared to assess the trade-offs between computational efficiency and accuracy. Experiment results indicate that the effectiveness of multi-task models vary widely, ranging from about 50% lower to 60% higher than single-task models, depending on the specific classification task. MobileNetV3 generally produces better results in age and gender classification, while ResNet50 performs better in facial expression recognition. Furthermore, testing on images containing only a single individual shows a marked improvement in performance, indicating that reducing dataset complexity, such as limiting images to a single person, can improve model accuracy. Among these tasks, gender classification consistently achieves the highest performance, highlighting the greater difficulty in age and expression classification due to complex aging patterns and subtle facial expressions. Although limited in dataset quality, these findings confirm the model’s viability and practicality for real-time data collection and analysis on edge devices.

title: Commonsense Reasoning 2.0: Symbolic Approaches to Close the GPT-4 Gap
authors: Agustinus Bimo Gumelar, Nurwahyu Alamsyah, Derry Pramono Adi, Slamet Winardi, Adri Gabriel Sooai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) like GPT-4 excel at text generation but struggle with commonsense reasoning, often producing logically flawed or unsafe responses (e.g., "water is dry" or "bleach cures infection"). This paper introduces Commonsense Reasoning 2.0, a neuro-symbolic framework that integrates LLMs with structured knowledge bases (KBs) to enhance verifiability and explainability. The framework combines three components: knowledge grounding (anchoring outputs in axioms such as physics laws), constraint-based generation (eliminating infeasible inferences via logic rules), and interactive refinement (dynamically updating KBs through human-AI feedback). We address GPT-4's limitations in causal, temporal, and social reasoning and demonstrate how symbolic KBs such as Cyc and ConceptNet enforce logical constraints. The framework navigates scalability and interpretability trade-offs through modular design and LLM-driven rule synthesis. In contrast to rigid symbolic systems or purely statistical LLMs, our approach maintains generative flexibility while enhancing safety and transparency. We present a taxonomy of GPT-4 commonsense failures and a design blueprint for scalable hybrid systems. A qualitative evaluation using examples from CommonsenseQA and HellaSwag shows the system’s ability to reject flawed outputs. Plans for future quantitative benchmarking are outlined. We conclude that symbolic reasoning must be embedded into AI systems to move beyond surface-level fluency toward trustworthy understanding.

title: Data-Driven Product Segmentation for Sustainable Microbusiness Optimization
authors: Shafira Primawati Junaedi, Meysi Diwa Ashania, Intan Rahmatillah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: The rapid growth of retail sales data offers both opportunities and challenges for businesses in understanding customer behavior and optimizing operational strategies. This study addresses the issue of manual and intuition-based product categorization, which often leads to suboptimal pricing, inventory control, and marketing efforts. To overcome this, we implement and compare two unsupervised machine learning algorithms—K Means and Hierarchical Clustering—for segmenting products based on transaction patterns. Using a dataset consisting of one month of sales from a retail microbusiness, the study includes data preprocessing, algorithm implementation, and performance evaluation using three widely accepted metrics: Silhouette Score, Davies-Bouldin Index, and Calinski-Harabasz Index. The results indicate that K-Means with five clusters (K=5) yields more optimal segmentation in terms of compactness, separation, and overall cluster quality. These findings provide valuable insights for data-driven decision-making in microbusinesses, particularly in optimizing pricing strategies, stock management, and targeted marketing initiatives. This study shows that using machine learning is important not just for sorting data, but also for making smart plans in small retail stores. The findings can help build better tools for predicting customer behavior and creating tailored marketing approaches.

title: Design and Evaluation of an Android-Based Auto Lockscreen Application to Support Parental Control in Child Device Usage
authors: Annisa Hakimi Nasry, Teddyyanto Idrus Jamallulail, Immanuela Puspasari Saputro, Voice Esther Ticoalu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Excessive use of gadgets among children has raised concerns about the need for effective tools that assist parents in managing screen time. This study aims to design and evaluate an Android-based auto-lockscreen application to support parental control over children's device usage. The system was developed using the Rapid Application Development (RAD) methodology, which includes the phases of Analysis, Design, Prototyping, and Testing. Functional evaluation was conducted using black-box testing, while usability was assessed using the Questionnaire for User Interaction Satisfaction (QUIS). The questionnaire encompasses five major domains: screen design, ease of learning, system capabilities, clarity of information, and overall user reaction. A total of 21 parents participated as respondents during the application testing phase. Results show that the application achieved an average usability score of 4.20 out of 5.00, with the highest score found in the "overall reaction" domain (4.30). These results indicate that the application is effective, user-friendly, and meets the expectations of parents seeking digital supervision tools. Moreover, the use of RAD facilitated a user-centered development process that allowed for rapid iteration and feedback integration. This research offers a practical contribution to the design of adaptive and accessible parental control applications based on auto-lockscreen mechanisms for child device usage.

title: Structural Health Monitoring System and Providing Data to Control of Inteligent Building’s Power Systems
authors: Yaşar Nuri Sevgen, Azer A. Kasımzade, Furkan Günday, Magsad Novruzov, Emin Nematli, Berna Tunç
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Structural Health Monitoring is a process that involves the use of various sensing technologies to assess the condition of structures such as buildings and other infrastructures. The primary aim of Structural Health Monitoring is to detect changes in the performance of these structures over time and to provide data that can help ensure their safety and integrity. This study is mainly proposed six subsystem. The first subsystem consists of a structure of sensors, placed at selected points of the structure. Secondly, there is a data acquisition system to collect data from sensors. Third one is data transmission network. The fourth subcomponent is the data processing and analysis center, which is used to obtain meaningful information about the current state of the structure. Fifth, there is a decision support system designed to utilize analysis results to determine the necessary maintenance or intervention for the structure. And finally, there is a user interface that allows users to access the system, view reports, and monitor analysis results. This study also aims to send information to the structure’s electrical power system when it detects critical values from a structural stability perspective, triggering the power system to enter an emergency mode.

title: Financial Crimes on Social Media: Leveraging Large Language Models and Generative AI to Detect Ponzi Schemes in Indonesia
authors: Rizaldy Anggriawan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: The study used Large Language Models (LLMs) and generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) to detect Ponzi schemes on social media, which is becoming increasingly complex in this digital age. With the widespread use of the Internet and social media in Indonesia, Ponzi schemes have found an effective means of spreading and attracting new victims. In this context, the research develops a prototype application based on LLM and Generative AI that can detect signs of a Ponzi scheme in social media content. The research methods include collecting textual data from social media associated with Ponzi and non-Ponzi schemes, model training using prompt engineering techniques, and few-shot learning with LLM, specifically ChatGPT and OpenAI. The Python, Gradio, and OpenAI APIs were used to develop the application prototype, which facilitates the analysis of text and the classification of potential Ponzi schemes through clear reasoning. The research reveals that the developed application can detect indications of a Ponzi scheme with a 92% accuracy rate. This application’s effective performance marks an important advancement in using AI technology for public financial protection and adds new insights into financial fraud prevention to the academic literature.

title: Era of the Girl: Postfeminist Identity Construction Through #Girlhood Trend on TikTok
authors: Fiona Catleyana, Ezmieralda Melissa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: This article examines how identity is constructed through digital media by using an interdisciplinary approach that incorporates technology, culture, and gender studies. The study explores TikTok’s #girlhood, a trend that aims to redefine the performance of femininity as self-affirming rather than compliance with the patriarchal power structure. Through the portrayal of unabashed femininity and sisterhood, the trend contributes to shaping and negotiating the identities of young women online. This research utilizes a mix of quantitative content analysis and Multimodal Critical Discourse Analysis (MCDA) to assess how the TikTok trend represents postfeminist media culture sensibilities that frame personal choice as empowerment while reinforcing normative femininity. The results of this study reveal that the #girlhood trend does encourage young women to freely express their femininity, but simultaneously upholds constant bodily control and lifestyle regulation. This phenomenon suggests that young women’s identity is still mediated through adherence to a particular standard of femininity under the guise of empowerment, reflecting the complex realities of navigating the self in postfeminist digital culture.

title: User Experience Analysis of AI-Based Interview Platform for Job Seekers Using System Usability Scale and Concurrent Think Aloud
authors: Asrina Nur Anbiya, Dimas Angkasa Nurindra, Refi Sesilia Marizka, Sunardi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Rapid population growth and rising unemployment rates in Indonesia create intense competition among job seekers, emphasizing the importance of adequate interview preparation. AI-Based interview platforms, such as WawancaraAI, provide solutions through practice interviews. However, usability issues include users not paying much attention to the initial interview session guide and difficulty understanding the questions given by the AI. Besides the AI's inconsistency, it cannot adjust the answer, asks questions irrelevant to the context, and is less interactive. This research evaluates the usability and user experience of WawancaraAI using System Usability Scale (SUS) and Concurrent Think Aloud (CTA). The SUS questionnaire involved 100 respondents, resulting in a SUS score of 67.925 (marginal high), with the lowest scores indicating problems in technical support, platform consistency, and ease of use. Additionally, 30 participants in CTA sessions who performed six tasks revealed issues like unappealing presented instructions, no help features, difficulty understanding AI questions, and the AI’s inability to personalize questions based on user backgrounds. The study recommends improving interactive guidance, adding a help button, adding subtitles during interviews, and adding CV uploads for better personalization. This study combines two methodologies to improve the use of AI in the interview platform to support better job preparedness and provide additional knowledge for academics.

title: Loss Analysis and Load Dependent Efficiency Assessment of GaN-Based Frequency Converters
authors: Mohammad Sadegh Golsorkhi, Mohammad Sadegh Eslahi, Thomas Ebel
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Recent advances in wide bandgap semiconductors have positioned Gallium Nitride devices as a compelling alternative to conventional silicon and silicon carbide technologies in high-efficiency power conversion. This paper presents a detailed investigation into the power loss characteristics of GaN-based DC-AC inverters for motor drive applications. The study includes circuit-level simulations and thermal-electrical co-modeling. Switching behavior is analyzed using detailed waveform modeling, and the impact of gate drive parameters, parasitics. Furthermore, a system level loss analysis based on thermos-electrical models is carried out for the entire frequency converter. The variations of the loss components (rectifier, inverter and passives) with respect to the motor load and speed changes are investigated and the impact of cooling on conduction losses is highlighted. The results show that GaN devices significantly reduce total power losses compared to silicon-based solutions, particularly under light-load conditions where switching losses dominate. These findings establish GaN-based inverters as an efficient and scalable solution for next-generation motor drive applications.

title: Evaluating LSTM, GRU, and Transformer Architectures for Music Note Pattern Generation with Small MIDI Datasets
authors: Cristoval Neo Sasono, Brandon Salim, Kenneth Jayadi Yu, Feri Setiawan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: The application of deep learning in music generation has drawn significant interest, notably with architectures such as Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Gated Recurrent Units (GRU), and Transformers demonstrating strong sequence modeling capabilities. This study evaluates the effectiveness of these architectures in generating musical note patterns using a reduced dataset of 130 classical MIDI files, reflecting real-world constraints commonly encountered in Information Systems (IS) environments. To ensure comparability, models were trained under identical conditions and evaluated quantitatively through loss, accuracy, and F1 score, as well as qualitatively through visual inspection using MuseScore. The results showed that LSTM achieved the best overall performance, attaining the highest F1 scores across training durations (0.2176 at 10 epochs, 0.3726 at 15 epochs, and 0.6737 at 30 epochs). GRU exhibited faster training and comparable melodic generation, though with slightly lower metric performance. Transformer models, while powerful in data-rich contexts, performed poorly under small-data conditions, achieving low accuracy and slow convergence. This work adopts a Design Science Research (DSR) lens by treating these models as design artifacts and contributes to the IS domain through insights into lightweight, generative components for creative systems operating under resource limitations.

title: A Two-Phase Approach to Fault Detection in Power Systems Using Machine Learning
authors: J.S.S Aditya, Jie Sheng, Thillainathan Logenthiran
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Electrical faults in transmission lines are a critical concern in power systems, as they impact the stability and reliability of electricity distribution. Rapid fault identification and classification are essential for timely intervention and the prevention of larger systemic failures. To accurately detect and classify various types of electrical faults in transmission lines, this paper presents a two-phase methodology that combines advanced machine learning techniques to analyze simulated fault data and improve the overall fault detection process. Using advanced algorithms and comprehensive data analysis, our ultimate goal is to improve the efficiency of power distribution and significantly reduce risks associated with electrical failures, such as power outages and wildfires. With a sophisticated machine learning model built in our approach, simulation results show that the integration of machine learning techniques provides effective real-time fault detection, reduces downtime and improves power system stability.

title: A 92.1-dB SNDR Easy-Driving Two-Step NS-SAR-Based Incremental ADC With Concurrent Gain-Error Plus Noise Suppression
authors: Chenyang Li, Tzu-Han Wang, Dongsuk Kang, Ken Li, Xitie Zhang, Wei-En Lee, Visvesh S. Sathe, Shaolan Li
abstract: This article presents a two-step incremental analog-to-digital converter (ADC) that achieves high resolution and energy efficiency while substantially easing the input driving constraints and interstage gain variation. By employing a level-shifted sub-ranging architecture with an input-tracking (IT) feature, the design obviates direct input sampling, thereby significantly relaxing the demands on the input driver. A gain-error-and-noise suppression (GENS) technique further enhances robustness to interstage gain variation through compact and hardware-efficient switched-capacitor (SC) operations. The prototype ADC fabricated in a 65-nm CMOS achieves a 92.1-dB signal-to-noise-and-distortion ratio (SNDR) over a 50-kHz bandwidth. With fully dynamic operation, the power consumption is only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$44.8~{\mu }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>W, resulting in a Schreier figure-of-merit (FoM) of 182.6 dB. The proposed ADC demonstrates competitive performance for low-power, high-precision, and multiplexable sensing in wearable, implantable, and edge AI applications.

title: A 50 μ W/Gbps/Lane Power-Efficient MIPI D-PHY Receiver With Architecture-Level Adaptive and Structural Optimizations for Micro-Displays
authors: Haoran Zeng, Yingqi Feng, Tianai Li, Hang Ye, Zunkai Huang, Hui Wang, Li Tian, Yongxin Zhu, Qiliang Li, Yajun Ha
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: Achieving high power efficiency in Mobile Industry Processor Interface (MIPI) D-PHY receivers is crucial for micro-display chips in AR/VR systems, where stringent power constraints exist. However, existing designs often sacrifice power efficiency for higher data rates due to architectural limitations, neglecting optimization for low-power applications. To address this issue, we propose a receiver architecture that substantially enhances power efficiency through three key techniques. First, we improve the gain-bandwidth product (GBW) by employing an autonomous gain scheduling analog front-end (AFE) that dynamically tunes the gain while reducing drive current. Second, we reduce clocking overhead by introducing a self-monitoring interferometric deserializer that enables clock-free pre-scaling and halves the DDR sampling frequency. Third, we increase transition speed and minimize short-circuit power by utilizing a chaotic topological flow actuator (CTFA) with multi-path current feedthrough. Compared to prior state-of-the-art designs, the proposed receiver achieves a power efficiency of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$50~\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>W/Gbps/lane (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$42~\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>A/Gbps/lane), reducing power and current consumption by 46% and 45%, respectively, using a standard 180-nm process.

title: SDR-GAIN: A High Real-Time Occluded Pedestrian Pose Completion Method for Autonomous Driving
authors: Honghao Fu, Yongli Gu, Yidong Yan, Yilang Shen, Yiwen Wu, Libo Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: With the advancement of vision-based autonomous driving technology, pedestrian detection have become an important component for improving traffic safety and driving system robustness. Nevertheless, in complex traffic scenarios, conventional pose estimation approaches frequently fail to accurately reconstruct occluded keypoints, primarily due to obstructions caused by vehicles, vegetation, or architectural elements. To address this issue, we propose a novel real-time occluded pedestrian pose completion framework termed Separation and Dimensionality Reduction-based Generative Adversarial Imputation Nets (SDR-GAIN). Unlike previous approaches that train visual models to distinguish occlusion patterns, SDR-GAIN aims to learn human pose directly from the numerical distribution of keypoint coordinates and interpolate missing positions. It employs a self-supervised adversarial learning paradigm to train lightweight generators with residual structures for the imputation of missing pose keypoints. Additionally, it integrates multiple pose standardization techniques to alleviate the difficulty of the learning process. Experiments conducted on the COCO and JAAD datasets demonstrate that SDR-GAIN surpasses conventional machine learning and Transformer-based missing data interpolation algorithms in accurately recovering occluded pedestrian keypoints, while simultaneously achieving microsecond-level real-time inference.

title: Descriptor: Dataset for Power SYstem Forced Oscillation Responses (DPSYFOR)
authors: Deepak Joshi, Menuka KC, Habib Wajid, Vaithianathan Mani Venkatasubramanian
abstract: Wide-area oscillation events can cause severe disruption to energy production and delivery in power systems. The use of data-driven approaches for oscillation detection and source location is gaining significant attention in power system studies. However, such oscillation events are rare, and detailed system recordings are not publicly accessible. They are mostly anonymously shared with the community, which makes it challenging to study and analyze the different scenarios of forced oscillation events. The lack of detailed system recordings from oscillation events has been a serious shortcoming in developing data-driven methods for oscillation analysis. This work has created an extensive set of time-stamped forced oscillation datasets called “Dataset for Power SYstem Forced Oscillation Responses (DPSYFOR)” (pronounced decipher) using realistic power grid models to leverage data availability with a wide range of forced oscillation frequencies and sources. A reduced-order model as well as a large-scale validated model, depicting the system conditions of the August 10, 1996, blackout of the Western American power grid, have been used to generate the oscillation datasets. This resource will significantly support the development of data-driven algorithms, particularly machine learning approaches, which have demonstrated considerable potential in the power industry for event detection and classification. Researchers can also utilize these datasets to validate and tune the performance of their existing data-driven methods.

title: Integrated Digital Twin Systems in Mining Operations: A Holistic Review of the Current State, Challenges, and Future Prospects
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: This review provides a systematic synthesis of the current state, challenges, and future prospects of integrated digital twin systems in the mining industry. Utilizing a comprehensive search of major electronic databases, we analysed peerreviewed literature published from January 2009 to August 2025. The study highlights that while digital twins are increasingly adopted for siloed applications—such as optimizing individual machines or specific processes—their full potential as holistic, integrated, mine-wide systems remain untapped. Key challenges identified include the high cost of implementation, complex data integration, and a lack of skilled personnel and robust cybersecurity protocols. Looking ahead, the paper suggests that future development will involve merging digital twins with artificial intelligence and machine learning to enable advanced applications like predictive maintenance and real-time optimization of the entire mining value chain, ultimately leading to smarter, safer, and more sustainable operations.

title: Cost-aware AUC Optimization via Adaptive Kernel Density Estimation
authors: Peisong Wen, Qianqian Xu, Zhiyong Yang, Huiyang Shao, Linchao Zhang, Qingming Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: The Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristics Curve (AUC) is a widely used metric for evaluating model performance across all possible decision thresholds. Existing methods for AUC optimization typically assume a predefined parametric distribution of thresholds. However, the optimal decision threshold depends on the misclassification costs, which follow a non-parametric distribution. This motivates us to introduce a variant of AUC, termed Cost-aware AUC (CAUC), where the thresholds are conditioned on an empirically determined cost distribution. Unfortunately, as a bilevel problem, it is challenging to directly optimize the CAUC: 1) The inner problem of finding the optimal thresholds is non-convex, leading to potential issues with convergence; 2) The outer problem involves the derivative of False Positive Rate (FPR) w.r.t. the threshold, which is unavailable without an explicit formulation of threshold distribution. To address challenge 1), we utilize the convex relaxation technique to reshape the inner problem into a convex one. Facing challenge 2), we propose an adaptive kernel density estimation framework. Specifically, the derivative of FPR is considered an aggregation of various kernel functions. To avoid manually crafting the aggregation function, we propose a finite-difference-based stochastic algorithm to optimize the model without explicit aggregation function. Theoretically, the proposed algorithm enjoys a convergence rate of $\mathcal {O}(\epsilon ^{-4})$. Empirical studies across various datasets and cost distributions speak to the effectiveness and soundness of our framework.

title: Research on Multiphysics Coupling Characteristics in Transient Electromagnetic Emission Process Based on ALE Moving Mesh Technology
authors: Linbo Yan, Xinbo He, Bing Wei, Qian Yang, Linqian Li
abstract: Accurately and efficiently solving the physical characteristics of electromagnetic railguns is essential for understanding their dynamic behavior and ensuring reliable design. However, an effective real-time solution for the multiphysics coupling characteristics of electromagnetic railguns has yet to be proposed. This article develops a modified set of governing equations for electromagneticthermal coupling based on the arbitrary LagrangianEulerian (ALE) dynamic mesh framework and applies them to the transient electromagnetic launch process. Additionally, a hybrid meshing strategy combining sliding and dynamic meshes is introduced, where sliding meshes are utilized for the armature region and the rail sections in contact with the armature, while dynamic meshes are applied to the remaining rail sections. This approach effectively balances computational accuracy and complexity, enabling precise real-time solutions for the multiphysics characteristics of transient and high-speed models. To validate the proposed method, numerical results from static meshes, single-physics simulations, and the modified multiphysics coupling solution are compared with experimental data. The results demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed approach in achieving accurate and real-time multiphysics simulations of electromagnetic railgun launches.

title: Navigation of Robotic Swarmalators with Dynamics and Constraints
authors: Xinyue Xu, Wei Xiao, Steven Ceron
abstract: Swarmalator studies have enabled self-organized collective behaviors that emerge from dual spatial and temporal coupling, without relying on external inputs. These behaviors arise solely from attractive and repulsive interactions modulated by a few global parameters. Here, we treat the swarmalator model as a planner and study how several of the collective behaviors change in terms of space-phase organization when the agents are robots with vehicle dynamics and constraints: including omnidirectional, unicycle, and bicycle dynamics. Furthermore, we use the control barrier function method to guarantee that the collective can navigate around objects, through cluttered environments, and transport objects in between obstacles by exploiting global and local control methods. This work brings us closer to realizing large groups of robotic swarmalators, of heterogeneous dynamics, that can enable shape formation, navigation, and object manipulation in cluttered environments.

title: Weighted Threshold Anonymous Credentials With Redactable Fine-Grained Blind Signature for Auditable Lending System in Blockchains
authors: Xianrui Zhang, Jun Zhou, Zhenfu Cao, Xiaolei Dong, Jianting Ning
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Anonymous credentials are ideal for decentralized systems like blockchains, as they enhance privacy, security, and regulatory compliance while maintaining flexibility and adaptability. These decentralized systems often require features such as weighted threshold issuance and tracing for elasticity of decision-making, fine-grained blindness for user privacy control, and issuer-hiding to reduce potential external threats. However, the latest advancements in anonymous credential schemes cannot meet all of these essential properties for blockchain systems. To address these challenges, we propose weighted threshold anonymous credentials with redactable fine-grained blind signature (WTAC). Firstly, by leveraging unlinkable redactable signatures (URS) and functional encryption techniques, our redactable fine-grained blind signature supports selective disclosure and permits credential issuers to learn a particular function value related to the attributes during issuance without revealing the actual attribute content. Secondly, we utilize weighted ramp secret-sharing (WRSS) and randomizable signatures to achieve weighted threshold anonymous credentials, which are issuer-hiding to both users and verifiers. Moreover, we provide a concrete construction instantiated by the Fiat-Shamir paradigm and demonstrate its application, a privacy-preserving auditable lending system in blockchain scenarios, achieving the integration of user privacy and regulatory compliance. Finally, we give a formal security proof of anonymity, fine-grained blindness, traceability, non-frameability, and issuer-hiding. Performance evaluation shows the practicability and efficiency of our proposed WTAC.

title: Evaluation of Insulation Lifetime under Short Rise Time and High-Frequency Square Wave Voltages at Sub-Atmospheric Pressures
authors: Sai Pavan Kalakonda, Mushfiqul Abedin Khan, Mona Ghassemi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: The reliability of motor winding insulation in all-electric aircraft is paramount due to the extreme operational stresses encountered during flight. These stresses include exposure to high-frequency, high-slew-rate voltage pulses generated by (ultra) wide bandgap ((U)WBG) inverters and the varying sub-atmospheric pressures inherent to high-altitude environments. This study explores the influence of reduced atmospheric pressure on insulation lifetime under the application of rapid rise-time square wave voltages, focusing specifically on the susceptibility of motor windings to partial discharge phenomena in such conditions. A 1.5 kV bipolar square wave with a rise time of 50 ns was employed across a pressure range of 20 kPa to 101 kPa. Testing was conducted at three distinct frequencies to evaluate the role of frequency in insulation degradation and on different magnet wire configurations. Exponential data fitting was applied to model the relationship between atmospheric pressure and the degradation rate of insulation at different frequencies quantitatively. The results underscore the synergistic challenges posed by high-frequency, high-slew-rate voltage pulses and low-pressure environments, emphasizing the necessity for advanced insulation designs. These findings are critical for enhancing the reliability and safety of motor winding systems in all-electric aircraft operating under these demanding conditions.
