title: Autonomous Task Offloading of Vehicular Edge Computing With Parallel Computation Queues
authors: Sungho Cho, Sung Il Choi, Seung Hyun Oh, Ian P. Roberts, Sang Hyun Lee
abstract: This work considers a parallel task execution strategy in vehicular edge computing (VEC) networks, where edge servers are deployed along the roadside to process offloaded computational tasks of vehicular users. To minimize the overall waiting delay among vehicular users, a novel task offloading solution is implemented based on the network cooperation balancing resource under-utilization and load congestion. Dual evaluation through theoretical and numerical ways shows that the developed solution achieves a globally optimal delay reduction performance compared to existing methods, which is also validated by the feasibility test over a real-map virtual environment. The in-depth analysis reveals that predicting the instantaneous processing power of edge servers facilitates the identification of overloaded servers, which is critical for determining network delay. By considering discrete variables of the queue, the proposed technique's precise estimation can effectively address these combinatorial challenges to achieve optimal performance.

title: SplitFrozen: Split Learning with Device-Side Model Frozen for Fine-Tuning LLM on Heterogeneous Resource-Constrained Devices
authors: Jian Ma, Xinchen Lyu, Jun Jiang, Qimei Cui, Haipeng Yao, Xiaofeng Tao
abstract: Fine-tuning large language models (LLMs) on private, on-device data can empower tailored personalized AI agents. However, fine-tuning LLMs on resource-constrained edge devices faces significant challenges, including excessive computation overhead, device heterogeneity, and data imbalance. This article proposes SplitFrozen, a split learning framework that enables efficient LLM fine-tuning by strategically freezing deviceside model layers while centralizing parameter-efficient fine-tuning on the server. Our framework partitions LLMs into device-side frozen layers and server-side fine-tuning layers, where heterogeneous resource-constrained devices execute only forward propagation. To minimize server-side training costs, we integrate Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) into the server-side layers. A pipeline parallelism strategy further optimizes training efficiency by decoupling device-server computations and leveraging decomposed backward propagation. SplitFrozen can also implement differential privacy and compression techniques for privacy preservation and transmission reduction. Experiments on GPT-2 with the MRPC, MNLI-matched, and SST-2 datasets demonstrate that SplitFrozen outperforms FedLoRA and SplitLoRA by 69.4% model accuracy under extremely imbalanced data, while reducing up to 86.8% device-side computations and 50.2% total training time. Experiments also validate the scalability of SplitFrozen on content generation task using Llama-3.2 model on GSM8K dataset.

title: Direct-to-Cell: A First Look into Starlink's Direct Satellite-to-Device Radio Access Network through Crowdsourced Measurements
authors: Jorge Garcia-Cabeza, Javier Albert-Smet, Zoraida Frias, Luis Mendo, Santiago Andres Azcoitia, Eduardo Yraola
abstract: Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite mega-constellations have emerged as a viable access solution for broadband connectivity in underserved areas. In 2024, Starlink, in partnership with T-Mobile, began beta testing an SMS-only Supplemental Coverage from Space (SCS) service. This marks the first large-scale deployment of Direct Satellite-to-Device (DS2D) communications, allowing unmodified smartphones to connect directly to spaceborne base stations. This article presents the first measurement study of deployed DS2D technologies. Using crowdsourced mobile network data from the U.S. between October 2024 and July 2025, we provide evidence-based insights into the capabilities, limitations, and future evolution of DS2D technologies for extending mobile connectivity. We find a strong correlation between the number of satellites deployed, the number of unique cell identifiers measured, and the volume of measurements, concentrated in accessible areas with poor terrestrial network coverage, such as national parks and sparsely populated counties. Stable physical- layer measurements were observed throughout the period, with a 24-dB lower median RSRP and a 3-dB higher RSRQ compared to terrestrial networks, reflecting the SMS-only usage of the DS2D network during this period. Based on the SINR measurements collected, we estimate the expected performance of the announced DS2D mobile data service to be around 3 Mb/s per beam in outdoor conditions. We also discuss strategies to expand this capacity up to 18 Mb/s in the future, depending on key regulatory and business decisions, including allowable out-of-band emissions, permitted number of satellites, and availability of spectrum and orbital resources.

title: OsteoFGRNet: Osteopontin-driven Expression Profiling for Early Fetal Growth Restriction Analysis
authors: Cuihong Gao, Xueyan Shen, Mei Qiao, Rongjuan Yang, Shasha Pang, Zhimin Bian, Jianghui Sun, Lina Wang
abstract: Fetal growth restriction (FGR) poses a serious threat to maternal and neonatal health, and its early diagnosis remains a major clinical challenge due to the complex, heterogeneous nature of its biological mechanisms. In this study, we propose OsteoFGRNet, a novel computational framework designed for early FGR detection using osteopontin-driven gene expression profiling. Unlike conventional methods that rely on limited clinical markers or static models, our approach integrates domain-specific biological knowledge with a multimodal deep learning architecture to capture both temporal dynamics and molecular interactions. OsteoFGRNet features three key components: a hierarchical feature extraction pipeline tailored for high-dimensional omics data, an attention-driven module that highlights biologically relevant biomarkers and developmental windows, and a graph-based propagation mechanism that encodes pathway-level dependencies informed by osteopontin expression. We incorporate multi-task optimization and biologically constrained regularization to enhance model robustness and interpretability. Extensive experiments on four benchmark molecular datasets demonstrate that OsteoFGRNet consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of accuracy, precision, and recall, achieving up to 91.02% accuracy on the Prenatal Growth Restriction dataset. Ablation studies further confirm the effectiveness of each component in improving predictive power and biological relevance. Beyond prediction, the attention mechanism provides interpretable insights into osteopontin-associated regulatory processes implicated in FGR pathogenesis. These results underscore the potential of OsteoFGRNet as a clinically meaningful tool for early risk stratification and mechanistic investigation of FGR. This work contributes a domain-aligned, interpretable, and high-performance solution to a critical problem in maternal-fetal medicine and opens new directions for multi-omics integration in prenatal diagnostics.

title: Spectral-Guided Multiscale Feature-Aware Transformer for Hyperspectral Image Classification
authors: Zhenqiu Shu, Kexin Zeng, Yuyang Wang, Songze Tang, Zhengtao Yu, Liang Xiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Transformer-based methods have recently shown remarkable success in hyperspectral image classification (HSIC). However, their applications, in practice, still face two significant challenges. First, although the multihead mechanism in self-attention improves model robustness during training, it may overlook the continuity of spectral bands. Second, existing methods often struggle to effectively balance global and local information during multiscale feature extraction, limiting further improvements in classification performance. To address these issues, we propose a novel spectral-guided multiscale feature-aware Transformer (SMFAT) framework for HSIC. Specifically, a global low-rank spectral learning (GLSL) module is introduced to project hyperspectral image patches into a low-rank subspace, reducing spectral redundancy and capturing global spectral correlations. Furthermore, we introduce the multiscale feature-aware self-attention (MFASA) mechanism, which dynamically integrates fine- and coarse-grained features to enhance multiscale feature modeling. Finally, a spectral-guided fusion (SGF) module leverages the global spectral information extracted by the GLSL module to guide MFASA in more effectively capturing interspectral correlations and spectral continuity. This approach facilitates a more effective integration of spectral and spatial features in HSIs. Experiments on three well-known HSI datasets verify that the proposed SMFAT method significantly outperforms several state-of-the-art approaches in real-world HSIC tasks. The source code for this work is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/stellaZ77/SMFAT</uri>

title: A Semantic-Aware and Multi-Guided Network for Infrared-Visible Image Fusion
authors: Xiaoli Zhang, Liying Wang, Libo Zhao, Xiongfei Li, Siwei Ma
abstract: Multi-modality image fusion aims at fusing modality-specific (complementarity) and modality-shared (correlation) information from multiple source images. To tackle the overlooking of inter-feature relationships, high-frequency information loss, and the limited attention to downstream tasks, this paper focuses on efficiently extracting complementary in formation and aggregating multi-guided features. We propose a three-branch encoder-decoder architecture along with corresponding fusion layers as the fusion strategy. Firstly, shallow features from individual modalities are extracted by a depthwise convolution layer combined with the transformer block. In the three parallel branches of the encoder, Cross Attention and Invertible Block (CAI) extracts local features and preserves high frequency texture details. Base Feature Extraction Module (BFE) captures long-range dependencies and enhances modality-shared information. Graph Reasoning Module (GR) is introduced to reason high-level cross-modality relations and simultaneously ex tract low-level detail features as CAI's modality-specific complementary information. Experiments demonstrate the competitive results compared with state-of-the-art methods in visible/infrared image fusion and medical image fusion tasks. Moreover, the proposed algorithm surpasses the state-of-the-art methods in terms of subsequent tasks, averagely scoring 8.27% mAP@0.5 higher in object detection and 5.85% mIoU higher in semantic segmentation.

title: DGPE: A Dual-Stream Geometric-Aware Positional Encoding for Transformer-based Object Detection
authors: Han-Cheng Hsiang, Zunliang Yan, Yong Liu
abstract: Accurately modeling complex spatial relationships is a pivotal challenge for Transformer-based object detectors, as existing models often rely on static positional encodings that fail to capture dynamic, real-world scene layouts. To address this issue, this work proposes a novel Dual-stream Geometric-aware Positional Encoding (DGPE) method. The proposed method innovatively designs two parallel streams to decouple and synergistically learn the explicit geometric priors and implicit contextual associations. This fused information is then projected onto a lightweight network to generate a content-aware dynamic attention bias, which actively guides the self-attention mechanism. Experiments demonstrate that DGPE improves the Average Precision (AP) of a strong baseline model by 1.4% on the challenging MS COCO benchmark without any additional inference cost. Furthermore, the method exhibited excellent generalization in applications such as industrial defect detection and remote sensing analysis, achieving a significant 16.4% AP gain on the NWPU VHR-10 dataset. This work provides a novel and efficient pathway for enhancing the spatial reasoning capabilities of object detectors, with proven generalization to industrial and remote sensing applications. Our code and pre-trained models are publicly available at: https://github.com/Merrrci/DGPE.

title: A High-Speed Thermometry System Utilizing the Time-Stretch Effect Based on Cascaded FBGs
authors: Weihao Lin, Junjie Bai, Zihan Huang, Renan Xu, Yutong Liu, Mingkun Zhang, Fang Zhao, Li-yang Shao
abstract: This work presents a dual-point temperature sensing system capable of high-speed based on the photonic time-stretch dispersive Fourier transformation (TS-DFT) technique. The system aims to overcome the speed limitations of traditional optical spectrum interrogators. A sensing array consisting of two cascaded fiber Bragg gratings (FBGs) with a 5-meter separation is illuminated by a 50 MHz femtosecond laser source. The reflected spectrum, encoded with temperature information, is then stretched in time by propagating through a dispersion-compensating fiber (DCF) with a total dispersion of -360 ps/nm. This process enables the direct mapping of the optical spectrum into a measurable time-domain waveform at a 50 MHz repetition rate. Experimental results demonstrate the system’s capability to perform measurements over a broad temperature range from 40 °C to 250 °C. The temperature sensitivities of both FBGs were characterized to be 0.012 nm/°C in the optical wavelength domain. Correspondingly, the obtained time-domain sensitivities are -4.28 ps/°C and -4.31 ps/°C, with a temperature resolution of approximately 5.8 °C in the time domain. This study validates the feasibility of the TS-DFT scheme for high-speed dual-point sensing in demanding applications.

title: Federated Learning-based Distributed Data Completion in Sparse Mobile CrowdSensing
authors: En Wang, Baoju Li, Wenbin Liu, Zengyi Han, Cong Wang, Ximing Li, Jie Wu
abstract: Sparse Mobile CrowdSensing (SMCS) is an emerging distributed data collection framework. As one of the core methods,data completion uses the collected data to fill in the missing data. However, this approach inevitably poses significant privacy risks, since the traditional data completion methods require users' time and location information. In this paper, we propose a federated learning-based distributed data completion framework, which employs matrix factorization (MF) for local completion model training and federated learning to aggregate parameters of the MF model. This enables the construction of a global completion model without requiring private data, thereby mitigating privacy concerns. To address the challenges posed by the sparsity and asynchrony of distributed data, we incorporate time-aware deep neural network architectures with an asynchronous mechanism to enable federated training under irregularly gathered local data. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves high data completion accuracy while ensuring robust privacy protection.

title: Experimental Verification of a Planar Dual Meander Slot-Line Slow-Wave Structure for a Q-Band Traveling-Wave Tube
authors: Yuxin Wang, Duo Xu, Lixia Yang, Xiangbao Zhu, Yang Dong, Jingyu Guo, Jingrui Duan, Zhanliang Wang, Zhigang Lu, Shaomeng Wang, Yubin Gong
abstract: A planar dual meander slot-line (DMSL) slow-wave structure (SWS) for the Q-band (33–50 GHz) traveling-wave tube (TWT) is proposed and experimentally validated. The basic electromagnetic parameters of the SWS were calculated. The SWS circuit was designed, fabricated, and tested. Simulation results demonstrate flat dispersion characteristics and excellent transmission performance. The proposed SWS design features a simple assembly process and is compatible with mass-production. It comprises three key parts: a laser-cut double-layer molybdenum–rhenium (Mo–Re) sheet forming the meander grooves, upper and lower enclosures made of nickel–copper (Ni–Cu) alloy via computer numerical control (CNC) machining, and a Ni–Cu spacer layer fabricated by electric discharge machining (EDM). High-temperature hydrogen reduction and full-surface gold plating applied to the laser-cut Mo–Re sheets effectively reduce SWS transmission loss. Cold-test results show close agreement with simulations, demonstrating insertion loss of 0.058 dB/mm. Particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations reveal that the SWS achieves an output power of 65.8 W and a gain of 27.39dB at 39 GHz under 7.4 kV, 0.1 A electron beam parameters, with a 3-dB bandwidth of approximately 8 GHz.

title: Research and Application of Particle Swarm Optimization Based on MOEDO
authors: Zaiyu Zeng, Yunge Shen, Yuxie He
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: The research and application of Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) based on Multi-Objective Evolutionary Dynamic Optimization (MOEDO) aim to address complex optimization problems in dynamic environments. This paper first introduces the traditional PSO algorithm and its limitations, then elaborates on the method of applying MOEDO principles to PSO, proposing an enhanced hybrid algorithm. By incorporating dynamic adaptation mechanisms, this improved algorithm enhances PSO's performance in changing environments. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm performs excellently on various dynamic test problems, showing robustness and efficiency. Firstly, three core 13 specific indicators are determined. The normalization method is applied to process the data. Subsequently, the model is constructed, and the Multi-Objective Exponential Distribution Optimizer (MOEDO) is utilized to solve and optimize the model. Finally, a sensitivity analysis is conducted using the Sobol index. The results show that the particle swarm optimization algorithm optimized by MOEDO has the best effect, with the objective function value reaching 83.1777. The key parameter values are determined, and factors such as the tourism tax parameter and the proportion of environmental protection expenditure have a significant impact on the sustainable development of tourism. This study provides an effective tool for accurate evaluation and scientific decisionmaking for tourist destinations, helps balance the goals of economic, environmental, and social development, and holds important theoretical and practical significance for promoting the sustainable development of global tourism.

title: Performance Evaluation of Laravel Application Deployment on Docker
authors: Abiyoga Dhaniswara, Tien Fabrianti Kusumasari, Ekky Novriza Alam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: This study evaluates the performance comparison of Laravel framework-based application deployment in a containerised environment using the traditional PHP-FPM + Nginx architecture and the modern integrated FrankenPHP architecture with Laravel Octane. A Laravel 12.x test application was deployed in Docker containers, and its performance was measured using Apache JMeter on two API endpoints representing different data retrieval workloads. The primary metrics analysed include average response time, throughput, and CPU and memory resource utilisation. The results indicate that on the endpoint with a large data processing load, both deployment architectures exhibited low performance and reached the capacity limits of computational resources, suggesting the primary bottleneck resides at the application level. However, on the endpoint with a lighter workload per request, FrankenPHP significantly outperformed PHP-FPM + Nginx regarding response time and throughput, supported by percentile analysis showing more stable performance under peak load. Nevertheless, FrankenPHP was recorded to have higher memory consumption. This study concludes that FrankenPHP offers potential performance improvements for specific workloads in Laravel applications on Docker, but it is essential to consider the trade-off with memory usage. These findings provide empirical insights for developers and engineers when selecting deployment architectures.

title: Design of Transpose Convolution Layer on FPGA
authors: Jong Youn Lee, Jeong Yun Seo, Harim Lee, Yong Hwan Lee
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: With the rapid development of deep learning, transposed convolution has become important for tasks like image generation and resolution enhancement. However, it is hard to implement in hardware because one input affects multiple outputs, often with overlaps, and the kernel moves in a reverse direction compared to standard convolution. In this study, we designed a transposed convolution module using Verilog HDL, built with a modular and parallel structure. We implemented it on an FPGA and used advanced extensible interface to connect the Processing System and Programmable Logic. The hardware showed faster processing than software, especially as the clock frequency increased. This result shows the potential of hardware-based transposed convolution for building faster deep learning systems.

title: Design and Verification of A Single-Cycle RISC-V Core Using MATLAB Simulink
authors: Atakan Beyen, Sezer Memiş, Ramazan Yeniçeri
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Model-based hardware design approaches have gained traction due to their efficiency in prototyping and verification. This paper presents the design and verification of a single-cycle RISC-V core developed using a model-based design approach in the MATLAB Simulink environment. The core implements a fundamental subset of the RV32I instruction set and is converted into SystemVerilog code using HDL Coder. The generated HDL code is synthesized and tested on the Cora Z7 board, which features a Xilinx Zynq XC7Z010-1CLG400C FPGA. Verification is performed using HDL co-simulation and FPGA-in-the-Loop techniques through HDL Verifier. Test programs written in RISC-V assembly are executed, and the results are compared against the Simulink reference model, confirming functional accuracy across all stages. This work introduces a novel and fully integrated model-based methodology for RISC-V core design and hardware verification, which is not previously reported in the literature.

title: The Role of Chatbot Conversational Skill and Social Presence in Building Trust and User Engagement within E-commerce
authors: Dave Bryan Hutagalung, Shelvy Kurniawan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: The rapid adoption of chatbots in e-commerce has significantly transformed customer service by enabling instant, automated, and personalized interactions. However, the effectiveness of chatbots in building deep user engagement remains under-researched, especially in terms of the underlying psychological mechanisms. This study examines the influence of chatbot conversational skills on user engagement through social presence and trust. Data were collected through a survey of e-commerce users in Indonesia who recently interacted with a chatbot and also made a transaction within the last three months. Analysis using PLS-SEM or Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling shows that conversational skills have direct and indirect effects on trust and engagement, with social presence as an important mediator. These findings emphasize the importance of building social presence through responsive chatbot interactions to improve trust and user experience. Limitations of this study include the use of self-report data and the limited context of e-commerce users in Indonesia.

title: Adaptive Modeling and Modular Control of Asymmetric Twelve-Phase (4×3) PMSG
authors: Ahad Fatahi, Mohamed Fouad Benkhoris, Djamel Ziane, Mohamed Assaad Hamida
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Multiphase machines have emerged as a promising alternative to conventional three-phase systems in high-reliability and high-performance applications, including electric propulsion and renewable energy systems. This paper presents an advanced modeling approach for twelve-phase permanent magnet synchronous generators (PMSGs) that addresses the heavy cross-coupling limitations in conventional multi-star methods. The approach extends multi-three-phase PMSM modeling to a twelve-phase (4×3-phase) configuration with sinusoidal EMF, demonstrating effective DC voltage regulation in PWM rectifierfed DC networks. A key contribution is the seamless fault tolerance capability, where the system maintains stability under open-phase faults by dynamically reconfiguring the transformation matrix from twelve-phase to nine-phase (3×3-phase) operation through isolation of the defective winding module. The approach preserves modular control advantages using conventional three-phase converter structures while ensuring continuous operation under fault conditions, making it suitable for critical applications requiring high reliability.

title: A Comparative Study of Packet Capture Tools for Reliable Network Telescope Traffic Collection
authors: Shereen Ismail, Eman Hammad, Salah Dandan, William Hatcher, Ammar Alomari
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Reliable packet capture is a critical first stage in the data collection pipeline of passive monitoring environments such as network telescopes, forming the foundation for subsequent network forensic investigations and large-scale traffic analytics. This study compares five widely used packet capture tools: libpcap, tcpdump, xdpdump, netsniff-ng, and dpdk, in the context of Merit Network's /13 telescope infrastructure. The evaluation focuses on throughput, packet loss, system resource usage, and capture stability. To support this analysis, we developed an automation script that manages capture rotation, tracks system statistics, and performs health checks on resulting pcap files. Experimental results highlight the tradeoffs between lightweight, general-purpose tools and specialized frameworks optimized for high-performance environments. The findings provide practical guidance for selecting and deploying packet capture solutions that balance reliability, efficiency, and operational simplicity in long-running telescope deployments.

title: Beyond Coding: Human-Centered Design in Computer Engineering Senior Projects: Lessons from the NicaAgua App
authors: Allan Báez Morales, Qiuwen Li, Angela Musurlian, Iris Stewart-Frey, Nicolas Gibson
abstract: Engineering students often face challenges designing digital tools for underserved communities due to limited understanding of local user contexts, particularly in cross-cultural and remote settings. This study addresses that gap through a case study: the NicaAgua App, which started as a senior design project by computer engineering students for climate forecasting for smallholder farmers in Nicaragua. Drawing on five years of iterative development, the authors introduce a method based on five Human-Centered Design (HCD) action items tailored for the exploratory phase of digital humanitarian projects. These include stakeholder analysis, community context overview, user and problem definition, competitive analysis, and rapid prototyping. The approach helps students develop empathy and gather actionable insights to create impactful solutions. The case underscores the importance of early stakeholder engagement and outlines best practices and tools for collecting relevant information to define product requirements and functionalities for digital technologies for humanitarian senior design projects in remote communities.

title: Comparison of EfficientNetB1 and ConvNeXtTiny Models for Coronary Artery Disease Detection
authors: Desta Atikananda, Slamet Riyadi, Chayadi Oktomy Noto Susanto, Khairun Nisa, Qodri Aziz, Ika Tania Chaerani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) remains a leading cause of mortality worldwide, and early detection is essential to reduce the risk of severe cardiovascular events. This study presents a comparative evaluation of two modern deep learning models—EfficientNetB1 and ConvNeXtTiny—for automated CAD detection using Coronary Computed Tomography Angiography (CCTA) images. A total of 4,705 CCTA images from 500 patients were utilized, categorized into positive and negative classes. Preprocessing steps included image normalization, one-hot encoding, and data augmentation techniques such as rotation, flipping, and zooming. Both models were trained using transfer learning and fine-tuning strategies to enhance performance and generalization. The results show that EfficientNetB1 achieved the highest classification accuracy of 96.37%, with balanced precision and recall across both classes. In comparison, ConvNeXtTiny reached an accuracy of 94.66%, showing slightly lower performance but with the benefit of reduced computational cost and faster inference time. The findings indicate that EfficientNetB1 is more suitable when accuracy is prioritized, while ConvNeXtTiny is a viable alternative in resource-constrained clinical environments. This study contributes to the field of medical image analysis by offering practical guidance for selecting appropriate deep learning models for CAD diagnosis. The insights gained support the development of AI-driven diagnostic tools that are both accurate, efficient, and adaptable to real-world clinical workflows.

title: Enhanced Fault Detection and Exclusion in GNSS/INS Integrated Navigation Systems via Robust Estimation
authors: Mehmet Gokberk Patan, Ilker Ustoglu
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: A robust estimation-based fault detection and exclusion algorithm is proposed for GNSS/INS integrated navigation systems to mitigate the error tracking effect that limits traditional innovation monitoring methods. By adaptively adjusting the Kalman filter gain using the IGG-III weight function within a sliding window framework, the proposed approach enhances sensitivity to ramp faults and improves fault handling robustness. Simulation results demonstrate up to 34% faster detection in ramp fault scenarios and the successful isolation and exclusion of faults that remain undetected by traditional methods, underscoring its effectiveness in improving reliability and robustness in integrated navigation systems.

title: The Hybrid Blockchain Model to Enhance The Transparency of Hotel Sanitation
authors: Inayatulloh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Hotel sanitation management is a series of structured efforts to ensure that all facilities and services in a hotel meet established hygiene and health standards. The goal is to prevent the spread of disease, maintain environmental quality, and improve guest satisfaction. Sanitation management in hotels is a crucial aspect of the hospitality industry that aims to maintain the cleanliness, health, and comfort of guests and staff. The issue lies in the lack of real-time sanitation monitoring features in the current hotel system. This makes it difficult for management to immediately identify and respond to areas that require cleaning or sanitation repair. Therefore, hotel sanitation management requires a system that provides transparent and valid information. Blockchain technology has a peer-to-peer validation feature that ensures all transaction information related to hotel sanitation is transparent and valid. Each transaction must be validated by all participants before being stored on the blockchain network. Thus, the purpose of this research is to build a hybrid blockchain model to improve the transparency of hotel sanitation. The research employs a qualitative methodology, utilizing a comprehensive literature review. The research output is in the form of a proposed model and a simulation with Hyperledger fabrics. Based on simulation results with Hyperledger Fabric, every transaction related to hotel sanitation must be validated by all nodes in the blockchain network. This condition ensures that the information generated by the blockchain-based system is transparent and valid.

title: Blockchain Technology for Sustainability: Integration and Policy Support in Thai Food Industry
authors: Thanida Wanamkang, Pittawat Ueasangkomsate
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Amid the growing complexity and competition within global supply chains, organizations have increasingly recognized the importance of adopting innovative technologies to support sustainability goals. For example, blockchain can shine by boosting transparency, making it easy to track products from start to finish, and helping all partners in the supply chain work together more smoothly. This research explores how blockchain technology adoption (BTA) shapes supply chain integration (SCI) and drives sustainable supply chains performance (SSCP). It also explores the moderating role of Government Support and Policies (GSP) in these relationships. This study gathered data from 76 companies of medium and large size operating in Thailand’s food and beverage sector. The analysis shows that BTA contributes positively to both SCI and SSCP. In notably, SCI appears to play an essential role in linking BTA to improved sustainability outcomes. The research also observed that GSP can reinforce the connection between BTA and SSCP, especially when such support is substantial. On the other hand, GSP did not exhibit a significant influence on the relationship between SCI and SSCP. Collectively, these results underscore the importance of combining technological adoption, integration strategies, and supportive public policies to enhance sustainability in Thailand’s key food industry, a sector underpinning the national economy.

title: Securing Blockchain-Based Distributed Learning for Heterogeneous Clients Through Knowledge Distillation and Zero-Knowledge Proofs
authors: Ghislain Nkamdjin Njike, Anh-Tu Hoang, Stefan Schulte
abstract: Distributed learning (DL) is gaining popularity as it enables clients (e.g., AI Agents) to enhance their machine learning (ML) models’ performance by exchanging knowledge without revealing private datasets. State-of-the-art DL approaches primarily focus on transferring knowledge between heterogeneous clients with diverse model architectures, connecting clients with those that can improve their models, and protecting data privacy. However, they overlook the threat of malicious clients that potentially downgrade the models’ performance by sharing inaccurate knowledge or excluding high-performing clients from the training procedure.Therefore, we introduce the Zero-Knowledge Blockchain-Based Knowledge Distillation Learning Framework (zkBKD). In zkBKD, heterogeneous clients communicate with a blockchain network to discover high-performing clients, verify zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) to ensure the correctness of the knowledge shared from other clients, and vote to eliminate malicious clients. We analyze security and privacy risks and show that zkBKD prevents membership, poisoning, and collusion attacks. We conduct extensive experiments on two standard datasets across heterogeneous clients with four model architectures. The experimental results demonstrate that zkBKD relatively improves the average model accuracy of all clients by 25.71%. Even lightweight models such as ResNet-2 achieve up to a 103.35% accuracy gain compared to independent training.

title: SPARK – Smart Plug-and-Play AI Framework for RAG & Knowledge
authors: Nirmit Dagli, Chetan Jaiswal, Sanjeev Kumar Marimekala
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: The rapid evolution of Generative AI has demonstrated strong capabilities in natural language understanding; however, its capabilities and applications in specialized domains remain limited due to issues such as hallucinations, a lack of contextual grounding, compliance concerns, and privacy concerns. This paper presents framework SPARK, which is Smart, Plug and Play AI framework based on RAG and Knowledge. RAG systems are designed to enable domain-specific assistants that are privacy-aware, deploymentflexible, and require no model fine-tuning. The proposed system supports multiple data modalities and inference backends, e.g., AWS Bedrock, Google Vertex, Azure AI Foundry, or GPUenabled, while offering a fallback mechanism that integrates private knowledge bases with controlled Internet search. The framework also augments the system by engineering the prompts on-the-fly i.e. Prompt Engineering. As a Proof of concept, we demonstrate the use case of a student and professorcentric AI assistant deployed in a university setting, grounded in instructor approved course material and designed to provide custom course guidance. We detail the system design, deployment pipeline, and multi-layered query flow, concluding with a discussion of border applications in education, enterprise, and healthcare.

title: A Wearable Abdominal Sound Device Using Personalized Reduction of Hemodialysis Complications in Dialysis Patients
authors: KengWei Liu, ChuanChia Wang, Chen Han, ChunKeung Chau, JwoShiun Sun, TungJing Fang
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) are prone to various complications during hemodialysis. The most common complications include hypotension and gastrointestinal dysfunction. Traditional hemodialysis monitoring methods cannot detect physiological changes in real time. Wearable abdominal sound detection devices can monitor intestinal activity, including bowel sounds, in real time. AbSound integrates multimodal physiological parameters through signal analysis and provides personalized health management recommendations tailored to individual needs. In hemodialysis patients, six-month changes in TNF-α and CRP levels were closely associated with PEW. AbSound improves physical function and nutritional status in patients with chronic inflammation. AbSound is a potential application of wearable abdominal sound devices for reducing complications associated with hemodialysis. AbSound proposes a new model that combines dietary management and health monitoring to improve patients' quality of life and cognitive function. We used AbSound's product-moment correlation method to examine the relationship between health indicators and overall quality of life in hemodialysis patients. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to investigate the effect of abdominal sounds on the intake response in patients with endstage renal disease (ESRD). AbSound monitoring of health indicators and quality of life in hemodialysis patients is precise.

title: Towards Robust Prostate Segmentation in Mri Using Boundary-Aware Hybrid Dice-Bce Optimisation for Early Cancer Detection
authors: Imran Ahmed, Silvia Cirstea, Jin Zhang, Gwanggil Jeon, Misbah Ahmad
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of the prostate gland in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is essential for computer-assisted diagnosis, treatment planning, and radiotherapy in prostate cancer management. Segmentation also enables robust extraction of quantitative MRI features-such as shape, texture, and intensity pat-terns-that are important for risk stratification and multimodal integration with biomarkers. However, anatomical variability and indistinct gland boundaries present major challenges. In this work, we propose a prostate segmentation framework based on U-Net, incorporating a novel hybrid loss strategy that combines the Dice loss, binary cross-entropy (BCE), and a boundary-aware term to refine gland contours, particularly. Additionally, we introduce a curriculum weighting scheme that dynamically adjusts the relative contributions of Dice and BCE during training, stabilising early convergence and enhancing boundary delineation in later stages. Experiments conducted on a publicly available annotated prostate MRI dataset demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves competitive Dice similarity coefficients and intersection-over-union scores, with improved accuracy at apical and basal regions compared to standard hybrid losses. This study highlights the effectiveness of hybrid loss innovation for prostate segmentation. It provides a reproducible benchmark that facilitates reliable MRI feature extraction for downstream research on prostate cancer prediction and early, non-invasive detection

title: A Culturally Adapted Modified Guided English Reading Program for K-1 Students in India
authors: Prisha M. Juddoo, Neeraja S, Akshaya S, Punya Pomeroy-Ward, Georg Gutjahr, Radhika Menon, Prema Nedungadi, Raghu Raman
abstract: In resource-constrained classrooms in India, where foundational literacy remains uneven, contextually grounded interventions can drive measurable learning gains aligned with global education goals. This quasi experimental study evaluated the effectiveness of a culturally localized guided reading program—anchored in the nine-level Amrita Levelled Books framework and supported by a mobile learning appin accelerating early literacy among Grade K-1 student in rural India. Sixty intervention students received two 60minute small-group sessions per week over one term, whereas sixty matched controls followed the standard curriculum. After three weeks, 38 % of the participants in the intervention group advanced from Level 1 to Level 2, whereas 0 % of those in the control group did. Growth curve modeling revealed weekly gains of 11 % in sight-word accuracy for the intervention group versus 3 % for the control group (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{p}<.001$</tex>), and end-of-term t tests revealed medium effect sizes (Hedges’ <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{g} \approx 0.60-0.75, \mathrm{p}<0.01)$</tex> for improvements in letter-sound mastery and oral-reading fluency. These findings demonstrate that just two hours per week of level-matched, culturally responsive instruction can rapidly enhance decoding and fluency skills, contributing to effective early learning outcomes, as outlined in SDG 4.1.1. The approach offers valuable insights into scaling inclusive, data-driven literacy programs in similarly underserved settings across the Global South and beyond.

title: AI-Driven Customer Churn Prediction in SAP BRIM Environments Using Machine Learning
authors: Prakash Subramani, Arun Prasad Jaganathan
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Customer churn remains a significant challenge in subscription-based industries, particularly in telecommunications, where contractual structures and usage dynamics directly influence revenue outcomes. SAP Billing and Revenue Innovation Management (BRIM), through its core components Subscription Order Management (SOM) and Convergent Charging (CC) captures these contractual and behavioral signals. This study develops a machine learning (ML) framework for churn prediction by using publicly available telecom datasets to reflect SAP BRIM's data structures. Contractual attributes (tenure, contract type, service bundles) and usage-related billing events (charges, discounts, consumption volumes) were operationalized as predictive features. Four machine learning models, such as Random Forest (RF), XGBoost, LightGBM and a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) were trained and evaluated. The results show that the MLP classifier achieved the best performance, with a test accuracy of 78 %, precision of 83 %, recall of 89 % for churn class, and micro F1-score of 70 %, outperforming Random Forest (test accuracy 77.5%) and XGBoost (test accuracy 77.4 %). Feature analysis identified tenure, contract type, and billing anomalies as key predictors of churn. The results show that telecom data can be meaningfully adapted to BRIM contexts, enabling the use of AI-driven churn prediction within enterprise billing workflows.

title: Performance Evaluation of eLoran Spatial ASF Corrections Based on Measured ASF Map
authors: Jaewon Yu, Pyo-Woong Son
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper analyzes the effectiveness of spatial ASF correction methods in the Korean eLoran system using measured ASF maps. Three correction scenarios were evaluated under identical simulation settings: no correction (S0), local correction using true ASF values (S1), and wide-area correction using a single reference station value (S2). Simulation results show that S1 consistently achieved the lowest positioning errors, while S0 exhibited the largest errors with extensive high-error regions. S2 provided limited improvements near the reference station but degraded with increasing distance and ASF spatial gradients. The findings highlight that local ASF correction significantly improves eLoran positioning performance, whereas wide-area correction has only localized benefits.

title: Development of "Mathgician": A Differentiated and Gamified Instructional Website for Fourth Grade Multiplication Learning
authors: Ivonni Gozali, Ubaidah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: According to international standards from Cambridge Curriculum, TIMSS, and others, 4th-grade students should have mastered multiplication up to 2 digits and 3 digits by 1 digit. To address this challenge, innovative learning media are needed to accommodate the limited classroom time while catering to students' diverse levels of understanding and maintaining their engagement and motivation during lessons. This study aims to develop a Web-Design for Learning model to create an educational website that applies process differentiation through the absorb-do-connect learning approach, integrated with gamification. The research employs the Research and Development (R&D) method, utilizing quantitative analysis to assess content and technological validity and qualitative analysis to examine students' learning needs. The Wilcoxon Signed Rank Test results indicate an improvement in students' learning outcomes. Additionally, the student satisfaction survey was classified as "highly satisfied." Based on these findings, it can be concluded that the developed educational website is highly valid and effective in enhancing both students' learning outcomes and motivation, with a well-designed structure that meets diverse learning needs.

title: Frequency Modulating Networks: Parameter-Efficient Spectral Refinement at Image and Feature Levels
authors: Jungwoo Bae, Minseon Park, Jitae Shin
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Deep models for retinal fundus analysis often depend on handcrafted preprocessing (e.g., CLAHE, background division) that is dataset-specific and costly to tune. We propose a Frequency Modulating Network (FMN), a parameter-efficient, plug-and-play module that operates in the Fourier domain using soft radial band masks (Gaussian/RBF) and a residual, mean-preserving gate. FMN can be placed either (i) before the backbone as a learnable, end-to-end preprocessing block (image space) or (ii) after high-level stages as a feature-refinement block (feature space). On the APTOS 2019 five-grade diabetic retinopathy benchmark, across CNN (ResNet-18/50) and ViT backbones, FMN consistently improves accuracy, specificity, sensitivity, F1, and macro-AUC while adding only a single FFT/iFFT pair per insertion and negligible parameters. An ablation on the number of radial bands shows a U-shaped trend, with moderate band counts performing best. A comparison with hand-crafted pipelines (stochastic augmentations, CLAHE, Ben-Graham) finds FMN competitive or superior without task-specific tuning. Notably, an input-conditioned variant—where band gains are generated from the input image—underperforms the unconditioned FMN, suggesting that per-image modulation can overfit sample-specific quirks, whereas the unconditioned FMN learns a global task/domain-level spectral regularizer that generalizes more robustly.

title: Bridging Neurological Care Across Borders: A Comparative Study of Kazakhstan and U.S. Healthcare Systems
authors: Angelina Penza, Tiya Patel, Jonathan Sferratore, Luke Blum, Emma Jovanovic, Yelgezek Muza, Jumagalieva Daiyana, Dhruv R. Seshadri
abstract: Neurological disorders are an escalating global health concern, particularly as populations age and the prevalence of chronic neurodegenerative conditions increases. Parkinson's disease, a leading contributor to disability in older adults, demands coordinated, accessible, and sustained care. This paper presents a comparative analysis of the standard of care for Parkinson's Disease in Kazakhstan and the United States, highlighting how national healthcare systems-one evolving within a state-funded primary care model, the other shaped by a specialized, insurance-based framework-address diagnosis, treatment access, multidisciplinary management, and long-term support. By examining epidemiological data, health system structures, and policy landscapes, the authors of this work have identified key gaps and opportunities in both countries. This work analyzes seven key dimensions of comparative health systems; Reimbursement Models, Regulatory Framework, Cost and Efficiency, Access and Coverage, Quality of Care, Health Outcomes, and Sociocultural and Economic Context- to generate actionable insights for health planning. Ultimately, the findings from this study are intended to inform the design of low-cost, wearable health solutions that are equitable, scalable, and responsive to the diverse needs of patients across settings-particularly in resource-limited environments.

title: AI-Assisted Music Therapy Intervention for Alleviating Exam Anxiety in University Students: System Design, Implementation, and Efficacy Evaluation
authors: Xiaoyi Song, Jie Zheng, Jun He
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Exam anxiety is a prevalent concern among university students, adversely affecting their academic performance, mental health, and overall well-being. This study investigates the efficacy of an AI-assisted music therapy intervention specifically designed to alleviate anxiety during exam periods. We conducted a single-blind randomized controlled trial involving 150 participants, wherein the intervention group received personalized music playlists generated in real-time based on facial emotion recognition data. In contrast, the control group engaged in passive listening to pre-defined playlists that lacked personalization. The primary outcome was assessed using the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7 (GAD-7) scale, which participants completed both before and after the intervention. Statistical analysis revealed a significant reduction in GAD-7 scores for the intervention group (Mean: 6.0, SD: 2.4) compared to the control group (Mean: 11.5, SD: 2.2), resulting in a large effect size (Cohen’s d=1.9). Participants in the intervention group also reported enhanced emotional engagement and satisfaction during their sessions. These findings suggest that AI-assisted music therapy is not only effective in reducing exam anxiety but also highlights the potential for using technology to create personalized therapeutic experiences. This innovative approach can be an important contribution to mental health strategies aimed at supporting students during critical academic periods, paving the way for future research in the field of digital therapeutics.

title: Comparative Study: Cloud Segmentation Using U-Net & DeepLabV3+ Architecture
authors: Nicholas Abel Williem, Nicholas Rahim Lim, Nickholas Nickholas, Alexander Agung Santoso Gunawan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: This research examines the segmentation of clouds from imagery acquired from Sentinel-2 satellites with the goal of reducing the difficulties created by clouds in remote sensing. The study compared two deep learning networks, DeepLabV3+ and U-Net, and their performance in classifying cloudy and clear skies. The study made use of datasets from Kaggle, which gave images of high quality necessary for training and testing the models. The performance of DeepLabV3+ compared with U-Net indicated a higher performance with a 91.5% Intersection over Union (IoU) and accuracy of 96.3%, accompanied with training and validation losses of 12.45 and 14.72, respectively. This study demonstrates the use of deep learning techniques for enhanced accuracy in segmentation of clouds, hence more accurate assessments in the field of remote sensing. The motivation for this research stems from the need to enhance cloud segmentation in satellite images, a component that is central to a wide range of remote sensing applications. Clouds can obscure vital information, leading to data insufficiency and inaccuracies in environmental monitoring, land-use evaluation, and disaster management. By advancing segmentation techniques, this research aims to make contributions towards more reliable satellite-derived data, thus enabling better decision-making in scientific and industrial applications.

title: Trust and Security in Digital Payments Drive Small Business Growth in Bandung
authors: Fakhri Syauqi Haris, Okky Rizkia Yustian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: This study looks at how the safety and reliability of digital payments affect the use of Financial Technology (FinTech) services. It also looks at how these services affect the commercial performance of Micro, Small, and Medium-sized Enterprises (MSMEs) in Bandung, Indonesia. The study combines survey data from 400 MSMEs in Bandung and Structural Equation Modeling (SEM-PLS) to do descriptive statistics and test hypotheses. The results show that people are more likely to trust and use FinTech services when they can make safe digital payments. People are also more likely to use FinTech services if they trust digital payments. This is good for businesses in a number of ways. These results show that having adequate security for digital payments and creating trust are particularly important for getting people to use FinTech services. This would help small and medium-sized businesses in Bandung do better. This study looks at the unique condition of MSMEs in Bandung to give us new information about how FinTech is used and how it could assist local firms do better. It also allows researchers and those who work in the field a place to start for future research that will help Indonesia's digital economy grow in a way that is good for the environment.

title: Exploring Visual Hierarchy, Banner Blindness, and Selective Attention in Tokopedia Search Ads: A Qualitative Screencast Videography Analysis
authors: Cifran, Djohan Gunawan Hasan, Rajesh Prettypal Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: This study examines the influence of visual hierarchy, banner blindness, and selective attention on user interactions with search adverts on Tokopedia, a prominent e-commerce site in Indonesia. As digital advertising emerges as a pivotal revenue generator for Tokopedia, comprehending user interaction with advertisements is essential for augmenting efficacy and refining user experience. The study is based on behavioral economics, elucidating how cognitive biases and emotional elements affect user behavior in a multifaceted digital landscape. The study use qualitative screencast videography to investigate the influence of visual design elements and cognitive processes on user attention and decision-making. Although visual hierarchy (e.g., contrast, size, alignment) directs attention, the perception of stimuli is more crucial in fostering engagement. Banner blindness arises from cognitive filtering, wherein people unconsciously disregard advertisements perceived as irrelevant. Moreover, selective attention affects purchasing decisions as consumers prefer advertisements that match with their objectives. The results underscore the necessity for a comprehensive strategy in advertisement design, integrating emotional resonance, contextual significance, and multi-sensory components. Recommendations for Tokopedia encompass tailored, adaptive advertising forms that diminish cognitive load and augment relevance to user intent. This study enhances digital marketing by utilizing behavioral economics to refine e-commerce advertisements. Subsequent research may enhance these findings by cross-platform investigations, eye-tracking, and neuroimaging to investigate the behavioral dynamics of internet advertising.

title: Paradigm Scale: IoT-Integrated Digital Scale for Post-Harvest Accuracy in Sragen Agriculture
authors: Dikhi Martin, Jullend Gatc
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Conventional harvest weighing in agriculture is prone of being imprecise as it is mostly humans handling. Measurement results of conventional methods are susceptible to human errors. In this regard, an IoT-based digital weighing system that is connected to a smartphone application is developed. It consists of a NodeMCU ESP32 microcontroller, load cells, and a digital weighing indicator that communicates via RS232 port. Voltage levels are matched through an RS232-to-TTL adapter. The mobile application is designed to be used in an offline mode, therefore suitable for locations with low connectivity. The result of field test was the average measurement of 138.43 kg (digital) and 142.79 kg (traditional), with the total deviation of 832.45 kg, and MAPE was of 7.19%. Results show an increase in the accuracy and operational ability. Although there are still challenges for user adaptation, the measuring mode becomes a two-button operation which will become an interesting alternative of the manual weighing system. Thanks to its IoT functionality, the system increases the weighing precision without complications for the user. Manual to digital can be incremental to actual conditions. More empirical verification is necessary to improve the accuracy and the implementation of this type of system.

title: Structure Reorganization of Zipformer for Automatic Speech Recognition
authors: Chao-Hsien Lee, Min-Rui Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Automatic speech recognition (ASR) has become a pivotal modality for human–computer interaction as smart devices and voice assistants diffuse into everyday life. Regarding the edge deployment, this paper considers Zipformer, which is one of famous and efficient ASR encoder, and further optimizes the recognition accuracy and computation loading. According to our experimental results on LibriSpeech, the proposed Zipformer-RNAS can keep the 6.34% word error rate (WER) and reduce 42.45% floating-point operations per second (FLOPS).

title: Optimization of Robotaxi Dispatch With Pick-Up/Drop-Off-Point and Boarding-Time Recommendation
authors: Mengqi Li, Liang Qi, Wenjing Luan, Qurra Tul Ann Talukder, Xiwang Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: With the advancement of vehicular automation and communication technology, autonomous driving has emerged as a significant trend in future transportation. Robotaxis, an innovative mode of transportation that integrates robotics and artificial intelligence, are anticipated to become widely used, thereby revolutionizing urban mobility. This work proposes a multi-objective mixed integer programming model for robotaxi dispatch. Unlike previous approaches, it can recommend passengers’ pick-up points, drop-off points, and boarding time (BT) that may deviate from their initial origins, destinations, and BT, respectively. It encourages passengers to accept the recommended pick-up and drop-off (UO) points or to be picked up slightly earlier or later. The objectives are to maximize the profit per kilometer of robotaxis and to minimize the total travel expense of passengers. Subsequently, a nondominated sorting genetic algorithm with mass center (NSGA-MC) is proposed to solve the model. It outperforms nondominated sorting genetic algorithm II (NSGA-II) and multi-objective evolutionary algorithm based on decomposition (MOEA/D) across several metrics. Some instances provide detailed results that illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm. Additionally, a sensitivity analysis is performed, comparing scenarios with and without UO-point and boarding-time recommendations. An experiment is also conducted to examine various recommendation acceptance rates, demonstrating the advantages of the proposed model in developing intelligent public transportation systems.

title: Robust Dual-Camera Lane-Keeping System Using YOLOv8 and ROS2 for Autonomous Driving Education
authors: Hye Hyeon Park, Yeong Gwang Choi, Hye Jun Hong, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper presents a study on the development of a lane-keeping system using front and rear dual cameras, a core technology for advancing AI-based autonomous driving education. To expand traditional autonomous driving education, which focuses on static obstacles, to a more realistic dynamic environment: stable driving control technology must be established first. To this end, this study proposes a system that recognizes lanes in real-time using the one-stage object detection model YOLOv8 and generates and follows a driving path based on this recognition. The entire system is based on the Robot Operating System (ROS2), with perception, path planning, and motion planning modules designed as independent nodes to ensure flexibility and scalability. The proposed system provides a stable foundation for adding complex scenarios such as dynamic obstacle avoidance and traffic light recognition in the future. Its performance is verified through driving tests in a closed-loop track environment.

title: Strategies for Sustainable Transition: The Urban Area of Hammarby Sjöstad as an Experiment in Technology-Driven Change
authors: Einar Iveroth, Sofie Pandis-Iveroth, Karel Mulder
abstract: This paper explores the role of technology-driven approaches in facilitating sustainable transitions in urban development. Using the case of Hammarby Sjöstad in Stockholm, we analyze the implementation of eleven sustainable technologies and examine their impact on the broader transition process. Existing literature often frames sustainability transitions in terms of social, technical, or socio-technical approaches. Our findings suggest that a successful technical innovation approach constitutes a well-crafted strategy for managing the supply and demand sides of innovation throughout the extended phases of the innovation journey. Technological advances alone are insufficient: successful transitions also require active engagement from the demand side, including market actors, institutional stakeholders, and consumers, at specific stages. Our study highlights the interaction between the supply side (push), which drives technological innovation, and the demand side (pull), which determines adoption, acceptance, and long-term viability. We identify three recurring mechanisms—infrastructural compatibility, demand-side catalysts, and institutional resistance—that explain when and why technology-driven approaches succeed or fail. The findings emphasize the need to align new technologies with broader systems, ensuring they are not only technically feasible but also institutionally supported and socially desirable. We propose a more nuanced and comprehensive perspective than that of prior transition research, arguing that technological, social, and socio-technical approaches all play essential roles throughout the transition process. Additionally, we contribute to innovation policy and transition management research by demonstrating how the interaction between supply and demand influences the outcomes of sustainability initiatives. Also, we respond to calls for greater attention to the demand side of innovation, offering insights that can inform policymakers and technology developers working toward sustainable change. Our research provides a strategic framework for understanding the conditions under which technology-driven transitions can succeed in practice.

title: High Communication Performance Internet of Robotic Things Systems Based on RT-Middleware
authors: Daishi Yoshino, Yutaka Watanobe, Keitaro Naruse
abstract: The use of the Internet by robots is referred to as the Internet of Robotic Things (IoRT). IoRT is expected to enable robots to create innovative services by effectively utilizing information and resources previously inaccessible when robots were offline. An IoRT system is a complex structure comprising multiple layers, including field-side systems (such as robot systems), cloud-side systems, and the Internet-based communication infrastructure connecting them. Middleware, platforms, and communication protocols differ across layers depending on purpose, further increasing system complexity. When exchanging data between layers with different protocols, a data conversion mechanism is required. If this conversion bridge is provided separately, additional communication overhead occurs, reducing overall performance. To address this issue, we integrated a new communication interface using MQTT, the de facto standard IoT protocol, into RT-Middleware, one of the established middleware frameworks for constructing robotic systems. This integration enables the development of Internet-connected robotic systems entirely within RT-Middleware, eliminating the need for external bridges. In such IoRT systems, the boundaries between layers are removed, and the entire structure functions as a unified middleware-based system. We evaluated the communication performance of IoRT systems seamlessly constructed on RT-Middleware against ROS1- and ROS2-based IoRT systems that require an IoT bridge. Latency measurements revealed that for small- and medium-sized payloads, the IoT bridge accounted for up to 40% of the total system latency. These results demonstrate that IoRT systems built with RT-Middleware, without relying on an IoT bridge, achieve lower latency and better support real-time performance.

title: Scheduling UAV-based deliveries with an approximation algorithm
authors: Giulio Attenni, Viviana Arrigoni, Matteo Finelli, Novella Bartolini
abstract: The need for environmentally conscious alternatives to traditional road transport is progressively growing as digital marketplaces continue to integrate more deeply into our daily lives. Employing drones for parcel delivery is a possible solution to mitigating road traffic and pollution. Nevertheless, designing an efficient drone delivery system comes with numerous challenges, including planning efficient scheduling of delivery tasks and coping with the strong impact that weather conditions have on drones' mobility. We consider a drone delivery service based on a distributed infrastructure of service stations that a fleet of drones can use for battery replacement, allowing long-distance deliveries. We formulate the problem of scheduling the drone fleet's operations so as to minimize the completion time of the delivery tasks and propose an approximation algorithm called REDMAT. Our algorithm enables a straightforward extension to consider real-time demands and variable wind conditions, based on a thorough mathematical model, and that we simulate in our experiments. We simulate our solutions under numerous experimental settings, including dynamic scenarios with online delivery demand arrivals, and variable wind conditions, and compare the achieved performance against other existing solutions. Our experiments show the superior efficiency of our algorithm, which provides a remarkable improvement in the makespan (i.e., the maximum delivery time) and average delivery completion time, respectively up to 40% and up to 24.5% with respect to the state-of-the-art solutions.

title: Over-the-Air Testing on Artificial Intelligence Based Beam Management Evaluation of Millimeter-Wave Devices
authors: Zhanyuan Wang, Mengjie Yan, Wentao Zhao, Chong Guo, Zhengbo Jiang, Wei Hong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper proposes an over-the-air (OTA) channel emulation methodology within the multi-probe anechoic chamber (MPAC) framework to test artificial intelligence (AI)-based spatial-domain beam management (BM) for millimeter wave devices. The reconstructed channel provides reliable measurements as AI input and accurate ground truth for validating AI predictions in instantaneous multi-beam environments. Base station (BS) filtering is applied to the Cluster Delay Line (CDL) channel model, which results in rapid fluctuations in the propagation environment at the user equipment (UE) side during the BM procedure. Two novel approaches-approach A and approach B-are proposed to emulate the instantaneous multi-beam channel environment, with approach A suitable for emulating random target beams and approach B for pre-defined ones, respectively. Both approaches are based on the Beam Power-Angular-Spectrum Similarity Percentage (BPSP), a new metric introduced to evaluate the channel accuracy of reconstruction. Simulations and experimental results are presented to validate the accuracy of the channel reconstruction. Furthermore, the performance of an actual AI model deployed at the UE side is evaluated using the proposed methodology.
