title: AI-Driven Edge Cloud Collaboration Framework With Autonomous Resource Allocation for Standardized 6G Healthcare Networks
authors: S. Balakrishnan, M. Senbagavalli, M. Manikandan, D. Sumathi, Navyatha Ravi, Mohammad Shabaz
abstract: 6G networks are booming, and they will transform healthcare; ultra-low latency, massive connections, and intelligent services will finally reach critical applications. Real-time performance, standardization, and scalability of healthcare networks are impacted by having various categories of devices, changing workloads, and changing resource requirements. This paper suggests a new AI-based method for standardized 6G healthcare systems, referred to as the Cognitive Autonomous Resource and Edge Collaboration Framework (CARE-6G). The use of cognitive AI agents together with edge-cloud cooperation in CARE-6G enables automated prediction, allocation, and optimization of computing, storage, and networking resources. The framework is constructed hierarchically such that edge nodes perform low-latency processing, while cloud infrastructure performs big-scale analytics. AI-based predictive orchestration ensures that the needs for workloads and healthcare services can shift. The experiments indicated that CARE-6G is 35% quicker, 30% more resource-efficient, and 27% more reliable than the existing practices. When compared to the best methods available, CARE-6G was 39% faster, 30% better at using resources, 27% more reliable, 25% less power-hungry, and 15% better at getting things done.

title: A Low-Cost Low-Profile Dual-Band Dual-Circularly Polarized Antenna with Shared-Radiator for L-/S-Band Phased Array Applications
authors: Yuekun Sun, Chunxu Mao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This communication presents a highly-integrated dual-band dual-circularly polarized (CP) shared aperture phased array with reduced profile and cost for L-/ S-band satellite communications. In this work, the radiating patch is shared by the L- and S-band for the first time to realize left-handed CP (LHCP) and right-handed CP (RHCP), respectively. The dual-band operation for each polarization is realized by introducing intensive mutual coupling between the radiator and the resonator through the slots in the ground. The dual CPs in the two bands are achieved by combining the two orthogonal polarizations of the same band using a power divider with a 90° phase difference. To improve the cross-band isolations, two groups of split-ring resonators (SRRs) with different resonances are adopted. Besides, the analysis method of equivalent circuit is adopted to investigate the mechanism of the proposed design. Based on the element design, a four-element phased array is developed and a self-rotating method is analyzed and used to improve the axial ratio (AR) performance. The 1 × 4 L/S-band dual-CP shared aperture phased array is prototyped and verified, demonstrating the impedance bandwidths from 1.67 to 1.76 GHz and from 2.11 to 2.29 GHz for the L-band and S-band operation, respectively. The 3-dB AR bandwidths for the L/S-bands are 1.68-1.75 GHz and 2.17-2.24 GHz, respectively. The measured results also show a good beam scanning ability of ±50° in both bands with a scanning loss of about 3 dB.

title: Optimal Hybrid Transmission Strategy for Remote State Estimation With Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Hongxia Rao, Zitian Li, Lixin Yang, Yong Xu, Tingwen Huang, Leszek Rutkowski
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: This work delves into an optimal hybrid transmission strategy for remote state estimation (RSE), where some smart sensors observe various systems and transmit their local state estimates to a remote estimator. Inspired by the high bandwidth of a high-frequency (HF) link alongside the robust reliability and low energy consumption of a low-frequency (LF) link, a novel hybrid transmission strategy is proposed. This strategy allows smart sensors to utilize either the HF link or the LF link dynamically, each with distinct channel characteristics and energy consumption. To achieve highly reliable and energy-efficient transmission, it is imperative to devise an optimal transmission scheduling strategy that dictates the selection of the link and channel allocation. Formulating this challenge as a Markov decision process (MDP), a sufficient condition ensuring the existence of an optimal deterministic and stationary (ODS) policy is established. The structural characteristics of the optimal policy are derived. Furthermore, a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach, specifically the dueling double deep Q-network (D3QN) algorithm, is employed to approximate the optimal policy. Finally, the structural results and the effectiveness of the DRL algorithm are verified by simulation examples.

title: Performance Enhanced Risk-Aware MPPI using Gaussian Process for Robust Mobile Robot Control
authors: Fauz Hanif Edma, Jae-Han Park, Jung-Su Kim
abstract: This paper presents a performance enhanced Risk-Aware Model Predictive Path Integral (RA-MPPI) control using Gaussian-process (GP). To this end, the real system is run with arbitrary control input and the resulting data is saved. Based on the nominal model of the system and the collected data, uncertainty affecting the state transition is estimated by a Gauss-Newton method offline. Then, the used control input and the estimated uncertainty are used to train the Gaussian process which generates the mean and variance of the uncertainty. Online, the gap between the nominal and real dynamics is compensated by the trained GP. In other words, the nominal model is refined using the estimated uncertainty mean, while the estimated uncertainty variance is directly incorporated into the RA-MPPI framework, eliminating the need to manually tune the disturbance covariance parameter. Validation is conducted through simulation experiments in Gazebo using a F1TENTH car with a bicycle model navigating a track with and without obstacles. Also, real-world performance is further demonstrated on the F1TENTH car platform driving the same track under similar conditions. Across both simulation and real-world scenarios, the proposed method demonstrates improved safety and trajectory tracking performance compared to baseline MPPI and RA-MPPI techniques in terms of lap times and the number of crash-free lap completions. Videos of the F1TENTH car simulations, experiments, and similar Gazebo simulation results using a Clearpath Jackal with a differential drive model are available at the project webpage: https://gp-ramppi.github.io.

title: Non-Centralized Quantum Neural Networks for Cell-Free MIMO Systems
authors: Bhaskara Narottama, Berk Canberk, Simon L. Cotton, Hyundong Shin, George K. Karagiannidis, Trung Q. Duong
abstract: This paper propose a two-stage quantum neural network (QNN) framework for cell-free multiple-input and multiple-output (MIMO) wireless communication systems. Cell-free MIMO, which has been regarded as a key technology for enhancing the performance of the next-generation wireless communication systems, leverages the collective capability of multiple distributed access points (APs), allowing collaboration between them. However, optimizing cell-free MIMO can pose challenges for centralized optimization schemes. In particular, complexities associated with the joint optimizations of user-transmission assignment and transmission precoding, two factors which are of much importance for determining the quality-of-service, grow with the number of APs and served users. To this end, a unified scheme employing distributed QNNs is used to optimize downlink transmitter-user assignment and transmit precoding with the goal of maximizing the achieved sum rate. Firstly, the cloud processing unit, which holds holistic information about the particular wireless communication network, employs QNN to assign each AP to its designated mobile terminal. Secondly, the edge processing units, which are computed in proximity relative to the AP in order to reduce latency, estimate transmission precoding for their corresponding APs. Moreover, numerical results are presented to showcase the performance of the proposed protocol.

title: MPT-MIL: Multimodal Aware Prompt Tuning For Prediction of Cancer Survival
authors: Ruofan Zhang, Mengjie Fang, Shengyuan Liu, Zipei Wang, Xuebin Xie, Xiaoke Ma, Jie Tian, Di Dong
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: As a critical statistical technique in oncology, survival prediction is used to estimate the probability of survival or time-to-event outcomes. Identifying survival-related factors from pathology and genomic data is a key approach for analyzing survival outcomes. However, current methods face several challenges, such as the suboptimal adaptation of pre-trained vision foundation models to specific tasks during feature extraction from whole slide images (WSIs), and the fact that many pathology-based models fail to integrate repetitive gene expression information during pre-training. In this study, we propose a plug-and-play multiple instance learning (MIL)-based foundation model tuning strategy to adapt vision foundation models for downstream tasks and incorporate knowledge from genomic data. Specifically, we introduce Task-specific Instance Selection, which utilizes zero-shot learning to efficiently select task-relevant WSI regions, improving tuning efficiency and reducing interference from irrelevant tissue areas. Additionally, we develop a multi-model prompt token for model fine-tuning, which integrates genetic information into the prompt-tuning process and transfers new modality information to pre-trained vision foundation models. To further enhance the model's ability to learn genetic information during fine-tuning, we introduce a Gene Distribution Aware Task as an auxiliary task to the traditional survival task. This auxiliary task helps the model better perceive multimodal information. Extensive experimental results on three public TCGA datasets demonstrate that our model outperforms all previous MIL-based methodologies and fine-tuning approaches in terms of performance.

title: Fully Distributed Fault-Tolerant Consensus-Tracking Control for Multiple Wheeled Mobile Robots With Event-Triggered Communication
authors: Yafeng Li, Bin Du, Changchun Hua, Guopin Liu, Yu Zhang
abstract: This article investigates the fully distributed output feedback consensus-tracking control problem for multiple wheeled mobile robots (multi-WMRs) subject to dual-actuator faults (DAFs) under the directed graph. First, a fully distributed estimator is designed to asymptotically estimate the leader’s states with nonzero input under event-triggered communication. Next, novel filters are introduced to compensate for unmeasured velocity information in the presence of DAF, and output feedback fault-tolerant controllers are developed to ensure asymptotic consensus tracking despite the faults of actuators. Each robot in the considered multi-WMR system is equipped with two controllers that are co-designed in a unified framework. The final control laws are obtained by solving a set of equations, for which the existence of a unique solution is rigorously established. The proposed scheme not only enables output feedback control under partial loss-of-effectiveness (PLOE) faults in dual actuators, but also ensures fully distributed consensus tracking with event-triggered communication. The simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Leveraging Learnable Defense Prompts and One-Step Diffusion Model for Adversarial Purification in Remote Sensing
authors: Weidong Wang, Zhi Li, Long Zheng, Zhenyu Dai, Chuhua Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have demonstrated outstanding performance in remote sensing imagery (RSI) analysis. However, their sensitivity to adversarial perturbations remains a critical bottleneck for their deployment in security-sensitive scenarios. Currently, most mainstream adversarial purification methods focus on pixel space example reconstruction, neglecting the effective recovery of deep semantic features and the classification decision space, thereby failing to mitigate the adversarial attacks adequately. To address this challenge, we propose a novel multimodal adversarial purification framework, Leveraging Learnable Defense Prompts and a one-step diffusion model (LDP-Diff), which aims to achieve robust adversarial defense with semantic consistency. Firstly, we introduce a learnable defense prompt (LDP) mechanism in LDP-Diff. Through the learnable optimization of input prompts, LDP-Diff can provide precise semantic guidance for the purification process. Next, we introduce a One-Step Diffusion Model combined with the low-rank adaptation (LoRA) for lightweight fine-tuning, significantly reducing the inference complexity while effectively removing adversarial perturbations and achieving high-quality structural and semantic reconstruction. Moreover, to further enhance the stability of purified examples in the classification space, we propose a entropy-guided logit fusion (EGLF) loss, which quantifies the confidence entropy and adaptively fuses the logit distributions between examples to alleviate the class bias remaining in the classification space after reconstruction. Comprehensive experimental results show that LDP-Diff exhibits excellent defense capabilities in multiple RSI datasets. LDP-Diff achieves an accuracy improvement of 2.40% on the UCM dataset and realizes a significant performance improvement of 10.84% on the AID dataset compared to the existing state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods. Notably, LDP-Diff exhibits excellent robustness, generalization, computational efficiency, and significant advantages in cross-domain defense.

title: AGVOT: Visual Object Tracking via Cooperation of Aerial and Ground Views
authors: Kaixiang Yan, Wenhua Qian, Jinde Cao, Cong Bi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Visual object tracking (VOT) is a fundamental task in computer vision that underpins many higher-level tasks. Previous VOT methods have explored various approaches to improve the performance of VOT tasks and achieve predetermined goals. However, due to the limitations of a single view, issues such as visual blind spots and glitches in photographic devices present insurmountable challenges, often causing the visual features of the tracked object to vanish entirely or partially. Providing supplementary images from another view is an effective way to improve tracking performance by eliminating blind spots and enhancing the reliability of image sources. In this work, we propose a novel benchmark called the Aerial and Ground Cooperation Dataset for VOT (AGVOT). AGVOT consists of 643 sequences from aerial and ground views, comprising 119,859 image pairs. These image pairs were collected from 15 scenes and span 26 object categories. Every sequence is strictly time-aligned and annotated with 4-point bounding boxes. For comprehensive evaluation, AGVOT is further categorized into 12 challenging attributes, each labeled at the frame level. Moreover, we introduce an Aerial and Ground Cooperation Tracking Network (AGTrack) to demonstrate dual-view feature integration and cross-view tracking cooperation. Extensive experiments show that AGTrack outperforms 10 state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods in the computer vision community when tested on AGVOT’s dataset and its challenging attributes. These results demonstrate that implementing VOT tasks with cooperative views achieves more accurate and reliable tracking performance. The project source is available at the link.

title: Highly Integrated Four-State Diplexers Based on Multimode Resonators
authors: Chi-Feng Chen, Tsang-Ning Tien, Chung Ting Liu, Kuan-Chih Chen
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of highly integrated four-state diplexers based on multimode stub-loaded resonators (SLRs) for multifunctional and frequency-hopping communication systems. Two design prototypes are proposed: one employing dual-mode SLRs and the other utilizing tri-mode SLRs, achieving second- and third-order bandpass responses, respectively. The dual-mode version demonstrates low insertion loss, and the tri-mode configuration provides enhanced frequency selectivity and stopband suppression without additional matching networks. Both diplexers operate under four distinct states using a single circuit topology, offering high reconfigurability and substantial design flexibility for multi-band front-end integration. Fabricated on Rogers RO4003 substrates, the prototypes exhibit measured insertion losses of 0.47–1.02 dB and port-to-port isolation exceeding 25–38 dB, demonstrating strong advantages in selectivity, low-loss performance, and multi-state scalability. These results show that the proposed designs achieve an improved balance between frequency selectivity, low insertion loss, and reconfigurability, making them promising candidates for frequency-agile and reconfigurable multi-band communication front-ends.

title: Analyzing Shared Features Between Countries to Create a Predictive Model on Disease Outbreaks
authors: Ariel Prandi Darmawidjaja, Orlando Jonathan Padiman, Viona Djunaidy, Nunung Nurul Qomariyah, Raymond Bahana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Humanity has faced numerous pandemics in the past, some of which include Tuberculosis and COVID-19. Thus, this study aims to investigate the factors that contribute to the spread of diseases by utilizing historical data on the Tuberculosis outbreak and the COVID-19 pandemic. These factors include the WHO region, World Bank income group, population, and population density. We hypothesize that there is a correlation between these factors and the incidence of a disease during outbreaks. To test this hypothesis, we applied several machine learning models and analytical methods. The findings indicate that XGBoost is the most effective model for outbreak prediction. Furthermore, it was found that population size and a country’s World Bank income group may be the key factors that significantly influence the severity of disease spread during an outbreak.

title: Temporal-Aware Multi-Image Vision Transformer for Cervical Cancer Screening via Cervicography
authors: Seung Jin Hong, Jeong A Kang, Seung Yong Park
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Cervical cancer remains a critical public health challenge in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), where AI-assisted cervicography offers promising potential for scalable screening solutions. However, current AI-based single-image classification models face a fundamental limitation: when applied to multiple tele-cervicography images from the same patient, they produce inconsistent predictions that create diagnostic uncertainty and undermine clinical confidence. To address this challenge, we present a temporal-aware, multi-image Vision Transformer (ViT) architecture that processes multiple cervical images collectively, generating unified patient-level predictions using a five-class framework (Negative, Atypical, Positive 1, Positive 2, Positive 3). Our approach incorporates temporal embeddings to capture sequential relationships between images acquired during visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA) examinations, enabling the model to leverage complementary information across the image sequence. Experimental results demonstrate that our multi-image ViT-Huge variant achieves 70.4% accuracy when processing all patient images, outperforming single-image baselines and establishing temporal-enhanced Vision Transformer as an effective solution for reliable AI-assisted cervical cancer screening in resource-limited settings.

title: Enhanced Skin Disease Classification Using a Modified VGG19 Architecture and Curated Multisource Image Dataset
authors: Zul Indra, Rahmadi Kurnia, Yessi Jusman, Tisha Melia, Evfi Mahdiyah, Feri Candra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Skin diseases are among the most prevalent health issues worldwide, particularly in tropical developing countries such as Indonesia. National statistics indicate that dermatological conditions rank third among the top ten outpatient diagnoses. Accurate diagnosis of skin diseases often requires expert evaluation and can be time-consuming, making early detection challenging for the general public. To address this issue, this study proposes a deep learning-based image recognition model utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to facilitate rapid and accurate skin disease classification. A total of 3,890 dermatoscopic images encompassing four classes—Melanoma, Acne, Ringworm, and Normal Skin—were compiled from multiple sources. The dataset underwent pre-processing, augmentation, and class balancing. A modified VGG19 pre-trained model was fine-tuned using a transfer learning approach by adding two dense layers (1024 and 512 units, respectively) with dropout to mitigate overfitting. The model was trained and evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score metrics. Experimental results demonstrated high performance, achieving 98% across all key metrics, indicating robust classification capability. The outcomes suggest that the proposed CNN-based model provides a reliable and efficient diagnostic support tool for early skin disease detection and has potential for integration into clinical and teledermatology applications.

title: AI for Human Behavior Prediction
authors: R. Trivedi
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Human behavior prediction has evolved beyond simple rule-based systems into sophisticated technologies that analyze complex behavioral patterns. While current systems effectively handle standard scenarios, they often fail to adapt to dynamic human behavior in real-world applications. This paper presents a framework that continuously evolves with human patterns, validated through a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 4}$</tex>-month study across four major institutions involving <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4, 2 0 0}$</tex> participants. Our framework addresses key challenges in modern behavioral prediction by combining real-time adaptation with privacy-focused design. Through extensive testing in health-care, transportation, education, and manufacturing sectors, we demonstrate significant improvements in operational outcomes. The system's success stems from its ability to learn from daily interactions while protecting user privacy, offering a practical and ethical solution for real-world applications where human behavior prediction is critical for safety and efficiency.

title: AI-Driven Real-time Crack Detection System for Industrial Applications
authors: MinCheol Park, HoangKhanh Lam, Hayotjon Aliev, HyungWon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: In industrial systems, real-time condition monitoring and the detection of processing faults are essential components of the manufacturing process. Computer vision-based crack detection systems can quickly identify critical damage and issues, thereby preventing the production of defective products. However, the real-time detection of small and unshaped cracks in bad working environments poses difficulties for existing methods and affects the recognition system accuracy. To address this issue, we propose a real-time crack detection framework using YOLOv5n, a lightweight object detection model specifically optimized for manufacturing automation processes. As an example application, we implemented the proposed algorithm to detect crack lines in wafer carrier plates used in semiconductor fabrication. The experimental testing results with a custom dataset of wafer carrier plates have demonstrated that the proposed approach achieves a satisfactory balance between speed and accuracy, making it suitable for deployment in edge computing environments for industrial inspection systems.

title: Multi-Objective Constraint-Based Optimization of Human-Machine Instruction Combinations for a Hexapod Robot
authors: Hanwei Qu, Yantao Zhang, Pengfei Sui
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Hexapod robots have important applications in task execution in complex environments due to their excellent terrain adaptability and locomotion flexibility. However, in the process of human-robot interaction, due to the complexity of instruction combinations and the diversity of task requirements, realizing efficient and stable human-robot cooperative control still faces many challenges. In this paper, we propose a human-robot command combination optimization method based on multi-objective constraints for hexapod robots, and design an algorithmic framework applicable to command combination optimization by constructing a multiobjective optimization model with motion stability, path efficiency and energy consumption as the objectives. Experimental results show that the method in this paper exhibits significant advantages in terms of path planning accuracy, interaction efficiency and adaptability, and provides an effective solution for the practical application of hexapod robots in human-robot cooperative tasks.

title: Analysis of Attention Modules in Unfolding Tensor Rank Minimization-Based Pansharpening
authors: Dung Viet Phan, Chuong Hoang Vo, Chul Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: We examine the effect of various attention modules on a low-rank tensor minimization model for pansharpening. First, the pansharpening problem is formulated as a low-rank tensor minimization task, integrating a detail injection term and an attention module to guide the model to focus on salient regions of the feature map obtained by detail injection. Then, the problem is solved using a deep unfolding network, where each stage updates the variables and the regularizer via closed-form solutions and learned deep networks. Experimental results show that a simple and parameter-free attention module outperforms the baseline model.

title: Real-Time Surgery, Delayed: Internet Latency and the Prospect of Telerobotic Surgery
authors: Kennedy Orwa, Yixin Chen, Varun Bathija, Mike Teodorescu
abstract: Despite significant advancements in telerobotic surgery technologies, their widespread adoption hinges on the availability of low-latency, high-bandwidth networks. In telerobotic surgery, internet latency directly impacts surgical outcomes, patient safety, and overall system reliability. Our research assesses latency behavior from Seattle to 146 hospital domains across 55 countries in Africa and Europe, revealing notable disparities and significant variability even under low mean latency conditions. These findings raise concerns about the feasibility of telerobotic surgery, particularly in regions and countries with high latency networks. We propose targeted policies that prioritize latency reduction as a step to accelerate integration of telerobotic surgery in healthcare settings.

title: Optimization of Hybrid Fuzzing Based on Random Forest Algorithm
authors: Pujun Lin, Chengyin Ye
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: Fuzzing is one of the most effective vulnerability detection techniques for modern software. Hybrid fuzzing, as an efficient method in fuzzing, enhances testing efficiency through an additional concolic execution component. Seed scheduling significantly impacts the efficiency of hybrid fuzzing. Existing hybrid fuzzing systems schedule seeds based on fixed heuristics designed to predict input utility. However, such heuristic methods often prove inefficient, and these approaches typically exhibit poor transferability - they may perform well on programs from which they were derived but fail to generalize to others. Moreover, due to the efficiency imbalance between the concolic execution component and seed generation component, the concolic execution component can only process a small fraction of generated seeds.To address these issues, this paper proposes an optimization method that first collects high-quality seeds based on features like code coverage, constructs a model using the random forest algorithm to characterize these seeds, and employs this model to classify subsequently generated seeds. Evaluations demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art hybrid fuzzers, achieving higher code coverage than QSYM. Additionally, the learned model exhibits strong reusability and transferability across different programs.

title: Typology of Offensive Play Styles in UEFA Champions League: A Machine Learning-Based Clustering Study
authors: Nasy’an Taufiq Al Ghifari, Adam Hanafi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: This study uses the K-Means Clustering algorithm to classify the attacking playing styles of football players participating in the 2021–2022 UEFA Champions League season. The data used included nine offensive statistical variables: the number of assists, successful dribbles, shots on target, corner kicks, offside, and number of matches. After going through a preprocessing and standardization process, the K-Means algorithm is applied to form three clusters representing different offensive play patterns: the defender or attacking supporter, the offensive midfielder or the supporting attacker, and the most aggressive main attacker. To evaluate the quality of the grouping results, this study also compared K-Means' performance with Hierarchical Clustering using the Davies-Bouldin Index. The results show that K-Means produces a more compact and separate cluster. This research contributes as a data-based offensive style classification map, which can be used by coaches, analysts, and talent scouts to strategize, evaluate performance, and make recruitment decisions more objectively and efficiently.

title: Using Open Access Remote Sensing to Improve Grazing Access and Reduce Conflict Among Pastoralists in Northern Kenya
authors: Matthew Leopold, Audrey Xiao, Vincent Park, Catherine McManus, Ahmed Mohamed, Siddhartan Govindasamy, Justin Henriques
abstract: Pastoralist communities in Northern Kenya use migratory herding as an adaptive strategy in response to the vari-ability of grazing lands and water sources. Increasing variability associated with climate change can increase scarcity and can lead to resource conflict. This paper demonstrates an approach to using Sentinel-2 satellite images to map biomass productivity using the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI). Cloud-filtered images were processed using open-access tools to generate NDVI areas, identifying areas of vegetation as potential grazing zones. This approach could provide information on vegetation coverage that could help inform migration decisions, reduce competition over scarce resources, and support equitable access to food and water. The approach demonstrates how open data and spatial tools can aid climate adaptation and support conflict prevention in resource-constrained context.

title: DUAL-VAD: Dual Benchmarks and Anomaly-Focused Sampling for Video Anomaly Detection
authors: Seoik Jung, Taekyung Song, Joshua Jordan Daniel, JinYoung Lee, SungJun Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Video Anomaly Detection (VAD) is critical for surveillance and public safety. However, existing benchmarks are limited to either frame-level or video-level tasks, restricting a holistic view of model generalization. This work first introduces a softmax-based frame allocation strategy that prioritizes anomaly-dense segments while maintaining full-video coverage, enabling balanced sampling across temporal scales. Building on this process, we construct two complementary benchmarks. The image-based benchmark evaluates frame-level reasoning with representative frames, while the video-based benchmark extends to temporally localized segments and incorporates an abnormality scoring task. Experiments on UCF-Crime demonstrate improvements at both the frame and video levels, and ablation studies confirm clear advantages of anomaly-focused sampling over uniform and random baselines.

title: The Design and Testing of a Low-Cost Prosthetic Hand for use in Jaipur, India
authors: Steven Reimer, Christopher Kitts, Michael Neumann
abstract: This paper presents the design and development of a low-cost, powered prosthetic hand specifically tailored for trans-radial amputees in Jaipur, India. Santa Clara University's Robotic Systems Laboratory aimed to create an affordable yet functional prosthetic device that restores independence and enhances the quality of life for users. By utilizing rapid prototyping techniques, electromyography (EMG) sensor-based actuation, and anthropomorphic design, the prosthetic hand integrates features such as lightweight design, low-cost materials, and multiple control modes. Extensive testing validated its usability and was conducted both with non-amputees at Santa Clara University and with amputees in Jaipur, India.

title: Blackhole Attack Analysis On VANET Networks
authors: Asroni Asroni, Ronald Adrian, Indra Setyo Wibowo, Jackson, Cahya Damarjati, Haris Setyawan, Nurwahyu Alamsyah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: This study aims to analyze the impact of Blackhole attacks on the performance of the AODV protocol in Vehicular Ad-Hoc Networks (VANET). The AODV protocol, commonly used because it dynamically forms routes, is highly vulnerable to routing attacks such as Blackhole. In my experience, this attack manipulates the route construction procedure by fraudulently claiming ownership of the shortest path, resulting in the redirection of sent data, which is ultimately discarded by the attacker node. Such vulnerabilities can reduce network reliability and result in significant packet loss. For my testing, I utilized MATLAB to monitor network performance and SUMO to predict traffic flow. To defend against these types of attacks, the AODV protocol was upgraded to incorporate a loop detection mechanism. We compared the system’s performance in the normal and attack modes using latency and throughput measurements. This experimental technique substantially degraded network performance due to the Blackhole attack. The findings show a significant performance degradation due to the Blackhole attack, with throughput decreasing by 43.48% and latency increasing by 33.92%. The main contribution of the work is a detection technique that is lightweight and reduces the impact of the assault while leaving the danger unabated. Contrary to popular belief, mathematical modeling confirms the existence of a correlation between route stability, throughput, and delay. These findings might be useful in developing a funding agency that is both strong and current. This organization need to be disbanded if it does not exist.

title: Advancing Campus Sustainability Through Waste Sorting and Value Addition at Gulu University
authors: Paige Balcom
abstract: A review of literature shows that integrated waste management systems on university campuses can recover the majority of waste streams when paired with education and campus-wide participation. A global review notes that campus waste is often dominated by organics, paper, and plastics, and achieving sustainability goals demands a holistic approach from source separation infrastructure to recycling/composting programs - coupled with university community participation [3]. At Nigeria's Federal University of Technology Akure (FUTA), over 80 % of campus waste was recyclable, and researchers proposed color-coded bins, optimized collection routes, and partnerships with recyclers to close the loop [2]. In East Africa, studentled initiatives like Kenyatta University's “Kijani Bin” project-which upcycles plastic bottles into waste bins and runs awareness campaigns-demonstrate how handson student engagement drives behaviour change [4]. Together, these examples highlight that co-designed, behaviour-focused, and value-added approaches can transform universities into models of sustainability for their wider communities.

title: Defending Every Tick: Comprehensive Attack Mitigation and Feasibility Analysis for Ad Hoc Time Synchronization
authors: Cole Ulrich, Laura Estremera, Sima Jafarikhah, Hosam Alamleh
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Time synchronization is essential for coordination in wireless sensor and ad hoc networks, yet existing protocols remain vulnerable to adversarial manipulation. This paper systematically examines the attack surface of ad hoc time synchronization, categorizing threats that include delay, replay, spoofing, drift, Sybil, wormhole, selective forwarding, man-in-the-middle, flooding, and clock skew. We review and map countermeasures such as authentication, statistical filtering, neighbor consistency checks, distance bounding, and anomaly detection, highlighting their strengths, costs, and residual risks. Our analysis reveals key security-performance trade-offs and provides practical guidelines for resource-constrained deployments. Research shows that no single defense is sufficient; instead, layered approaches are required to achieve a balance between resilience, scalability, and precision.

title: Optimizing Wireless Coverage Through Intelligent Router Height and Location Adjustment
authors: Ahmed Saad Hussein
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Achieving maximum wireless coverage inside buildings is an ongoing issue, especially in compound building layouts such as modern houses and offices with varying wall types and structural obstructions. This paper proposes an intelligent optimization framework for achieving maximum Wi-Fi coverage using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to determine optimal router location and altitude, as well as the directed placement of signal boosters. The proposed model mimics real-world 2D architectural layouts accounting for 3D propagation effects using adjustable antenna height and material-based wall attenuation. The system is simulated for two indoor environmentsa home and an office space with partitioned areasto evaluate the performance of the system. Simulation results show dramatic coverage improvements, with dead zones reduced by over 75% in cases of optimized settings. Heatmaps, convergence curves, and comparative analysis between manual and AI-optimized placements are provided to demonstrate the efficiency and flexibility of the model. This work offers a flexible and accurate smart network planning tool for different indoor environments.

title: Simulation of New Energy Power Investment Monitoring and Decision Model Based on Power Big Data
authors: Jin Luo, Shuming Yao, Yimin Tang, Xiaotian Chen, Jian Hu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: In this paper, a simulation method of new energy power investment monitoring and decision-making model based on power big data is proposed, aiming at solving the decision-making problems brought by high initial investment, long return period and strong volatility in the field of new energy investment. By constructing a multi-source heterogeneous data fusion system based on Lambda architecture, the data of power generation, meteorology, equipment status, power grid dispatching and market quotation are integrated to realize a comprehensive perception of the new energy operating environment. Furthermore, the two-layer graph neural network (GNN) model is used to mine the spatio-temporal correlation characteristics of new energy systems, so as to improve the forecasting accuracy of power generation. Construct a third-order dynamic risk transmission model of “resource-market-policy” to quantify the risk of new energy investment; A virtual power plant simulation environment based on Unity3D, Monte Carlo simulation and deep Q network (DQN) algorithm is developed to shorten the response time of strategy adjustment to minutes. A case study of a wind, light and storage integration project in Ningxia shows that the prediction accuracy of this model is significantly better than that of the traditional method, and the continuous rank probability score (CRPS) is reduced to 0.04 and 0.03 respectively, and the Mean absolute error (MAE) is as low as 1.1MW. In the aspect of strategic response time, in the face of scenarios such as sudden change of electricity price, extreme weather warning and policy risk transmission, the response time is shortened to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 2}$</tex> minutes, 0.8 minutes and 2.1 minutes respectively, which is 99 % to 100 % higher than that of traditional methods. The economic verification shows that the internal rate of return (IRR) is 2.5 percentage points higher than that of the traditional method, reaching 11.2 %, the power cut-off loss rate is reduced from 6.3 % to 2.1 %, and the energy storage utilization rate is increased to 89 %. In addition, in the verification of sandstorm extreme scene in April 2023, this model showed high prediction accuracy, successfully reduced the income loss of 820,000 yuan, and avoided the fine of 120,000 yuan for power grid assessment. The statistical significance test results further prove the superior performance of the new model in forecasting accuracy, decision-making timeliness and economic return.

title: A Review of Quantum Supremacy in QUBO-Based Applications
authors: Arim Ryou, Kiwoong Kim, Kyungtaek Jun
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: We propose a unified approach for reformulating diverse computational challenges into Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) models and solving them via quantum annealing. By applying this framework across multiple domains, we demonstrate its flexibility in handling structurally different problems within a single mathematical formulation. The study highlights QUBO’s capability to exploit quantum parallelism, integrate regularization seamlessly, and address ill-posed inverse problems. These advantages position QUBO-based quantum annealing as a promising tool for large-scale optimization and reconstruction tasks, with strong potential for impact in scientific computing, engineering, and data-driven applications.

title: A Modular VLA for Autonomous Driving: Evaluating VLM Performance and Safety
authors: Young Hoon Suh, Eun Ho Kim, Yeong Gwang Choi, Hyo Gin Park, Hye Hyeon Park, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper proposes a modular architecture for Vision-Language-Action system that partially integrates the perception, decision and control process for autonomous vehicles, along with a benchmarking framework for quantitatively evaluating the performance of backend models. The proposed system enhances decision-making efficiency by preprocessing visual information and feeding detection results into a language model (VLM) to convert this data into driving actions. The system’s vision module uses YOLOv8 to spot objects and segment lanes. It has a smart safety feature that specifically looks out for obstacles in the driving lane. When we compared three VLM models—Gemini, LLaVA, and Qwen—we found that Qwen scored the highest overall, while Gemini was the most reliable. The system was able to provide helpful decision-making assistance for real-world driving, with a quick average response time of 2.1 seconds. Next, we plan to fine-tune the system using the LoRA technique to improve how well it matches actions. We’ll also see how practical the system is by testing it on a real track with a 1/5-scale autonomous vehicle.

title: Development of a Smart Differential Relay Using IoT and Wireless Communication Technologies
authors: Saif Ur Rahman, Tajammal Hussain, Manzoor Ellahi, Muhammad Faiq, Amber Tariq, Muhammad Nadir
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: This paper presents an IoT-based pilot wireless differential relay for real-time monitoring of power system. The designed system will have a broader scope for the detection of faults with reduced installation cost and increased overall reliability using the latest in wireless communication technologies and integration with the IoT. Traditional differential relays, though quite efficient in detecting faults, are mostly of wired communications that are not only expensive but also less flexible. Wi-Fi, LoRaWAN, or cellular networks are used to establish wireless communication between the relays to perform the real-time monitoring, and fault detection. The system transmits the data to the cloud platform for further remote access, data storage and future analysis. The performance of the prototype is validated through the developed GUI and designed small-scale, laboratory-based hardware of wireless differential relay. The designed system also combines the prototype with cloud computing for improved user interfacing, to facilitate realistic deployment. The outcomes show that the developed system can help in improving the fault detection, enhance real-time monitoring and predictive maintenance in electrical grids.

title: Co-Defining Success and Impact of Co-Creating Through International Engineering Projects
authors: Philippe Damoiseaux, Taylor Ericson, Colleen McCulloch, Melissa Trykowski, Marie Stettler Kleine
abstract: Success and impact of international engineering projects are difficult to define, as they depend on the groups involved, available resources, and methods of engagement. In February 2025, Colorado School of Mines sent two Capstone Design teams to Miraflores, Colombia to engage in a collaborative engineering implementation trip to build a coffee thresher and a honey-hauling zipline in collaboration with community partners and Diversa, a Colombia-based nonprofit. Students had been co-designing with their partners for 7 months and would continue to design and test prototypes until May 2025. These projects were situated in the Engineering with Communities Design Studio (ECDS), which integrates community engagement into senior design. Four Humanitarian Engineering & Science (HES) graduate students also attended the trip. They were invited to offer physically prototyping assistance while also offering guidance to undergraduate students on humanitarian engineering practices and critically engaging with engineering identity, sustainable development, and community engagement. Using semi-structured interviewing and analysis methods of seven different project participants, the HES students and a faculty advisor have analyzed through reflexive thematic analysis the different perspectives surrounding successes and impacts of this collaboration to explicate, complicate, and analyze the value of academically driven international development projects and how success and impact are measured within these contexts. The HES students recognize their unique position as both trip participants and researchers of the experience.

title: Smart Crew Dispatch System in Distribution Networks: A Digital Simulation Approach
authors: Gagandeep Singh Dua, Balaji Ramachandran, Shiraj Shaikh, Omar Hukal, Abdulrahman Aljasmi, Ahmad Ahli, Tareg Ghaoud
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Field Crew (FC) dispatch plays a critical role in the smooth and reliable operation and maintenance of power networks. In this context, this paper proposes a Smart Crew Dispatch (SCD) system implemented using a digital simulation approach in a distribution network, aimed at enhancing the efficiency of fault management and restoration processes. It involves the integration of a number of services in a simulation control platform to accurately model the travel path of field vehicles, mimic faults in the power network, and realize smart dispatch algorithms. This platform can be used by operators for training purposes to improve crew dispatch. The services provided by the simulation control platform consist of real-time FC tracking and automated dispatching, fault localization and restoration, and notifications and visualization. The proposed solution has been tested and validated using a real distribution network comprising three 11kV feeders. The results suggest that the proposed solution enhances operational efficiency, reduces downtime, and ensures an efficient FC management process.

title: The Impact of Collection Mechanisms on Player Experience in Puzzle Games
authors: Qingyun Lin, Chanyuan Yan, Xiaoyi Song, Jun He
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This study focuses on puzzle games to explore the impact of collection mechanisms on player experience. By analyzing 39 classic game cases and employing sentiment analysis, it sorts out the manifestations and typed characteristics of collection mechanisms, with a focus on dissecting the unique value of collection mechanisms in puzzle games. The research finds that collection mechanisms in puzzle games are centered on enhancing cognitive abilities and maintaining pure gameplay experience, and their positive impact on player engagement and satisfaction depends on the balance between content attractiveness and acquisition mechanisms. This study reveals the correlation between collection mechanisms and the intrinsic motivation of puzzle game players, offering insights for optimizing puzzle game design.

title: Learning Gas Laws with HoloAir: A VR Educational Tool for the Ideal Gas Equation
authors: Toshiki Hamaoka, Tatsuro Ueda, Kazuhisa Nakasho
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Against the backdrop of the "high academic achievement despite low learning motivation" paradox in Japanese physics education, this study focuses on the difficulties of learning abstract concepts such as thermodynamics. To address this challenge, we improved HoloAir, an educational application that utilizes Virtual Reality (VR) technology to promote conceptual understanding of the gas laws, in particular Boyle’s, Charles’s, and Gay-Lussac’s laws. The enhanced version of HoloAir provides an environment where learners can interactively manipulate state quantities such as pressure, volume, and temperature to explore their relationships. We specifically designed and implemented "educational scaffolding" that links abstract physical quantities to visual feedback accompanied by physical sensations, such as representing volume changes as the vertical movement of the ceiling within the VR space. The results of a usability evaluation conducted with seven graduate students in information science showed that learning involving physical sensations, such as the ceiling’s movement, significantly promoted a more intuitive understanding of the laws compared to learning with only numerical changes. These results suggest that embodied learning experiences using VR are effective in deepening the understanding of abstract scientific concepts.

title: Challenges at Each Stage of the Kenyan Cage Fish Farming Cycle
authors: Lillian Downs, Anshu Nunemunthala, Gauri Patil, Adeline Weitknecht, Benjamin Roy, John Gershenson
abstract: This paper investigates the cage fish farming process practiced by farmers at Dunga Beach in Kisumu, Kenya. The research expounds upon issues discussed by cage fish farmers and the potential viability of their proposed solutions. We outline the various stages of the fish farming cycle, including cage construction, the stocking, growing, and harvesting of tilapia, and the fish market, as described by cage fish farmers. We also identify common issues farmers encounter during each stage of the process and the methods farmers use to address them. By defining these process and challenges, we aim to provide insights into the budding Kenyan cage fish farming market and suggest methods for enhancing Kisumu farmers’ efficiency and economic viability. We asked 23 cage fish farmers to split into three groups to outline the cage farming process from start to finish. Each group was then asked to list the problems they faced and discuss practical solutions. Each discussion was led by a facilitator, recorded by a notetaker, and monitored by a secondary note taker. From these conversations, we identified five steps in the cage farming cycle - (1) cage construction, (2) stocking the cage, (3) feeding, (4) harvesting, and (5) inspecting. We found no singular cause of low profits amongst farmers in Kisumu, rather farmers described various issues at each point of the cage farming process which collectively decreased their profits. Farmers expressed a wide ‘success bracket,’ spanning from extremely low profits to high ones and indicating significant variability within the market. Key hindrances mentioned by farmers are: a lack of access to technical farming knowledge, access to quality trainings and the continuity of knowledge sharing between farmers; identifying quality feeds; the capital costs of farming, including cage costs, quality feed costs, and access to payment plans and loans; and security, including lake pollution due to large companies, mass fish kills, and tearing of underwater nets. Farmers proposed several potential solutions, most notably real-time knowledge sharing through water quality sensors and education on how to use that information, and a pay as you go model for purchasing cages to reduce barriers to entry. High earners in the market show that cage fish farming at Dunga Beach has the potential to be an extremely profitable business, however lack of technical knowledge, capital, and security are leading many farmers to suffer low returns. This paper expounds upon the issues discussed by cage fish farmers and the potential viability of their proposed solutions.

title: Essential Factors Influencing Smart Healthcare Implementation: A Perspective of Leavitt Diamond and TOE Model
authors: Enrique Julian Aldo, Nathanael Nicholas Tjhin, Jose Andreas Hung, Meyliana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: The rapid advancement of industry 4.0 has driven the transformation of conventional healthcare services by adopting digital healthcare systems or smart healthcare as a solution to improve service efficiency, quality of care, and patient safety. Despite its great potential, the smart healthcare implementation process faces various challenges such as user acceptance, organizational readiness, technological infrastructure, and complex regulations. This study aims to identify the main factors that influence the success of Smart Healthcare implementation through a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) approach. A total of 135 scientific articles were collected and selected based on inclusion and exclusion criteria, resulting in 29 selected studies that were analyzed in depth. As a result, 52 main factors were found and grouped into five components based on a combination framework that takes from the Leavitt Diamond Model and the Technology-Organization-Environment (TOE) Framework. The factors include People, Process, Technology, Organization, and Environment. The result shows that the Technology and People components are the most dominant aspects that influence Smart Hospital implementation, followed by Organization, Process, and Environment.

title: Silicon-Proven Chaos-Based Random Number Generator Using the Sky130 PDK
authors: Onur Karataş, Sezen Bal, Hayriye Korkmaz
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: A digitally implemented chaos-based random number generator (RNG) is presented, designed, fabricated, and validated via the Efabless Open Multi-Project Wafer (MPW) shuttle program using the Sky130 Process Design Kit (PDK). The proposed design utilizes a discretized chaotic attractor to produce inherently unpredictable bitstreams. Using a fixed-point digital model, the design is fully synthesizable and compatible with standard ASIC and FPGA design flows. The silicon-proven implementation was integrated into the Caravel SoC platform and successfully manufactured through the Open MPW program. Post-silicon validation was performed by reading data from the RNG block using a RISC-V processor. The results demonstrate a low-cost, fully realized solution for embedding chaos-based entropy sources into secure hardware systems.

title: Mood-Based Food Recommender System for Sustainable Smart Supermarket
authors: Yang Yang, Yanxin Zhong, Fan Cheng, Wei Song, Hanyi Zhou, Michal Aibin, Sarita Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: This study aims to propose a mood-based product recommendation system in a supermarket setting for enhanced customer experience as well to reduce product wastage. The project introduces a hybrid recommender system that integrates Collaborative Filtering and Content-Based Filtering, enhancing recommendation accuracy and relevance by considering both historical data and current customer states. Key features of the system include face recognition for identity verification, emotion detection for mood-based product suggestions, and dynamic pricing strategies to encourage the sale of products nearing expiration. Validated through simulations and real-world datasets, including the publicly available Instacart dataset, this study advances customer behavior analysis and sustainable marketing by offering a more dynamic and personalized shopping experience while promoting waste reduction.

title: Phishing Experiments in the Wild: Lessons for Ubiquitous and Context-Aware Security
authors: Samantha E. Smith, Marc J. Dupuis
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Phishing remains a pervasive social engineering threat, undermining users across ubiquitous and interconnected computing environments. Unlike traditional exploits, phishing adapts dynamically, leveraging emotional triggers, urgency, and high-fidelity mimicry to bypass technical defenses. This paper reports on phishing experiments conducted in the wild, designed to capture unprimed user behavior under realistic conditions rather than laboratory constraints. Data collection occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic, providing a natural context of heightened uncertainty that parallels attacker exploitation strategies. Three contributions are emphasized. First, we present empirical evidence of susceptibility and lure effectiveness under authentic delivery constraints, documenting how adaptive spam filters shaped exposure over time. Second, we analyze methodological lessons, including the decision to abandon tracking-pixel “opens” in favor of unique-token click-throughs, aligning with recent cautions about automated prefetching and measurement bias. Third, we evaluate the ethical and legal considerations of deception-based fieldwork, situating safeguards within the Menlo framework and recent critiques of IRB sufficiency. The findings highlight that in ubiquitous computing environments, resilience depends not only on end-user awareness but also on system-level factors such as filtering dynamics, crowd-sourced detection, and measurement robustness. Lessons from this case study provide guidance for researchers and practitioners designing context-aware, humancentered defenses in pervasive systems.

title: Machine Learning-Based Customer Lifetime Value Prediction Framework: An Integrated Approach Using Behavioral Intention Analytics in Digital Service Ecosystems
authors: Sabar Aritonang Rajagukguk
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Customer Lifetime Value (CLV) prediction has become increasingly critical for digital service organizations seeking to optimize customer acquisition and retention strategies. This study presents a comprehensive machine learning framework that integrates behavioral intention analytics with advanced feature engineering techniques for enhanced CLV prediction accuracy. Using a dataset of 300 customer records from a digital service provider, we developed and evaluated eight machine learning models spanning both classification and regression paradigms. Our novel feature engineering approach incorporates Satisfaction Gap Score calculations, weighted Loyalty Index construction, and K-means clustering-based customer segmentation. The XGBoost classifier achieved superior performance with 94.2% accuracy and 0.963 AUC-ROC, while the Random Forest Regressor demonstrated optimal regression performance with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.923. Feature importance analysis revealed that engineered behavioral features significantly outperformed traditional demographic variables, with the Loyalty Index and Satisfaction Gap Score emerging as the strongest predictors. These findings provide actionable insights for implementing data-driven customer relationship management strategies in digital service ecosystems, demonstrating the value of integrating psychological constructs with computational methods for business analytics applications.

title: Enhancing Encrypted Data Security in True Color Images Using PVD and XOR-VLSB StegoCrypto Scheme
authors: Nur Rochmah Dyah P.A, Ika Arfiani, Ardhan Hanif
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Ensuring the security of encrypted data in digital images is a critical challenge in modern information security. This research proposes an enhanced steganographic scheme combining Pixel Value Differencing (PVD) and XOR-based Very Least Significant Bit (XOR-VLSB) techniques, termed PVD and XOR-VLSB StegoCrypto, to improve the security of encrypted data embedded in true color images. The proposed method leverages the adaptability of PVD for embedding capacity optimization while utilizing XOR-VLSB to enhance security against statistical and steganalysis attacks. Experimental results indicate that the proposed scheme achieves a high embedding capacity while preserving image quality, as evidenced by peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) and structural similarity index (SSIM) evaluations. Additionally, security analysis confirms the robustness of the scheme against various steganalytic techniques. These findings demonstrate that the PVD and XOR-VLSB StegoCrypto scheme provides an efficient and secure approach for encrypted data concealment in true color images, making it suitable for various sensitive data protection applications.

title: SARF: Sparsity-Aware Reconstruction Framework for Large-Scale Datasets
authors: Agustin Zuniga, Huber Flores, Ngoc Thi Nguyen, Pan Hui, Sasu Tarkoma, Petteri Nurmi
abstract: Large-scale datasets, particularly those collected from smart devices and Internet of Things sensors, usually exhibit significant temporal and spatial sparsity, resulting in high amounts of missing data. Unless addressed in the analysis, this sparsity can result in substantial gaps and biases as well as limit the generalizability of conclusions drawn from such data. To address this challenge in data quality, we contribute the Sparsity-Aware Reconstruction Framework (SARF) as a novel and unified data fusion and reconstruction framework that enhances data quality and addresses sparsity. SARF analyzes datasets, partitioning the data into segments with similar characteristics, and reconstructs the data in each segment individually by selecting a reconstruction technique that is tailored to the internal temporal-spatial characteristics of the dataset. Through extensive experiments on two representative datasets - mobile application measurements and IoT sensor data from low-cost air quality sensors - we demonstrate that the targeted adaptation of reconstruction strategies employed by SARF significantly enhances the quality of reconstructed data. Our results show the robustness of SARF's performance across spatiotemporal variations, outperforming current state-of-the-art methods by margins up to 68% on average (74% for compressive sensing, 53% for convolutional sparse coding, 78% for deep learning). These findings underscore SARF's potential to enhance datadriven insights across multiple domains, paving the way for more robust analyses of sparsity-affected datasets.
