title: Application and Effect Analysis of the Intelligent Feedback System Based on Emotion Recognition Technology in Higher Vocational Education
authors: Jing Mou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: The application of emotion recognition technology in education has drawn increasing attention, yet research on its implementation in higher vocational education remains limited. This study focuses on the intelligent feedback system based on this technology in higher vocational education. Emotion recognition technology analyzes multi - modal data to identify emotions, and the related intelligent feedback system can support teaching. By exploring students’ personalized needs, this research conducts an experiment. Subjects are selected through stratified sampling and random grouping, and data is collected, processed with a multi task learning model, and analyzed by a structural equation model. Results indicate that emotional states have a notable impact on academic performance. The intelligent feedback system effectively enhances students’ academic performance, course satisfaction, and emotion regulation skills. It offers an innovative approach for higher vocational education. Future research will center on optimizing system functions and expanding applications.

title: Explicable Artificial Intelligence for Affective Computing
authors: Rui Mao, Erik Cambria, Yang Li, Newton Howard
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly tasked with recognizing and responding to human emotions, making affective computing one of its most consequential frontiers. As AI spreads into finance, policymaking, and mental health, the opacity of deep learning models raises urgent challenges for trust, accountability, and ethics. This special issue addresses explicability not just as algorithmic transparency, but as a paradigm integrating cognitive science, the humanities, and ethical foresight with technical innovation. Guided by the “Seven Pillars for the Future of AI”— multidisciplinarity, task decomposition, parallel analogy, symbol grounding, similarity measure, intention awareness, and trustworthiness—it envisions affective AI as a partner in meaning-making rather than a mere inference engine. The six featured articles span topics from depression detection and sentiment analysis to hate speech moderation and interpretable driving behaviors, advancing affective AI that is accurate, interpretable, and aligned with human dignity.

title: Front-of-Package Labelling as a Global Public Health Tool: A Comprehensive Review of Nutritional Labelling Systems and Their Role in Reducing Diet-Related Non-Communicable Diseases
authors: Elizabeth Ehrhardt, Laurent Tong, Tara Chelvam, Khanjan Mehta, Joseph A. Menicucci
abstract: How can we empower consumers to make healthier dietary choices and alleviate the global burden of non-communicable diseases (NCDs) through simple, scalable interventions? Nutritional labelling-particularly front-of-package labelling (FOPL)-has emerged as a promising public health strategy to guide consumer behavior and improve food environments. While robust evidence from high-income countries shows that FOPLs can effectively promote healthier purchasing patterns, their implementation and context-specific adaptation in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) have not been adequately explored. This article presents a comprehensive review of global FOPL systems, categorizing them into directive, semi-directive, and non-directive formats, and evaluating their effectiveness in shaping consumer choices. Specific attention is given to the feasibility and potential of semi-directive systems in LMICs, where a balance between informational clarity and implementation practicality is crucial. However, the success of FOPL interventions is contingent not only on the label design itself but also on broader enabling factors-such as public education, regulatory frameworks, and trust in oversight mechanisms. Ultimately, this review positions front-of-package labelling as a scalable and adaptable tool that promotes healthier food consumption and reduces the burden of diet related NCDs in vulnerable populations in LMICs.

title: Covert Surveillance in Smart Devices: A Scour Framework Analysis of Youth Privacy Implications
authors: Austin Shouli
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: This paper investigates how smart devices covertly capture private conversations and discusses in more in-depth the implications of this for youth privacy. Using a structured review guided by the PRISMA methodology, the analysis focuses on privacy concerns, data capture methods, data storage and sharing practices, and proposed technical mitigations. To structure and synthesize findings, we introduce the SCOUR framework, encompassing Surveillance mechanisms, Consent and awareness, Operational data flow, Usage and exploitation, and Regulatory and technical safeguards. Findings reveal that smart devices have been covertly capturing personal data, especially with smart toys and voice-activated smart gadgets built for youth. These issues are worsened by unclear data collection practices and insufficient transparency in smart device applications. Balancing privacy and utility in smart devices is crucial, as youth are becoming more aware of privacy breaches and value their personal data more. Strategies to improve regulatory and technical safeguards are also provided. The review identifies research gaps and suggests future directions. The limitations of this literature review are also explained. The findings have significant implications for policy development and the transparency of data collection for smart devices.

title: How Machine Automation Shapes Performance Optimism: The Roles of Job Insecurity, Work Engagement, and Conscientiousness
authors: Falerin Natalia, Valerianus Fernaldi Hartanto, Teuku Risyad Fabrian, Darjat Sudrajat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: One of the major technological advancements in the modern era is machine automation, which could help companies by simplifying tasks that are commonly performed by human resources. However, automation has a negative impact by causing job losses. On the other hand, machine automation can provide benefits to employees, such as helping to increase productivity and effectiveness at work. The objective of this study is to explore the influence of machine automation on employee performance optimism, as well as the role of job insecurity and work engagement as mediating variables, and conscientiousness as a moderating variable. Using a quantitative survey method with 102 employees in the manufacturing sector, the structural model analysis results showed that the use of machine automation has a significant impact on job insecurity but does not directly affect work engagement and performance optimism. Additionally, conscientiousness was not proven to be a moderator that could strengthen the relationship between machine automation and other variables. Nevertheless, work engagement has a significant positive relationship with performance optimism, indicating that employees who are more engaged in their work tend to be more optimistic about their performance. This study emphasizes that although automation can increase job insecurity, it does not necessarily reduce employee engagement or optimism about their performance, so companies that implement automation should focus on enhancing work engagement as a key factor in maintaining employee optimism.

title: Wearable Pulsatile Compression Devices During Intradialytic Promote Individual Quality of Life in Chronic Kidney Disease Patients
authors: ChunKeung Chau, ChuanChia Wang, Chen Han, KengWei Liu, JwoShiun Sun, TungJing Fang
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Patients suffering from end-stage renal disease (ESRD) have been shown to exhibit systemic inflammation. Effective management of lower limb venous return is crucial for maintaining cardiovascular health. The objective of this study was to investigate the effects of passive resistance exercise on inflammatory markers and physical performance in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) undergoing hemodialysis (HD). An intelligent external pulsed compression (SEPC) device was applied to the calves. This device integrates advanced wearable biosensors, intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC), passive resistance muscle exercise, and peripheral venous return enhancement technology. Within six months, the incidence of IDH decreased from 34.43% to 7.55%, and the proportion of IDH patients also decreased, indicating that SEPC can significantly reduce the incidence rate (from 32.98% to 6.19%). Inflammatory markers were significantly reduced (P < 0.01). The markers evaluated included C-reactive protein (CRP), tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α), and classical monocytes. The study found that six months of SEPC exercise during regular dialysis led to improvements in patients' physical function. This finding suggests that SEPC effectively reduces the incidence of HD-related complications and significantly improves clinical outcomes and quality of life in the entire patient population. The administration of SEPC during conventional dialysis has been demonstrated to elicit anti-inflammatory effects. SEPC has been shown to enhance physical function and functional capacity in cases of chronic inflammation.

title: Multifunctional Wearable Wireless System Based on RF and TENG Hybrid Energy Harvesting
authors: Chao Zhang, Shao-Hua Xing, Zhen-Huo Liu, Yin-Feng Wang, Yi-Hao Liu, Yi-Xuan Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper presents self-powered wearable wireless communication system based on hybrid energy harvesting. The proposed system integrates a communication antenna, RF rectenna and triboelectric nanogenerator (TENG) into a compact, structure through a shared-aperture approach. It supports wireless data transmission simultaneously harvesting ambient RF and mechanical energy to enable battery-independent operation. The communication and rectifying antennas operate in the 2.4–2.5 GHz band, achieving peak gains of 5.3 dBi and 6 dBi, respectively, with a maximum radiation efficiency of 60%. Orthogonal polarization ensures effective antenna isolation. The RF rectifier achieves a power conversion efficiency of up to 70%, and the dual antennas also serve as electrodes for the TENG. Dedicated power management circuits are employed to handle the distinct characteristics of the two energy sources, ensuring efficient energy regulation and storage. This work provides a viable pathway for the development of next-generation battery-free, self-sustaining wearable IoT systems.

title: Dynamic Offloading Optimization for Multi-Pim LLM Inference
authors: Jeong Yoon Kang, Jae Hyung Ko, Taeho Hwang, Kyu Hyun Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: The growing demand for energy-efficient on-device AI in consumer appliances is drawing significant attention to Processing-In-Memory (PIM) architectures. This trend is largely driven by the proliferation of Large Language Models (LLMs). While these models have enabled remarkable advances in reasoning and generative tasks, they increasingly face the memory wall problem, where data movement between processors and memory dominates both latency and energy consumption. Processing-In-Memory (PIM) architectures have emerged as a promising solution by executing memory-intensive workloads directly within memory, thereby reducing data transfer overhead. However, efficient integration of PIM into existing heterogeneous systems requires careful management of data transfers between host processors and PIM devices, as well as scheduling policies for inference graph execution. This paper introduces a Node-Aware tensor offloading method that leverages topological analysis of the model computational graph to capture tensor layout relationships across consumer nodes. An Affinity-Based device scheduling algorithm is also proposed, which uses a shared hash table to align operand tensors with their execution device for each operation kernel, eliminating redundant inter-device communication. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method extends a GDDR6-based PIM emulation framework integrated with ONNX Runtime to support 4D matrix multiplication. The optimizations achieve up to 15.63× and 29.3× latency reduction for QK and SV multiplications in the prefill stage, resulting in 93.6% and 94.0% energy savings, respectively. Additionally, in the decoding stage, execution time is reduced by 1.09× and 2.01×, resulting in 8.3% and 50.4% energy savings, respectively.

title: Enhancement Algorithm and Adaptive Generation Method of Practical Writing for Cross-Domain Scenarios
authors: Junlin Zhai, Zhuoying Zhou
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: With the increasingly frequent cross-disciplinary cooperation, practical writing faces many challenges, such as knowledge differences, diverse norms and different styles. In this paper, an enhancement algorithm and adaptive generation method of practical writing for cross-domain scenes are proposed, aiming to help writers cross domain barriers and achieve efficient and accurate writing. The overall framework of the algorithm covers four modules: data preprocessing, domain adaptation, text generation and post-processing. Among them, the domain adaptive module uses deep learning technology, pre-trained BERT model and CNN to extract domain features, and realizes knowledge transfer through domain adaptive technology and antagonistic training; Text generation module combines template and generation strategy, and introduces GPT language model to optimize text. The experiment takes legal documents and business mail data sets as examples, and the results show that the algorithm can effectively generate practical texts that meet the specifications and styles of the target domain.

title: Comparative Analysis of LSTM and XGBoost Models for Cryptocurrency Price Forecasting Under High Volatility
authors: Darren Tangamus, Nathanael Alvaro Thai, Jung Shan, Alexander Agung Santoso Gunawan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Cryptocurrency has emerged as a leading digital innovation in the financial and technological landscape, playing an increasingly significant role in the global financial ecosystem. However, their prices are highly volatile and are influenced by a wide range of external factors, making accurate forecasting complex and essential. This study intends to compare two popular machine learning algorithms equipped in time-series forecasting, namely LSTM and XGBoost which are optimized using Grid Search for hyperparameter tuning. Their predictive performance is compared using daily historical data of Bitcoin, Ethereum, Ripple, and Solana from its first appearance to 28 May 2025, and trained using two data normalization techniques: StandardScaler and MinMaxScaler, combined with two different sliding window configurations: 7-day and 30-day window, each with a 1-day forecasting horizon. Evaluation of each model's performance will be determined using MAE, MAPE, and RMSE. This research’s findings show that GS-LSTM using a 7-day sliding window and MinMaxScaler with 80/20 data split achieved the best overall results. However, results varied across cryptocurrencies: GS-LSTM with 7-day window and MinMaxScaler with an 80/20 data split performed best for Bitcoin and Ripple; StandardScaler worked better for Ethereum; and a 30-day window with StandardScaler and an 80/10/10 data split was optimal for Solana. This research has assessed the influence of data normalization techniques, sliding window approaches, and hyperparameter tuning algorithms on the predictive performance of LSTM and XGBoost in cryptocurrency price forecasting.

title: Short-Term Power Forecasting Technology of Cluster Wind-Solar Integration Based on Machine Learning
authors: Yuxuan Ye, Zhaofeng Guo, Jian Zhang, Hao Ning, Shengwei Wang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: This article focuses on the short-term power forecasting technology based on ML (Machine Learning), aiming at meeting the challenges of intermittent and uncertain power generation from renewable energy to power grid dispatching. In the research method, RNN (Recurrent Neural Network) is selected as the core algorithm model, and the power prediction model is constructed through data preprocessing, feature selection and model training. In the experiment, the model is trained and tested by using the actual operation data, and the prediction results are comprehensively evaluated by using the determination coefficient (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex>) and other indicators. The findings demonstrate that the model effectively captures power generation fluctuations, with the predicted values closely aligning with the actual values and exhibiting minimal error. This strongly supports the efficacy and benefits of using machine learning-based power prediction technology. The short-term power forecasting method utilizing ML for wind-solar integration shows high accuracy, stability, and adaptability, offering valuable decision-making support for power grid dispatch and operational management.

title: Calculating the Increased Speed of Polymorphic Encryption
authors: Albert Carlson, Benjamin Williams, Sai Ranganath Mikkilineni, Christopher Briscoe, Mandeep Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Polymorphic encryption techniques are relatively new and generally not well understood. Although practitioners claim that this type of encryption is slower due to steps such as sharding, selecting random keys, and choosing random ciphers, these encryptions can be even faster than the linear version of encryption for the same message. However, there has been no published mathematical analysis of this claim. (Security analysis is beyond the scope of this paper.) The study presented in this paper encompasses shards of both identical and differing sizes. It also demonstrates that partitioning and queuing functions can be handled by one or more cores, enabling efficient and predictable operation and analysis. Logic might dictate that speeding up processing would require the use of multiple cores, threads, or GPUs, since shards constitute orthogonal encryption problems. However, with only two cores, a polymorphic cipher offers superior security without loss of speed. Ambiguous statistical analysis techniques, such as benchmarking, are not used due to the impossibility of effectively controlling for all hardware variations and configurations, and because even on the same hardware, non-real-time OS schedulers can cause significant variation from one test to the next. Rigorous mathematical analysis is used here, because it is much more reliable for comparative study.

title: Research on UAV Path Planning Based on Improved Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm
authors: Qixiang Wang, Weijun Pan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: Due to the fast convergence speed of traditional particle swarm optimization algorithm in UAV 3D path planning, it is easy to fall into local optima, while genetic algorithm, although slow in convergence speed, is prone to jumping out of local optima. This article uses RRT to generate an initial population to prevent collisions between drones. Using PSO to lead the search and update particle velocity and position to quickly approximate the potential optimal region. Further enhance diversity through GA, select, crossover, and mutate the population after PSO update, and retain the optimal individuals of each generation through elite strategy to ensure algorithm convergence while considering global exploration ability. Finally, a large number of experimental results have shown that compared to the three typical path planning algorithms, the improved particle swarm optimization algorithm has strong local optimization ability and stable optimization ability.

title: Rule-Based Root Cause Analysis of Site Outages in Mobile Networks: A Deterministic Approach for Alarm Correlation
authors: Serkan Karadag, Aydın Duruoz, Mehmet Balci, Melih Bilir, Koray Uygun, Ayse Guvez, Eda Konakyeri Arici, Arzu Kuru Sahin
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: In telecommunication networks, the prompt identification of outage causes at sites significantly improves the efficiency of site operations and enhances service continuity. This paper presents a rule-based system designed to determine root causes of site outages by evaluating historical and real-time network alarms. Developed and deployed in a national mobile operator's environment, the system eliminates redundant site visits, improves repair efficiency, and enables faster response by directing the right site team with the necessary equipment. Unlike machine learning methods, the approach leverages deterministic logic derived from expert defined rules, ensuring traceability and rapid deployment. Site implementation results demonstrate reduced Mean Time to Repair (MTTR), increased operational accuracy, and a measurable improvement in customer satisfaction.

title: Applications of in Situ Microbiological Water Quality Monitoring
authors: Whitney N. Knopp, Joshua T. Klaus, Laura MacDonald, Evan Thomas
abstract: Over half the world lacks access to safe drinking water, with fecal contamination cited as a primary source of pollution. E. coli is a widely used indicator for fecal contamination, however, existing monitoring methods limit spatially and temporally dense data collection. Developed by our research group, the E. coli sensor uses tryptophan-like fluorescence (TLF), a wavelength of fluorescence correlated with microbial activity, fused with machine learning analytics to estimate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E$</tex>. coli contamination. Raw sensor data are matched with E. coli enumerated in samples using EPA-approved methods to train the model. The technology outputs quantitative E. coli levels, is designed for continuous in-situ deployment, and utilizes internet connectivity to upload data in real time. Ongoing sensor deployments to validate the sensor performance are being conducted with partners across diverse environmental and social contexts. In Kenya, the sensor monitors borehole system functionality for community drinking water systems, where detection of contaminated water can inform health advisories and infrastructure repair. In Kigali, Rwanda sensors are installed in community water filters to validate filter functionality and support carbon credit generation. In the US, sensors monitor surface waters for compliance with regulations and to protect recreation along Boulder Creek in Colorado, Chicago River in Illinois and Charles River in Massachusetts.

title: Real-time Fighting Game Commentary Generation via Strategic Rationale Distillation
authors: Boyu Chuang, Menghan Zhang, Thai van Nguyen, Yiyang Liu, Ruck Thawonmas
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper presents an application of using large language models (LLM) in real-time commentary generation in a fighting game. This study transfers the strategic reasoning of GPT-4o to a lightweight T5 model (248M parameters) using rationale distillation inspired by RDRec. We introduce Combat Flow, a compressed representation of 180-frame (3-second) game segments extracted from raw frame-level battle data including player health, energy, position, and stamina. Across 300 test cases, our approach achieves approximately 113% quality improvement over direct fine-tuning, while maintaining equivalent fluency (4.04) to the teacher model. Processing speed improves by 15.0% on RTX 3080 and 20.0% on P2000 GPUs. Human evaluation with 160 votes shows our model places first or ties in 75% of commentary styles, with technical commentary outperforming the teacher model (52.5% vs. 45%). This enables practical real-time commentary systems deployable on limited edge hardware.

title: RT-YOLACT: Real-Time Instance Segmentation on Zynq SoC for Autonomous Driving
authors: Gyu Hyeon Hwang, HoBin Oh, Min Kwon Choi, HyeonJin Sim, Seung Wook Oh, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Edge autonomous driving systems are need to process visual information in real time under strict limits on computation, memory, and power. Instance segmentation, especially for lane detection, remains challenging to deploy on embedded platforms due to the complexity of modern deep learning models. We present RT-YOLACT (Real-Time YOLACT), an optimized instance segmentation framework tailored for FPGA-SoC deployment. Our approach integrates input resolution reduction, a lightweight MobileNetV4 backbone, INT8 quantization, and streamlined post-processing. The pipeline executes on Ultra96-V2 with DPU B1600, achieving 16.64 FPS end-to-end—a 13.4× speedup over the baseline with only 2.35% accuracy loss. Model size and parameters are reduced by 87%, and post-processing latency drops from 200.88 ms to 11.31 ms. These results demonstrate that real-time instance segmentation can be realized on ultra-low-power FPGA-SoC platforms.

title: Design for Humanitarian Markets Revisited: Human Versus Artifical Accountability
authors: Brita Fladvad Nielsen, Ana Laura R. Santos
abstract: AI promises what all humanitarian NGOs want: to reach as many war and disaster victims as possible with targeted care and protection services. However, the exponential growth of tech enhanced services with unhinged scalability potentials developed for humanitarian markets hold fundamental weaknesses and potential direct threats. We describe the experience of three NGOs, within health care for marginalized women and translation services for migrants. While designers keep the initial designs human centered and work for humanitarian outcomes, the love affair between humanitarian customers and donors with new technology is risky: on a direct, human level, and on a system level where the dependency on AI models can make it impossible to regulate and to localize ownership and contribute to longer term sustainability in low-income countries.

title: An Improved Small Target Detection Algorithm for YOLOv8 Aerial Images
authors: Zaijun Wang, Xue Wang, Ruizhe Yang, Yeteng Yan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: In the context of small target detection in aerial photography, the dense distribution of targets and the susceptibility to background occlusion often lead to missed and false detections during the detection process. Based on the YOLOv8 algorithm, a small target detection method called SOU-YOLO is proposed. In the backbone network, the lightweight network FasterNet-Block structure is introduced and combined with the multi-scale attention EMA to improve the C2f module, which reduces the model’s computational load while enhancing its feature extraction capabilities. According to the divide-and-conquer principle of the feature pyramid network, a high-resolution feature map P2 with 4× down-sampling is added for small target detection, which strengthens the model’s multi-scale feature fusion ability and improves the network’s detection accuracy for small targets.

title: Millimeter Wave Communication Channel Estimation and Intelligent Optimization Algorithm Design for 6G Era
authors: Chunqin Cao
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: In this paper, a channel estimation method based on compressed sensing and deep learning is proposed for millimeter wave (mmWave) communication system facing the 6G era, and the deep neural network (DNN) is optimized by combining genetic algorithm (GA) to improve the accuracy and efficiency of channel estimation. Firstly, the mmWave channel model including multipath effect and path loss is established, and the channel state information (CSI) is reconstructed from a small number of observation data by compressed sensing technology, and the initial channel estimation is made by orthogonal matching pursuit (OMP) algorithm. Then, the depth residual network is introduced to optimize the initial estimation results of OMP, and the nonlinear mapping ability of DNN is used to further improve the estimation accuracy. In addition, this paper transforms DNN optimization problem into GA fitness function optimization problem, and improves the generalization ability of DNN parameters through population evolution. The simulation results show that the OMP+DNN+GA method proposed in this paper improves the channel estimation accuracy by about 3.5 dB compared with the traditional OMP algorithm in the indoor mmWave communication scenario with 28 GHz band and 400 MHz bandwidth, and the normalized mean square error (NMSE) reaches -25.6 dB when the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is 20 dB, which meets the requirements of 6 G system. At the same time, this method has excellent performance in bit error rate (BER). When SNR is 20 dB, BER is as low as 3.0e-7, which is significantly lower than the traditional method. The introduction of GA further improves the convergence speed and performance stability of the system, and verifies the effectiveness of the intelligent optimization algorithm in channel estimation of 6G mmWave.

title: A study on predicting ward outpatient income based on the GB-PS model
authors: Tian Qi Hou, Bao Tian, Hao Xu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: A sound mechanism for refereeing historical data is an important basis for medical resource allocation and subsequent management. This study focuses on analyzing the historical development and trend of outpatient revenue in the operating data of medical institutions, and adopts various key prediction models to analyze and predict outpatient revenue. Taking the date, number of patients, total drug revenue and ward revenue of the day as the basic inputs, this study constructs LSTM, Prophet, ARIMA and SARIMA models to predict outpatient revenues, and introduces MSE, MAE, RMSE and the coefficient of determination $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$ as the evaluation indexes, and selects LSTM and Prophet, which are more applicable models, after comparative analysis. After comparative analysis, LSTM and Prophet, two models with higher applicability, were selected, and their results were combined for further optimization. In this study, the integrated learning models Random Forest and GBDT were used for analysis and prediction respectively. Comparing the MSE and $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$, the $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$ scores of Random Forest and GBDT were 0.98 and 1.0, respectively, but in the case of the maximum normal MSE with a value of about 170 million, the MSE of Random Forest was even more up to 290 million, and the MSE of GBDT was controlled to be 0.1 million. The evaluation concluded that the GBDT model has a better prediction effect and provides a reliable decision basis for medical management and subsequent allocation of resources.

title: Federated XGBoost-Powered Web Application for Safeguarding Personal Health Data in Hospitals and Clinics of Metropolitan Lima
authors: Sebastian Yon, Jenny Espinoza, Carlos Alvarado
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: In the current context of digitalization, artificial intelligence (AI) has become a key opportunity for transforming operations in the healthcare sector. However, its adoption faces challenges related to data privacy, trust in emerging technologies, and technical limitations, particularly in medical institutions in developing countries. Although several studies have explored federated learning (FL) for preserving privacy in clinical environments, there remains a gap in its application within contexts that face limited infrastructure and operate under specific regulatory frameworks, such as in Peru. In this study, we present a federated-learning-based web platform integrating an XGBoost model to diagnose premature births without centralizing sensitive clinical data. The system was designed to operate across multiple healthcare institutions in Metropolitan Lima, ensuring regulatory compliance and preserving data privacy. Preliminary results demonstrate the technical feasibility of this approach, highlighting an effective balance between privacy, diagnostic accuracy, and adaptability to limited infrastructures. This proposal contributes to the secure adoption of AI in Latin America's healthcare sector.

title: Using Retrieval Augmented Generation and Knowledge Graphs to Understand Climate Obstruction
authors: Michael DeBellis, George Gino, Aadarsh Balaji, Jacob Gino
abstract: Climate change is one of the most serious crises the human race has faced. Unlike previous crises such as the destruction of the ozone layer, the world has not addressed the issue. This has been blamed on poor science communication. Social scientists have hypothesized that the primary problem is that large corporations with vested interests have orchestrated a campaign of disinformation called Climate Obstruction. This project collects various resources about Climate Obstruction into a knowledge graph corpus using a Large Language Model (LLM) as the user interface via a Retrieval Augmented Generation architecture (RAG). The corpus includes databases about Climate Obstruction as well as documents that define concepts such as Green Washing. The immediate benefit is a tool that facilitates accessing heterogeneous data in a unified portal via natural language. Our approach uses the logical foundation of the Web Ontology Language (OWL), coupled with the LLM capability to model text meaning as vectors. This enables defining rigorous climate obstruction models that can be tested against data. The current system is a prototype that is robust and usable but has not yet gone through user testing.

title: Benchmarking YOLOv8 Model Compression Techniques for Egg Detection on Edge Hardware
authors: Karisma Trinanda Putra, Hasan Zidni, Moh. Khairudin, Adi Izhar Bin Che Ani, Rizki Ahmad Setiadi, Deny Budi Hertanto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Accurate object detection is crucial in modern poultry farming particularly for egg detection, to support automation and monitoring systems. However, deploying advanced models such as YOLOv8 on edge devices poses challenges due to limited computational and memory resources. This study evaluates the effectiveness of compressing YOLOv8n using TensorFlow Lite (TFLite) to enable real-time egg detection in resource-constrained environments. A custom dataset of annotated egg images was used to train a baseline YOLOv8n model. The trained model was then converted into two TFLite variants: 16-bit floating point (FP16) and 8-bit integer (INT8), using TensorFlow’s export pipeline. The original YOLOv8n achieved 0.87 mAP@0.5, 0.88 precision, and 0.86 recall with a memory size of 5.96 MB. The FP16 model preserved comparable accuracy (mAP@0.5 = 0.83) while reducing memory usage to 5.88 MB and improving inference time. The INT8 model further reduced memory usage to 3.13 MB, with minor accuracy degradation (mAP@0.5 = 0.80, precision = 0.85, recall = 0.84). The results demonstrate that TFLite-based compression enhances model deployability on edge hardware by reducing resource demands while maintaining real-time performance, providing practical insights for implementing efficient object detection in smart farming applications.

title: Utilizing Ai to Support Conversations in Individuals With Asd
authors: John M. Esparragoza, Armando Delgado, Berenice De la Cruz, Damian Valles
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: This project explores the feasibility of integrating Computer Vision and Natural Language Processing to support conversations in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Our goal was to develop the framework and prototype of a system capable of generating meaningful narratives from both images and videos. However, due to technical and resource constraints, we refined the scope to focus solely on image-based inputs. We implement vision-language models to generate simplified, contextually relevant captions that can be adapted to the user's communication level through a most-to-least prompting strategy. The end product is a web-based prototype using Streamlit. The prototype features an accessible interface designed for users with ASD, text-to-speech functionality, and adjustable prompt fading controls. This system establishes a foundation for future research aimed at improving the quality of narrative generation, incorporating user feedback, and implementing a scalable platform that supports expressive communication and social participation for individuals with ASD.

title: Machine Learning Classification of Anomalous Durations of Electrical Appliance Utilization
authors: David Shilane, Ashwathi Prakash Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Non-intrusive load monitoring (NILM) utilizes power readings from electrical appliances to gain insights about energy usage without the use of specialize sensors. Many applications of NILM focus on the classification of electrical appliances. This study investigates cases of anomalous utilization of household appliances based on an unusually long duration. Automatic detection of anomalous usage would facilitate a system of reminders to shut off electrical appliances and to reduce unnecessary power utilization. This study develops machine learning approaches to classifying cases of anomalous durations of electrical utilization. The publicly available SustDataE2 data set provides a time series of electrical power readings for a range of household appliances. We defined anomalous cases based upon a duration that exceeds 1.5 standard deviations above the average value partitioned by category. We developed random forest machine learning models to classify anomalous cases. The features of the model include the observed peak power, mean power, time to peak power, and the number of local maxima prior to the peak for each period of activation. We also incorporate a predicted classification of the appliance category based on an intermediate random forest model. In addition to the original training data, we also applied upsampling to increase the number of cases in the training data by a factor of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4}$</tex>. The classification models of anomalous duration were compared based upon a range of classification metrics. These models demonstrated moderate performance, modest specificity. The balanced accuracy of the upsampled model was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 4. 0 \%}$</tex>. This demonstrates a promising baseline for further improvements in detecting anomalous durations of utilization with NILM techniques.

title: From Lab to Field: Lessons from a Design-Led PhD in Humanitarian Healthcare Technology
authors: Md Haseen Akhtar
abstract: This paper presents a reflective account of a design-led PhD journey in humanitarian technology, focused on developing deployable mobile Primary Health Centers (mPHCs) for low resource settings. Through an iterative, community-centered approach, the author navigated the complex challenges of designing healthcare technologies for underserved populations, addressing the five A's framework: Awareness, Access, Absence, Affordability, and Accountability. Our research culminated in a novel collapsible mPHC system that reduced deployment weight from 75kg to 5kg and setup time from 60 to 10 minutes. This work demonstrates the critical importance of contextual design thinking, stakeholder engagement, and empathetic innovation in humanitarian technology development, offering valuable insights for the research community pursuing socially impactful technological interventions.

title: Research on Virtual Power Plant Prediction and Scheduling Algorithm Based on Big Data
authors: Yuxuan Ye, Zhaofeng Guo, Jian Zhang, Hao Ning, Shengwei Wang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: With the wide access of renewable energy sources and the continuous improvement of power system intelligence, Virtual Power Plant (VPP), as an important means of integrating distributed energy resources, has gradually become a key component in the construction of smart grid. Due to the uncertainty of renewable energy output and the volatility of customer load, VPP faces the problems of insufficient prediction accuracy and inefficient scheduling efficiency in actual operation. The development of big data technology provides new ideas for the accurate prediction and intelligent dispatch of virtual power plants. This paper focuses on the research of virtual power plant prediction and scheduling algorithms based on big data, firstly, we analyze the acquisition and processing of heterogeneous data from multiple sources in the virtual power plant, and construct a load prediction framework integrating machine learning and deep learning models; then, we put forward a multi-objective scheduling optimization algorithm, which improves the economy and reliability of the scheduling strategy; and finally, we discuss the collaborative control mechanism based on the big data drive to realize the dynamic resources within the virtual power plant and to realize the dynamic resources within the virtual power plant. Finally, a big data-driven cooperative control mechanism is explored to realize dynamic coordination and adaptive scheduling of resources within virtual power plants. The results of the study show that big data technology has significant advantages in improving the operational efficiency and intelligence level of virtual power plants, which provides theoretical support and technical paths for the construction of a new type of power system.

title: A Study on the Correlation Between Metafiction Games and Game Addiction Prevention
authors: Qi Yi, Jeanhun Chung
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: In game studies, narrative and mechanics have long been treated as distinct entry points of analysis. Research on game addiction has largely focused on Flow Theory and Positive Feedback Loops, emphasizing how mechanics sustain immersion and reinforce addictive behaviors. In contrast, relatively little attention has been paid to how narratives shape addiction, either intensifying or mitigating it. Metafiction games, as a self-reflective genre, often disrupt immersion through strategies such as breaking the fourth wall, prompting players to reflect on their actions, and interrupting the flow of play. Drawing on Brecht's theory of the alienation effect, this paper examines how metafiction games can reduce addictive tendencies through narrative, and explores ways of embedding anti-addiction strategies into game design. As a theoretical inquiry, the study offers a framework for future empirical validation and provides a reference point for developing narrative-based approaches to addiction prevention in games.

title: Research on Comprehensive Modeling and Optimization Algorithm of Environmental Energy System Driven by Multi-Source Data
authors: Xuewei Wang, Zhi Li, Chunfang Zhang, Yuanyuan Fang, Hua Zhou
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Traditional modeling methods rely on simplified models and limited data, so it is difficult to accurately reflect the complexity and dynamics of the system. This paper proposes a comprehensive modeling method based on multisource data, which integrates multi-source data such as sensors, monitoring equipment and historical records, and establishes a comprehensive model of environmental energy system (EES) through data preprocessing, feature extraction and model construction. In data fusion, Kalman filter algorithm is used to fuse sensor data to improve the accuracy of system state estimation; In feature selection, ReliefF algorithm is used to screen out features useful for modeling; Deep neural network (DNN) is selected for modeling, and the prediction of EES performance index is realized through the division of training set, verification set and test set and the training of back propagation algorithm. In the research of optimization algorithm, this paper chooses Differential Evolution Algorithm (DE) as the main optimization algorithm to reduce the total energy consumption of the system, improve the energy efficiency by at least 10 % and reduce carbon emissions. DE algorithm iteratively optimizes through the steps of population initialization, mutation operation, crossover operation and selection operation until it meets the predetermined iteration times or convergence conditions. Taking an industrial production line as an example, through the data fusion of Kalman filter algorithm and the establishment of DNN model, the optimization measures have significantly improved a number of key performance indicators. The energy utilization efficiency has increased by 12 %, the total energy consumption of the system has decreased by 10 %, the carbon emission has decreased by 16 %, and the production qualification rate and the average running time of equipment have also been optimized, which proves the effectiveness and practicability of the multi-source data-driven comprehensive modeling method and optimization algorithm in EES optimization, and provides useful reference for other EES optimization.

title: Research on Distribution Network Condition Monitoring and Fault Diagnosis Algorithm Based on Beidou Positioning System
authors: Yufeng Chai, Zhongying Zhao, Bo Jia, Yide Xie, Bin Li
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: As an important part of power system, the stability and reliability of distribution network's operation state are directly related to users' electricity consumption experience and the normal operation of economy and society. However, the complex distribution network structure and frequent line faults, especially single-phase grounding faults, have brought great challenges to the operation and maintenance of the power grid. Traditional troubleshooting methods rely on manual inspection and empirical judgment, which are inefficient and have limited accuracy. In this paper, a distribution network condition monitoring and fault diagnosis algorithm based on Beidou positioning system is proposed. The system consists of digital fault indicator of distribution network, Beidou communication network and master station system. Through real-time monitoring of current, voltage and other parameters of distribution network, Beidou positioning module is used to determine the fault location, and fault diagnosis is carried out with the help of intelligent algorithm. The algorithm extracts fault features through wavelet transform, makes preliminary fault location and type judgment by combining Beidou positioning information, further establishes fault model and introduces genetic algorithm optimization to improve diagnosis accuracy and speed. The experimental results show that the algorithm is superior to the existing technology in fault location accuracy, fault type judgment accuracy and operation efficiency, and can realize high-precision diagnosis in a variety of complex fault scenarios, providing new technical support and solutions for intelligent operation and maintenance of distribution networks.

title: Research on Intelligent Algorithm-Driven Fault Localization and Repair Technology of Power Line
authors: Zhengwei Li, Yalin Wu, Baocheng Zhang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: With the increasing scale and complexity of modern power grids, the rapid localization and efficient repair of power line faults have become a key issue in ensuring the stable operation of power systems. Traditional fault detection and repair methods often rely on manual inspection or rule-based diagnostic models, which have limitations such as long response time, insufficient accuracy, and poor adaptability. In recent years, the application of intelligent algorithms in power systems has become increasingly widespread, and fault diagnosis and repair schemes based on machine learning, deep learning and intelligent optimization techniques can effectively improve the accuracy of fault location and repair efficiency. This paper systematically discusses the application of intelligent algorithms in fault location and repair of power lines, analyzes the data-driven fault detection method, and focuses on the improvement of intelligent optimization algorithms in positioning accuracy. Intelligent repair strategies based on automated scheduling, robot and UAV-assisted repair, and multi-source information fusion are studied. Future development directions are proposed to address the challenges faced by the current technology, such as algorithm generalization capability, computational resource requirements and real-time issues. The study shows that the intelligent algorithm-driven fault location and repair technology can significantly improve the intelligent management level of power grids, which is of great significance for enhancing the security and reliability of power systems.

title: Two-Decade Assessment of Land Degradation (SDG 15.3.1) and Urban Expansion in Lucknow Using MODIS and Landsat
authors: Zahra Rizvi
abstract: A detailed, reproducible analysis of land-cover change in Lucknow, India (26.72°-26.96° N, 80.80°-81.10° E), over a 20-year period (2001–2020) is presented using Google Earth Engine (GEE). The analysis integrates MODIS MCDl2Qlland-cover data (International Geosphere-Biosphere Programme (IGBP) scheme, 500 m resolution) with Landsat 7/8 surface reflectance composites (30 m resolution) to quantify changes in land classes and vegetation health. The workflow involves (1) computing pixel counts for 17 IGBP categories in 2001 and 2020, (2) generating median Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) composites with corresponding sum-mary statistics (mean, minimum, maximum), and (3) sampling 1,000 random pixels in 2020 to examine the NDVI-IGBP class relationship. To strengthen the validity of findings, the results were cross-validated using official zoning maps and visual inspection against high-resolution basemaps. A preliminary supervised learning experiment using logistic regression was also conducted to demonstrate the dataset's suitability for classification tasks. Results show a 13.9 % decrease in cropland (Class 12) and a 17.0% increase in urbanlbuilt-up land (Class 13), along with a decline in mean NDVI by 0.0315. These findings support applications in environmental monitoring, poli-cymaking, and machine learning workflows. The complete GEE scripts are openly available on GitHub to promote transparency and community-driven extension.

title: Utilization of Large Language Model-Based Embeddings for Recommendation Systems
authors: Aiden Bosela, Heba Elgazzar
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: The field of recommendation systems has seen rapid innovation and exploration of new techniques in recent years. One area of recent focus has been on incorporating large language models (LLMs) into the recommendation process for various purposes. One of the few methods for this incorporation has been to use LLMs to embed textual descriptions of recommendation items into high dimensional vectors. This paper focuses on investigating and comparing the ways these LLM embeddings can be utilized in conjunction with traditional recommendation system methods. In this paper, we design and implement a hybrid recommender system that consists of a collaborative filtering system and multiple separate content-based systems which utilize LLM-generated text embeddings. Several different methods for recommendation based on these embeddings were implemented in order to compare between them. Experimental results indicate a better performance and relevance from methods which rely on item-embedding distances in embedding space than other popular methods, and that clustering embeddings for recommendations may not be possible in all use cases. Additionally, the results highlight the potential utility and use cases of textual embeddings for recommendation systems.

title: IndoGroundingDINO: Monolingual Open-Vocabulary Visual Grounding with Swin-T and IndoBERT
authors: Diva Aninditha, Suryo Adhi Wibowo, Koredianto Usman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Recent advancements in Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have unlocked open-vocabulary visual grounding in English. However, reliance on English-only prompts limits applicability in low-resource settings. We present IndoGroundingDINO, the first fully monolingual Indonesian open-vocabulary object detector, by replacing Grounding DINO’s English BERT encoder with IndoBERT and translating caption of the COCO val2017 captions into Indonesian language. We conduct a controlled three-way comparision: (i) English Grounding DINO (Swin-T & BERT) with original English captions, (ii) the same model with manually translated Indonesian captions, and (iii) IndoGroundingDINO (Swin-T & IndoBERT) trained on Indonesian inputs. Each setup uses subsets of 200 COCO images (600 captions) for 20 epochs and evaluated using mAP, Recall, IoU, and F1-score. IndoGroundingDINO achieves an F1-score of 0.210 (versus the English baseline’s 0.220), recovering 91.8% of the F1-score gap, and increases mAP@0.5:0.9 from 0.118 to 0.132 (a 1.1× improvement over the English model, while requiring only 200 images and minimal computational cost. Qualitative analyses further demonstrate high-confidence localization of Indonesian prompts, comparable to the English model. The results show that language-consistent encoders can effectively bridge the performance gaps in monolingual grounding, paving the way for globally inclusive VLMs in under-resourced languages.

title: Development of a Servo-Based Model Rocket and Flight Behavior Analysis Using IMU Data
authors: Conrad Motis, Safina Baiocchi, Jie Sheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: A servo-based model rocket uses small servomotors to control its flight path, which is thus known as using “active control” instead of relying on passive stabilization fins only. This paper presents our project in developing a servo-based model rocket by modifying an Estes Green Eggs model rocket. By integrating a Pi Pico, BNO055 IMU and SD card into the rocket, we are able to launch the rocket with active vertical-flight steering fin control and got flight data recorded from numerous launches. Although no GPS used, we are able to analyze the active flight control behavior based on fundamental physics and IMU data logging to the SD card. There are plenty of similar hobby projects broadcast over social media platforms; however, few of them have been written down and published to share with the academic community. It is thus the contribution of this paper that we describe in details the design, building and data loggging/analysis of a servo-based model rocket with active control. In addition, we have made this project open-source on GitHub.

title: Research on multimode wireless communication system for the Niihama Taiko Festival drum position display application
authors: Haruto Yamada, Mikiko Sode Tanaka
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: The Niihama Taiko Festival is a major event in Ehime Prefecture. However, as 54 taiko floats parade freely through the city, it is difficult to know their current location, causing traffic jams in various locations as people try to view the floats. Improving spectator convenience and mitigating traffic congestion are key challenges, and tracking the location of the 54 taiko floats is a key issue. In this study, as part of Niihama City's Smart City Project, we aim to solve these issues using IoT technology. We developed a multi-mode wireless communication system to effectively utilize existing wireless systems in daily use. Bluetooth beacons are installed on the taiko floats to obtain real-time location information for each float. The Bluetooth beacons communicate with beacon base stations via Bluetooth. Communication between beacon base stations is via LoRa. Data is collected by the main base station via LoRa, uploaded to the cloud, and displayed on the web application "Dondoko," which presents the taiko float's location information to visitors. This paper introduces this multi-mode wireless communication system. This paper provides a detailed explanation of the system architecture and application functionality. The system performed as planned in tests.

title: Forecasting Sea Water Level Using Deep Learning Models for Enhanced Coastal Flood Management and Mitigation
authors: Md Shah Mominul Islam Momin, Damian Valles, Eunsang Cho
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Accurate forecasting of coastal seawater levels is essential for flood mitigation, infrastructure planning, and port operations in coastal regions. This study evaluates four deep learning models-LSTM, GRU, CNN-LSTM, and Transformer-for hourly sea level forecast using 50 years of water level data. A complete modeling pipeline was implemented, including STL decomposition, temporal feature engineering, normalization, and walk-forward validation to find out the best parameters for each model. Then each model fully trained with those parameters and assessed using RMSE, MAE, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> metrics. The Transformer outperformed others, achieving the highest accuracy and lowest errors. It also maintained strong generalization in forecasting for December 2024. These results highlight the Transformer's capability to model complex tidal behavior and long-range temporal dependencies, making it a promising tool for operational coastal flood management.

title: Joint Forecasting Method for Wind and Solar Power Generation and Electricity Load
authors: Jian Zhang, Lei Zheng, Shengwei Wang, Lei Li, Yuxuan Ye
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: In today's energy field, Wind Turbine Generator (WTG) and photovoltaic power (PV) have become the mainstream forms of wind and solar energy development and utilization. They play a key role in the global energy transition process with their clean and renewable advantages. However, the output power of wind and PV generation exhibits significant volatility and instability. This characteristic makes it difficult to accurately control and schedule in practical operation, posing many challenges to the grid connected operation of the power grid. Based on this, this paper proposes a deep learning (DL) based joint prediction model for wind and solar power (WSP) generation and electricity load. This model improves the prediction accuracy of WSP generation and load by deeply exploring and learning the dynamic coupling relationship between them. After extensive experimental verification, the model constructed in this article can accurately predict the power and load of WSP generation, providing strong data support for the stable operation and reasonable scheduling of the power grid, and helping to improve the safety and economy of the electrical power system (EPS).

title: Advanced Machine Learning Models for Predicting Irrigation Water Quality: A Comparative Study of LSTM, SVM, and XGBoost Algorithms in Rice Cultivation
authors: Vito Hafizh Cahaya Putra, Agung Rachmat Raharja, Ghanim Kanugrahan, Cuk Tho, Muhammad Al-Husaini
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Managing Irrigation water quality plays a crucial role in ensuring healthy crops and sustainable agricultural practices, particularly in rice farming. This study evaluates the effectiveness of three machine learning algorithms—LSTM, SVM, and XGBoost—in classifying the quality of irrigation water based on real-world datasets. The dataset included key parameters such as pH, temperature, dissolved oxygen (DO), and carbon monoxide (CO). Preprocessing techniques like data augmentation and normalization were applied to enhance model performance. The results revealed that XGBoost outperformed the other models with an accuracy of 77.93%, followed closely by LSTM at 76.77%, and SVM at 76.43%. XGBoost demonstrated superior performance in handling structured data and real-time monitoring, while LSTM excelled at capturing temporal patterns. SVM, though effective for simpler classification tasks, struggled with larger time-series datasets. These findings underscore the potential of machine learning models for improving irrigation water quality predictions. Future research will explore hybrid models and incorporate larger datasets to further enhance prediction accuracy, ultimately supporting sustainable irrigation practices and precision agriculture.

title: Lightweight Image Super-Resolution via Progressive Pruning and Adaptive Distillation
authors: Jeonghyeok Park, Byung Cheol Song
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Recent advances in image super-resolution (SR) have achieved remarkable performance through the adoption of transformer-based and diffusion-based models. However, their high computational complexity and memory requirements pose significant challenges for real-world deployment. To address these issues, we propose a two-stage lightweight training framework that integrates model pruning and knowledge distillation. In the first stage, we perform efficient channel reduction using progressive local filter pruning, which balances structural preservation with computational cost reduction. In the second stage, we introduce mask-based adaptive response distillation to overcome the limitations of conventional L1-based response distillation, enabling more effective knowledge transfer focused on informative regions. Experimental results on various benchmark SR datasets demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior performance and efficiency compared to existing lightweight SR approaches.

title: Understanding and Reducing the Risk of Extreme Photovoltaic Degradation
authors: Y. Tang, S. Poddar, M. Kay, F. E. Rougieux
abstract: A small number of photovoltaic modules degrade far more rapidly than average, creating a “long tail” in degradation rate distribution that poses a critical challenge to the reliability and financial viability of solar projects. This study investigates the factors contributing to this phenomenon by analyzing a large global dataset from the National Renewable Energy Laboratory. Our analysis reveals that the long tail is an intrinsic and composite feature of module degradation, not merely a statistical consequence of combining different climates. We identify at least three distinct pathways that could contribute to its formation. The first is accelerated degradation driven by strong statistical associations between different degradation modes, where the interplay of mechanisms appears to be a primary contributor of the most severely degraded modules. The second is rapid early-life failure (infant mortality), which populates the tail with modules likely containing initial manufacturing or material defects. The third is failure of individual latent defects, such as solder fatigue or cell cracks, which can cause sudden severe performance loss at random points in a module's life. Based on our results, we suggest that efforts should be made to understand and mitigate the interaction between associated degradation modes. For instance, the careful selection of key components, such as backsheet, is crucial as it could initiate multiple pathways of degradation.

title: Investigation of the Phase Tuning Technique to Improve Performance of an E-Band Sheet Beam TWT for Communication
authors: Yuxin Wang, Yuan Zheng, Yubin Gong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a comprehensive analysis and application of the phase tuning (PT) technique to enhance the performance of an E-band sheet beam (SB) folded waveguide (FWG) traveling wave tube (TWT). An in-house 1-D code was developed to rapidly determine PT parameters for different optimization objectives. A novel high-frequency circuit with a replaceable interaction structure was designed, fabricated, and cold-tested to validate the practical implementation of PT in an FWG circuit. The experimental results show good agreement with simulations: the in-band (71–76 GHz) error for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$S_{21}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> magnitude is below 6%, and the phase shift error at 73.5 GHz is 3.3%. These results validate the theoretical relationship between spatial parameters and phase shift. The two distinct PT strategies successfully increase the interaction efficiency at the center frequency by 37.9% or reduce the in-band gain fluctuation from 0.85 to 0.18 dB, respectively.

title: Energy Detection over Composite $\kappa - \mu$ Shadowed Fading Channels with Inverse Gaussian Distribution
authors: He Huang, Zeping Sui, Zilong Liu, Haishi Wang, Wei Huang, Zhiheng Hu, Md. Noor-A-Rahim
abstract: This paper investigates the characteristics of energy detection (ED) over composite $\kappa$-$\mu$ shadowed fading channels in device-to-device (D2D) networks. We have derived the closed-form expressions of the probability density function (PDF) of signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) based on the Inverse Gaussian (IG) distribution. By adopting some novel integration and mathematical transformation techniques, we derive a truncation-based closed-form expression for the average detection probability for the first time. It can be observed from our simulations that the number of propagation paths has a more pronounced effect on average detection probability compared to average SNR, which contrasts with earlier studies that focus on D2D networks. It suggests that for D2D networks design, we shall consider enhancing transmitter-receiver placement and antenna alignment strategies, rather than relying solely on increasing the D2D average SNR.

title: On the Additivity of Optimal Rates for Independent Zero-Error Source and Channel Problems
authors: Nicolas Charpenay, Maël Le Treust, Aline Roumy
abstract: Zero-error coding encompasses a variety of source and channel problems where the probability of error must be exactly zero. This condition is stricter than that of the vanishing error regime, where the error probability goes to zero as the code blocklength goes to infinity. In general, zero-error coding is an open combinatorial question. We investigate two unsolved zero-error problems: the source coding problem with side information and the channel coding problem. We focus our attention on families of independent problems for which the probability distribution decomposes into a product of probability distributions. A crucial step is the additivity property of the optimal rate, which does not always hold in the zero-error regime, unlike in the vanishing error regime. When the additivity holds, the concatenation of optimal codes is optimal. We derive a condition under which the additivity of the complementary graph entropy H for the AND product of graphs and for the disjoint union of graphs are equivalent. Then we establish the connection with a recent result obtained by Wigderson and Zuiddam and by Schrijver, for the zero-error capacity C0. As a consequence, we provide new single-letter characterizations of H and C0, for example when the graph is a product of perfect graphs, which is not perfect in general, and for the class of graphs obtained by the product of a perfect graph G with the pentagon graph C5. By building on Haemers result for C0, we also show that the additivity of H does not hold for the product of the Schläfli graph with its complementary graph.

title: GhostUMAP2: Measuring and Analyzing (r,d)-Stability of UMAP
authors: Myeongwon Jung, Takanori Fujiwara, Jaemin Jo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Despite the widespread use of Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP), the impact of its stochastic optimization process on the results remains underexplored. We observed that it often produces unstable results where the projections of data points are determined mostly by chance rather than reflecting neighboring structures. To address this limitation, we introduce (r,d)-stability to UMAP: a framework that analyzes the stochastic positioning of data points in the projection space. To assess how stochastic elements-specifically, initial projection positions and negative sampling-impact UMAP results, we introduce “ghosts”, or duplicates of data points representing potential positional variations due to stochasticity. We define a data point's projection as (r,d)-stable if its ghosts perturbed within a circle of radius r in the initial projection remain confined within a circle of radius d for their final positions. To efficiently compute the ghost projections, we develop an adaptive dropping scheme that reduces a runtime up to 60% compared to an unoptimized baseline while maintaining approximately 90% of unstable points. We also present a visualization tool that supports the interactive exploration of the (r,d)-stability of data points. Finally, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our framework by examining the stability of projections of real-world datasets and present usage guidelines for the effective use of our framework.
