title: Multi-Perspective and Energy-Efficient Deep Learning in Edge Computing
authors: Haitao Yuan, Jing Bi, Ziqi Wang, Jia Zhang, MengChu Zhou, Rajkumar Buyya
abstract: The deployment of billions of Internet of Things (IoT) devices is driving unprecedented data generation at the network edge, demanding high computational power for real-time deep learning (DL) while raising serious concerns about energy consumption. While edge computing offers a viable paradigm for decentralized DL by preserving data privacy and reducing latency, the substantial energy costs of DL training and inference pose a major challenge for resource-constrained edge devices. This work provides a comprehensive review of state-of-the-art studies that address energy efficiency at the intersection of DL and edge computing. Moving beyond isolated solutions, we analyze the critical need for a co-design approach integrating hardware and software with adaptive resource management to build sustainable systems. The paper systematically examines hardware-level optimizations and software-level techniques for reducing energy consumption while maintaining model accuracy. Furthermore, it investigates how adaptive management of compute, memory, and communication resources is key to dynamic energy savings. Finally, the paper synthesizes recent trends, identifies emerging opportunities, and discusses open challenges, positioning hardware-software co-design as the most promising approach for achieving scalable and energy-efficient deep learning in edge computing.

title: Design and Analysis of PCB Embedded SiC Half-Bridge Packaging Cells with Low Thermal Resistance and Parasitic Inductance
authors: Chao Gu, Wei Chen, Hao Guan, Jing Jiang, Guanqiang Song, Yuhong Li, Tiancheng Tian, Junwei Chen, Xuyang Yan, Guoqi Zhang, Jiajie Fan
abstract: Reducing parasitic parameters and thermal resistance is critical for advancing power electronic devices. This paper designs and evaluates the three Printed Circuit Board (PCB) embedded 1200 V SiC MOSFET half-bridge packaging cells, where the traditional wire bonding process is replaced by a re-distribution layer (RDL) technique. A comprehensive evaluation of their electrical performance, thermal management, and mechanical performance is conducted. The three solutions that employ panel, active metal brazing (AMB), and lead-frame carriers, are developed through a streamlined process that includes die attach, molding, drilling, plating, and etching. This packaging approach readily reduces the parasitic inductance to below 5 nH. By utilizing a single-layer RDL with mutual inductance cancellation, the power loop inductance is reduced to as low as 2.4 nH (at 10 MHz), and the gate loop inductance to 1.57 nH (at 10 MHz). The junction-to-case thermal resistances of the three solutions are 1.88 K/W, 1.03 K/W, and 0.73 K/W, respectively. Compared with the other two packaging cells, the cell selecting AMB as a carrier reduces SiC MOSFET operational stress and deformation by approximately 34% and 75%. The lead- frame carrier offers superior thermal dissipation for potential TO package replacement in half-bridge topologies, while the panel solution is promising for dual-sided cooling applications. With low thermal resistance, minimal stress, and excellent backside electrical insulation, the packaging cell with an AMB carrier is ideally suited for integration with heatsinks in traction inverters.

title: Design and Implementation of a Magnetostatic-Responsive Stub-Loaded Phase Shifter with Stepwise Precise Phase Control for X-Band Wireless and Radar Applications
authors: Muhammad Ayaz, Ahmed Alqurashi, Turki Essa Alharbi, Fatima Abdul Rasheed
abstract: This research work presents a compact, low-insertion-loss, and bias-free stub-loaded phase shifter with wideband characteristics operating in the X-band frequency range (10.4–11.4 GHz), termed the Magnetostatic-Responsive Stub-Loaded (MS-SL) Phase Shifter. The design consists of two cost-effective FR-4 substrates, with transmission lines placed on the top and bottom layers, and a slotted ground plane sandwiched between them. The coupled region incorporates two rectangular stubs which consists of Magneto Static Responsive Structures (MSRS) arranged in both horizontal and vertical configurations. Each MSRS cavity is filled with nano-magnetic particles (25 μm in size, containing 15% silver) and capped with copper on both ends. These structures are activated using small external magnets to achieve discrete phase shifts of 3°, 4°, 5°, 15°, 25°and 35°. For larger phase shifts 90°or 180° multiple MS-SL units can be cascaded. The proposed phase shifter is highly compact (13 mm × 5.65 mm) and achieves low insertion loss (~3 dB). It enables precise stepwise phase control through selective row-wise and column-wise activation of MSRS elements. Further, its RMS magnitude error across the operational band (10.4−11.4 GHz) lies between 0.3 and 0.5 dB, which is well within acceptable limits for practical RF applications. Similarly, the RMS phase error approaches 0° at 11 GHz and remains within 0°to 1.5°for all tested phase steps (3°, 4°, 5°) indicating high precision in phase-shifting performance. The proposed MS-SL phase shifter was analyzed using comprehensive mathematical modeling using MATLAB environment, ADS circuit simulations, and full-wave EM simulations in CST Microwave Studio Suit, with final validation through VNA measurements. These excellent matching results confirm its suitability for advanced RF applications, particularly beamforming antenna arrays, where precise and compact phase control is essential. Furthermore, the strong agreement between simulation and measurement underscores the robustness of the proposed MS-SL phase shifter and its practical potential for X-Band wireless and radar applications.

title: FSO communication system with energy harvesting strategy for smart city application: Design and performance analysis
authors: D Komathi, G Aarthi
abstract: Smart cities play an important role in leveraging the lifestyle of their citizens through the integration of information and communication technology (ICT). Most of the smart city applications, like intelligent traffic monitoring, smart emergency transportation, and IoT-based urban surveillance, depend on ICT in order to support intensive data transmission. The free space optical communication (FSO) system integrated with an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) is considered a potential approach to implement the aforementioned applications. This work focuses on UAV-based FSO communication for smart emergency transportation in smart cities. The key contribution of this proposed work is energy harvesting (EH) using simultaneous lightwave information and power transfer (SLIPT) technology in UAVs in order to extend its lifetime for supporting the emergency services. The analysis is done by deriving an analytical equation considering atmospheric turbulence, pointing error, and angle of arrival (AoA) fluctuation. This study achieves a maximum average harvested power of about 72 mW. Hence, this study would help to establish a framework for autonomous and sustainable communication in smart cities. In addition to energy harvesting, the outage probability and average bit error rate (ABER) of the system are analyzed. The analytical results that are obtained are validated by Monte-Carlo simulations using MATLAB.

title: Frequency-Hopping Continuous-Wave and Pulsed Microwave Signal Generation in An Optoelectronic Parametric Oscillator
authors: Ziwei Xu, Xuyan Zhang, Zhenlong Li, Zhen Zeng, Heping Li, Zhiyao Zhang, Yong Liu
abstract: An approach for generating frequency-hopping continuous-wave (CW) and pulsed microwave signals is proposed and demonstrated. It is based on an optoelectronic parametric oscillator (OEPO) that incorporates a tunable dual-passband filter, a microwave mixer and a dual-drive Mach-Zehnder modulator (DDMZM). By injecting a single-tone signal with its frequency equal to the frequency difference between dominated modes in the two passbands into the mixer, parametric oscillation causes the two modes to occur alternatively in each round trip, generating regular or random frequency-hopping CW signals. By injecting another multi-tone signal with its repetition rate equal to the free spectral range of the OEPO cavity into the DDMZM, active mode locking is achieved, generating frequency-hopping pulsed microwave signals. Numerical simulation and experiment are implemented to verify the feasibility of the scheme. In the experiment, regular and random frequency-hopping CW and pulsed microwave signals within the X band (8-12 GHz) are generated, achieving a frequency-hopping time as low as ∼25 ns and a frequency-hopping rate exceeding 60000 hops/s. The two hopping frequencies are tunable across the X band, with phase noise levels between -130.60 dBc/Hz to -123.87 dBc/Hz at 10 kHz offset. This approach offers a flexible solution for generating multi-format frequency-hopping microwave signals over a broad frequency range, showing promising potential for anti-jamming radar and wireless communication applications.

title: Edge-Aware Reparameterizable Network with Hybrid Bottlenecks and Spatial Attention for Efficient Compressed Image Super-Resolution
authors: Oguz Kirat, Tarik Yerlikaya
abstract: Recovering lost details from images that have been both downsampled and compressed is essential for practical computer vision systems deployed on bandwidth or memory-limited devices. We present Edge-Aware Reparameterizable Network for Compressed Image Super-Resolution (ERNCSR), a structurally reparameterizable network that couples efficiency at inference with high reconstruction fidelity. The core of ERNCSR is a lightweight multi-branch residual block that, during training, processes features through standard convolution, a fixed edge filter, and hybrid bottleneck branches to capture textures and sharp transitions. Before deployment these branches are algebraically fused into a single 3 × 3 kernel, collapsing the model to only 13.6K parameters and enabling over 20× speed-ups on consumer-grade CPUs. A spatial attention module further refines features while adding negligible overhead. Training follows a two-stage curriculum: we first learn on uncompressed bicubic data, then fine-tune with dynamically simulated JPEG, WebP, and AVIF degradations using a composite loss function. Extensive evaluations on uncompressed and compressed image variants of Set5, Set14, Urban100, DIV2K, and Manga109 demonstrate consistent gains in PSNR, SSIM, and LPIPS over comparably compact baselines, confirming ERNCSR’s suitability for realworld compressed image super-resolution.

title: Parameters and Bounds of Minimal Linear Codes Over Finite Commutative Rings
authors: Biplab Chatterjee, Ratnesh Kumar Mishra, Sihem Mesnager, Makhan Maji, Kalyan Hansda
abstract: Minimal linear codes have garnered significant attention in cryptography due to their essential role in secretsharing schemes, multiparty computation (MPC), and secure communication. While earlier studies primarily focused on minimal codes over finite fields, extending these codes to rings offers enhanced security, flexibility, and efficiency for various cryptographic applications. This article deals with minimal linear codes over finite commutative rings. Specifically, we handle a key question in minimal linear codes, which is determining the existence of an [m, k] minimal linear code with k ≤ m. In 2021, Lu,Wu and Cao proved that for some integer m(k; q), a minimal linear code of length m and dimension k always exists when m ≥ m(k; q), providing upper and lower bounds for m(k; q). This paper expands on these results by establishing both upper and lower bounds for m(k; pl) and m(k; p1p2) over Zpl and Zp1p2, respectively. We also present a necessary and sufficient condition for a linear code to achieve minimality when analyzed over the ring Zn. The fundamental question regarding minimal linear codes is whether a [m, k] minimal linear code exists, with k being less than or equal to m. Lu et al. demonstrated that there is a positive integer m(k; q) such that if m ≥ m(k; q), a minimal linear code of length m and dimension k over the finite field Fq must exist (where q is a prime power). They provided both upper and lower bounds for m(k; q). In our study, we investigate the existence of minimal codes within an extended novel framework. We analyze the case of one-dimensional minimal codes over Zn in depth and present improved upper bounds on m(k; q) specifically for the case when k = 1.

title: DynAvatar: Dynamic 3D Head Avatar Deformation with Expression Guided Gaussian Splatting
authors: Wenfeng Song, Zhongyong Ye, Zhenyu Wu, Shuai Li, Xia Hou, Aimin Hao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Generating high-fidelity, expressive, and realistic 3D head avatars remains a fundamental challenge for immersive applications such as virtual reality, gaming, and telepresence. This task requires not only precise modeling of non-rigid facial deformations but also semantically controllable expression synthesis under diverse viewpoints and motion contexts. We present DynAvatar, a novel framework that integrates expression-guided deformation into the 3D Gaussian splatting pipeline to produce photorealistic and emotionally resonant head avatars. Our method introduces two key innovations: (1) an expression-guided Gaussian deformation module that tightly couples geometric displacement with high-level semantic cues, enabling fine-grained and anatomically meaningful facial animation; and (2) a spatial context embedding mechanism that encodes the canonical position of each Gaussian to preserve semantic coherence and spatial consistency during expression generation. Extensive experiments on both controlled and in-the-wild datasets demonstrate that DynAvatar significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of visual realism, expression fidelity, and rendering quality. Our code and model will be made publicly available at https://github.com/YZhongYong/DynAvatar.git

title: Optimization of the Bit Mapping for LDPC-Coded Faster-Than-Nyquist Systems
authors: Jiayi Yang, Shuangyang Li, Qianfan Wang, Xiao Ma, Giuseppe Caire
abstract: This letter focuses on the analysis and optimization of the bit mapping for low-density parity-check (LDPC) coded faster-than-Nyquist (FTN) systems with high-order modulation. We propose the extrinsic information transfer (EXIT) chart analysis for LDPC-coded FTN systems based on the Ungerboeck observation model, where the vector-input and vector-output mutual information of the FTN detector is approximated using a suitably trained neural network (NN). Leveraging the EXIT chart, we optimize the bit mapping, i.e., the assignment of coded bits to the binary labeled constellation points, specifically for FTN systems. Through threshold analysis and simulations, it is shown that for an FTN system using a variant of the LDPC codes specified in the 5G standard, coded bits with highly reliable positions (information bits) in the Tanner graph preferentially to be transmitted over bit-wise sub-channels with higher capacity, while low-degree bits preferentially to be transmitted over bit-wise sub-channels with lower capacity. Numerical results show that: 1) the LDPC-coded FTN system with the optimized mapping outperforms those with random mappings, consistent with the proposed EXIT chart analysis; 2) under the same spectral efficiency, the LDPC-coded FTN system with optimized mapping also outperforms its 5G LDPC-coded Nyquist counterpart.

title: Knockoff-Guided Feature Selection via A Single Pre-trained Reinforced Agent
authors: Xinyuan Wang, Dongjie Wang, Wangyang Ying, Rui Xie, Haifeng Chen, Yanjie Fu
abstract: Modern data-driven applications generate vast, complex data that often contain irrelevant, redundant, or noisy features. The task involves selecting the optimal subset of features from a dataset by removing redundant and irrelevant ones to enhance downstream performance. Using reinforcement learning (RL) for feature selection is ideal for data-centric tasks due to its interactive nature, which dynamically adapts to evolving data environments. However, high initial exploration variability, reliance on downstream tasks, and the need to control the false discovery rate bring challenges. To address these issues, we introduce a knockoff-guided RL framework, which uses pseudo-features to control early-stage randomness and matrix reconstruction for unsupervised reward. Our approach is a single-agent RL approach with unsupervised rewards that utilize knockoff information and matrix reconstruction to enhance feature selection without relying on labeled data. The framework integrates three components: the knockoff information to control exploration variability, decision network pre-training to guide RL policy, and matrix reconstruction to guide unsupervised rewards. Extensive experiments are conducted on various datasets across different task types, including classification and regression, demonstrating the superiority of our framework. Codes are available here.

title: Multi-dimensional Eigenwave Multiplexing (MEM): A General Modulation for LTV Channels
authors: Zhibin Zou, Aveek Dutta
abstract: Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) and Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) modulations effectively mitigate interference caused by path delays and Doppler shifts. However, they are unable to address Inter-Doppler Interference (IDI) resulting from time-varying Doppler, and both require supplementary precoding to mitigate Inter-User Interference (IUI) in multi-user MIMO (MU-MIMO) channels. This paper presents a general modulation technique for multi-dimensional channels, called Multi-dimensional Eigenwave Multiplexing (MEM), which employs jointly orthogonal Eigenwaves as subcarriers. These Eigenwaves are derived by decomposing the channel kernel based on Higher Order Mercer's Theorem (HOGMT), enabling simultaneous cancellation of interference across all Degrees of Freedom (DoF), including space, time-frequency, and Doppler-delay. MEM achieves diversity gain in the eigen domain and eliminates the need for additional precoding. Simulations on various rapidly time-varying and MU-MIMO channels demonstrate up to two orders of magnitude improvement in bit error rate (BER) compared to OTFS, validating the accuracy and generality of the proposed modulation.

title: Frequency Domain Transformation and Loss Adjustment for Enhancing Transferability of Adversarial Examples
authors: Ruolong Wang, Jingyuan Xu, Longge Zhang, Chengchao Zhang, Wei Liu, Hongying Liu
abstract: Due to the exponential disparity in the magnitude of high- and low-frequency components in the image frequency domain, existing frequency-domain enhancement methods for adversarial examples often fail to balance the perturbations of high- and low-frequency information. To address this issue, we propose a novel Spectral Space Transformation and Loss adjustment (SSTL) method. Specifically, SSTL introduces a frequency-domain rotation-and-self-mixing strategy that adaptively balances perturbations across high- and low-frequency components, thereby generating more transferable adversarial examples. Furthermore, to mitigate semantic degradation during reconstruction, we design a logits fine-tuning mechanism that up-weights the logits of true labels while suppressing others, effectively preserving the original semantic information and avoiding misleading gradient propagation. Various experimental results demonstrate that SSTL effectively improves adversarial transferability while significantly preserving the semantic information of each image.

title: AQCSA: Anti-Quantum Cross-Server Authentication Protocol for the Industrial Internet of Drones
authors: Tuan-Vinh Le
abstract: With the advent of Industry 5.0, humans will again take center stage in decision-making processes, fully supported by artificial intelligence (AI). Drone technology has been adopted in the industry to permit efficient monitoring, detection, and avoidance of hazardous regions during industrial processes. It gives rise to a network architecture, namely industrial internet of drones (IIoD), that is controlled and managed by human expertise. Collaborative IIoD services are conducted by two or more parties in different domains, e.g., mining, construction, etc. Since the communications are carried out via public network channels, privacy and security issues, especially the risks of quantum computing, are of utmost importance. Existing cryptographic approaches encounter several disadvantages, e.g., security vulnerabilities, poor usability, etc. Moreover, no user authentication mechanisms in the literature could provide a countermeasure to quantum attacks for the above communication. Based on lattice-based cryptography (LBC), this paper proposes an anti-quantum cross-server authentication (AQCSA) protocol for securing cross-domain communication of the collaborative services. Our work is designed with a multi-factor authentication mechanism to protect cross-server user-to-user (CS-U2U) and cross-server user-to-drone (CS-U2D) communications. We conduct some practical implementations and experiments to evaluate the security and efficiency of the AQCSA. It is proven that the protocol can withstand various attacks while achieving a reasonable implementation cost in CS-IIoD environments.

title: A Federated Learning-Based Intrusion Detection System Using Dynamic Ensemble Aggregation for IoT Networks
authors: M. Baich, N. Sael
abstract: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) are essential for securing Internet of Things (IoT) and Industrial IoT (IIoT) environments, where data privacy and scalability are major challenges for traditional centralized approaches. This study proposes a Federated Learning-based IDS (FL-IDS) that leverages a lightweight Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) tailored for tabular data to detect cyber-attacks while preserving data confidentiality. To address class imbalance at the client level, we apply SMOTE locally before training. The system integrates a dynamic ensemble aggregation strategy combining Boosting with Top-K client selection, allowing the global model to adaptively weigh client contributions based on their performance history. Experiments conducted on three benchmark datasets—NSL-KDD, Edge-IIoTset and CICIDS2017 — under varying federation scales reveal that our approach consistently achieves high performance, with accuracy exceeding 98% and strong precision, recall, F1-score, and Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC), while maintaining a minimal false alarm rate. The obtained results demonstrate the capability of dynamic ensemble aggregation in federated learning for developing privacy-preserving, scalable IDS solutions suitable for IoT and IIoT environments.

title: Medium to High-Speed Position Estimation for SRMs With Single-Phase Fault-Tolerant Control Capability
authors: Zebin Yang, Lang Wang, Xiaodong Sun, Chao Sun
abstract: To address the problems of flux linkage nonlinearity and reduce the cost of estimation in position estimation of sensorless switched reluctance motors (SRMs) at medium to high speeds, a sensorless SRM control scheme based on harmonic elimination and interval position estimation is proposed in this paper, In addition, a single-phase fault-tolerant control strategy is proposed to address the possible occurrence of single-phase faults. Firstly, the flux linkage -related quantity containing rotor position information is processed by Fourier expansion to obtain the flux linkage function. Then, by enhancing the harmonic signal elimination (HSE) operator, a multi-stage harmonic elimination flux observer (MSHE-FO) is designed, which enables the generation of a set of orthogonal flux linkage signals. Subsequently, the proposed interval search estimation (ISE) method is utilized to obtain the optimal estimated position. Furthermore, this paper proposes a single-phase fault-tolerant control strategy based on the logical relationship between the phase current and the phase winding operational mode. Finally, experiments are conducted on a six-phase 12/10 SRM experimental platform. The experimental result not only verifying that the proposed sensorless control strategy offers higher control accuracy than the conventional PLL method but also confirming the effectiveness of the fault-tolerant control strategy.

title: Lokalfi: a Framework for Long-Range Wi-Fi Deployment in the Philippines
authors: Riza Carmela M. Pineda, Philip A. Martinez, Kenneth Rey L. Sumalinog
abstract: Internet access is an enabler of many human rights, including the right to education, yet billions remain offline, particularly in remote and rural areas. In the Philippines, existing public Wi-Fi networks often depend on unsustainable subsidies. LokalFi addresses this gap through a communitydriven, voucher-based Wi-Fi framework designed for last-mile deployment in geographically isolated and disadvantaged areas. This initiative aligns with the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), including ensuring inclusive and equitable quality education (SDG 4), providing universal and affordable access to the Internet (SDG 9), and making human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable (SDG 11). The LokalFi network offers internet connectivity and free access to onpremises applications tailored to community needs. Built using commercial-off-the-shelf hardware and open-source software, it features a customizable captive portal that also serves as a springboard for users to access the internet and local content. The LokalFi network was deployed in four rural communities through collaborative site selection and spectrum analysis. Field tests in mountainous terrain showed coverage radius of 450 meters, and post-deployment survey results indicate improved educational access and digital inclusion. The framework shows potential to scale sustainably with local stakeholder involvement and may extend to healthcare and disaster management use cases.

title: Towards a Computerized Information System for the Unified Management of Administrative and Educational Pathways for Learners (SIDEL)

abstract: A new and effective educational management system has been designed and implemented. Different courses of registered students are considered for the License Master Doctorate (LMD) system. Those involved in teaching experience difficulties in correctly managing and monitoring student developments. The implementation of information systems for student management and monitoring has become essential for the educational purposes. In order to respond to the problem of educational management and based on the Research Development model of [1]. The implemented platform for the management of educational registrations, evaluations and deliberations are perofrmed according to the LMD model. The results are positively appreciated by the various stakeholders and new platform has improved the efficiency in the educational facilities.

title: Stigma to Screening: Generative AI and Selfsampling Tools to Expand Cervical Cancer Screening in Low- and Middle-Income Countries
authors: Lorraine Rwasoka, Jackson Kramp, Khanjan Mehta
abstract: Cervical cancer (CC) remains a significant public health challenge in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), where limited healthcare infrastructure, socio-economic disparities, and cultural barriers greatly hinder access to screening and treatment. Despite these obstacles, many LMICs are striving to advance CC control. This study employs a narrative analysis of cervical cancer screening programs, examining eight exemplary programs and Rwanda's national initiative, to illuminate the successes, challenges, and ongoing progress in LMICs. Community engagement, mobile delivery of care, funding models, resource inadequacies, stigma, and logistical constraints. This analysis highlights the transformative role of technology in reshaping CC screening. AI-assisted diagnostics, mobile health (mHealth) platforms, high-performance HPV DNA testing with self-sampling kits, and generative AI-driven tools expand access, improving diagnostic accuracy and promoting equity. Enhancing healthcare systems through AI-based technologies helps build equity in lowincome areas.

title: Function and Practice of Large Model in Hydropower Dispatching Optimization Under Manmachine Cooperation Mode
authors: Wei Liu, Wei Dong, Huan Xu, Yun Bai
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Hydropower dispatching faces challenges such as uneven distribution of water resources, obvious seasonal changes and large fluctuation of power demand. Traditional dispatching methods rely on manual experience and simple mathematical models, and it is difficult to effectively deal with complex and changeable dispatching scenarios. This paper analyzes the role of large model in data integration and analysis, intelligent decision support, knowledge base construction and update, and man-machine cooperation mechanism, and takes a large hydropower station in China as a practical case to show the application practice of large model technology. By constructing a hydrological forecasting model that includes Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) networks, a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) power demand forecasting model, and a Reinforcement Learning (RL) algorithm for optimizing generator scheduling, the intelligence and precision of hydropower scheduling have been achieved. In the human-machine collaboration mode, human dispatchers work closely with large model systems to jointly complete hydroelectric dispatch tasks, significantly improving dispatch efficiency and economic benefits. The research results indicate that the application of large models has improved the economic benefits and environmental sustainability of hydropower stations, verifying their effectiveness and importance in hydropower scheduling optimization.

title: Reasoning in Signals: A Survey of Large Language Models for Sensor Data Understanding
authors: Ngoc Tuong Vy Nguyen, Yunting Yin
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: The application of Large Language Models (LLMs) to sensor data analysis is an emerging and impactful direction of research, which combines natural language reasoning with time-series and physical-world signals. This survey provides a comprehensive review of recent advances in applying LLMs to understand, reason about, and generate sensor data across domains such as health monitoring and Internet of Things (IoT). We categorize existing work by their input modalities, including raw signals, textual summaries, and visual prompts, as well as their application domains and technical strategies such as prompt engineering, sensor-text alignment, and hybrid frameworks. Despite encouraging results in low-dimensional and API-supported tasks, LLMs still struggle with complex signal processing and numerical reasoning, as well as multimodal sensor fusion. We also identify key challenges such as limited dataset availability, inadequate signal transformation, and the need for architectural adaptations. Future research directions are outlined to bridge these gaps. Our review emphasizes the potential of LLMs to serve as foundation models for analyzing sensor data, while also pointing out the importance of domainspecific knowledge and diverse modalities.

title: Reversed Doherty Power Amplifier with Third-Order Intermodulation Distortion Suppression
authors: Anidozie Lordsday Sunday, Wanhae Jeon, Paul Jeremiah, Waeed Hussain, Ali Raza, Khurshid Hussain, Inn-Yeal Oh
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper presents a Reversed Doherty Power Amplifier (RDPA) to minimize losses and improve efficiency, especially at output back-off (OBO). An adaptive biasing network is introduced to improve linearity. The transistors are carefully sized, and optimum load impedance is determined through systematic load-pull matching to ensure optimal efficiency and output power across operating conditions. The RDPA achieved 6% efficiency, better than the Conventional Doherty Power Amplifier (CDPA), which translates to 6.5% savings in consumption. Operating at 3.2 to 3.7 GHz and at P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1dB</inf>, the proposed amplifier achieved an output power of 30.87 dBm, suppresses third-order intermodulation by 41 dBc, and maintains a high efficiency of 43%, confirming its robustness and suitability for modern wireless communication systems that demand both linearity and efficiency over wide dynamic ranges.

title: Trust and Performance Outweigh Privacy: Generative Artificial Intelligence Adoption Among Undergraduate Students
authors: Kyori Tandiah, Yohannes Kurniawan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Nowadays, more and more undergraduate students in Indonesia are turning to generative artificial intelligence (AI) tools to help with their academic work, especially as digital access becomes increasingly effortless and widespread. This study incorporates trust propensity and privacy fatigue into the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology model to better understand the key factors influencing students’ intention to use such tools. Data were collected through a quantitative survey involving 198 students from various academic disciplines. The results reveal that students' intention to use the technology is strongly shaped by how useful and easy they believe it is, with performance expectancy having the biggest impact. Students with a higher tendency to trust see the technology as more helpful and easier to operate, indirectly influencing their decision to use it. There are also some insignificant paths, which include privacy fatigue and the direct effect of trust propensity on behavioral intention. Thus, students appear to prioritize the expected benefit and simplicity of use over privacy, underscoring the need to enhance usability, build trust, and promote greater digital privacy awareness in Indonesia.

title: Simulation and Control for Bilateral Tele Operation based on Software PSIM
authors: Hocine Khati, Hand Talem, Rabah Mellah, Mohand Achour Touat
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: The work presented in this paper was interested in the neuro-Fuzzy control of a system master - slave with feedback of force. From the architecture of control proposed by Lawrence, we synthesized two structures about control of tele operation position-force whose only position of the master devise is transmitted to the slave devise. Conversely, the slave devise transmits to the operator only the effort that it applies to the environment. The first structure is equipped with two controllers PI. The first controller is used in order to control the effort of the master devise and the second to control the position on the level of the slave devise. In the second structure, we replaced regulators PI of the first structure by two controllers neuro-fuzzy of structure ANFIS. A co-simulation is carried out combining Matlab/Simulink and PSIM environments in order to validate the control algorithms for the proposed tele operation system, through numerical simulation that show the performances and the robustness of the controllers proposed.

title: Multimodal Generative AI Framework for Therapeutic Decision Support in Autism Spectrum Disorder
authors: Santosh Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental condition characterized by deficits in social communication, repetitive behaviors, and atypical sensory processing. Traditional therapies, while effective, often face barriers such as limited availability of trained therapists, high costs, and inconsistent access. To address these challenges, this paper presents an AI-driven multimodal therapeutic framework that integrates computer vision, natural language processing, and sketch-based interpretation models to deliver affordable, scalable, and personalized ASD therapy. The proposed system comprises three modules: (i) a behavior therapy module leveraging pose estimation and emotion recognition to guide social skill acquisition, (ii) a speech therapy module utilizing lip-reading and speech-text alignment for articulation training, and (iii) an interpretation therapy module employing sketch recognition to foster creativity and conceptual understanding. Using datasets such as COCO (for pose estimation), QuickDraw (for sketch learning), and curated speech corpora, the system demonstrates competitive accuracy in activity recognition, word pronunciation scoring, and drawing similarity assessment. Experimental results highlight the framework's capacity to deliver consistent therapy sessions, achieve quantifiable progress tracking, and provide explainable feedback to caregivers and clinicians. This work represents a step toward AI-enabled precision therapies that bridge accessibility gaps and augment humancentered care.

title: Improving Online Merchant Evaluation Through Sentiment Analysis
authors: Gintoro
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: The exponential growth of Indonesian ecommerce platforms has created unprecedented challenges in merchant credibility assessment, where consumers struggle to efficiently process vast amounts of unstructured review data. The study addresses the fundamental research question of how automated sentiment analysis frameworks can address the critical gap between large-scale review volumes and reliable merchant evaluation in Indonesian e-commerce ecosystems. This investigation presents a comprehensive comparative study implementing multiple machine learning approaches for sentiment classification of Tokopedia reviews. The research methodology encompasses systematic web scraping, advanced text preprocessing with object detection and noise removal techniques, and comparative evaluation of Multinomial Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machine, and Random Forest classifiers. Class imbalance handling strategies including SMOTE and cost-sensitive learning were implemented to address inherent data distribution challenges. Evaluation on 450 Indonesian-language reviews reveals that while Naïve Bayes achieves 83% accuracy with exceptional positive sentiment precision (0.93), ensemble methods demonstrate superior balanced performance across sentiment classes. The Random Forest classifier achieved 89% overall accuracy with improved negative sentiment detection (F1-score: 0.45 vs. 0.20 for Naïve Bayes). These findings establish the practical viability of automated sentiment frameworks for large-scale merchant evaluation while highlighting the critical importance of algorithm selection and data balancing strategies in achieving equitable classification performance.

title: Supporting Inclusive Learning Through Technology: Evaluating a Digital Learning Module
authors: Nuril Kusumawardani Soeprapto Putri, Yuliana Lisanti, Istiani, Veronica, Chen Kang Lee
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: This study discovers how interactive digital learning modules can increase the classroom performance for learners with intellectual difficulties (LID). As it is previously observed that cognitive difficulties remain underexplored in existing researches. It focused on 3 (three) main indicators, which are: knowledge acquisition, task completion efficiency, and user satisfaction. This research evaluates the impact of designed multimedia content on learning performance. Experimental testing was held with the assistive technology (AT) as its intervention. A mixed-methods design was used, combined with pre-test and post-test. Moreover, the analysis of completion times, and Likert-scale surveys, along with a thematic analysis of open-ended feedback also conducted during research. The findings showed significant improvements in both comprehension and task speed, particularly for participants with cognitive difficulties. User satisfaction was related with elements such as intuitive navigation and the clarity of instructional objectives. These results suggested that well-designed digital learning modules can support inclusive learning environments, provided prioritize accessibility, and adapt to varied cognitive styles.

title: Intelligent Construction and Evaluation of Safety Management System Based on Multi-Level Algorithm
authors: Baocheng Zhang, Yalin Wu, Zhengwei Li
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: With the continuous renovation and complexity of network attack means, the traditional single protection strategy has been difficult to cope with the increasingly diverse network threats. Therefore, this study proposes a security management system that integrates multi-level algorithms. By integrating various algorithms and models, it can realize all-round and multi-angle protection of network security. The system design includes three main stages: data preprocessing, feature extraction and selection, and decision analysis. Algorithms such as data cleaning, principal component analysis (PCA), recursive feature elimination (RFE) and support vector machine (SVM) are adopted respectively to improve data quality and intelligent decision-making ability. The experimental results show that the system has excellent performance in key indicators such as accuracy, recall, precision and F1 score, short processing time and moderate resource consumption, and can meet the real-time and efficiency requirements in the actual network environment. This study provides a new and effective protection strategy for the field of network security, which has important theoretical significance and practical value.

title: Users’ Intentions to Use Product Review Feature for Purchasing in Indonesian E-commerce
authors: I Komang Ananta Aryadinata, Putu Wuri Handayani, Puspita Kencana Sari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Online commerce has become a driver of economic activity in Indonesia. The features and content of product reviews on e-commerce provide confidence for potential buyers to make transactions after reading testimonials from other buyers. This study seeks to determine the factors that influence users' intentions to use the product review feature and determine the influence of suspicious review content on purchasing decisions in e-commerce. Data collected from 369 respondents and proceed using covariance-based structural equation modelling. This study shows that the perceived ease of use and perceived usefulness influences the intention to use the review feature to complete shopping transactions. The suspicion of review content is proven to influence user attitudes towards e-commerce and user attitudes towards product brands to be negative. This attitude does not influence the intention to use the review feature to complete shopping transactions because suspicious review content does not always represent the collective experience of all buyers. This study provides guidance to e-commerce organizations to manage their online review features to increase e-commerce transactions.

title: Construction of New Electric Power System Model System and Synchronous Stability Control of Static Var Generator
authors: Yun Zhu, Huiyuan Chen, Qinghua Chen, Hongxi Liu, Yongjian Qin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: The purpose of this article is to discuss the synchronous stability control strategy of Static var generator under the new electric power system (EPS) model system, so as to meet the voltage stability challenge brought by the high proportion of renewable energy access. In terms of methods, this article first expounds the development trend of new EPS and the important role of SVG in it, and makes clear the necessity and urgency of the research; Then, a new EPS model system including renewable energy, power electronic equipment and intelligent control technology is constructed. Then, aiming at the synchronous and stable control of SVG, this article puts forward a phase angle and amplitude control method based on virtual internal potential, and carries out detailed model construction and parameter setting through simulation software. The experimental results show that SVG can significantly improve the voltage stability of EPS after its introduction. SVG can respond quickly and maintain voltage stability when faced with disturbances such as load change and power supply voltage fluctuation. Through comparative analysis, the effectiveness of synchronous stability control strategy is verified, and the stability and response speed of SVG are evaluated. The research results provide strong technical support for the stable operation and intelligent control of EPS.

title: A Single-Stage Isolation High-Step-Down Converter with Leakage Energy Recycling and Simple Circuit Configuration for Communication System Applications
authors: Chih-Lung Shen, Ho-Teng Huang, You-Lin Jian, Teresa Bei-Yi Shen
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: This paper presents a novel single-stage isolated high step-down converter (SIHDC) suitable for mobile communication system applications. The main circuit of SIHDC integrates Flyback and Buck configurations into a compact dual-switch structure that resembles a double-ended Forwardderived circuit, yet offers enhanced control flexibility and reduced component count. The SIHDC can recycle leakage energy of the isolation transformer, effectively minimizing power loss and improving conversion efficiency. The SIHDC achieves high step-down capability with a simple circuit structure, addressing the drawbacks of existing multi-stage and coupled-inductor-based solutions. The detailed theoretical analysis of the proposed converter is fulfilled, including operation principle, voltage gain, semiconductor stresses, inductance design, and efficiency estimation. In addition, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$150{-}$</tex> W prototype is built to step down a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$400-\mathrm{V}$</tex> bus voltage to 24 V, demonstrating the feasibility of the SIHDC. The measured peak efficiency is 95.37 % and an average efficiency from light to heavy load can be up to 95.21 %.

title: Vision-Based Target Recognition and Path Planning Algorithm in Manipulator Smoke Frame Cleaning System
authors: Yonggang Liu, Ziyu Liu, Hongliang Zhang, Liqiang Wu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: In cigarette production, cleaning the residue and dust at the bottom of cigarette frame is very important to the product quality, but the traditional manual cleaning method is inefficient and costly. Therefore, an automatic cleaning system is developed in this study, which realizes the accurate identification of cigarette frame residues through machine vision technology, and provides the optimal cleaning path for the manipulator combined with path planning algorithm. In the aspect of target recognition, the improved lightweight YOLOv5s model can effectively deal with complex working conditions such as illumination change and high reflection. The experimental results show that its <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mAP}{@}0.5$</tex> reaches 96.2 %, and the false detection rate and missed detection rate are as low as 1.8 % and 2.3 % respectively. Based on the improved <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A^{*}$</tex> algorithm, the path planning module significantly improves the coverage and planning efficiency of the cleaning path and reduces the jitter rate of the manipulator by optimizing the heuristic function and the direction weight strategy. The system-level verification shows that the average cleaning time of a single cigarette frame is 3 minutes and 12 seconds, the efficiency is four times that of manual work, and the cleanliness compliance rate is 99.3 %, which meets the requirements of high efficiency and high reliability in industrial field. This research provides an effective technical solution for automatic cleaning in cigarette production, which has important theoretical and practical significance.

title: Research on Scheduling Strategy of 5G Slice Resources in Deterministic Network Environment
authors: Jialin Chen, Dekun Zhou, Hongwei Wang, Jun Sun, Lu Ye, Yi He
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: This study discusses how to formulate and optimize the scheduling strategy of 5G slice resources in a deterministic network environment. The deterministic network environment requires the network to have high reliability and low delay characteristics to ensure the real-time and accuracy of key tasks. A general framework of resource scheduling strategy for 5G slicing is proposed, which consists of demand awareness module, resource evaluation module, intelligent decision-making module and execution monitoring module. The strategy follows the three principles of personalized customization, dynamic adjustment and fairness and rationality, supports highly personalized slice configuration, and has the ability of real-time adjustment to ensure the fairness and rationality of resource allocation. The simulation results show that the strategy is effective under different network traffic conditions, especially in the scene of sudden high traffic, which can quickly redistribute resources, reduce resource waste and effectively avoid network congestion and performance bottlenecks.

title: Performance Analysis of Native SOVD versus SOVD-to-UDS in Virtualized Automotive Diagnostic Systems
authors: Chae Eun Lee, Seong Hyeon Lim, Young Soo Do, Sung Bhin Oh, Beom Gi Suh, Young Min Kim, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: As automotive architectures transition to Software Defined Vehicle (SDV) with High-Performance Computer (HPC), Service-Oriented Vehicle Diagnostics (SOVD) emerges to replace traditional Unified Diagnostic Services (UDS). This study compares Native SOVD and SOVD-to-UDS diagnostic paths in a virtualized in-vehicle gateway using the NXP S32G399A platform with Xen hypervisor. Three guest domains were configured representing a gateway, ADAS controller, and legacy ECU simulator. Load testing with 10-100 concurrent connections revealed that SOVD-to-UDS conversion exhibits higher response times than Native SOVD. CPU utilization analysis revealed that Native SOVD maintained substantially higher usage compared to SOVD-to-UDS, indicating I/O wait times as the primary bottleneck rather than computational overhead. These findings quantify the performance cost of legacy compatibility and provide insights for designing optimal hybrid diagnostic architectures in next-generation vehicles.

title: Exploration of Quantum Algorithms for Future Communication Networks in Electronics and Communication Engineering
authors: Dong Chen, Jiemin Zhang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: With the continuous progress of quantum computing and quantum communication technology, the application of quantum algorithms in future communication networks is increasingly promising. Quantum algorithms have computing power beyond traditional algorithms and can effectively improve the performance and security of communication networks, especially in the field of electronics and communication engineering, showing great potential. In this paper, the application of quantum algorithms in future communication networks is discussed in depth, focusing on the analysis of quantum communication protocols, the application of quantum computing in network optimization, and the innovative methods of quantum algorithms in enhancing network security. By systematically analyzing the basic principles, application examples and development trends of quantum algorithms, this paper aims to provide theoretical support and technical reference for the design and realization of future communication networks. Finally, this paper summarizes the current challenges in the application of quantum algorithms and looks forward to the future development direction of its wide application in electronics and communication engineering.

title: A proposal control mechanism for remotely connected on-board weighing equipment to monitor heavy goods vehicles: the case of Senegal's road transport corridors
authors: Gaye Abdourahime, Mamadou Makhtar Mbaye
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: A connected and autonomous on-board weighing system that periodically monitors the weight of heavy vehicles, not just at weighing stations or on instrumented bridges, but wherever they are, helps to apply the brakes accidents, especially in developing countries where infrastructure is low. A number of laws and regulations have been put in place to take better care of roads and passengers, including law no. 2022-05 of 15-04-2022 on the Highway Code, which was published on Wednesday 27 April 2022 in the official journal of the Senegal Republic. According to investigations carried out at the weighing station, there are other real problems affecting the lifespan of our road infrastructure. Axles are weighed at the weighing area, but the axle overload is not taken into account [1], [3], [5]. It’s in this perspective, we proposed to set up a remotely connected on-board weighing system to overcome some of the limitations of the LS-WIM (Low Speed Weight-In-Motion) systems currently installed of our roads and motorways. In order to carry out this work, we begin by reviewing existing weighing systems and proposing alternative solutions. Next, we propose an overall system architecture (organic vision) with the design of the associated platform. Finally, we simulate the system using electronic/electrotechnical software and carry out implementation tests.

title: Transforming Auditing with Data Analytics: Examining the Influence of Big Data, Analytical Tools, and Data Quality
authors: Marianto, Therezia Tri Rahayu, Nuraini Sari, Tri Ayu Astari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Data analytics can improve audit quality by utilizing advanced technology used, thus triggering a revolution in the audit world. Data quality, analytical tools and big data are elements of data analytics that are considered to be able to create more accurate, efficient audits and provide more insight. This study aims to examine the influence of data quality, analytical tools and big data on audit quality, and explore how the integration of technological advances can change the audit process and results. The study will use primary data obtained by purposive sampling technique. A total of 78 respondents were collected consisting of auditors and data practitioners. Based on the results of the study, it states that data quality and big data have a positive and significant influence on efforts to improve audit quality. Meanwhile, the influence of analytical tools shows a positive and insignificant relationship to the quality of the resulting audit. Recommendations for public accounting firms, companies, and government agencies include investment in data management infrastructure, ongoing training for auditors in the use of analytical data, and the development of strict data quality standards. By addressing these aspects, Auditors can harness the full potential of data analytics consisting of data quality, analytical tools and big data to produce stronger and more reliable audits.

title: Modification Of YOLOv11n Algorithm Architecture to Improve Efficiency in Facial Acne Detection
authors: Randy Ardiansyah, I Gede Putu Wirarama Wedashwara, Ario Yudo Husodo, Heri Wijayanto, Cahya Damarjati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Acne is a skin condition that commonly affects young individuals and can cause permanent scars, emotional stress, and physical discomfort. Current dermatologist treatment is still manual, making it time-consuming and labor-intensive. Therefore, a lightweight, artificial intelligence-based acne localization model that can be implemented on devices with limited resources is needed. This implementation can reduce treatment time for dermatologists. Therefore, this study proposes the YOLOv11nMod model, a modification of YOLOv11n that has fewer parameters and layers than the original version. Our proposed model was tested using 5-fold K-Fold Cross Validation. The data used in this study came from Kaggle in the form of acne facial images. Data preparation was carried out and resulted in 915 image data and 915 txt data. The test data for the data split was 183 data points, with the remainder for training on K-Fold Cross Validation. From the test results, which were conducted by averaging the accuracy of 5 times, our proposed model achieved a detection accuracy of 66.64%. 3.34% Superior to YOLOv12n and 0.02% lower than YOLOv11n and 0.42% lower than YOLOv8n. Although the accuracy obtained is 0.42% lower, our model has a smaller size, namely 1.7 MB, compared to the YOLOv8n, YOLOv11n, and YOLOv12n models. Thus, our proposed model is more efficient than the original version with a similar accuracy. Therefore, our proposed model can be implemented on devices with limited resources. However, the accuracy of external data testing is still very low. Therefore, additional data is needed in future research.

title: Anti-Jamming Task Scheduling in MEC-O-RAN with Hierarchical DRL and Transformer-Based Control
authors: Ghazal Asemian, Mohammadreza Amini, Burak Kantarci
abstract: This paper presents a Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning (DHRL) framework for reliable task scheduling in MEC-enabled 5G Open RAN systems under on-off jamming attacks. The scheduling problem is modeled as a combinatorial integer nonlinear program (ComINP), which is hard to solve directly. To handle this, we use Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL). Since the jamming environment is only partially observable, the problem becomes a Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP). To deal with this, we split the problem into two DRL agents. The first agent is a jamming estimator that uses an Alternating Discrete Phase-Type Renewal Process (ADPHRP) to predict jammed time slots based on dense distribution patterns. It is trained using a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) algorithm. The second agent is a task scheduler called Weighted MAC-based Task Scheduler (WMAC-TS), which schedules tasks during non-jammed slots while maintaining quality of service (QoS). It uses a transformer-based Actor-Critic model with linear complexity relative to the number of tasks, considering both short-term and long-term rewards. Simulation results show that the PPO-based jamming estimator achieves a cumulative prediction error of 13 time slots in 100 time slots, compared to 25 time slots for DDQN with historical data and 48 time slots for standard DDQN. For 50 active users, WMAC-TS achieves a task drop ratio of 0.917 lower than the 0.942 of the baseline genetic algorithm, and cuts execution time from 1260 seconds to 316 seconds.

title: Waveform design for OFDM-based JRC systems via ambiguity function sidelobe and PAPR minimization
authors: Prasanth Logaraman, Aakash Arora, Prabhu Babu
abstract: In this paper, we propose a method for designing waveforms for quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM) orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM)-based joint radar-communication (JRC) systems that simultaneously minimizes the sidelobes of the ambiguity function and the peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR) of the transmit signal. Modern JRC systems require QAM-based OFDM to support higher data rates. However, the non-unimodular nature of QAM symbols leads to higher sidelobe levels in the ambiguity function, degrading radar sensing performance, and OFDM inherently suffers from the high PAPR. Thus, to achieve effective radar sensing and reliable communication, we propose a waveform design method that simultaneously minimizes sidelobe levels within a specified region of the ambiguity function and the PAPR of the waveform. The resulting problem is non-convex with a quartic objective function, which we address using an iterative method based on quadratic approximations of the quartic terms. Numerical simulations demonstrate that the proposed technique significantly reduces ambiguity function sidelobes and PAPR, thereby enhancing radar detection performance and maintaining communication reliability compared to recent methods in the literature.

title: DMSPSO: A multi-strategy mobile robot path planning algorithm in complex environments
authors: Yizhe Wang, Guangyi Zheng, Wenjie Bao, Yuwei Jiao, Songyong Liu
abstract: Robot path planning is challenged by issues including inadequate operating speed and environmental adaptability. In path planning, the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) method has been widely adopted as an efficient and effective approach. However, because of its single particle update method, PSO finds it difficult to strike a compromise between search capability and convergence speed. To address this, a dynamic multi-strategy particle swarm optimization algorithm (DMSPSO) is proposed. First, collision severity is embedded into the path cost to establish the algorithm’s optimization objective. Second, a particle updating strategy based on dynamic hierarchical mechanisms is proposed. Particles are divided into three groups using this method: elite, common, and backward. Their respective roles are then dynamically changed according to fitness. Third, a multi-strategy algorithm is proposed to leverage the positional characteristics of particles in different groups. For the elite group, an improved Hooke-Jeeves pattern search strategy is employed, facilitating small-step exploration in the vicinity of optimal solutions to accelerate convergence. For the common group, an attraction-repulsion search strategy is implemented, introducing a dynamic potential field to facilitate oscillatory fine-grained searches in optimal neighborhoods. For the backward group, a mirror search strategy enhances global exploration capabilities, preventing convergence to local optima. Simulation results in CEC2022 test functions and obstacle environments indicate that the DMSPSO algorithm possesses enhanced global search capability and faster operation speed. Under four different complex environments, DMSPSO converges 37.66% faster than other algorithms, and the length of the converged path is shortened by 13.08%, which can plan a better path faster. Experiments in real obstacle environments further prove the effectiveness of the method.

title: CombAlign: Enhancing Model Expressiveness in Unsupervised Graph Alignment
authors: Songyang Chen, Yu Liu, Lei Zou, Zexuan Wang, Youfang Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: Unsupervised graph alignment finds the node correspondence between a pair of attributed graphs by only exploiting graph structure and node features. One category of recent studies first computes the node representation and then matches nodes with the largest embedding-based similarity, while the other category reduces the problem to optimal transport (OT) via Gromov-Wasserstein learning. However, it remains largely unexplored in the model expressiveness, as well as how theoretical expressivity impacts prediction accuracy. We investigate the model expressiveness from two aspects. First, we characterize the model's discriminative power in distinguishing matched and unmatched node pairs across two graphs. Second, we study the model's capability of guaranteeing node matching properties such as one-to-one matching and mutual alignment. Motivated by our theoretical analysis, we put forward a hybrid approach named CombAlign with stronger expressive power. Specifically, we enable cross-dimensional feature interaction for OT-based learning and propose an embedding-based method inspired by the Weisfeiler-Lehman test. We also apply non-uniform marginals obtained from the embedding-based modules to OT as priors for more expressiveness. Based on that, we propose a traditional algorithm-based refinement, which combines our OT and embedding-based predictions using the ensemble learning strategy and reduces the problem to maximum weight matching. With carefully designed edge weights, we ensure these matching properties and further enhance prediction accuracy. By extensive experiments, we demonstrate a significant improvement of 14.5% in alignment accuracy compared to state-of-the-art approaches and confirm the soundness of our theoretical analysis.

title: AutoFPDesigner: Automated Flight Procedure Design Based on Multi-Agent Large Language Model
authors: Longtao Zhu, Hongyu Yang, Ge Song, Xin Ma, Yanxin Zhang, Yulong Ji, Jinchang Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Flight procedures are essential to the safety and efficiency of air traffic management. However, due to the highly specialized nature of the flight procedure design process, existing methods rely heavily on manual operations and adjustments with limited automation, resulting in inefficiencies and potential safety risks. This study introduces AutoFPDesigner, a new agent-driven approach to flight procedure design, leveraging large language models (LLMs). By utilizing multi-agent collaboration, AutoFPDesigner automates Performance-Based Navigation (PBN) procedures, enabling end-to-end automation. In this framework, the designer’s role shifts from an executor to a supervisor, issuing tasks through natural language, while the system integrates specialized knowledge and uses a toolset to complete the design. Experimental results show that procedures designed with this approach meet safety requirements nearly 100%, with 75% of tasks completed in a limited number of steps. Moreover, AutoFPDesigner performs effectively across various design tasks, outperforming existing methods. Additionally, this study conducted human interaction experiments and introduced an “instruction-based” feedback method to address agent misinterpretation of human feedback. Experimental results demonstrate that the system bridges the skill gap between experts and beginners, and that the “instruction-based” feedback method enhances the accuracy of agent feedback interpretation. title: Global Detection, Geolocation and Analysis of Terrestrial GPS RFI Using Spaceborne GNSS-R Receivers
authors: Mohammad M. Al-Khaldi, Joel T. Johnson, Scott Gleason
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: A method for detecting and geolocating terrestrial GPS L1 band interference sources using Cyclone Global Navigation Satellite System (CYGNSS) mission Level-1 noise floor estimates is described. Evidence of interference sources and their signal properties is first presented using CYGNSS’s special raw I/F acquisition mode. The associated Level-1 data is shown to require additional processing steps to provide information on the RFI contained. A “EIRP correlation” approach combined with a spatial anomaly clustering method is developed and applied to CYGNSS Level-1 noise floor data extending from August 1st, 2019 to April 1st, 2025 to produce a daily radio frequency interference (RFI) product on a ≈10 km grid and to geolocate the sources contained. The results reveal more than 25 unique GPS L1-band interferers over the analysis period, with the majority located within the MENA (Middle East and North Africa) region as well as Myanmar. Use of the method for detecting and geolocating interference sources beyond CYGNSS’s nominal northernmost 38°N latitude coverage is also demonstrated. The results highlight how GNSS-R observations can be instrumental in monitoring and understanding the GNSS RFI environment.
