title: GuardFL: Safeguarding Federated Learning against Backdoor Attacks via Attributed Client Graph Clustering_supp1-3639985.pdf
authors: Xinwang LIU
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) offers collaborative model training across multiple decentralized devices without the need to share data directly, enhancing privacy and data security. However, FL systems are susceptible to backdoor attacks, where malicious clients inject poisoned weights during training. Existing defenses, primarily based on anomaly detection, are prone to erroneous rejections of normal weights while accepting poisoned ones, largely due to shortcomings in quantifying similarities among client models. Furthermore, other defenses demonstrate effectiveness only when dealing with a limited number of malicious clients, typically fewer than 10%. To alleviate these vulnerabilities, we present G<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>uardFL, a protective framework that translates the detection of malicious clients into an attributed graph clustering problem, thus safeguarding FL systems. Specifically, this framework employs a client graph clustering approach to identify malicious clients and integrates an adaptive mechanism to amplify the discrepancy between the aggregated model and the poisoned ones, effectively eliminating embedded backdoors. Through empirical evaluation, comparing G<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>uardFL with cutting-edge defenses, such as FLAME (USENIX Security 2022) [37] and DeepSight (NDSS 2022) [43], against various backdoor attacks, including 3DFed (SP 2023) [26], our results demonstrate its significant effectiveness in mitigating backdoor attacks while having a negligible impact on the aggregated model’s performance on benign samples (i.e., the primary task performance). For instance, in an FL system with 25% malicious clients, G<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>uardFL reduces the attack success rate to 10.61%, while maintaining a primary task performance of 80.98% on the CIFAR-10 dataset. This surpasses the performance of the best-performing baseline, which merely achieves the attack success rate of 19.54%.

title: “It looks sexy but it's wrong.” Tensions in creativity and accuracy using genAI for biomedical visualization
authors: Roxanne Ziman, Shehryar Saharan, Gaël McGill, Laura Garrison
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: We contribute an in-depth analysis of the workflows and tensions arising from generative AI (genAI) use in biomedical visualization (BioMedVis). Although genAI affords facile production of aesthetic visuals for biological and medical content, the architecture of these tools fundamentally limits the accuracy and trustworthiness of the depicted information, from imaginary (or fanciful) molecules to alien anatomy. Through 17 interviews with a diverse group of practitioners and researchers, we qualitatively analyze the concerns and values driving genAI (dis)use for the visual representation of spatially-oriented biomedical data. We find that BioMedVis experts, both in roles as developers and designers, use genAI tools at different stages of their daily workflows and hold attitudes ranging from enthusiastic adopters to skeptical avoiders of genAI. In contrasting the current use and perspectives on genAI observed in our study with predictions towards genAI in the visualization pipeline from prior work, we refocus the discussion of genAI's effects on projects in visualization in the here and now with its respective opportunities and pitfalls for future visualization research. At a time when public trust in science is in jeopardy, we are reminded to first do no harm, not just in biomedical visualization but in science communication more broadly. Our observations reaffirm the necessity of human intervention for empathetic design and assessment of accurate scientific visuals.

title: Reducing and Compensating Hysteresis in Bowden Cable-Driven Manipulators via Optimized Transmission Paths and Improved Tension Modeling_supp1-3630101.mp4
authors: en li
abstract: Bowden cables offer flexible, compact, and long-distance force transmission, but they suffer from dead zones and hysteresis due to cable compliance and friction. This study improves the transmission efficiency and accuracy of Bowden cables in two key ways: 1) A general multicable transmission path optimization method is proposed to reduce overall hysteresis at its source. This method is based on parametric configurations and a Cosserat-based shape model with any fixed endpoints. 2) An asymmetric and nonlinear tension model is developed for forward tension estimation and inverse hysteresis compensation. The model integrates an improved Bouc–Wen model with simplified parameters and a long short-term memory network driven by the smoothing loss of fused data. Finally, the tension model, when applied to the optimized transmission path, achieves higher accuracy and better generalization than other methods across various datasets, particularly in strong hysteresis. The hybrid advantages of the tension model also allow it to maintain adaptability for transfer learning. Experiments on typical Bowden cable-driven manipulators with 2 and 12 segments show a 2.5 times improvement in transmission efficiency after optimization and an 82.5% reduction in motion error after compensation, providing new insights into high-performance Bowden cable actuation systems.

title: A Dual-Channel Deep Learning Model for Fault Diagnosis Fusing Time and Fractional Domains
authors: Shanze Wang, He Li, Quanyong Fan
abstract: To address the limited feature representation capability of existing time-frequency methods in analyzing non-stationary vibration signals and the inability of fixed transforms to capture dynamic characteristics of bearing faults, this paper proposes a dual-channel deep learning model integrating time-domain and fractional-domain features. The time-domain channel employs multi-scale convolutions with varying kernel sizes to simultaneously capture both fine-grained transient impulses and coarse-grained temporal patterns. The fractional-domain channel systematically processes nine-order fractional Fourier transforms, where temporal convolutional networks extract complex temporal dependencies through dilated causal convolutions, and channel attention mechanisms adaptively weight different fractional orders to enhance discriminative features while suppressing redundancy. This dual-channel architecture achieves synergistic modeling of both transient temporal information and non-stationary fractional-domain energy distributions, overcoming the limitations of traditional single-domain and fixed time-frequency resolution methods. Experimental validation on CWRU and SUFD datasets demonstrates superior diagnostic performance compared to existing advanced methods, with comprehensive ablation studies, multi-condition scenarios, and noise robustness tests confirming the method’s effectiveness and robustness for intelligent maintenance of rotating machinery.

title: A Novel Cryptocurrency Trend Prediction Framework Powered by Innovative Feature Engineering
authors: Rogerio de Aquino Silva, Alex Sandro Roschildt Pinto, Gustavo Medeiros De Araujo, Laura Emilia Maria Ricci
abstract: Bitcoin trend prediction in high-frequency environments remains a significant challenge. This study introduces a robust feature engineering methodology that achieves state-of-the-art accuracy in Bitcoin trend classification across multiple temporal granularities. Our approach, which systematically combines temporal variables with recalibrated technical indicators, was refined through rigorous hyperparameter optimization and forecasting horizon standardization. These methodological improvements unlocked remarkable predictive power, particularly at fine-grained intervals, demonstrating a relative accuracy improvement of up to 73% over established benchmarks. Through a comprehensive evaluation against two seminal studies using over 20 machine learning models, we demonstrate that our approach is effective at 5-minute, 15-minute, and 1-hour granularities, achieving a peak accuracy of 91.9% with a RandomForest model at the 5-minute level. This result challenges the conventional view that high-frequency data is too noisy for reliable trend prediction. A key finding is that intelligent feature engineering, when paired with appropriate model selection, surpasses the performance of more complex deep learning architectures, which consistently underperformed in our tests. The superior performance of tree-based ensemble methods highlights the synergy between our tabular feature set and these algorithms. This methodology provides immediate practical value for algorithmic trading and risk management, offering a validated, high-performance framework. Our study provides a complete and reproducible guide, from theoretical justification to empirical validation, establishing a new, robust baseline for cryptocurrency market analysis.

title: TCGU: Data-Centric Graph Unlearning Based on Transferable Condensation_supp1-3638465.pdf
authors: Dawei Cheng
abstract: With growing demands for data privacy and model robustness, graph unlearning (GU), which erases the influence of specific data on trained GNN models, has gained significant attention. However, existing exact unlearning methods suffer from either low efficiency or poor model performance. While more utility-preserving and efficient, current approximate methods require access to the forget set during unlearning, which makes them inapplicable in immediate deletion scenarios, thereby undermining privacy. Additionally, these approximate methods, which attempt to directly perturb model parameters, still raise significant concerns regarding unlearning power in empirical studies. To fill the gap, we propose Transferable Condensation Graph Unlearning (TCGU), a data-centric solution to graph unlearning. Specifically, we first develop a two-level alignment strategy to pre-condense the original graph into a compact yet utility-preserving dataset for subsequent unlearning tasks. Upon receiving an unlearning request, we fine-tune the pre-condensed data with a low-rank plugin, to directly align its distribution with the remaining graph, thus efficiently revoking the information of deleted data without accessing them. A novel similarity distribution matching approach and a discrimination regularizer are proposed to effectively transfer condensed data and preserve its utility in GNN training, respectively. Finally, we retrain the GNN on the transferred condensed data. Extensive experiments on 7 benchmark datasets demonstrate that TCGU can achieve superior performance in terms of model utility, unlearning efficiency, and unlearning efficacy compared to existing GU methods. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to explore graph unlearning with immediate data removal using a data-centric approximate method.

title: Smart Insert Layerwise learning QAOA for solving MaxCut problem
authors: Jaejoon Gill, Yunpyo Hong, Byung-Soo Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: In the Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) era, the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) has attracted significant attention as an algorithm for solving combinatorial optimization problems that are classically intractable. Various modifications and training strategies have been proposed to enhance the performance of QAOA. However, as the circuit depth increases, existing methods encounter greater training difficulty and reach a barren plateau in performance improvements. In this paper, we propose the Smart Insert Layerwise QAOA (SIL QAOA) to overcome these challenges. In SIL QAOA, at each stage, a new layer is inserted into all possible positions; each circuit is independently optimized, and the parameter set from the circuit yielding the highest expectation value is adopted as the initial parameter for the next stage. Applying the proposed method to the MaxCut problem, we achieved up to approximately 11% higher approximation ratios compared to conventional Layerwise learning QAOA, while successfully mitigating early performance saturation observed at shallow depths. These results demonstrate the superior performance improvement capability of SIL QAOA. Furthermore, we also discuss its potential applicability to more complex optimization problems and deeper variational quantum circuits in future work.

title: Stock Prediction Based on Technical Indicators and News Using LLAMA, Exploring LLM Possibilities in Financial Context
authors: Emmanuel Brandon Hamdi, Riyanto Jayadi, Tanty Oktavia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Stock prediction has been prevalent in financial market research as a research interest due to its benefit where successful stock predictions especially automatically allow an individual for asset diversification, with an increase participation in the stock market for profit and financial literacy, technological advancement in Artificial Intelligence and computation has made it possible for computer to be used in the complex prediction of stock with one such AI model is called Large Language Model (LLM), by training the model on a large dataset, LLM is able to generate human like text with good reasoning capabilities with LLAMA being one such model, the experiment used various stock data from the US stock market alongside news and technical indicators with LLAMA 2 trained using the QloRA method and prompting technique for an efficient yet effective stock prediction, With an up to Accuracy 0.6612, Precision of 0.6619, Recall of 0.6594, and F1 of 0.6591 on specific stock company, LLM shows promising results for stock prediction with future prospects being the usage of other LLM model and more complex text generation using LLM benefit in human like response and reasoning for more informed stock prediction.

title: Early Fusion-Based Road Obstacle Risk Classification and Behavior Control Using Camera and 2D LiDAR
authors: Sungtae Park, Jongwon Jeon, Hye Hyeon Park, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Implementation of autonomous driving requires location recognition, lane detection, and distance information collection of other vehicles. Information collected from human senses (eyes, ears, touch, etc.) travels to the brain to recognize, judge, and control it. The ultimate goal is to implant this process into the vehicle as it is. Humans recognize distance by calibrating information obtained through both eyes in the brain. To implement this, we collect information about objects using two sensors, camera and LiDAR. Cameras have strengths in object recognition and resolution, and LiDAR has strengths in distance information collection. The fusion of these sensors maximizes their respective strengths, enabling effective detection of obstacles around the vehicle. This is much more effective than systems that rely on a single sensor or whose sensor settings are not properly calibrated or synchronized. Systems based on a single sensor are vulnerable to problems such as object clogging, visually similar items. This can lead to excessive avoidance behavior, unnecessary pauses or obstacle recognition errors. In this work, a combination of camera-LiDAR early fusion, dual-condition gating, and risk-level classification (level 1 = speed bump, level 2 = vehicle, level 3 = human) can improve avoidance success rate and driving consistency compared to single sensor-based control algorithms while reducing unnecessary responses.

title: Improvement of Distribution Feeder Fault Locating in the Presence of Soft Open Point
authors: Seyedamin Hosseini, Ehsan Hajipour, Esmaeil Anani
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Distribution networks (DNs) are usually designed in a ring configuration but operate radially. In a typical structure, normally open points (NOs) are used to create alternative paths and supply un-faulted loads after fault clearance. A soft open point (SOP) is a power electronic device that can enhance DN performance under normal and fault conditions. However, its impact on protection algorithms has been less considered in the literature. So far, a few methods have been suggested to detect fault type and estimate fault location in the presence of SOP; however, those methods have poor performance when fault resistance is not neglected and are not effective for ungrounded DNs as well. In this paper, a new method is proposed to overcome these obstacles that significantly improves fault locating and protection performance.

title: Development of a Digital Literacy Curriculum for Rural Women in India
authors: Drishti Marwaha, VR Bhanu, Sayujya R S, Sruthy V Nair
abstract: The digital divide in rural India poses a major challenge to socio-economic development, particularly for women, who often face added barriers such as limited education, socio-cultural restrictions, and poor access to technology. This paper presents the development of a digital literacy curriculum designed specifically for rural women under the SANKALP project, an initiative by Amrita Vishwa Vidyapeetham in collaboration with the National Skill Development Corporation (NSDC). Using the AWESOME (Advancing Women's Empowerment through Systems Oriented Model Expansion) framework, the curriculum aims to empower women by building practical digital skills in smartphone use, internet navigation, and digital tools for business and livelihood development. The curriculum is integrated into vocational education to enhance employability and entrepreneurial potential. Key components include modules on technology access, awareness-building, and hands-on application of digital tools for daily life and small enterprises. Beyond technical skills, the program focuses on building confidence and agency, enabling women to overcome cultural and societal barriers. This innovative approach not only supports digital adoption but also promotes sustainable livelihoods. The paper highlights how the curriculum contributes to reducing the digital gender divide and offers a replicable model for advancing digital inclusion and women's empowerment in other rural communities across India.

title: An Enhanced Mobile RFID Authentication Protocol Based on Parity Check Patching Operation
authors: Cheng-Ying Yang, Chia-Chun Wu, Nan-I Wu, Min-Shiang Hwang
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) is a short-range wireless communication technology commonly used for identification and data exchange. However, numerous studies have highlighted that traditional RFID authentication protocols often fail to meet the security demands of mobile RFID systems. To address these limitations, Li recently proposed an efficient mobile RFID authentication protocol based on a parity repair operation. This operation is lightweight and well-suited for RFID environments. Nevertheless, Li’s protocol assumes that the Reader, Tag, and Server all share a common private key—an assumption that is impractical in real-world deployments. In typical RFID systems, a single server communicates with multiple readers and numerous tags. If a Reader were to store the private keys of all Tags, compromising or stealing that Reader would not only lead to significant storage overhead but also pose a serious security threat to the entire system. To overcome this limitation, this paper proposes an improvement to Li’s protocol by modifying the key management mechanism. Specifically, private keys are shared only between the Server and each Tag, and separately between the Server and each Reader. This design enhances the security and practicality of the RFID system while maintaining protocol efficiency.

title: A Study on Network Security Situation Awareness Prediction
authors: Jong-Shin Chen, Cheng-Ying Yang, Jenq Foung JF Yao, Hsuan Fu Wang, Shu-Chen Chang, Min-Shiang Hwang
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: The emergent topic of Network Security Situation Awareness (NSSA) consists of the situation awareness, the situation estimation and the situation prediction, three stages. Among these stages, the situation prediction scheme is the most challenging and valuable. With the accurate prediction, the security status development in network in time, the traditional defense tools, e.g. the invasion detection, could facilitate a transition from passive to active defense. Consequently, NSSA prediction has become a crucial research focus. NSSA estimation and prediction are accentuated toward a systematical model establishment. This study emphasizes model development for NSSA estimation and prediction. Leveraging domain expertise and data science, the estimation model applies logical reasoning based on the Dempster–Shafer theory to identify critical predictive factors. Prediction is framed as a pattern recognition problem, addressed using the Support Vector Machine (SVM) learning algorithm. Performance evaluation uses credibility metrics for estimation and accuracy rates for prediction. Simulation experiments with training and testing datasets assess sensitivity coefficients and refine control factors for prediction. The goal is to develop a robust NSSA prediction scheme that enhances overall network security.

title: Impact of Gamification on Student Learning and Motivation in Introductory Programming Courses
authors: Fifinellametta Kurniadi, Felisiscametta Kurniadi, Tracy Elysia Tandra, Thaniesya Sahana, Felicia Evan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: This paper investigates the usage of gamification in an academic setting, specifically in introductory programming courses, and how it may affect student learning outcomes and motivation. After the collection of 301 valid responses, this research utilized PLS-SEM or Partial Least Square Structural Equation to examine key variables influencing behavioral intention, namely attitude toward using, social influence, perceived enjoyment, perceived usefulness, and perceived ease of use. Results show that all proposed relations achieved the threshold for t-value and p-value, respectively above 1.96 and below 0.05, validating all hypotheses and concluding that social influence affects how useful and convenient technology is perceived to be. The relationship between perceptions of convenience, usefulness, and entertainment is validated as well. Notably, the link between user attitude and intention is 0.904, slightly exceeding the Heterotrait-Monotrait threshold of 0.9 and suggesting a potential overlap between constructs. The results provide useful insights into how gamification performs in education, offering meaningful contribution to the discussion of gamified learning and the key variables behind its adoption in introductory programming courses.

title: Analysis of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) using the K-Prototype Method
authors: Lisna Zahrotun, Miftahurahma Rashida, Muhammad Faris Akbar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) are the foundation of the economy of a region. The importance of analyzing MSMEs is useful for knowing the level of conditions of the distribution of MSMEs in each region. In this study, we propose to cluster MSME data using the K-Prototype method with center point initialization using the Cao method, where the centroids are obtained from data density and the distance between objects. By using the silhouette method, the highest accuracy is obtained, with a value of 0.838 in 2 clusters. This is 0.109 higher than the Analytical Hierarchy Clustering method. Meanwhile, using the Elbow method, the best number of clusters is obtained in 5 clusters with a silhouette value of 0.233. The clustering results show that MSMEs in the service sector still need to increase their annual turnover, which on average is still below 10 million with marketing locations still having to be expanded outside the region and promotional media increased using e-commerce.

title: VISTA: Visual Infrastructure Supporting Technology in Autonomy through Precise, Keypoint-based AVP Localization
authors: Yeong Gwang Choi, Hye Hyeon Park, Eun Ho Kim, Hye Jun Hong, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This study aims to implement precise vehicle localization, a core technology for Autonomous Valet Parking (AVP) systems, without expensive sensors. In GPS-denied environments such as indoor and underground parking lots, conventional methods based on LiDAR or high-precision Inertial Navigation Systems (INS) present significant cost challenges. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes an infrastructure-centric 2D vehicle pose (position and orientation) estimation system, named VISTA, that utilizes only multiple low-cost, CCTV-grade cameras. The proposed system first integrates multiple camera images into a single global Bird's-Eye View (BEV) map via homography transformation. Subsequently, it robustly estimates the vehicle's pose, even under partial occlusion, by applying a hierarchical keypoint-based algorithm that leverages the vehicle's structural features. Finally, to satisfy both the rapid responsiveness and stability required for vehicle control, a hybrid filtering strategy is employed, combining a responsiveness-focused Kalman Filter with a moving average filter. Experiments conducted in a Gazebo simulation environment confirmed that the proposed system achieves centimeter-level position accuracy and sub-degree orientation accuracy, suggesting that VISTA can serve as an effective and economical alternative to existing high-cost solutions.

title: Deep Learning Approaches for Railroad Infrastructure Monitoring: Comparing YOLO and Vision Transformers for Defect Detection
authors: Advay Chandramouli, Hwapyeong Song, Mingyan Liu, Aayush Damai, Husnu S. Narman, Ammar Alzarrad
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Railroad crossties are paramount to ensuring structural integrity and passenger safety. Traditional inspection methods have been a manually intensive process, subject to fatigue, bias, and human error, prompting an inquiry into more consistent and expedited inspection modalities. Automated defect detection leveraging deep learning and computer vision can drastically reduce diagnostic time and ensure prompt maintenance intervention. This paper evaluates two contrasting state-of-the-art object detection models, You Only Look Once (YOLOv11, the latest release from Ultralytics) and Real-Time Detection Transformer (RT-DETR), for automating detection of defective ties, marking the first competitive benchmarking within this domain. This study uses real, field-test footage collected on stretches of railroads that was standardized and preprocessed for normalization to form our dataset, consisting of 500 annotated frames across three distinct classes: wood checks, decay, and ties. Both models were trained using 5-fold cross-validation and evaluated based on the F1 score, Precision, Recall, and Mean Average Precision (mAP) at varying IoU thresholds. YOLOv11 outperformed RT-DETR in all metrics except Recall (0.9104 vs. 0.9119), achieving an F1 score of 0.9400, mAP50 of 0.9530, and mAP50-95 of 0.9014. These results suggest that YOLOv11 is effective not only in defect recognition but also in spatial localization at various precision thresholds, fostering higher safety standards in the process. This makes it a strong candidate for deployment on lightweight mobile or embedded platforms, representative of real-world use cases. Overall, this research demonstrates the robust utility of deep learning for enhanced infrastructure monitoring, reducing inspection time and labor costs while heightening passenger safety and mitigating derailment risks, with future work needed to assess performance under varied lighting, weather, and tie conditions.

title: Probing Bioacoustic Soundscapes: An Empirical Study of Few-Shot Sound Event Detection
authors: Zhor Diffallah, Hadjer Ykhlef, Hafida Bouarfa
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Few-Shot Learning (FSL) has recently emerged as a promising approach for sound event detection in scenarios where labeled data is scarce. In this study, we investigate the effectiveness of a transfer learning-based FSL pipeline for detecting animal vocalizations. Building on the groundwork laid by previous contributions, our approach leverages pre-training and transfer learning to equip a sound event detector with rich, discriminative features. A classifier is then trained on support-query samples to perform few-shot classification, with experiments conducted under different fine-tuning settings. Through extensive evaluations on the DCASE2022 Task 5 dataset, we explore the impact of key design choices, including temperature scaling in contrastive loss and the trade-offs of fine-tuning. Our findings provide insights into the applicability and limitations of SCL-driven FSL for bioacoustic event detection, highlighting its potential for deployment in low-resource settings.

title: Excel-in-the-Loop Active Learning on KoMaP for Consumer Electronics Materials, with Extension to Battery Electrode AI Autonomous Manufacturing
authors: Hyunjong Kim, Suyoung Chi, Yongkwi Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: We present Excel-in-the-Loop Active Learning on KoMaP, a researcher-in-the-loop platform for consumer-electronics (CE) materials that operationalizes active learning and Bayesian optimization (AL–BO) through a familiar Excel-based workflow. KoMaP’s next-experiment recommendation engine uses a Gaussian-process surrogate with calibrated uncertainty to propose feasible batches under domain constraints (e.g., ternary compositional sum-to-100%, low-temperature processing windows) and constrained acquisitions (EI/UCB; c-EHVI for multi-objective runs). Practical features—spreadsheet I/O, auditable logs, and SHAP-based interpretability—lower adoption barriers while preserving transparency and traceability. We prototype the service in Streamlit and demonstrate it on a 10-round perovskite stability optimization, where the loop rapidly concentrates on low-instability regions and reduces experiment count versus grid/random baselines, all while honoring CE-relevant limits. Beyond single-objective stability, KoMaP supports multi-objective optimization (e.g., stability–efficiency–Tmax–cycle-time–cost), exposing Pareto candidates and user-steerable preferences for CE trade-off decisions. Finally, we outline an extension from lab to line toward battery electrode AI autonomous manufacturing: KoMaP’s recommendations and uncertainty metrics feed quality-prediction and productivity objectives on the shop floor, enabling factory-in-the-loop optimization and compatibility with future robotic execution. Together, KoMaP bridges advanced AL–BO methods and everyday experimental practice, empowering CE-oriented materials R&D to "learn more from fewer experiments" without disrupting existing workflows.

title: Research on Crop Planting Strategy Optimization Based on Multiple Optimization Algorithms
authors: Biaohang Yuan, Qihong Lin, Chun Yan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: This paper focuses on the optimization and risk management of crop planting strategy, aiming to provide scientific and reasonable decision support for crop planting in rural areas through data analysis and model construction. Firstly, we carried out statistical analysis on the yield and economic returns of various crops in different plots, and established a single-objective programming model aiming at profit maximization, comprehensively considering various practical constraints, and used parallel genetic algorithm to predict and analyze the potential economic returns from 2024 to 2030. Secondly, in order to deal with the uncertainties in the planting process, this paper established a robust optimization model, which only considered the return maximization in the worst case and introduced the loss rate index of high-risk crops to reduce the planting area of this type of crops. Finally, this paper uses the K-means clustering algorithm to classify crops, analyze the substitutability and complementarity between crops, and combine the random forest algorithm to predict crop sales volume to further optimize the planting strategy. The research results show that by optimizing planting strategy, the economic benefits can be guaranteed while the planting risks can be effectively reduced.

title: PM2.5 Concentration Prediction with Neural ODEs
authors: Dingyu Ge, Shaoting Shi, Xianghong Lin, Xiangwen Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Accurate prediction of PM2.5 concentration is of paramount importance for effective pollution prevention and control. Existing deep learning models frequently struggle to achieve high precision owing to their disregard for underlying physical mechanisms, a deficiency that undermines their reliability in real-world applications. To tackle these challenges, we propose NODE, a framework for PM2.5 concentration prediction that integrates the advection partial differential equations with neural ordinary differential equations, which conceptualizes the spatiotemporal evolution of air pollutants as a closed-system dynamic process governed by advection dynamics. Specifically, a second-order residual neural network is engineered to model flow velocity, while the partial differential equations are discretized via the method of lines and solved using numerical solvers. Spatiotemporal features are systematically encoded through trigonometric time embedding, latitude-longitude encoding, and static spatiotemporal covariates. These methodologies effectively address the limitations of traditional deep learning's black-box paradigm and inadequate physical mechanism integration. Experimental findings demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms methods without incorporating physical information in prediction accuracy, offering a robust solution to air quality challenges in practical environmental settings.

title: Research on Accurate Positioning and Assembly Path Optimization Algorithm of Assembly Building Components Based on Image Recognition
authors: Dongmei Xu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: With the modernization of the construction industry, assembly building has gradually become an important development direction in the construction field due to its high efficiency, environmental protection and sustainability. In this project, the path optimization problem of large-scale electronic assembly process is studied, for the current large-scale assembly path optimization algorithm exists in the solution quality and solution speed problems, this paper respectively put forward corresponding improvement measures to overcome the above problems, and combined with the improved path optimization algorithm to design the control system of the fully automated crimping equipment, and apply the improved algorithm to the fully automated assembly and crimping process, and experimentally verify the improved effect of the algorithm, the precise positioning of the assembly building components, and the accurate positioning of the assembly building components. The improved algorithm was applied to the fully automatic assembly and crimping process, and the experimental verification of the improved algorithm was completed. The accurate positioning and assembly path optimization of assembly building components still face many challenges in practical applications, especially in complex construction environments, where the traditional methods are difficult to meet the requirements of high precision and high efficiency at the same time. In this paper, a solution for accurate positioning of assembled building components is proposed based on image recognition technology, and an assembly path optimization method is designed by combining intelligent algorithms. By constructing a mathematical model and introducing improved algorithms, this paper comprehensively optimizes the assembly path of components, which effectively improves the construction efficiency and accuracy. Experimental and simulation results show that the proposed method is better than the traditional method in terms of positioning accuracy and path optimization effect, and has been verified in actual engineering cases. The integration and application of image recognition technology and intelligent algorithm in assembled buildings can significantly improve the level of construction automation and intelligence, and provide new ideas and technical support for the development of assembled buildings.

title: Application of High Reliability 5G Slicing Technology in Emergency Communication System
authors: Bo Jin, Jialin Chen, Jie Xu, Liang Dong, Zhirui Zhou, Chen Hu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: The application research of high reliability 5G slicing technology in emergency communication system aims to improve the performance and stability of emergency communication system. With the development of 5G technology, its characteristics of high speed, large capacity and low delay bring new development opportunities for emergency communication systems. 5G network slicing technology allows multiple logical networks to be built on a physical network, and each slice can be customized and optimized according to different business requirements, which improves the flexibility and scalability of the network and provides unprecedented high reliability and security for emergency communication systems. By analyzing the core advantages and characteristics of 5G network slicing technology and the challenges faced by the existing emergency communication system, this paper shows how to enhance the performance and stability of emergency communication system through network slicing technology. In addition, practical application scenarios are discussed, and how the 5G network slicing technology can help the emergency communication system to better serve the public safety field and improve its ability to respond to emergencies is explored. Through experiments and results analysis, it is proved that the application of 5G network slicing technology in emergency communication system can significantly improve the reliability and performance of the system, especially in the state of resource shortage and failure, the slicing system shows better fault resistance and transmission stability.

title: A Low-Cost Quantitative Evaluation Testbed of Small-Sized IMU Sensor Modules Using a Smartphone
authors: Myeongjun Kim, Seungmin Lee, Junjae Park, Nahyun Lee, Jo Woon Chong
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a low-cost testbed and quantitative evaluation methodology that assesses the performance of small-sized inertial measurement unit (IMU) sensor modules. Existing IMU performance verification required expensive specialized equipment, posing an economic burden for small-scale developers. We used the LSM6DSV from the Samsung Galaxy S25+ as the reference sensor and the BMI270 IMU from the Arduino Nano 33 BLE Sense Rev2 as the evaluation target. A testbed was constructed using 3D printing and commercial components. Gyroscope data was collected by applying identical rotational motion to both sensors. Quantitative evaluation of signal similarity via cross-correlation analysis shows that a cross-correlation coefficient exceeds 0.90 when applying a 10Hz low-pass filter, confirming the importance of software filtering. While limited to single-axis rotation evaluation, our proposed testbed contributes to lowering the barrier to entry for IMU-based system development by providing an economical alternative for developers to independently verify sensor performance.

title: A Novel Heuristic Algorithm for Scalable and High-Performance Automated Single-Line Diagram Generation in Electrical Grids
authors: Oğuz Deniz, Süha Nur Arslan
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Automated generation of single line diagrams (SLDs) from power distribution network Geographic Information System (GIS) data remains a computational challenge requiring efficient algorithms that can handle networks of varying complexity. A novel smart bottom-up heuristic approach is developed to address these challenges through a comprehensive seven-phase methodology. The proposed pipeline addresses key challenges in existing SLD generation algorithms by implementing a comprehensive seven-phase methodology that efficiently handles networks of varying scales while maintaining superior computational performance. The algorithm integrates connectivity and topological network data through a systematic workflow beginning with data preprocessing and busbar subsystem extraction, followed by global network construction using shortest path analysis between busbar pairs weighted by Euclidean distances. A critical innovation lies in the component analysis phase, which identifies electrically isolated subnetworks to prevent impossible connection attempts, followed by a topology-based connection algorithm employing a Hybrid Multi-Criteria Approach that combines betweenness, closeness, and degree centrality metrics to optimize starting point selection. The pipeline’s advanced crossing avoidance mechanism utilizes computational geometry techniques to generate clean orthogonal connections through sophisticated routing algorithms that systematically evaluate multiple path strategies including elbow-shaped and three-segment routes with strategic offsets. Missing line detection ensures comprehensive network representation by identifying secondary connections for redundant paths and backup routes, while the final visualization phase maintains professional electrical drafting standards through standardized symbols and consistent scaling.

title: Redesign Website HalloPets Using Design Thinking Method
authors: Amalia Ayu Ardian, Raden Roro Astria Aurellia Cahyarini, Riyan Leandros
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: HalloPets is a pet shop that operates in the sales, care and accommodation of animals. To develop the business, a website was created to introduce and promote the product. However, there are limitations to the product purchasing feature on the HalloPets website, customers can only add products to their basket but cannot continue the purchasing process then customers must contact HalloPets WhatsApp or use an e-commerce platform such as Tokopedia. Customers can only read about services on the HalloPets website, to make reservations for grooming, pet hotel and pet photo services. The shop head must record all transactions and reservations in Microsoft Excel and the ledger. To fulfill these needs, research was conducted using the design thinking method, which has five stages: Empathize, Define, Ideate, Prototype and Test. The design of the HalloPets website was made in the form of a prototype based on interviews and questionnaires. From the prototype testing using the System Usability Scale (SUS) assessment, the result was that the prototype that had been made was classified as Acceptability Marginal High with Grade Scale C and received an Adjective Rating of Good. There are future recommendations for development on the Home Page, Register Page, Login Page, Product Purchase Page, Grooming Service Reservation Page, Pets Hotel Service Reservation Page and Pets Photo Service Reservation Page.

title: Machine Learning-Based Detection of Aquatic Defects Using EfficientNet
authors: Syrin Alabrach, Yumna Salaas, Meriem Bettayeb
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Aquatic ecosystems play a crucial role in maintaining the balance of the ecological system and human health. However, they are threatened by a large range of defects and contamination sources. Traditional inspection methods are time-consuming, costly, and limited in scope. To address the challenges posed, this work makes use of machine learning and computer vision for detecting and classifying aquatic defects in underwater imagery. We used the EfficientNet-B2 architecture, chosen for its accuracy, efficiency, and balance in classification problems. We applied it to a curated dataset of 2,228 underwater images. The dataset was preprocessed and prepared to reduce bias and avoid overfitting, as we aimed to create a local and generalized model. Misclassified images were further refined into a separate test set. The model was trained using PyTorch, and it reached a high accuracy of over 97 % during training. It also performed strongly on the test set. This paper shows how the use of artificial intelligence and computer vision applications can help automate underwater inspections despite design constraints. It offers a more scalable, practical, and reproducible baseline for a sustainable way to protect aquatic ecosystems. As part of the International Conference on Image Processing (ICIP 2024), the model was tested and validated in the Machine Vision Innovation (MVI) Tournament [1]. The system performed strongly, earning second place.

title: Research on Energy-Saving Optimization Strategy of Different Network Roaming Base Station Based on Dynamic Shutdown and Intelligent Scheduling
authors: Xudong Zhang, Xinlei Bai, Guanghua Wu, Peng Tao, Wei Guo
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: In the roaming scenario of different networks, the base station needs to support multi-operator network access and handover, and the energy consumption is further aggravated. Dynamic shutdown technology can dynamically shut down some base stations or functions according to the network load, and intelligent scheduling technology uses artificial intelligence algorithm to optimize the resource allocation of base stations. The combination of the two can effectively reduce the energy consumption of base stations. In this study, by monitoring the network load, user behavior and the status of base station equipment in real time, the working mode and resource allocation of base station are dynamically adjusted, and an energy-saving optimization scheme is proposed. The simulation results show that the scheme can save energy by 33.2 % in the whole day, which is significantly better than the traditional fixed shutdown strategy, on the premise of ensuring that the quality of service (QoS) decline does not exceed 2 %. The access success rate is 99.3 %, the average delay is 28.7 milliseconds, and the traffic satisfaction rate is 98.1 %. Compared with the traditional strategy, it has a significant improvement while ensuring high QoS. This strategy not only improves the utilization efficiency of base station resources, but also responds to the environmental protection concept of energy saving and emission reduction, and provides an effective way for energy saving optimization of roaming base stations in different networks.

title: Analysis and Design of a Broadband Antipodal Finline Structure for Coaxial Waveguide to Microstrip Transition
authors: Senanur Kekeç, Volkan Açıkel, Serkan Şimşek
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: In solid-state power amplifiers, high power levels are achieved through power combining. Spatial power combining is one of the N-way combining techniques that utilizes waveguides. The transition from waveguide to microstrip can be accomplished using an antipodal transition. In this paper, the design of an antipodal finline transition in a coaxial waveguide medium is examined in terms of the main parameters that affect its performance. An optimized design is proposed, offering broadband performance from 2 to 18 GHz with low insertion loss.

title: Water Depth Remote Monitoring in University of Sriwijaya Lake, Indonesia
authors: Khairul Saleh, Rendy M. Wahid, Grahadi Ganang Aditya, Hadi, Yulinar Adnan, Octavianus Cakra Satya, Iskhaq Iskandar, Assaidah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: A telemetry system of water depth monitoring is required to have bidirectional communication for obtaining an effective and efficient measurement system. It should be conducted at any meaningful time requested by the user so that the collected data becomes more crucial which eventually generates an energy and memory-saving scheme. This work proposed the design to be applied at a campus lake with flood and dryness warning functions to avoid the common natural disasters in rainy and dry seasons, respectively. The system is based on an Arduino board and an Ultrasonic sensor equipped with a Wi-Fi modem to communicate with the user’s phone which can start the measurement and monitor the water depth through a website. The result showed that in the laboratory test, the alert was successfully sent to the user’s phone whenever the water depth was past the threshold value. In the field test, the measurement of the lake’s water depth was effectively monitored via the website using a 6000 mAh battery that lasted for 72 times data transmission for 12 hours. This was the baseline for modem power consumption.

title: Developing Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources Implementation Guide for Indonesian Health Services
authors: Diana Wijayanti, DGunawan Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) is an emerging global standard for health data exchange, which is increasingly being adopted in national platforms, such as Indonesia’s SATUSEHAT. However, Indonesia currently lacks domain-specific FHIR Implementation Guides (IG), limiting consistent data modeling, validation, and exchange across health systems. This study uses an Action Design Research (ADR) approach to develop a FHIR IG for antenatal care (ANC) services in Sampang, East Java, guided by the WHO SMART Guidelines. The development process involved defining scope and requirements, modeling FHIR profiles, and validating the IG using standard tools. Supporting workflows and architecture were documented using UML and ArchiMate 3.2. The IG was authored in FHIR Shorthand (FSH), starting with the conversion of the SATUSEHAT Core IG from Forge using GoFSH. Validation included unit testing with SUSHI and Firely Terminal, and system testing with HAPI FHIR to ensure interoperability for the antenatal care dataset. The IG focuses on Logical Models, Value Sets, Code Systems, and Profiles. Findings emphasize the urgent need for reusable, standards-aligned components and strong stakeholder engagement to support interoperable, scalable digital health systems in Indonesia.

title: A Study on Optimal Hydrogen Supply for Combined Cycle Power Plants through an Expert Survey
authors: Da Hee Kim, Min Chul Lee
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: This study analyzed four hydrogen transportation methods from supply sources to combined cycle power plants and conducted a comparative analysis through expert surveys. The results showed supplying hydrogen through gas pipelines at a pressure exceeding the gas turbine requirements (Case 2) as the most advantageous approach in terms of stability of supply, economic effectiveness (long-term use), convenience of administrative control, and space occupancy. Although this method has the drawback of high initial investment costs, it demonstrates the potential to offset these through long-term operational efficiency and reliability. Furthermore, for the successful implementation of Case 2, additional measures such as technical standard, comprehensive safety, and public acceptance are required. Adopting this approach is expected to enable the establishment of a stable and sustainable hydrogen energy supply chain.

title: ZKPU: A Novel NVMe-Based Accelerator for Scaling Zero-Knowledge Proofs in Blockchain Systems
authors: Dingsen Shi, Chris Tsu, Ying He, Alex Goss, Donger Chen, Harry Fu, Yanbo Dai, Song Fu
abstract: Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) are becoming a foundational technology for scalable and privacy-preserving blockchain systems, especially through applications like zkRollups. However, the computational intensity of proof generation continues to limit real-world deployment. We present ZKPU, a hardware-software co-designed ZK accelerator that combines native NVMe integration—ensuring seamless compatibility across existing server and edge infrastructure—with a modular RISC-V System-on-Chip (SoC) architecture that opens the path to eliminating host–device communication bottlenecks. ZKPU is designed to flexibly support a wide range of ZK workloads; in this work, we demonstrate its capabilities by implementing and optimizing multi-scalar multiplication (MSM), a core bottleneck in many zk-SNARK systems. Built using the Chipyard framework and equipped with dedicated modular arithmetic units, ZKPU achieves significant performance and energy efficiency improvements over CPU, GPU, and FPGA baselines. Our results highlight ZKPU as a practical and forward-compatible foundation for scalable ZK acceleration in modern decentralized systems.

title: Dynamic Modelling of Complex Systems Based on AHP, GRA Algorithm and Lotka-Volterra Model
authors: Yinquan Hou, Ruiyu Gao, Keyu Mao
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: In this study, the influence of different features in multidimensional data on the dynamic equilibrium of the system was investigated by applying the Lotka-Volterra model in combination with the hierarchical analysis method (AHP) and grey correlation analysis (GRA). Firstly, the key features in the data were weighted and approximated using the hierarchical analysis method (AHP), and the main influencing factors were identified. Subsequently, the correlations between the features, especially the positive correlations between resource availability and different variables in the system, were assessed by Grey Correlation Analysis (GRA). Finally, the paper applies the Lotka-Volterra model to simulate the interactions between the variables in the system and assesses the impact of different variables on the overall system stability during the system evolution by means of the damage function. This study demonstrates the application of multiple computer algorithms in the dynamic modelling and analysis of complex systems, which provides theoretical support and practical references for further improvement of system stability analysis.

title: Greenwashing in Indonesia Through the Lens of Social Media: A Latent Dirichlet Allocation Approach
authors: Mulyani Karmagatri, Hansel Verrell, Rudy Aryanto, Hazmilah Hasan, Isma Addi Jumbri, Benjamin Casteillo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Greenwashing has become a major concern in the business and environmental communication landscape, as companies increasingly adopt environmentally friendly messages to enhance their public image. This study explores public perception and awareness of greenwashing by analyzing user-generated comments on selected YouTube videos. Data were collected from publicly available comment sections and analyzed using Python on Google Colab, employing Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) for topic modeling. The analysis revealed five dominant topics in the public discourse: (0) Rhetoric vs. Reality, (1) Environmental Narratives and the State, (2) Youth Awareness and Corruption, (3) Palm Oil and Environmental Impact, and (4) Systems and Public Awakening. Among these, Topic (1) demonstrated the highest coherence and exclusivity, highlighting strong public concern over the role of government and institutional actors in environmental sustainability. The results suggest that audiences are not only aware of greenwashing tactics but also critically engage with the legitimacy of corporate and government environmental claims. These insights suggest a shift in public discourse that favors transparency and accountability in environmental communication and demonstrates the growing importance of public literacy in identifying greenwashing practices

title: A Unified Framework for Mitigating Hallucinations in Large Language Models: Integrating Internal and External Validation Strategies
authors: Akshay Mittal, Goutam Tadi, Srinu Madduri
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) suffer from hallucination-generating plausible but factually incorrect content-posing significant threats to AI system reliability with documented <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${\$} \mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex> billion market losses and critical failures across healthcare, legal, and educational domains. Existing mitigation techniques achieve <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 - 3 5 \%}$</tex> improvements but lack comprehensive integration. This paper proposes a unified validation framework combining internal and external validation strategies. Internal validation uses semantic entropy, attention analysis, and representation probing to achieve 79 % AUROC in hallucination detection. External validation employs advanced RAG architectures and automated factchecking, demonstrating <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28-95 \%$</tex> hallucination reduction. The framework uses internal signals as an efficient triage mechanism (95 % overhead reduction) to trigger external verification, achieving 1.82x cost-effectiveness ratios. Evaluation across 15+ benchmarks and production deployments validates effectiveness in critical applications.

title: Optimizing BERT for Fake Job Posting Detection: A Comparative Study for Data Augmentation Integrity and Model Performance
authors: Jonathan, Steven Valentino Taslim, Kenzie Farrel, Almuzhidul Mujhid, Hidayaturrahman
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: The growth of fake job postings creates serious risks for job seekers, with about 36% of online job ads being fraudulent according to recent reports. This study compares different machine learning models to detect fake job postings using the EMSCAD dataset. We tested modern transformer models (BERT, RoBERTa, DeBERTa, ELECTRA) against traditional methods (XGBoost, Random Forest, Logistic Regression). A key finding of our research was discovering data leakage problems when adding external fake job data to improve our dataset. When we first tried to balance our dataset by adding synthetic fake job data, it created false patterns that made our models learn wrong things, especially linking "internship" with fake jobs when this wasn't actually true. After finding and fixing these data problems, BERT-base-uncased performed the best with 98.88% accuracy, 0.8802 F1-score for detecting fake jobs, and 0.9909 ROC AUC score. XGBoost with TF-IDF features also showed strong results among traditional models. This work shows why careful data checking is important in machine learning projects and provides reliable models for detecting fake job postings online.

title: Multi-view Facial Emotion Recognition using Attention-based Convolutional Network for Human-Machine Interaction
authors: Muhamad Dwisnanto Putro, Miesje Karenia Lolowang, Amir Tjolleng, Jane Lotouw, Alwin M. Sambul, Hebron Prasetya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: The limited presence of facial features is a problem for facial expression recognition in multi-pose conditions. Accurately identifying the non-frontal facial position represents this issue when a machine interacts dynamically with a human. On the other hand, the implementation in real applications encourages a vision method to be able to operate on cheap devices. An efficient and high-performance Convolutional Neural Network model is proposed to recognize multi-pose facial emotions. A light inception and channel wave approach generates an efficient and lightweight structure. In order to boost the accuracy of the model prediction, it implements a combined attentive module that avoids excessive parameters. This module captures useful facial elements by generating the feature representation along the channel vector and the spatial dimension of the input map. Experimental results show that the proposed model achieves competitive accuracy compared to CNN architecture and other works. The model demonstrates real-time performance on edge computing devices, achieving 27 frames per second on a Jetson Nano, including integrated face detection. This performance was validated under real-world multi-view conditions, where facial orientations are not aligned with the camera.

title: From "Optimal" to "Intentional": Strategic Understanding in Fighting Game AI via Large Language Models
authors: Yiyang Liu, Boyu Chuang, Thai Van Nguyen, Ruck Thawonmas
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper presents an exploration of large language models (LLMs) in the context of competitive fighting game AI, addressing the limitations of reinforcement learning (RL) agents that often exhibit mechanically optimal yet strategically shallow behavior. Using the 2D fighting game platform DareFighting-ICE [1], we constructed a supervised fine-tuning dataset from gameplay logs of the top-performing RL agent, "Blackmamba." The Meta Llama 3.2 3B model was fine-tuned with techniques including whole-word embedding for stable action representation, automatic generation of strategic explanations, and vLLM-based inference for low-latency performance. Our experiments demonstrate the feasibility of achieving real-time play while enabling the AI to make coherent, interpretable, and tactically grounded decisions.

title: Autonomous Drone-Assisted Wheat Health Prediction Using CNN Model
authors: Shreyan Mitra
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Wheat diseases such as brown rust and leaf rust may lower crop yields by as much as 35 % if not detected early. Conventional monitoring techniques tend to be reactive, require a lot of labor, and are frequently inaccessible to smallscale farmers. This study introduces an affordable, autonomous drone-based system for immediate detection of wheat diseases utilizing a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) implemented on a Raspberry Pi Zero 2W. The drone autonomously hovers over wheat fields following a set flight route, taking pictures at consistent intervals for analysis. The Raspberry Pi processes these images locally, using the CNN model to classify each one as either healthy or diseased, and also detect specific diseases such as brown rust, black rust, aphids, and more. A LiPo battery powers the Raspberry Pi system, enabling it to function in the field without requiring an external power source. Experimental outcomes from the test dataset show a classification accuracy of 94 %, and findings from wheat field trials further illustrate its effectiveness in practice. This method provides an affordable, scalable, and sustainable way to detect diseases early, potentially decreasing pesticide usage, preventing crop loss, and enhancing yield results in farming.

title: Time-Optimal Trajectory Planning for Robotic Manipulators with Differentiable Jerk Minimization
authors: Tanyaradzwa Chinyai, Lizhe Tan, Mengji Yao
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: This paper investigates polynomial interpolation functions for generating time-optimal trajectories with continuous and differentiable jerk profiles for robotic manipulators. Specifically, a 6-7-6 polynomial interpolation function is proposed with successive differentiation of the position function to derive the jerk function, ensuring differentiability at the intermediate interpolation points. The proposed algorithm is validated on the 6-DOF robotic manipulators and demonstrates an improved approach for generating time-optimal and jerk-constrained trajectories for robotic manipulators.

title: Pose Analysis of Amateur Badminton Players Using Transformer-Based Models
authors: Muhammad Abdul Haq, Nurwahyu Alamsyah, Muhamad Amirul Haq, Slamet Riyadi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Accurate motion analysis is critical for improving performance in fast-paced sports like badminton, where precise body movements and techniques play a crucial role in success. Traditional 2D pose detection methods often fall short in capturing the complexities of human motion in the sport. In this paper, we utilize existing 3D pose detection methods and focus on visualizing keypoint data for badminton players, enabling more detailed insights into athlete movements. By processing video frames and extracting 3D keypoints, we provide visualizations that offer coaches and players an intuitive method to analyze technique, optimize performance, and prevent injury. Our approach successfully detects and visualizes the 3D poses of badminton players, providing valuable insights into their dynamic movements. Our findings demonstrate the potential of 3D pose detection visualization to revolutionize training techniques in badminton and provide a foundation for similar applications in other sports.

title: RT-AUGGAN: Robust Fingerprint Positioning under Environmental Variations via Ray Tracing-Assisted GAN Augmentation
authors: Jaehyun Choi, Sehyun Ryu, Seungmin Choi, Hyun Jong Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: Accurate UE positioning is critical for emerging applications such as autonomous robotics and industrial automation. Recognizing its importance, the 3GPP standard has incorporated wireless-signal-based positioning methods since Release 11. While CSI fingerprinting enables fine-grained spatial awareness, it remains highly sensitive to environmental changes, and closet prior work like DEGN-LIC, though aiming to enhance robustness, struggle to generalize across domains and capture spatial semantics effectively. To address this, we propose RT-AUGGAN, a data augmentation framework that generates consistent CSI fingerprints under changing environments. Rather than reconstructing explicit spatial representations, our approach directly injects spatial semantics through positional encoding and guides the generation process via a location-aware encoder. Using NVIDIA Sionna ray-tracing simulations, we demonstrate that RT-AUGGAN significantly improves positioning accuracy, achieving up to 32% gain at a 3.0m error threshold over the original library—outperforming existing baselines. These results highlight the effectiveness of targeted CSI augmentation for robust indoor positioning in dynamic environments.

title: Information bottleneck for attribution applied to object detection
authors: Bruno Coelho, Jaime S. Cardoso
abstract: Object detection is a computer vision problem related to the localization of an object in an image. Most of the algorithms used today are based on deep learning techniques, which reach state-of-the-art results but still cannot explain why the model makes that particular decision. Explainable Artificial Intelligence emerges to address this issue, with many works seeking visual explanations (saliency maps) of the internal workings of the model. In this work, we propose a new attribution method for generating saliency maps named D-IBA (Detector Information Bottleneck for Attribution) as an alternative to the state-of-the-art D-RISE. We evaluated our technique with the pre-trained Faster R-CNN, RetinaNET, and YOLOv11n models on subsets of the MS COCO 2017 and PASCAL VOC 2012 datasets showing that D-IBA achieves similar results compared to D-RISE but with a lower computational cost (more than 50 times faster). We also evaluate how the method supports the interpretation of misclassified detections and how it can perform contrastive explanations, and propose a new evaluation metric that efficiently assesses the quality of a saliency map by performing only two forward passes through the network.

title: Semantic Correspondence: Unified Benchmarking and a Strong Baseline
authors: Kaiyan Zhang, Xinghui Li, Jingyi Lu, Kai Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Establishing semantic correspondence is a challenging task in computer vision, aiming to match keypoints with the same semantic information across different images. Benefiting from the rapid development of deep learning, remarkable progress has been made over the past decade. However, a comprehensive review and analysis of this task remains absent. In this paper, we present the first extensive survey of semantic correspondence methods. We first propose a taxonomy to classify existing methods based on the type of their method designs. These methods are then categorized accordingly, and we provide a detailed analysis of each approach. Furthermore, we aggregate and summarize the results of methods in the literature across various benchmarks into a unified comparative table, with detailed configurations to highlight performance variations. Additionally, to provide a detailed understanding of existing methods for semantic matching, we thoroughly conduct controlled experiments to analyze the effectiveness of the components of different methods. Finally, we propose a simple yet effective baseline that achieves state-of-the-art performance on multiple benchmarks, providing a solid foundation for future research in this field. We hope this survey serves as a comprehensive reference and consolidated baseline for future development. Code is publicly available at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/Visual-AI/Semantic-Correspondence</uri>.

title: Long-Distance Relay-Free Interferometric Fiber-Optic Hydrophone Based on White-Light
authors: Zexu Wang, Feifei Yin, Kun Xu, Yitang Dai
abstract: In practical applications, the achievement of long-distance, large-array-scale, relay-free sensing is associated with the accommodating loss of the system. The most effective way to improve it is to increase the maximum optical power entering the transmission fiber. However, this will inevitably lead to more significant fiber nonlinear effects, resulting in deterioration of the system noise performance. In comparison to the narrow- linewidth laser, the white-light suffers less from fiber nonlinear effects, and thus has a higher maximum fiber-input power. Here we present an interferometric fiber-optic hydrophone system that employs a white-light source. We develop a concise theoretical model of this scheme and elucidate the limitations of the light source factors on the minimum phase noise of the system. The experimental results show that the maximum fiber-input power of our scheme is enhanced by 11 dB to 20 dBm, and the maximum link accommodating loss is augmented by 12 dB to 70 dB in comparison to the scheme that employs a narrow- linewidth laser. A phase noise of -95.08 dB ref 1 rad/√ Hz near 1kHz is obtained at the accommodating loss of 70dB. The proposed scheme can provide effective support for low-noise underwater detection applications in long-distance, relay-free scenarios.

title: A Comprehensive Survey on Energy-Efficient Intelligent Reflecting Surfaces-Assisted Unmanned Aerial Vehicle-Based Communications
authors: M. S. Lavanya, Rajalekshmi Kishore, Sanjeev Gurugopinath, Sami Muhaidat
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) have emerged as transformative enablers in next-generation wireless communication systems due to their mobility, flexibility and rapid deployment capabilities. The integration of intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRS) further enhances their potential by enabling intelligent signal propagation control, improving coverage and reducing active transmission power. However, energy efficiency (EE) remains a major bottleneck in sustaining prolonged UAV operations, especially in dense, latency-sensitive and high-demand communication environments. While EE is studied independently with respect to UAV and IRS, integration-level EE, jointly considering UAV flight dynamics, IRS control and communication design, remains underexplored. Existing surveys largely focus on architectural or algorithmic aspects of either UAV or IRS systems with only limited or domain-specific treatment of EE. Motivated by these gaps, this paper presents first survey that consolidates and extends the EE perspective in IRS-assisted UAV communications. We focus on key-domains such as trajectory optimization, power control, cooperative deployment and secure transmission, examine a wide range of IRS deployment strategies, including ground-based, UAV-mounted and hybrid IRS systems and explore how they dynamically enhance link reliability, spectral efficiency and energy savings under various operational scenarios. Furthermore, we investigate cutting-edge optimization algorithms, including convex programming, deep reinforcement learning and semantic-aware control frameworks, which jointly manage UAV mobility, IRS beamforming and computational offloading to reduce energy consumption. Channel modeling advances are also discussed, highlighting the transition from traditional line-of-sight models to complex, stochastic and near-field models tailored for IRS-UAV integration. By synthesizing findings from recent studies, this article underscores the transformative potential of IRS in addressing the energy limitations of UAVs. The insights presented can serve as a reference for researchers and system designers aiming to deploy sustainable, scalable, intelligent and energy-efficient IRS-assisted UAV communication networks aligned with future sixth generation (6G) standards for wireless communications.

title: Effect of X-ray Irradiation on the Insulating Properties of Epoxy Materials for GIS Applications
authors: Xi Yang, Houde Xu, Jian Zhang, Jie Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: The impact of X-ray irradiation on the insulation properties of materials used in electrical equipment is not well understood, particularly regarding the potential degradation of insulating materials under high-energy X-rays. To investigate this, epoxy resin/alumina (EP/Al<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>) insulation samples were exposed to X-ray sources with different tube voltages and energies in air and SF<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sub> environments at different pressures. Following irradiation, a series of tests were conducted on the samples, including dielectric property measurements, volume resistivity, surface potential decay, energy trap analysis, and surface voltage flashover assessments. The results showed that X-ray irradiation caused a slight increase in the dielectric constant and loss factor of the EP/Al<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> insulation, though the changes were minimal. Volume resistivity decreased by approximately 20% under 50 kV irradiation but remained nearly unchanged at higher voltages. The influence of atmosphere and SF<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sub> pressure on volume resistivity was found to be negligible. X-ray irradiation also reduced the depth of energy traps in the material, with 300 kV and 7.5 MeV irradiation leading to reduced residual charges and more efficient space charge dissipation at high voltage. At the same time, as the tube voltage and SF6 pressure increase, the absolute value of the initial potential decreases. Additionally, irradiation with different tube voltages and energies raised the surface flashover voltage, with enhanced insulation performance observed at higher SF<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sub> gas pressures.

title:
