title: Design and Evaluation of An IoT-Based Lorawan Water Flow Monitoring System
authors: Nur Hayati, Muhamat Sholeh, Muhamad Yusvin Mustar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: This paper presents the design and performance evaluation of an IoT-based water flow monitoring system using LoRaWAN technology. The system integrates a YF-S201 flow sensor, ESP32 microcontroller, LoRa RFM95 module, Dragino LG308 gateway, and the Antares cloud platform, with a mobile interface developed via MIT App Inventor. Functionality tests confirmed reliable real-time data transmission, while accuracy was validated by comparing sensor readings with 1-liter and 2-liter reference volumes. The system achieved an average error of 18.8% and 18.5%, respectively, demonstrating practical viability for low-cost remote monitoring.

title: The Hybrid Machine Learning-Based Decisionmaking Approach to Predict Employee Performance
authors: Prakash Subramani, Arun Prasad Jaganathan, Nirmal Manmathan
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Efficient human resource management (HRM) is based on the accurate prediction of workforce performance as it helps in identifying and fostering high-performing staff, strengthening employee planning, and increasing overall productivity. The major challenge in HRM is the accurate prediction and evaluation of employee performance. In this research, we propose a Hybrid Machine Learning (ML) approach, specifically the Feed Forward Neural Network (FNN)eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) to predict employee performance. Data was collected from three companies and has 15 different features. The dataset was preprocessed and normalized to identify major features affecting employee performance. The performance of the Hybrid model is evaluated using different metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The overall accuracy was 97 %. The FNN-XGBoost showed better performance compared to the other conventional ML techniques, accurately predicting employee outcomes, flagging potential attrition risks, and identifying low performers. This approach enables HR departments to implement proactive performance management strategies by facilitating timely and informed decision-making. The study highlights the role of ML in improving HRM processes by identifying critical performance determinants and enabling data-driven decision-making for organizational advancement.

title: From Technology to Digital Ecosystem Engagement: Investigating Students’ Satisfaction with the Distance Learning Experience
authors: Michael Christian, Henilia Yulita, Oktafalia Marisa Muzammil, Yuli Kartika Dewi, Kornelis Seralarat, Guan Nan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: The present digital landscape has expedited digital transformation across multiple sectors, including higher education, via the global adoption of distant learning methodologies, notably in Indonesia. This research seeks to examine the digital ecosystem of students' distance learning experiences, focusing on five primary factors: time management flexibility, content flexibility, lecturer contact flexibility, online communication self-efficacy, and self-regulated effort, in relation to student satisfaction in distance learning. Quantitative approaches were employed via an online survey targeting Indonesian students with experience in distant learning courses. The PLS-SEM analysis conducted on 149 participants revealed that all variables significantly influenced student satisfaction, with the exception of online communication self-efficacy, which did not mitigate the association between interaction flexibility with lecturers and learning satisfaction. This research is limited by its sample coverage and does not account for characteristics such as computer self-efficacy. Additional research is advised to investigate the context of particular degrees or academic programs. These findings offer practical implications for universities to develop adaptive online learning systems tailored to student needs, while reinforcing the theoretical framework of Self-Determination Theory to elucidate the significance of autonomy and intrinsic motivation within the digital learning environment.

title: PACE: Personalized Adaptive and Contextual Exercise Application for Optimal Scheduling and Fatigue Management
authors: Lorraine Pearl B. Malubag, Brix Mayabason, Caitlin Bernadette T. Villanueva, I Elizabeth Cha, Yong-Xiang Chen, Jan Kevin A. Galicia
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: The rising popularity of mobile fitness applications has transformed how individuals engage with exercise, yet many existing platforms remain limited by static workout plans that fail to adapt to users’ physical states or changing schedules. This study presents a mobile system designed to dynamically generate, schedule, and adjust workout plans based on contextual fatigue estimation from user inputs. The application incorporates a workout generation module tailored to user goals, fitness levels, and limitations, combined with a scheduling algorithm that identifies optimal exercise gaps from calendar availability. A multi-factor fatigue model was developed using mood, resting heart rate, sleep duration, schedule density, perceived fatigue, and historical data, processed through Gaussian penalty functions and smoothed with an Exponential Moving Average to ensure stability. The resulting fatigue score enables real-time workout adjustment, modifying exercise intensity or rescheduling sessions when necessary. A prototype was implemented using React Native with Firebase integration, and tested with real-world data through four simulated representative user personas: consistent, busy, sick, and casual users. Results showed that the application effectively adjusts generated workout plans in response to fatigue fluctuations. While limitations remain, such as reliance on manual input, findings highlight the potential for contextual fitness applications to enhance personalization, prevent overtraining, and improve long-term adherence.

title: Reproducing Synthetic Waveforms for Metrological Studies
authors: Tezgül Coşkun Öztürk, Alexander Gallarreta, Yljon Seferi, Adem Gedik, Mehedin Arifoviç, David De La Vega, Handan Sakarya, Heiko Füser
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: This study presents the methodology and scripts developed to reproduce synthetic waveforms for characterization of data converters under realistic conditions. Firstly, frequency content of synthetic waveforms is extracted. Waveforms synthesized from the extracted frequency content and the predefined synthetic waveform are compared. The root mean square (RMS) of the difference is presented as a metric of equality of the two waveforms. The results of this study provide information on the required sampling frequency and spectral purity of a waveform generator when the waveforms are intended to be reproduced. The achieved results emphasize the need of using Josephson Arbitrary Waveform Synthesizer (JAWS) which is a quantum-based waveform generator. Then, the synthesized waveforms are pulse modulated to be reproduced by JAWS. The scripts are validated by biasing the JAWS system operated in a cryocooler. Power grid representative synthetic waveforms are selected for this study. Measurement setup and results proving that the scripts are working as intended are presented.

title: PSO-Tuned LQR for Energy-Optimized Control of Two-Wheeled Inverted Pendulum with Trajectory Input Comparison
authors: Sutthipong Thunyajarern, Jatupon Em-Udom
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper presents a method for tuning a Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) controller using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) with the objective of lowering control energy while preserving response quality for a two-wheeled inverted pendulum (TWIP). The proposed framework comprises: (1) a fitness function that combines control-input energy, position error, and tilt angle; and (2) a trajectory-shaping procedure that quantifies the impact of trajectory shaping on energy consumption and transient response. We compare several reference inputs— step, first-order model-reference, ramp, and Linear Segment with Parabolic Blends (LSPB). Simulation results indicate that PSO-tuned LQR can significantly reduce control energy subject to prescribed tracking requirements. The choice of reference signal has a clear influence on energy: the ramp input yields the lowest energy consumption, whereas the step input produces the fastest response at a higher energy cost.

title: Energy Management in Hybrid Solar PV Systems Using Artificial Neural Network-Based Controllers
authors: Amira Albarsha, Mohamed Almaktar, Ibrahim Seah, Zakariya Rajab
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Due to persistent electricity shortages and frequent outages in Libya, this research investigates the integration of a hybrid solar photovoltaic (PV) and grid-connected power solution for the Venice Dental Clinic (VDC), a healthcare facility located in Benghazi. The primary objective is to ensure a reliable energy supply, reduce reliance on fossil fuels, and promote sustainability. PVsyst software is used for precise solar system design and sizing, while MATLAB/Simulink is employed to implement and simulate an Artificial Neural Network (ANN)-based energy management controller. Results show that activation function selection significantly influences model accuracy. Using the Tanh function, the optimal network configuration involves two hidden layers with three neurons each, achieving a Mean Squared Error (MSE) of 0.5718. By contrast, the ReLU function improves model performance, with a three-layer configuration (10, 8, and 5 neurons) producing a lower MSE of 0.3937. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of ANN in making real-time energy distribution decisions under variable operating conditions. The optimized system is capable of meeting up to 85% of the clinic’s energy demand, reducing annual electricity costs by approximately 40%, and lowering carbon emissions substantially. This work not only validates the feasibility of intelligent hybrid systems in healthcare but also establishes VDC as a replicable case study model for wider application across both public and private institutions in Libya and beyond.

title: MtDB: A Decentralized Multi-Tenant Database for Secure Data Sharing
authors: Showkot Hossain, Wenyi Tang, Changhao Chenli, Haijian Sun, WenZhan Song, Seokki Lee, Mic Bowman, Taeho Jung
abstract: Healthcare data sharing is fundamental for advancing medical research and enhancing patient care, yet it faces significant challenges in privacy, data ownership, and interoperability due to fragmented data silos across institutions and strict regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA). Patients possess distributed records across multiple hospitals, each maintaining autonomous databases. Access to consolidated records by secondary entities mandates explicit patient consent while ensuring strict isolation between multi-tenant datasets, requiring fine-grained access control across organizational boundaries. Existing solutions exhibit critical limitations: blockchain-based databases lack robust fine-grained cryptographic enforcement of dynamic access policies, while TEE-enhanced systems suffer from synchronization overhead and poor scalability in distributed deployments. To bridge these gaps, we propose MtDB, a novel decentralized database architecture addressing secure data sharing in multi-tenant database ecosystems. MtDB employs blockchain for metadata coordination and sharing, IPFS for distributed data addressing, a universal SQL query interface for data access, and Intel SGX for integrity-protected query execution with enforced access control. We provide an open-source implementation demonstrating MtDB’s capabilities for secure, patient-centric healthcare data sharing while preserving ownership and enforcing policies. Experimental results show MtDB achieves 35 milliseconds query latency for indexed queries over 400M multi-tenant medical records while maintaining cryptographic security guarantees, with only 1.2–1.3× performance overhead compared to non-secure baselines.

title: Analysis of Secondary Schools' Lesson Planning Processes in Kisumu, Kenya
authors: Christina Sang, Jaiden Asch, John Gershenson
abstract: This study aims to identify areas to improve efficiency in the lesson planning process for secondary school teachers in Kisumu, Kenya. Drawing from interviews with 24 teachers across five schools, the research reveals that while lesson outlines take an average of 5–10 minutes per class, lesson notes require 15–30 minutes, with greater variability based on subject complexity and teacher experience. Conversations with teachers support the need for online platforms that enable them to find quality lesson content. This research provides insights for developers interested in creating platforms to reduce teacher workloads and improve lesson planning efficiency, addressing broader critical challenges within Kenya's evolving education system. Future research should explore broader integration strategies and refine tools to enhance their long-term usability.

title: Proof of Concept of a Portable Wind-Solar Hybrid Generating Device for Use in Remote Areas
authors: Albert Jorddy Valenzuela Inga, Liz Analy Tapahuasco Zúñiga, Boris Senin Carhuallanqui Parian, Elian Eleazar Ramos Cordova, Victor Cristian Hinostroza Maravi, Yefry Huincho Quispe, Cesar Whesly Segura del Rio
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Access to electricity remains a challenge in remote areas due to limited infrastructure and high installation costs. This paper presents a proof-of-concept for a portable wind-solar hybrid generator housed in a compact rectangular cabinet with a novel aluminum rail-based deployment mechanism that enhances portability and energy harvesting. The system integrates four monocrystalline solar panels and a mini wind turbine, connected to a hybrid charge controller, a lithium battery, an inverter, and USB/AC outputs. The design, modeled in Autodesk Inventor, follows the VDI 2206 methodology, ensuring a structured and replicable development process. Simulations estimate a daily energy generation of 2.32 kWh under optimal conditions; however, the current battery specification <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(12 ~\mathrm{V}, 7 \text{Ah})$</tex> is insufficient to store this energy, indicating a key area for future improvement. The estimated construction cost is USD 666, excluding labor, making the system potentially cost-effective for off-grid applications. This conceptual work contributes to the development of compact hybrid renewable energy systems and establishes a foundation for future physical prototyping, experimental validation, and optimization of energy storage component.

title: Broadband Design of Microwave Absorber for Shielded Anechoic Chambers with Enhanced Performance
authors: Aya Raad Thanoon, Khalil H. Sayidmarie
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Shielded anechoic chambers are used to evaluate and test electronic devices and systems in civilian and military applications. The walls of the chambers are covered with metal plates to eliminate external interference, and they are lined with pyramidal absorbers made from materials that absorb the incident electromagnetic waves. This paper explores how the various design parameters of the pyramidal absorber impact its performance, aiming to identify optimal design values for enhanced efficiency. Factors such as permittivity, loss tangent, height of the pyramidal structure, and the thickness of the base all influence the absorber's performance. The pyramidal absorber supported by a 0.5 mm thick iron plate was investigated using the CST Microwave suite over the frequency range (1-10) GHz, where the reflection coefficient and power density distribution are studied. The study showed that lower permittivity or permeability leads to lower reflectivity, while lower loss still gives higher reflectivity. Increasing the pyramid's height and the base's thickness leads to lower reflection, but the first is more effective. The investigated pyramidal absorbers with a height of 16 cm, and equal values of permittivity and permeability, achieved a reflection coefficient lower than -70 dB across most of the 1 to 10 GHz frequency range.

title: Increasing Learning Data by Using Audio Data Augmentation for Bat Swing Motion Classification with Acceleration Sensor
authors: Yuichi Yakiyama, Koki Yamada, Toshimitsu Honda, Kohei Miyase, Stefan Holst, Shudai Ishikawa, Roshwin Sengupta, Ilia Polian
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: In recent years, motion analysis has attracted attention as an important tool in the field of sports science. It significantly contributes to the improvement of athletes’ skills. Motion classification using machine learning can distinguish between good and bad motions. However, when the number of subjects is often limited, i.e. a team with few players, it is difficult to collect a sufficient amount of data for machine learning. In this work, we apply audio data augmentation in order to increase learning data for bat swing motion classification. Since audio data can be expressed as waveforms, we similarly treat waveforms of bat swing data collected by an acceleration sensor. Experimental results show that audio data augmentation is effective for bat swing motion classification.

title: Translational Telemedicine for Indigenous Health: A Community-Centered Approach in the Karmata Rúa Reservation
authors: Hernan Felipe Garcia Arias, Laura García-Mosquera, Luis Fernando Torres-Torres, Alexander J. Passo-Polanco, Isaac E. Uribe-Jaramillo, Luisa F. Taho-Mateus, Weimar Arenas Gonzalez, María Clara Marín-Valencia, Alejandro Hernández-Arango, Sara Valencia-Cadavid, Augusto E. Salazar-Jimenez, Jesus Vargas Bonilla
abstract: The SmartCare Technologies project addresses the critical challenge of healthcare accessibility for older adults with reduced mobility in the Karmata Rúa Indigenous community of Antioquia, Colombia. Located between the municipalities of Jardín and Andes, this geographically isolated population faces significant physical and economic barriers to timely medical care. This paper presents a community-centered telemedicine model designed through a six-phase translational pipeline that integrates co-design with local leaders, deployment of context-appropriate technologies, culturally aligned training, community-led implementation, iterative feedback, and sustainability plan-ning. The system combines wearable medical devices, simplified digital interfaces, and AI -assisted monitoring to enable remote check-ups, early risk detection, and integration of biomedical and ancestral care practices. The project is implemented with the support of the Hospital Alma Mater de Antioquia and the Machine Learning and Robotics research seedbed focused on humanitarian engineering, promoting active student involvement and interdisciplinary collaboration. Outcomes include improved continuity of care, strengthened local health capacities, and increased cultural acceptability of digital health interventions. Preliminary pilot implementation has begun, with initial qualitative insights gathered through caregiver and patient feedback sessions. This paper contributes to the growing decolonial, ethically grounded telehealth field by demonstrating how participatory methods and culturally responsive technologies can effectively bridge health care gaps in Indigenous and rural populations.

title: Communication Target Localization and Trajectory Optimization Based on TDOA and Kalman Filter
authors: Xinchun Zhu, Bozheng Zhu, Hongming Shao, Hongyu Cui
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Passive localization technology plays a vital role in precisely tracking distant airborne targets over the ocean and minimizing positioning errors. However, due to multi-path effects, complex system geometrical configurations, and observational inaccuracies in offshore environments, positioning systems often encounter issues such as data gaps, fragmented trajectories, and error accumulation. Therefore, establishing a model capable of effectively processing multi-source observation data while mitigating errors is crucial for enhancing tracking accuracy and system stability. This paper integrates a TDOA (Time Difference of Arrival) model with a Kalman filter-based multi-source data fusion approach to reduce cross-system error propagation; introduces an improved K-means clustering algorithm combined with trajectory interpolation techniques to strengthen trajectory continuity and precision for multi-target scenarios; and employs error propagation modeling along with trajectory interpolation methods to reconstruct missing data and address trajectory fragmentation, thereby improving system robustness.

title: Intelligent Control Strategy Optimization of Hydraulic Transmission System Based on Deep Learning
authors: Juan Ding, Chunyan Huo, Fanju Zeng, Tianshu Li, Xiaolan Liu
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: Hydraulic transmission systems play an important role in multiple industrial fields due to their high power density, smooth transmission, and ease of automation control. However, in the face of complex operating conditions and nonlinear, time-varying system characteristics, the limitations of traditional control strategies are becoming increasingly apparent. This article proposes an intelligent control strategy optimization method based on deep learning, aiming to improve the stability, accuracy, and adaptability of hydraulic transmission systems. The study used a combination of deep neural networks (DNN) and long short-term memory networks (LSTM) to construct an intelligent control model to handle the nonlinearity and dynamic changes of hydraulic systems. Through simulation experiments, compared with traditional PID control strategies, the new strategy exhibits significant advantages in system robustness under step response, sine wave tracking, and external disturbances. The experimental results show that deep learning control strategies can significantly improve system stability (reduce 60% of output fluctuation standard deviation), enhance control accuracy, increase mean absolute error (MAE) by nearly three times, accelerate response speed (increase by about 52 %), and improve energy efficiency ratio (increase by about 9 %). These achievements have validated the potential and value of deep learning technology in the field of intelligent control of hydraulic transmission systems, providing a new technological path for industrial automation.

title: Micro-expression recognition method based on improved GhostNet combined with attention mechanism
authors: Zaijun Wang, Lin Zhou, Yeteng Yan, Haixin Li, Ruizhe Yang, Yuheng Jiang, Wenze Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Big Data Engineering and Education (BDEE)
abstract: Micro-expressions are brief facial expressions that conceal a person’s genuine emotions. In recent years, GhostNet has attracted significant attention in image classification. This article proposed an improved version of GhostNet V2 combined with an attention mechanism for micro-expression recognition. The model was centered around the improved GhostNet V2, which incorporated both channel attention and spatial attention mechanisms in each convolutional block to enhance the overall performance. The model achieved an accuracy of 99.2% and an F1 score of 95% on the CASME II dataset, demonstrating its effectiveness in recognizing facial micro-expressions.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Original ResNet Models in Pneumonia Detection using Medical Image Data
authors: Louis Oktovianus, Robert Tanriwan, Ivan Sebastian Edbert, Alvina Aulia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Pneumonia stands as one of the principal factors leading to mortality rates primarily affecting children in areas with limited resources. The early identification and precise diagnosis of pneumonia serves as the most important factor for lowering mortality rates. The research assesses different ResNet models as they identify pneumonia presence in chest X-ray images. A total of 5,863 labeled images between normal and pneumonia categories serve as the training and evaluation basis for the models. Performance measurements consisting of accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score and AUC ROC serve to evaluate the models. ResNet50 surpasses all competing models by reaching 97.9% accuracy and producing precision at 97.3% and recall at 97.8%. The model performance of ResNet50 demonstrates excellent results with an AUC value of 0.9974. The performance of ResNet101 V2 and ResNet152 V2 models shows robust results through their AUC values reaching 0.9954 and 0.9947, respectively. The research establishes deep learning models specifically ResNet architectures as powerful tools for automatic pneumonia detection tasks. The next phase of research needs to concentrate on generalization improvements of detection models while implementing multiple data sources and establishing medical system integration for better pneumonia diagnosis accessibility.

title: Stepped-Frequency Radar Target Recognition Using Complex 1D-CNN
authors: Ismail Jouny
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Noncooperative radar targets illuminated using stepped-frequency radar systems are classified using 1D-complex convolutional neural networks. Real target-backscatter returns of commercial aircraft models as measured in a compact range are used to assess the performance of the classifier. The results are compared with those using the Bayesian classifier assuming a mixed Gaussian model. Scenarios of azimuth ambiguity, occlusion, and extraneous scatterers are considered.

title: A High-Precision Ku-band Passive Vector Phase Shifter with 360° Phase Tunability for satellite communications
authors: Wanfu Liu, Jianhui Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This brief presents a high-precision passive vector phase shifter with 360◦ phase tunability for satellite communications. The innovative topology consists of a quadrature filter (QAF), an input matching circuit, a 180° phase rotator, an analog attenuator, an amplitude compensation and an output matching circuit. The phase shifter, based on the principles of a vector modulator, provides 360° linear control range with resolution better than 5.625°. The experimental results show that the phase error of this phase shifter is 3.4° from 10.7GHz to 12.7GHz. The measured amplitude variations of 64 phase states fall in the range of -0.44 dB to +0.38 dB. Meanwhile, the measured root-mean-square (rms) phase accuracy of different frequencies is better than 1.9° over 10.7GHz to 12.7GHz, achieving 0°-360°phase shift with almost flat phase response. The proposed phase shifter, which is able to cover X- and Ku-bands, is a good candidate for broadband phased array applications.

title: Encryption and Decryption Time Analysis of LUC and Vincent-Sathiyamoorthy RSA Algorithms on Document Files
authors: Hasyyati Nadhilah, Mohammad Andri Budiman, Mahyuddin K.M. Nasution
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: In contemporary digital cryptography, the public key method is known. In public key cryptography, encryption and decryption keys are required. The public key algorithms used to secure messages are the LUC algorithm and the Vincent- Sathiyamoorthy RSA algorithm. In solving the LUC algorithm there is a simple public key generation by multiplying a specified prime number for the key n. To determine e, a relatively prime number is sought. The relative prime number is found using the modulo division function. The private key generation involves finding d and requires the public key e. Data encryption is done using the public key (e, n) and decryption transforms the encoded data using the private key (d, n). The Vincent-Sathiyamoorthy RSA key generation involves only one prime number and other values are non-prime numbers. To obtain n variables such as p, q, r, s, t and e are needed. Private key generation depends on variables p, u and t in the public key generation. In the encryption and decryption processes, the Vincent- Sathiyamoorthy RSA algorithm is faster than the LUC algorithm. In testing the encryption and decryption processes using the .doc file extension with different character lengths, it can be concluded that the longer the characters length processed during encryption and decryption, the longer the encryption and decryption processes take. We have added recommendations to test the algorithms on other file formats and under real network conditions to observe the effects of latency and throughput.

title: Implementation of a Semi-Autonomous ENT Robotic Clinics System: Dual-Perspective Framework for Coordinated Robot Control with Tool change
authors: ShoHyun Lee, DongWoo Lee, Byung-Ju Yi, YongBae Ji, Seonmin Jung
abstract: Otolaryngology (ENT) procedure in outpatient settings presents several challenges such as procedural complexity, assistant dependency, and high infection risks due to its nature. To address these challenges, this paper presents a semi-autonomous, dual-arm robotic system for ENT outpatient procedures designed for a separated-space configuration. The system’s design is based on an ENT-specific task and workspace analysis, which establishes the detailed specifications for control parameters and hardware configurations required for implementing various procedures. The system integrates an automated tool-changing system that can handle instruments such as suction, swabs, and forceps, enabling a complete diagnostic and therapeutic workflow managed by a single clinician. The total coordinated workflow is designed within a dual-perspective framework, implemented as a Hierarchical Finite State Machine (HFSM), which translates high-level clinical intent into executable robotic actions through an intuitive user interface, refined through extensive UX/UI research. Experimental evaluations verified the usability of the implemented system throughout the entire workflow. The platform makes solo-physician ENT procedures available via teleoperation, reducing assistant dependency, physician workload, and the potential for infection. This adaptable framework offers a comprehensive solution for improving ENT clinical practice and can be extended to other medical domains that demand advanced automated workflow execution.

title: CMA+DB: How to Automatically Tune Database Parameters through Collaborative Multi-Agents
authors: Shaojie Qiao, Rongmin Tang, Jiangmin Li, Yunjun Gao, Quanqing Xu, Nan Han, Bangping Wang, Guan Yuan, Xindong Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: Database parameter automatic tuning is one of the challenging and difficult tasks that database administrators (DBAs) frequently encounter in artificial intelligence (AI) enabled database (DB) systems. Preferentially optimizing key parameters emerges as a critical point in addressing this issue, and it can help identify important parameters by exploring the interactions between parameters. Aiming to overcome the disadvantages of existing methods, we propose a collaborative multi-agents model called CMA+DB to automatically tune DB parameters in an effective and efficient fashion. CMA+DB integrates three components including SAPM (Single-Agent Pre-trained Model), MATM (Multi-Agent Joint Training Model), and PJTM (Probability-based Joint Training Model). SAPM applies the deep deterministic policy gradient to explore the impact of one single agent on DB performance, MATM uses multi-agent deep deterministic policy gradients to find agents that collaboratively work to improve DB performance, and PJTM can enhance parameter tuning by important agents based on a probabilistic selection factor. In the CMA+DB model, each agent is responsible for tuning a portion of the parameters, and multiple agents collaborate to recommend the optimal parameter configuration. This hybrid model can expand the number of tunable parameters in order to perform parameter tuning from the aspects of functions and parameter levels (i.e., global, DB, and session level). Experimental results reveal that CMA+DB obtains the fastest convergence performance (when reaching the largest throughput) of 14.83% faster than the state-of-the-art (SOTA) algorithms in the TPC-C benchmark on average. Essentially, after the phase of SAPM model training, CMA+DB outperforms the performance of the SOTA models in throughput. Furthermore, DB performance of CMA+DB can be improved by 1.758% through the phases of MATM and PJTM model training.

title: Channel Estimation for RIS-Aided MU-MIMO mmWave Systems with Practical Hybrid Architecture
authors: Liuchang Zhuo, Cunhua Pan, Hong Ren, Ruisong Weng, Shi Jin, A. Lee Swindlehurst, Jiangzhou Wang
abstract: This paper proposes a correlation-based three-stage channel estimation strategy with low pilot overhead for reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-aided millimeter wave (mmWave) multi-user (MU) multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems, in which both users and base station (BS) are equipped with a hybrid radio frequency (RF) architecture. In Stage I, all users jointly transmit pilots and the uncompressed received signals are recovered to estimate the angles of arrival (AoAs) at the BS using the discrete Fourier transform (DFT)-based approach enhanced by angle rotation method. Then, we propose a novel decomposition method that the overall cascaded MIMO channel can be directly decomposed into multiple multiple-input single-output (MISO) sub-channels, based on which the cascaded channels for a typical user and remaining users are estimated in Stage II and Stage III. Specifically, in Stage II, ultilizing the invariance of angles and the linear correlation of gains among different cascaded subchannels, we use compressive sensing (CS), least squares (LS), and a one-dimensional search to estimate the overall cascaded channel of the typical user. In Stage III, the remaining users independently transmit pilots to estimate their individual cascaded channel with the same approach as in Stage II, which exploits the equivalent common RIS-BS channel obtained in Stage II to reduce the pilot overhead. In addition, the hybrid combining matrix and the RIS phase shift matrix are designed to reduce the noise power, thereby further improving the estimation performance. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm can achieve high estimation accuracy especially when the number of antennas at the users is small, and can significantly reduce pilot overhead compared with the existing benchmark approach.

title: Design and Performance Evaluation of a Gas Blow Thermal Coupling for High-Speed HTS Rotors
authors: Kihwan kim, Yubin Kim, Yonghyun Kwon, Seokho Kim
abstract: High-temperature superconducting (HTS) rotating machines have emerged as promising candidates for next-generation electric propulsion and energy systems requiring high efficiency and power density. One of the major technical challenges in such systems is realizing cryogenic cooling of the rotating components—especially the field rotor—without mechanical contact with stationary cooling sources such as cryocoolers or heat exchangers. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a novel non-contact thermal coupling structure, referred to as the Gas Blow Coupling (GBC). The GBC enables cryogenic cooling by reducing thermal resistance between a stationary cryocooler and a rotating HTS device through a fluid-based thermal medium. The cooling process operates in two stages: in the initial phase, heat is transferred by conduction across a narrow fluid gap to establish minimum operating conditions. In the operational phase, once the rotor begins to spin, forced convection is induced by an impeller attached to the rotor, enhancing heat transfer via fluid circulation. This dual-mode cooling approach simplifies the system architecture while maintaining thermal reliability under cryogenic conditions. The conceptual design and thermal performance of the GBC are evaluated through numerical simulations, confirming its feasibility as an effective thermal interface for rotating HTS applications.

title: The Recursive Richmond Method for Mantle Cloaking With Surface Impedance Multilayers
authors: Giuseppe Labate, Cristina Yepes, Alessio Monti, Filiberto Bilotti, Andrea Alù, Giampiero Gerini
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: The classical analytical formulation of 2D Mie scattering for coaxial cylindrical multilayers requires solving a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2N\times 2N$</tex-math></inline-formula> system of equations for each polarization, where <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$N$</tex-math></inline-formula> is the number of layers, which quickly becomes cumbersome as <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$N$</tex-math></inline-formula> increases. In this paper we address this challenge by developing a compact recursive approach, based on Richmond's 1965 method for dielectric shells, reformulated as a sequence of simple <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2\times 2$</tex-math></inline-formula> systems. We extend Richmond's formulation to the case of multilayer impedance boundaries (e.g., metasurfaces), making it particularly effective for modern scattering engineering problems such as metasurface cloaking design. The effectiveness of the approach is demonstrated through the minimization of the scattering signature of a metallic cylinder surrounded by such multilayer impedance surfaces. The results are validated against independent full-wave electromagnetic simulations.

title: Ripe Stage Identification of Amrapali Mango using QSVM Classifier on 6-point Impedance Phase Data
authors: Dibakar Roy, Chiranjib Ghosh, Avishek Adhikary
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: As a climacteric fruit, mango undergoes a rapid transition to the senescent stage within a few days past harvest. Presently, no simple mechanism exist for defining ripe stages of mango and to classify accordingly. The paper present a non-destructive impedimetry based technique for assessing mango ripe stage. The work shows that the first two principal components (PC) of the phase impedance spectra is a reliable marker of mango ripeness dynamics. It is also shows that phase at 6 frequency points bear strong correlation with the first two PCs of phase spectrum and hence can be chosen as the directly measurable marker for ripeness. It further explores k-mean clustering to overcome the issue of lack of standardized ripeness labels through unsupervised clustering. It further introduce to quality indices to make such unsupervised learning closely reflecting the ground reality as observed by physical parameters. Finally, a quadratic support vector machine (QSVM) model is proposed to classify the ripe stage. The work is carried out on Amrapali species of mango; the k-mean clustering and QSVM model are trained using 1528 class balanced training data acquired from 98 samples. The training accuracy based on 5-fold validation is found 96.5%. The test accuracy is found 94.7% based on 114 test data.

title: Development of a flexible magnetic catheter for urinary stone removal_supp1-3639932.mp4
authors: Jayoung Kim
abstract: The rising burden of kidney stone disease worldwide highlights the need for more efficient debris clearance strategy with single session, low-complication, and less pain. This paper presents a development of a flexible magnetic catheter for urinary stone removal, offering a highly flexible tip with large working channel and magnetic maneuverability for deep penetration of catheter into minor calyces. A flexible magnetic catheter is constructed from multiple polymer materials and multiple magnetic rings. A model-based optimization algorithm is developed to determine the optimal design parameters of the catheter ensuring high bending angle and reasonable stiffness for insertion and stone's debris suction. The catheter performances are validated through finite-element simulation comparison and human-sized phantom model experiments, demonstrating superior control performance and its potential of a single session catheter for urinary stone removal application.
