title: Story Ribbons: Reimagining Storyline Visualizations with Large Language Models
authors: Catherine Yeh, Tara Menon, Robin Singh Arya, Helen He, Moira Weigel, Fernanda Viégas, Martin Wattenber
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Analyzing literature involves tracking interactions between characters, locations, and themes. Visualization has the potential to facilitate the mapping and analysis of these complex relationships, but capturing structured information from unstructured story data remains a challenge. As large language models (LLMs) continue to advance, we see an opportunity to use their text processing and analysis capabilities to augment and reimagine existing storyline visualization techniques. Toward this goal, we introduce an LLM-driven data parsing pipeline that automatically extracts relevant narrative information from novels and scripts. We then apply this pipeline to create STORY RIBBONS, an interactive visualization system that helps novice and expert literary analysts explore detailed character and theme trajectories at multiple narrative levels. Through pipeline evaluations and user studies with STORY RIBBONS on 36 literary works, we demonstrate the potential of LLMs to streamline narrative visualization creation and reveal new insights about familiar stories. We also describe current limitations of AI-based systems, and interaction motifs designed to address these issues.

title: A Parallel Inchworm Piezoelectric Actuator With an Active Swing Driving Biomimetic Structure
authors: Lingchen Meng, Guoshuai Liu, Pengbo Liu, Peng Yan
abstract: The designs and working principles of bioinspired inchworm-type piezoelectric actuators have been well studied in recent literature, with promising applications in precision engineering. However, it is challenging to extend the existing methods to cross-scale planar motion scenarios, which significantly limits the applicability of these actuators. In this article, a parallel, two-degree-of-freedom piezoelectric inchworm actuator is proposed, bioinspired by the skeletal structure of a snake’s spine with a novel active swing driving unit. Unlike conventional series-type actuators that utilize on separate modules for different directions of motion, the proposed design enables 2-D cross-scale parallel inchworm motion in the XY plane by actively switching between swing and translational modes using a shared clamp–drive–clamp assembly. A systematic design of the biomimetic piezoelectric actuator is presented, where modeling and analysis of the driving and clamping units are also supported by finite-element simulations. A design prototype was fabricated, and comprehensive experiments were conducted, demonstrating better performance than representative results in the literature. In particular, the actuator achieves high-performance planar cross-scale trajectory tracking and positioning with XY collaboration in full-step and sub-step scenarios. It has also been successfully applied in full-size chip stitching inspection experiments, highlighting significant potential for advanced semiconductor manufacturing, precision metrology, and inspection applications.

title: ZS-KAN: Zero-shot Image Denoising with Lightweight Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks
authors: Jianxu Wang, Ge Wang
abstract: Current learning-based image denoising methods have achieved impressive performance. However, their reliance on deep neural architectures and large paired datasets limits their applicability in data-limited or edge computing scenarios. Motivated by the expressive functional approximation power of Kolmogorov-Arnold networks (KANs), here we present ZS-KAN-a lightweight yet highly effective and computationally efficient zero-shot denoising method. ZS-KAN combines the computational efficiency of convolutional neural networks with the representational flexibility of KANs, achieving competitive denoising performance while requiring only 1%-25% of the parameters used by other recent zero-shot approaches. Experimental results on synthetic and real-world noisy data demonstrate that ZS-KAN achieves comparable or even superior performance to state-of-the-art zero-shot methods while maintaining significantly lower model complexity. These advantages highlight the potential of ZS-KAN for practical deployment. The PyTorch implementation is publicly available at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/Jayx-Wang/ZS-KAN</uri>.

title: Swarmodroid & AMPy: Reconfigurable Bristle-Bots and Software Package for Robotic Active Matter Studies
authors: Alexey Dmitriev, Vadim Porvatov, Alina Rozenblit, Mikhail Buzakov, Anastasia Molodtsova, Daria Sennikova, Vyacheslav Smirnov, Oleg Burmistrov, Timur Karimov, Ekaterina Puhtina, Nikita Olekhno
abstract: Large assemblies of extremely simple robots capable only of basic motion activities (like propelling forward or self-rotating) are often applied to study swarming behavior or implement various phenomena characteristic of active matter composed of non-equilibrium particles that convert their energy to a directed motion. As a result, a great abundance of compact swarm robots have been developed. The simplest are bristle-bots that self-propel via converting their vibration with the help of elastic bristles. However, many platforms are optimized for a certain class of studies, are not always made open-source, or have limited customization potential. To address these issues, we develop the open-source Swarmodroid 1.0 platform based on bristle-bots with reconfigurable 3D printed bodies and simple electronics that possess external control of motion velocity and demonstrate basic capabilities of trajectory adjustment. Then, we perform a detailed analysis of individual Swarmodroids’ motion characteristics and their kinematics. In addition, we introduce the AMPy software package in Python that features OpenCV-based extraction of robotic swarm kinematics accompanied by the evaluation of key physical quantities describing the collective dynamics. Finally, we discuss potential applications as well as further directions for fundamental studies and Swarmodroid 1.0 platform development.

title: Engagement, Usability, and Learning in Narrative-Driven Cybersecurity Awareness Games
authors: Claire Jennings, Seth Pham, Marc J. Dupuis
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Cybersecurity awareness remains a persistent challenge despite significant investment in technical defenses. Attackers exploit the human element, requiring new approaches that sustain attention and promote actionable decision-making. This paper evaluates a narrative-driven, choose-your-own-adventure (CYOA) serious game designed to teach core cyber-hygiene practices. Narrative drafts were generated with the assistance of AI-based text generation tools and subsequently refined by the research team, illustrating the potential of AI to support scalable development of cybersecurity training content. Two design variables were systematically compared: narrative depth (long-form versus short-form storytelling) and interaction modality (link-based versus swipe-based navigation). A total of 422 participants were recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk, representing a diverse adult population. Outcomes were measured through custom Likert-style items assessing engagement, usability, and perceived learning, supported by qualitative reflections. Results show that long-form narratives increased immersion and contextual understanding, while short-form narratives emphasized efficiency and decision reinforcement. Usability ratings were high across all conditions, with swipe-based navigation slightly preferred on mobile devices. Participants consistently reported increased awareness of phishing, oversharing, identity theft, and ransomware. These findings demonstrate the viability of narrative-driven games as scalable, user-centered cybersecurity training tools. We discuss design implications for organizations deploying awareness programs across heterogeneous desktop and mobile platforms and highlight opportunities for hybrid narrative strategies that balance immersion and efficiency.

title: Leveraging Artificial Intelligence and Smart Information Systems to Enhance Tourist Advocacy
authors: Stefanus Rumangkit, Rininta Ayu Pradhani, Suryanto, Hartini Husin, Ilham Sentosa, Antonius Satria Hadi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Smart Information Systems (SIS) is reshaping tourism experiences, yet their behavioral impacts in Southeast Asia remain underexplored. This study investigates the indirect influence of AI on tourist advocacy via SIS, perceived destination image (PDI), and perceived tourist satisfaction (PTS), grounded in the Stimulus-Organism-Response (S-O-R) framework. Data from 100 respondents across Indonesia, Japan, and Malaysia were analyzed using PLS-SEM. Results show AI does not significantly affect SIS (p = 0.316), diverging from prior assumptions. However, SIS significantly influences both PDI (p = 0.002) and PTS (p < 0.001), which in turn significantly affect tourist advocacy (PDI: p = 0.036; PTS: p = 0.001). SIS explains 12.8% of PDI and 21% of PTS, while both contribute to 23.2% of advocacy behaviour. These findings validate the S-O-R model in a tourism tech context and suggest that enhancing SIS functionality can strengthen destination image, satisfaction, and advocacy despite AI’s limited direct impact.

title: Comparing Big Data Messaging Platforms: An Evaluation of Apache Kafka, Rabbitmq, and Redis
authors: Aditya Pujara, Faheem Ullah, Jamal El Hachem
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Big data messaging platforms such as Apache Kafka, RabbitMQ and Redis are used across distributed messaging systems to orchestrate information to their users. With the large number of messaging platforms available and used in the industry, difficulty arises in choosing the right platform for a particular use case. This paper presents a guiding framework to assist in making an informed decision on the big data messaging platform of choice for a given distributed messaging task. Upon testing latency, throughput, publish and consumption rate for each big data messaging platform in this study, a framework is presented which differentiates each platform based on positives and potential setbacks. This study finds that for reliable messaging infrastructure and no message loss, RabbitMQ is the messaging platform of choice. For ease of use and speed respectively, Apache Kafka and Redis are best choices to consider.

title: Impact of Variable Water Conditions on Cage Fish Farming in Lake Victoria
authors: Lillian Downs, Anshu Nunemunthala, Gauri Patil, Adeline Weitknecht, Benjamin Roy, John Gershenson
abstract: This research focuses on the measurement of water parameters in Lake Victoria and their impact on tilapia health. Tilapia, a staple protein in the region, is impacted by pH, dissolved oxygen (DO), nitrite, and ammonia nitrogen, which are negatively impacted by agricultural runoff, municipal waste, and aquaculture pollutants. Understanding how pH, DO, nitrite, and ammonia nitrogen change across the lake would allow cage fish farmers to optimize cage placement and fish care, and inform environmental groups and regulatory bodies in improving lake health. This preliminary study attempts to map these parameters at various lake depths and distances from shore, which, to the best of the authors' knowledge, has not yet been done on Lake Victoria. The data collected shows ideal tilapia fish farming conditions are not uniform, with more favorable conditions further from shore. Our findings suggest that more extensive water parameter mapping could determine ideal fish cage locations and help vested groups respond to lake conditions.

title: AI Agents in Customer Service: Enhancing MSME Competitiveness through Automatic Systems
authors: Kukuh Lukiyanto, Davin Danika Sasongko, Maranatha Wijayaningtyas, Zainal Abidin, Mariah Awang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) agents have become a game changer for micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) to improve their customer service, however, AI finds its place in the market by targeting MSMEs that do not have access to resources for the creation of AI agents. Automation of system-independent operations for the use of interactions is a competent tool that helps MSMEs to increase their competitiveness based on an automated customer management system, which functions at a lower level of operating costs. AI agents are transformed to improve MSMEs’ operations in customer service by changing their interaction systems while this study will determine the basic success factors during implementation. This research method uses qualitative interviews with 10 MSME owners who implement AI Chatbot for customer services in their businesses. The customer benefits of AI agents are the fact that the system is effective in answering standard questions that enable people to solve complex problems while providing the same quality of service at scale. System design and user acceptance need to be addressed as these barriers are against the implementation of technological solutions. AI agents enable small businesses to experience equal access to highly sophisticated customer service tools, giving them the ability to compete in the digital business market. Business stakeholders need to target the development of support systems and policies that are accessible to MSMEs by addressing AI in their movement to realize economic equality through technological advancement.

title: A Robust and Efficient Threshold Signature Scheme Based on ECDSA
authors: Dongsu Shen, Yangning Zhou, Benteng Deng, Shujuan Tian, Yanchun Li
abstract: Threshold signatures serve as a cryptographic primitive fundamental to blockchain security and reliability. However, a significant limitation of existing ECDSA threshold signature protocols is their lack of robustness during the signing phase. Specifically, the presence of even a single malicious participant requires the termination of the protocol, thereby undermining the availability of the system. To address this critical issue, we present a novel robust threshold ECDSA signature scheme that guarantees uninterrupted operation even in the presence of adversarial participants. Our scheme consists of three distinct phases: distributed key generation, offline pre-signing and online signing. During the offline pre-signing phase, pre-signing shares are generated in advance to ensure fault-tolerant online signing. A key innovation of our approach is the offloading of computationally intensive operations to the offline phase, significantly optimizing the online signing efficiency. Security analysis demonstrates that our scheme achieves active security under the Strong RSA and Decisional Diffie-Hellman (DDH) assumptions. Compared to prior work, our solution not only ensures robustness but also reduces communication and computational overhead, making it particularly suitable for real-world blockchain deployments where both efficiency and fault tolerance are paramount.

title: Case Study of the Cheeba Solar Energy Kiosk
authors: Peter Dauenhauer, Rabia Khan, Bennett Schmitt, Hansel M Mweetwa, Brad Helland, Henry Louie
abstract: This paper presents a detailed case study of the Cheeba solar energy kiosk. A solar energy kiosk is a building that houses several small businesses that are powered by a single stand-alone off-grid solar system. Cheeba is a community in Zambia's Southern Province that is not connected to the national power grid. In 2019, KiloWatts for Humanity (KWH), a U.S.based nonprofit organization, in partnership with Caritas Monze, a Zambian nonprofit organization, and in close collaboration with the community, implemented a 3 kilowatt solar energy kiosk. The solar energy kiosk is operated by the Lower Kafue Women's Group, a local community-based organization. In 2024, the aging components coupled with the growth of demand for electricity motivated KWH and Caritas Monze to expand the solar energy kiosk's electrical capacity and physical building space. The case study describes the social, economic, technical, and organizational aspects of the Cheeba solar energy kiosk.

title: Optimization of Charging Estimation in Lithium-ion Batteries Based on BiLSTM-AM
authors: Dian Premana, Imam Fachruddin, Djati Handoko, I Bagus Ngurah.Alit Putra Wiryawan, Nurlayla Amanah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Estimating the State of charge (SOC) a crucial aspect of the keys of Lithium-Ion Battery BMS Management. At present, data-driven calculations are predominantly used to determine SOC levels. One of the learning methods used is a recurrent neural network (RNN) which performs very well. We propose a bidirectional long-term memory neural network (BiLSTM) for SOC estimation. This BiLSTM also undergoes optimization with several variations used. In this paper, we compare the variations between BiLSTM and BiLSTM-AM. Using public data that has been published, we propose 4 data that we process using separate BiLSTM and BiLSTM-AM neural networks for 4 batteries. The SOC estimation obtained from each battery will be assessed, with an R2 value 0.99, enabling the model to produce more accurate and better results.

title: Development of a Hearing Probe for a Low Cost Newborn Hearing Screening Device
authors: Venkadesh Eswaranandam, Ayush Chakraborty, Elizabeth Johansen, Bradley Minch, Siddhartan Govindasamy
abstract: Newborn hearing screening remains a global challenge, even in well-resourced healthcare systems, due to its reliance on objective, biosignal-based methods that differ from adult screening. Early detection of hearing loss has proven impact in improving life outcomes, yet access is limited by the high cost and specialized training required to operate existing devices. A team of undergraduate students from the Olin College and Babson College Design Justice Studio are developing a low-cost screening device designed for use by individuals without formal audiology training. We discuss our human-centered design approach, technical implementation, and cost-reduced methods enabled by advancements in consumer-grade electronics. As a case study, we highlight our ear probe system, which uses low-cost, low-noise digital microphones and SLA printing to make an easy to fabricate prototype.

title: Simplicity Wins: Lightweight Vision Transformer Heads for Presentation Attack Detection
authors: Jan König, Pedram Khatamino, Deniz Kumlu, Hossein Fereidooni
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: The growing reliance on digital services has amplified the need for secure and seamless identity verification, particularly in regulation-sensitive domains such as online banking. Facial recognition-based Know Your Customer (KYC) procedures are increasingly targeted by presentation attacks (PAs), including printed photographs, video replays, and 3D masks. To mitigate these threats, Presentation Attack Detection (PAD) systems are critical components of robust authentication pipelines. While recent advances have centered around deep and complex neural network architectures to enhance PAD performance, these models often exhibit limitations when faced with out-of-distribution samples and scarce training data.In this study, we explore a data-centric approach to PAD by leveraging a pre-trained Vision Transformer (DINOv2) as a fixed feature extractor, coupled with a lightweight classification head. We hypothesize that, given access to sufficiently diverse training data, such a simplified architecture can match or exceed the performance of more intricate models. Experimental results across multiple attack scenarios validate our hypothesis, demonstrating competitive accuracy and improved generalizability. These findings emphasize the efficacy of scalable, data-driven methodologies over architectural complexity in PAD system design.

title: The analysis of Data Annotation Operation Mechanisms in Industrial
authors: Tongtong Cheng, Yang Liu, Zihang Yin, Tingting Xu, Can Luo, Yuanchao Liu
abstract: Industrial data annotation serves as the critical link connecting raw data and Artificial Intelligence models in industrial intelligence. The scientific rigor of annotation directly determines the quality of training data and the reliability of industrial AI applications. Focusing on the core of industrial data annotation, this paper examines the process, task allocation, quality control, and collaborative management mechanisms of industrial data annotation based on the industrial data characteristics. Finally, it analyzes the applicable scenarios and limitations of current mainstream annotation modes and discusses the lightweight application of technologies.

title: Crop Yield Prediction on Worldwide Data Using Tabnet Regressor
authors: Dheovan Winata Alvian, Jefferson Darren Cendres, Jonathan Hopi Pranata, Muhamad Fajar, Puti Andam Suri
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Quantities of global crops are influenced by multiple elements composed of climate change and farming practices, and land utilization patterns. Wrong predictions regarding crop yields play a vital role in protecting world food security. The proposed research utilizes TabNet Regressor as a Deep Learning (DL) regression model to forecast crop yields from worldwide agricultural data covering multiple crops and multiple countries. The implementation of Optuna as a hyperparameter tuner resulted in the best possible predictive results. Using Optuna enables the process to identify optimal parameters such as optimizer function, learning rate, batch size, and number of steps within the TabNet architecture framework. Multiple agricultural records obtained from several countries allowed the model to become robust while being evaluated across various crops under multiple environmental scenarios. Model optimization yielded an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> value of 95.8% which indicates great capability to forecast. The research demonstrates that TabNet Regressor serves as an efficient model for yielding better predictions of crop yields. DL combined with hyperparameter optimization techniques delivers important insights which enable policymakers together with farmers and agricultural organizations to conduct data-driven sustainable farming practices decisions. One of the key challenges that this study is overcoming is that extant models lack a wide range of data. The analysis of a global dataset and TabNet Regressor improvement allow the research to reach high levels of prediction and, therefore, make credible projections in a wide range of agricultural conditions.

title: PolyLink: A Blockchain Based Decentralized Edge AI Platform for LLM Inference
authors: Hongbo Liu, Jiannong Cao, Bo Yang, Dongbin Bai, Yinfeng Cao, Xiaoming Shen, Yinan Zhang, Jinwen Liang, Shan Jiang, Mingjin Zhang
abstract: The rapid advancement of large language models (LLMs) in recent years has revolutionized the AI landscape. However, the deployment model and usage of LLM services remain highly centralized, creating significant trust issues and costs for end users and developers. To address these issues, we propose PolyLink, a blockchain-based decentralized AI platform that decentralizes LLM development and inference. Specifically, PolyLink introduces a decentralized crowdsourcing architecture that supports single-device and cross-device model deployment and inference across heterogeneous devices at the edge. Moreover, to ensure the inference integrity, we design the TIQE protocol, which combines a lightweight cross-encoder model and an LLM-as-a-Judge for a high-accuracy inference evaluation. Lastly, we integrate a comprehensive token-based incentive model with dynamic pricing and reward mechanisms for all participants. We have deployed PolyLink and conducted an extensive real-world evaluation through geo-distributed deployment across heterogeneous devices. Results indicate that the inference and verification latency is practical. Our security analysis demonstrates that the system is resistant to model degradation attacks and validator corruptions. PolyLink is now available at https://github.com/IMCL-PolyLink/PolyLink.

title: Capacity Optimization Model of Hybrid Energy Storage System Considering Battery Service Life
authors: Hao Ning, Jialin Chen, Jian Zhang, Yuxuan Ye, Yixi Wang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: A capacity optimization model of hybrid energy storage system (HESS) considering battery service life is proposed. By comprehensively considering battery performance parameters, operating environment and conditions, management strategies and other factors, battery service life is maximized and system performance is optimized. The model aims at maximizing battery life, minimizing system loss, maximizing power response and minimizing total cost, and constructs a multi-objective optimization function, and uses NSGA-II algorithm to solve Pareto frontier. The effectiveness of the model is verified by simulation experiments. The results show that the optimization scheme can significantly extend the battery life (up to 90 %), improve the system efficiency to 91 % and maintain good economy in different scenarios. The model has strong robustness to temperature and cost fluctuations, and is suitable for high dynamic scenarios such as wind and solar storage microgrid and electric vehicle, which provides theoretical basis and practical guidance for the optimal design of HESS.

title: Priority-Based Electricity Consumption Scheduling Using Greedy Optimization in Residential Areas
authors: Efraim Melvyn Rafelino Lahai, Nurwahyu Alamsyah, Agustinus Bimo Gumelar, Evan William, Dustin Pranata Wangsawidjaja, Daniel, Slamet Winardi, Adri Gabriel Sooai, Devi Dwi Purwanto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: The growing demand for home electricity necessitates innovative approaches to balance the consumption of energy with cost-saving. In this paper, a priority scheduling system for home appliances using a greedy optimization algorithm is proposed to minimize energy expenditure without compromising user comfort. By dynamically assigning priority to devices based on need and usage patterns, the algorithm allocates optimal operating times to high-priority devices (e.g., refrigerators, lighting) when tariff rates are lowest and off-peak period assignment for low-priority devices (e.g., washing machines, entertainment systems). Greedy approach imposes household power capacity constraint satisfaction as well as budget constraints by iteratively taking optimally cost-minimal scheduling decisions. Testing in several different residential environments demonstrates a 22–30% reduction in monthly electricity costs and a 15–25% reduction in peak-load demand compared to unoptimized consumption. The system also provides actionable feedback for load shifting, enabling consumers to avoid grid overloads and adopt environmentally friendly consumption habits. This work demonstrates the potential of algorithmic-based prioritization in transforming residential energy management without compromising convenience of lifestyle.

title: Multi-Classification of Mental Illnesses through Social Media Posts using RoBERTa
authors: Dimas Bramantyo Putra Santoso, Melvern Michio Chie, Ivan Sebastian Edbert, Alvina Aulia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Social Media has become a popular space for people to share their feelings and thoughts. While keeping pace with current technological developments, social media has become more advanced and increasingly populated by people from around the globe, with a wider variance in audience, which can increase the chance of negatively impacting interactions. One result of such interactions is lower self-esteem, potentially worsening into self-harm or even suicide in the worst-case scenario. To raise awareness of the dangers associated with the situation, this study, utilizing RoBERTa, aims to detect and classify mental illnesses through user-generated text or posts on social media. We used a publicly available dataset from previous research to test it, by applying a supervised learning approach and fine-tuning the hyperparameters. After testing, the model has an 89% accuracy in classifying users with mental illness. Other than that, the model has a high recall, indicating its effectiveness in identifying even subtle hints in the text. With the results shown by the model, it is evident that AI has the potential to be a major helper in detecting mental illness and notifying people of early interventions.

title: Reliable Design of Asynchronous Isolated Communication in High Voltage Battery Monitoring System
authors: Seong-Ho Oh, Jong-Hun Kim, Ah-Rum Hur, Seung-Yeon Kim, Sung-Hoon Bang, Sang-Ho Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: This paper focuses on the method of improving reliability of communication in high voltage battery monitoring system. In high voltage battery monitoring system, it is important to measure the voltage of hundreds of battery-cells using fewer monitoring ICs. In general, the system is composed of a micro-controller (MCU) for controlling and processing the measured voltage monitoring data, and the chain of several battery monitoring ICs. Since the ground levels of each ICs connected to battery cells are different, the communication of this system is implemented by isolated communication. For improving reliability, we propose following two methods. First, compensating the sampling baud rate and the frequency of oscillator at each receiving commands using the synchronization frame of MCU. Second, a representative physical layer structure optimized for isolated communication is introduced. These methods can highly improve the reliability and robustness of asynchronous isolated communication.

title: Low-Cost Sun Vector Estimation-Least Squares Optimization in Polyhedral Photodiode Arrays
authors: Sabire Betül Çınar, Ramazan Yeniçeri
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: Accurate and robust estimation of the Sun’s direction is a critical requirement for attitude determination systems in small-scale aerospace platforms such as UAVs and CubeSats. This paper presents a low-cost Sun sensor design based on discrete photodiodes arranged over symmetric polyhedral geometries—specifically, the icosahedron and the truncated icosahedron. A simulation framework has been developed in MATLAB to evaluate Sun vector estimation using a least-squares method, incorporating realistic photodiode characteristics and system noise. Two sensor configurations, using 12 and 20 photodiodes respectively, are tested and compared in terms of accuracy, coverage, and a proposed optimization metric that quantifies performance per sensor. Monte Carlo simulations revealed that while the icosahedron configuration offers marginally higher efficiency, it suffers from larger worst-case errors. In contrast, the truncated icosahedron maintains bounded errors below 2°, providing more reliable performance across the entire field of view. The results highlight a practical trade-off between average efficiency and robustness in geometric sensor deployment for Sun sensing applications.

title: Precision Bot Hunting with Hybrid ML Models
authors: Vanchhit Khare, Ankush Rastogi
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Fake accounts and bots flood social media with spam, rumors, and harmful content, so we tested machine learning to spot them using three paths. Classic models such as Random Forest, Support Vector Machines, and XGBoost check numeric clues like post rate or follower growth. Deep nets like LSTM read timelines in sequence and catch style shifts. Blended teams let many models vote when one feels unsure. Our recipe is clear: collect raw account data, turn each action into clean features, train on labeled bots and humans, then judge performance with accuracy, recall, and area under the curve. In live trials classic models already score above ninety percent while deep nets climb higher when fed large data sets. Tools like Botometer and Bot Sentinel confirm the method by rating real accounts in seconds. We keep jargon light so any reader can follow the flow yet still include the technical steps for those who want detail. This work shows that smart models, clear features, and honest testing pull the mask off social bots and protect online conversation.

title: Smartphone-Based Tilapia Pond Water Quality Monitoring
authors: Adityo Arya Putra, Aldi Septiyanto, Hari Wahyu Ramadhan, Haris Setyawan, Nasy’an Taufiq Al Ghifari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Technology and Computing (ICITCOM)
abstract: Tilapia fish farming is one of the important sectors of the fisheries industry in Indonesia. However, the success of tilapia fish farming is highly dependent on the quality of the pond water. To overcome this problem, an effective and efficient solution is needed. In this study, an Android-based tilapia fishpond water quality monitoring system was developed. This system allows farmers to monitor important water quality parameters such as pH, temperature, and water turbidity in real time via mobile devices. The data collected by the sensor is then sent to the server via the internet, and then the data is displayed in graphical form using third-party software called UBIDOTS. The results of this study indicate that the developed device can work well and has accurate reading results. Furthermore, direct testing needs to be carried out on the fish farming pond so that the effectiveness of the developed system can be analyzed.

title: DPU-Aware Hardware-Software Co-Design for Real-Time Semantic Segmentation
authors: Seung Wook Oh, Gyu Hyeon Hwang, HoBin Oh, HyeonJin Sim, Min Kwon Choi, Jae Wook Jeon
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: On specialized hardware like the Xilinx Deep Learning Processing Unit (DPU), the theoretical efficiency of a neural network model often does not translate into real-world performance. This work investigates a hardware-software co-design methodology for adapting lightweight models to the DPU architecture through an exploratory case study. We replaced the encoders of ERFNet and ESNet with the DPU-friendly MobileNetV2 and evaluated the performance on the Xilinx Kria KV260 platform. While this co-design strategy boosted ERFNet’s DPU-only inference throughput by 2.14x (from 9.05 to 19.36 FPS), the end-to-end system throughput—including pre-and post-processing—remained stalled at roughly 0.35 FPS. This outcome provides empirical evidence of a "bottleneck shift," where the performance constraint migrates from the DPU hardware to CPU-bound software routines. Our findings emphasize that achieving true real-time performance in embedded AI systems requires a holistic optimization of the entire pipeline, not just the neural network accelerator.

title: Development of An IMM Filter For Tracking Agile Drone Targets
authors: Hakan Ataman, Muhammed Faruk Yılmaz, Haluk Gözde, M.Cengiz Taplamacıoğlu, Mahir Dursun
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: In this study, an Interacting Multiple Model (IMM) filter algorithm is developed for tracking highly maneuverable targets such as FPV drones. Constant Velocity (CV), Coordinated Turn (CT), and Constant Acceleration (CA) motion models of targets are created in MATLAB simulation environment, and performance analyses are conducted towards classic Kalman filter, using measurements corrupted by noise. It is observed that the Kalman filter is particularly inadequate for this type of targets in the CT and CA scenarios, causing prediction deviations. To improve this situation, an IMM filter, capable of switching between different motion dynamics, is integrated into the algorithm. Comparative test results revealed that the IMM- based approach delivers superior performance with low Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) values and high tracking accuracy against highly maneuverable drones. In the next study, the developed IMM filter will be optimized and implemented for the real applications.

title: Enhancing Liquidity in Blockchain-Based IoT Data Trading through Semi-Fungible Tokens
authors: Yueqi Su, Yuji Dong, Jie Zhang
abstract: The economic potential of vast IoT data remains largely underutilized due to market illiquidity, which arises from a mismatch between traditional liquidity definitions and IoT data’s unique characteristics (e.g., anti-rivalrous, combinatorial, perishable). To address this, we propose the Data Asset Liquidity Index (DALI), a novel multidimensional liquidity framework for blockchain-based IoT data trading. We also introduce a decentralized trading mechanism leveraging ERC3525 Semi-Fungible Tokens (SFTs). This approach facilitates granular data tokenization, enabling flexible trading and reducing friction. We further enhance this mechanism with intelligent device grouping, advanced SFT merging functionalities, and a novel device package trading system, allowing for even more flexible and efficient data transactions. Through theoretical analysis and a case study, we demonstrate how SFTs enhance key DALI components, fostering a more efficient IoT data market.

title: Design of On-Body Matching Networks for Reliable Capacitive Coupling
authors: Sung-Eun Kim, Taewook Kang, Kwang-Il Oh, Mi-Jeong Park, Hyuk Kim, Hyung-Il Park, Jae-Jin Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE/IEIE International Conference on Consumer Electronics-Asia (ICCE-Asia)
abstract: The human body can be used as a signal transmission medium to make connections among on-body edge devices for Wireless Body Area Networks (WBANs). However, when a signal is transmitted through the body, various types of external interference are induced, disrupting signal transmission. To improve the performance of signal transmission through the human body, on-body matching networks should be designed with consideration of the human body’s characteristics. This paper proposes a method for optimizing the values of design variables in an on-body matching network considering the human body impedance and evaluates frame synchronization performance based on the IEEE 802.15.6 preamble structure and detection algorithm. Analysis results verified that optimizing these values significantly improved communication reliability in capacitive-coupling systems.

title: Machine Learning for Ppe Compliance in Underground Mining
authors: Milka C. I. Madahana, Tetelo Mamabolo, John E. D. Ekoru
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: The safety of underground mine workers is of paramount importance due to the hazardous nature of their working environment. Personal protective equipment plays a crucial role in minimizing risks and ensuring workers' health and safety. However, effective assessment of Personal Protective Equipment compliance and performance is a challenging and resource-intensive task. This study explores the application of a machine learning technique to enhance Personal Protective Equipment assessment in underground mines. By utilizing computer vision, images of mine workers wearing PPE are used to customize a pre -trained yolov8n.pt model on the COCO dataset to be able to detect and classify three Personal Protective Equipment classes through model training and validation. This is done with the aim of developing a model that can determine whether PPE has been worn or not. The research employs real dataset collected from a real mine, which undergo a rigorous data wrangling process. Findings of this study indicate that the model can successfully identify helmets with high precision and recall by achieving a mean average precision of 90 %, demonstrating strong potential to replace manual inspection methods. The model's performance dropped for safety goggles and face masks with mAP values of 68 %, highlighting areas for improvement. The model also demonstrated real-time monitoring potential by processing 6.5 frames per second. Ultimately, the findings of this study highlight the potential of machine learning as a transformative tool in occupational safety management within the mining industry.

title: Human Rights in the Shadow of AI: Confronting Bias and Accountability
authors: Mehdi Ghayoumi, Kambiz Ghazinour
publish: 2025 IEEE 16th Annual Ubiquitous Computing, Electronics &amp; Mobile Communication Conference (UEMCON)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly integrated into daily life, shaping decisions in healthcare, employment, law enforcement, and social interactions. Although AI offers considerable benefits, it also carries the potential to perpetuate harmful biases and discrimination, thereby undermining fundamental human rights. This paper explores the ways in which AI systems, whether through design flaws or deliberate misuse, can foster inequities and result in unfair treatment of specific groups. It further addresses the pressing challenges of ensuring accountability when AI contributes to human rights violations. Finally, the paper considers strategies to promote fairness, transparency, and respect for human rights in AI development and deployment, with an emphasis on policy and legal reforms aimed at mitigating these risks.

title: Exploring Sentiment Analysis and Classification on Amazon Alexa Reviews: A Comparative Evaluation of ANN, LSTM, and Large Language Models
authors: Sarah S.M. Almuqati, Areej Alhothali
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: In recent years, e-commerce products have become increasingly diverse, leading consumers to make more informed purchasing decisions based on previous customer experiences. One of the primary sources for such insights is customer reviews on online platforms. However, manually analyzing these reviews is both time-consuming and labor-intensive. To address this challenge, sentiment analysis techniques have been applied to automatically analyze reviews written by customers who have purchased and used the products. These reviews are typically classified into positive, negative, or neutral sentiments, helping consumers make better choices. Several studies have investigated this problem using a variety of natural language processing NLP, machine learning, and deep learning techniques to automatically analyze customer reviews. However, these studies often rely on general-purpose datasets and traditional models that fall short in capturing contextualized information of user sentiments, especially in domain-specific scenarios. To address this gap, this paper presents a comprehensive analysis of several machine learning and deep learning models, including large language models (LLMs), applied to Amazon Alexa Reviews dataset. Specifically, we evaluate the performance of artificial neural networks (ANNs), long short-term memory networks (LSTMs), and LLMs such as generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and bidirectional encoder representations from transformers (BERTs). The models are compared based on precision, recall, F1 score, and accuracy. Among them, BERT achieved the best performance, with 99% accuracy and a loss of 0.03.

title: Design and Implementation of a Customer-Interactive Cargo Delivery System: A Case Study from Türkiye
authors: Ali Osman Kabil, Sefa Sarı, Ümit Köse, Seda Aslan Bengül, Mustafa Ersel Kamaşak
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Electrical and Electronics Engineering (ICEEE)
abstract: The rapid growth of Türkiye’s e-commerce sector has created a pressing need for more flexible, customer-centric, and operationally efficient last-mile delivery solutions. In response, a national logistics provider implemented an Interactive Cargo Delivery System, enabling recipients to manage their deliveries through a web-based platform accessible via short messaging system (SMS). Core functionalities include address confirmation, delivery rescheduling, and alternate drop-off options, all integrated with real-time courier tracking and geo-fenced delivery verification. Following its deployment, the system achieved a measurable 1.8% increase in same-day delivery success and contributed to a reduction in branch return rates from 14.2% to 11.6%, representing an 18% relative improvement. In 2024, over 2 million satisfaction surveys were collected, with 89.7% of respondents reporting a positive experience. Furthermore, the system has been utilized in over 42 million shipments, with data indicating a strong preference for unattended delivery and flexible redirection options. These findings underscore the system’s potential to enhance delivery performance, elevate customer satisfaction, and provide a foundation for future AI-driven personalization and optimization in logistics operations.

title: Intelligent Analysis and Operation and Maintenance of Power Grid Operation State Based on Streaming Computing
authors: Zhengrong Wu, Weigui Bai
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Telecommunications and Power Electronics (TELEPE)
abstract: The streaming-computing-based intelligent analysis and maintenance system for power grid operations is designed to enhance the efficiency, reliability, and security of the power grid. By collecting real-time operational data and utilizing streaming computing for rapid processing and analysis, the system delivers precise information on the power grid's status and provides intelligent decision support to maintenance personnel. The system is structured in a hierarchical architecture, comprising a data acquisition layer, a data flow processing layer, an intelligent analysis layer, and a decision support layer, ensuring scalability, maintainability, and efficiency. The data acquisition layer gathers operational data via sensors and other devices, while the data flow processing layer employs Apache Kafka and Flink for efficient handling. The intelligent analysis layer leverages machine learning and deep learning for condition monitoring and fault prediction, and the decision support layer generates maintenance recommendations based on analytical outcomes. Experimental results indicate that the system excels in real-time performance and accuracy across data acquisition, processing, and intelligent analysis, meeting the demands of real-time power grid operations. This research not only elevates the intelligence level of power grid maintenance but also strongly supports the digital transformation of the power industry.

title: Modeling Gen Z’s Emotional Engagement in AI-driven Personalized Playlist: Spotify Daylist Case Study
authors: Illene Michaela, Shiona Vianca, Fitrie Handayani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Information Management and Technology (ICIMTech)
abstract: This study examines how AI-driven personalization in Spotify Daylist, which dynamically adapts to users’ emotional states by curating music aligned with time-specific moods and microgenres, influences emotional engagement among Generation Z in Indonesia. Grounded in McCarthy’s theory of personalization and the Stimulus-Organism-Response (S-O-R) model, it examines how personalized content (stimuli) influences users’ emotional responses (organism), leading to various engagement (response). Motivated by previous studies that only discussed the mechanism, technical, and visual aspects of Spotify’s AI-driven playlists without examining their impact on Gen Z users, this study aims to explore whether Spotify’s AI-driven personalization new feature, Daylist, elicit emotional engagement on users, and to what extent. A quantitative approach was employed via questionnaire with Likert scale, to measure emotional engagement across various dimensions of personalization, targeting 400 Indonesian Spotify users aged 13 to 28. The collected data was analyzed using PLS-SEM to assess the structural model and explore relationships between constructs. Findings of this research successfully address the research questions and confirm the hypothesis that AI-driven personalization in Spotify Daylist significantly influences emotional engagement among Indonesian Generation Z users. Enhanced by the dynamic content layout: personalized titles, contextual descriptions, and frequently regenerated song selections tailored to specific moods and times of day, which appears to be the most influential sub-dimension. Whereas immersive experience demonstrates the strongest relationship with emotional engagement among Indonesian Generation Z users. This evolving structure fosters a sense of novelty, emotional relevance, and also makes the listening experience more enjoyable and deeply engaging for its users.
